headline: Joshua Wong and Alex Chow: The People of Hong Kong Will Not Be Cowed by China
abstract: You can arrest us. But more protesters will keep coming out.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — “If we burn, you burn with us.” A famous line in the movie “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay” has been given a new life in Hong Kong’s summer-long protests: It has come to represent the spirit unleashed by hundreds of thousands of protesters. As many commentators have pointed out, the massive, leaderless resistance movement here is a critical front-line battle against the authoritarian Chinese Communist Party in Beijing. A dictatorial party facing domestic and global pressures — especially from the ongoing trade negotiations with the United States — the C.C.P. is getting impatient, apparently. On Friday, it targeted leading activists and politicians in Hong Kong with a round of arrests, possibly signaling that a broader crackdown may be around the corner.

headline: 53 People Died in Mass Shootings in August Alone in the U.S.
abstract: So far this year, there have been at least 38 shootings with three or more fatalities, data shows.
lead_paragraph: The month of August ended as it began: with a shooting rampage and a significant death toll.

headline: A Very German Idea of Freedom: Nude Ping-Pong, Nude Sledding, Nude Just About Anything
abstract: Germany’s nudist movement, unique in the world, has survived Hitler, Communism and Instagram. It has everything to do with wanting to be free, say nudists, and zero to do with sex.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The first time Michael Adamski saw his mother-in-law naked it was awkward.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Horrible Bosses’ and ‘Juno’
abstract: Three friends take their workplace problems into their own hands in “Horrible Bosses.” And a pregnant teenager wrestles with life’s big decisions in “Juno.”
lead_paragraph: HORRIBLE BOSSES (2011) 8 p.m. on TNT. In the spirit of Labor Day, revisit this outrageous black comedy about three friends who, despite working hard, are repeatedly tormented by their bosses. Their simmering grievances reach a boiling point when the buddies — Nick (Jason Bateman), Dale (Charlie Day) and Kurt (Jason Sudeikis) — decide to put an end to their misery by killing their higher-ups (played by Jennifer Aniston, Kevin Spacey and Colin Farrell). Their scheme quickly falls off the rails, because, well, they’re not experienced killers. And the “murder consultant” (Jamie Foxx) they turn to isn’t much help either. Watch with a grain of salt: In his review, the New York Times critic A.O. Scott wrote that while the movie’s humor “flirts with racism, goes steady with misogyny and pretty much marries homophobia,” it also draws plenty of laughs. The less successful sequel, which brings on Chris Pine, Christoph Waltz and Jonathan Banks, follows at 10 p.m.

headline: No Matter How You Slice It, a Stealthy Backhand Still Works

lead_paragraph: Roger Federer and Ashleigh Barty strode toward the weekend at the United States Open dogged by a question.

lead_paragraph: One of the most visible tennis legends at the United States Open has been Billie Jean King, for whom the tournament venue is named and who hasn’t competed in a Grand Slam event since 1983.

abstract: Here comes a big new picture book, organized by decade and with more than 700 photographs.
lead_paragraph: The reason Bill Cunningham’s photographs for The New York Times quickly morphed from occasional small street fashion or society-affair feature into an enormously popular weekly visual column called On the Street was simple.

lead_paragraph: Watching is The New York Times’s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our twice-weekly newsletter here.

abstract: Here’s what we learned about a feminist message in a six-woman field.
lead_paragraph: We just need more women.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1,500,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Cooking Eggs in the Morning and Shucking Oysters at Night, Thanks to an App
abstract: Facing a labor shortage, restaurants are turning to on-demand services for line cooks, dishwashers and other trained workers.
lead_paragraph: As he wrapped up a brunch shift at the Australian cafe Two Hands in the Little Italy section of Manhattan, Christopher Mortenson saw his phone light up. All afternoon, he had been waiting for the notification: ABC Cocina, an upscale Latin American restaurant in the Flatiron district, needed a line cook. He had an hour to get there.

headline: Hong Kong Protesters Squeeze Access to the Airport
abstract: A day after clashes between the police and protesters, including inside a subway car, demonstrators tried to disrupt service at a critical Asian travel hub.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy demonstrators in Hong Kong began a new campaign on Sunday to squeeze access to the airport, hours after one of the most tumultuous days since protests in the city began in June.

headline: Taliban Attack Second Afghan City in 2 Days as Peace Deal Nears
abstract: For the second time in two days, Taliban fighters attacked a provincial capital as government forces scrambled to respond amid peace talks.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban fighters mounted their second attack in two days on a provincial capital in northern Afghanistan on Sunday, as American and Taliban negotiators finalized the details of a preliminary peace agreement.

headline: Matt Tyrnauer: Chronicler of Trump’s Mentor Roy Cohn
abstract: A Vanity Fair correspondent turned documentarian with a fascination for figures of the late 20th century.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD — Back in 2016, when Matt Tyrnauer was cutting his documentary “Studio 54,” he was steeped in archival footage from the late 1970s of the Dante-esque disco.

headline: ‘Steven Universe’ Evolves from 11-Minute Shorts to a 90-Minute Musical
abstract: The hit show’s creator Rebecca Sugar discusses what it was like to make a movie about Steven and the Crystal Gems.
lead_paragraph: Since its 2013 debut, Cartoon Network’s “Steven Universe” has followed the lovable titular teen on his adventures with the Crystal Gems, a team of Earth-defending extraterrestrials. Together, they fight epic cosmic battles while simultaneously attempting to fit in with their human neighbors in the quirky town of Beach City.

headline: Storm Slams into Bahamas, and Menaces Florida
abstract: Dorian struck the northern Bahamas as a Category 5 hurricane, and mandatory evacuations were ordered along the southeastern coast of the United States.

headline: In Republican-Leaning Districts, Lawmakers Shy Away From Broaching Impeachment
abstract: A key group of lawmakers in Republican-leaning districts are staying cautious, and many of their constituents — even impeachment supporters — appear to tolerate that.
lead_paragraph: HOWELL, Mich. — The message printed on a pair of handmade wood-and-cardboard placards could not have been clearer as Representative Elissa Slotkin gazed out on a crowd of about 300 of her constituents who gathered for a town hall-style meeting to discuss their biggest concerns: “IMPEACHMENT INQUIRY NOW.”

headline: A Storm Expert’s View: Dorian’s Damage Remains Impossible to Predict
abstract: One big question about Hurricane Dorian remains: Will the ferocious storm cause significant damage in the United States?
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian’s clear eye and near-circular symmetry, apparent in satellite images, signify a ferocious storm. The Bahamas are in serious, imminent danger. But for all we know about Dorian, which reached Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson scale on Sunday with maximum winds of 185 miles an hour, one big question remains: Will it be a disaster for the United States?

headline: Hurricane Dorian Batters Bahamas as ‘Catastrophic’ Storm
abstract: The strongest storm to reach the northwestern Bahamas, with wind gusts up to 220 m.p.h, Hurricane Dorian brings “devastating” conditions.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian slammed into the Bahamas Sunday, the strongest on record to hit the northwestern part of the archipelago, leaving residents seeking shelter as they faced rising waters, torrential rains and wind gusts up to 220 miles per hour.

headline: Put Your Greens to Work
abstract: Head to the market, and make a greenest green salad, Julia Moskin’s kale-romaine Caesar or Sarah Jampel’s tangy braised collard greens.
lead_paragraph: Good morning! Did you wake up today wondering where August went? Are you, like me, somewhat ambivalent? There’s one half of my psyche ruing the end of shorts-and-sandals season, while the other is itching to tighten my apron strings and get back to work, without the interruptions of travel, school vacations and the general languidness of the season getting in the way.

headline: 2019 U.S. Open: Matches to Watch on Sunday
abstract: Roger Federer, Serena Williams and Novak Djokovic are in action. And there’s still a chance to see Coco Gauff.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic, who has struggled with a sore left shoulder, looked in fine form on Friday night in his third-round match against Denis Kudla.

headline: The Week in Business: A Breakthrough Ruling on Opioids
abstract: The U.K. is convulsing over Boris Johnson's Brexit maneuver, and Wall Street will be squinting at two start-ups' unprofitable business models.
lead_paragraph: It has been 137 years since the first Labor Day march for workers in New York City — and 125 years since Labor Day was declared a United States holiday. If you use Uber, Lyft or DoorDash this weekend, know that the companies just pledged $90 million to fight a California bill that would force them to treat workers as employees, not contractors. — Graham Starr

headline: West Texas Shooting Spree Terrorized Two Towns and Killed 7
abstract: Twenty-two others were wounded, including three law enforcement officers and a 17-month-old who remained in serious condition Sunday morning.
lead_paragraph: ODESSA, Tex. — The 36-year-old man who terrorized two West Texas towns with an assault-style rifle Saturday had been fired from his trucking job a few hours before he led the authorities on a chaotic high-speed chase that ended with his death and the deaths of seven others.

headline: Our Andes Bureau Chief on the One Thing Every Correspondent Prays For in an Emergency
abstract: Hint: It involves cold, hard cash.
lead_paragraph: The Reader Center has started an interview series, Behind the Byline, to introduce you to Times journalists. Is there a reporter, photographer or editor whom you would like to get to know? Tell us in the form below.

headline: Woman Gave Birth in Denver Jail Cell Alone, Lawsuit Says
abstract: Security footage showed Diana Sanchez writhing in pain while she screamed for help.
lead_paragraph: Pacing in her jail cell, Diana Sanchez knew she was about to go into labor. She had been experiencing contractions for nearly five hours.

headline: Clora Bryant, Trumpeter and Pillar of L.A. Jazz Scene, Dies at 92
abstract: Dizzy Gillespie called her his protégé. But faced with sexist discrimination, she did not establish herself as a bandleader until middle age.
lead_paragraph: Clora Bryant, a trumpeter who was widely considered one of the finest jazz musicians on the West Coast  — but who ran into gender-based limitations on how famous she could become — died on Aug. 25 in Los Angeles. She was 92.

headline: An Hourly Worker’s Questions for the President
abstract: A hotel employee describes the uncertainties he faces week to week while the president touts his record on job creation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Edda Servi Machlin, 93, Champion of Italian Jewish Cuisine, Dies
abstract: Friends urged her to write down her recipes, and in 1981 she brought a little-known side of Jewish food to the public
lead_paragraph: Edda Servi Machlin, who survived the harrowing World War II years in Italy by hiding out with anti-Fascist partisans, then immigrated to the United States and wrote a definitive cookbook on Italian Jewish food, died on Aug. 16 at her home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 93.

headline: The Use of Personality Tests in the Workplace
abstract: Readers discuss one woman’s bad experience with the Myers-Briggs test.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The High School Course Beijing Accuses of Radicalizing Hong Kong
abstract: Pro-Beijing officials say a course that teaches critical thinking has created a generation of rebels. Students and teachers say it has made them more engaged with society.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — They are sitting in orderly rows, wearing neatly pressed uniforms. But in this class, as they debate the merits of democracy and civil rights, Hong Kong high school students are prompting Beijing to worry that they are increasingly out of control.

headline: How Many Humps on a Camel? In Kazakhstan, It’s Complicated
abstract: To diversify away from oil, Kazakhstan is supporting an ancient form of camel hybridization. Hump variations abound.
lead_paragraph: AKTAU, Kazakhstan — In most of the world, camels come in two types: two-humped Bactrian and one-humped dromedary.

headline: Why Some Labor Unions Are Holding Back on 2020 Endorsements
abstract: Democratic candidates are jockeying for labor support, but union leaders aren’t rushing to endorse. The race is “so fluid,” one said.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Bernie Sanders was in his element — railing against “the billionaire class” — as he talked up his “100-percent pro-union voting record” and his participation in “God knows how many picket lines.”

headline: Oakland’s Closer Goes by His Own Book
abstract: ‘I like not thinking,’ Liam Hendriks says of an approach that puts the focus on his pitches, not batters’ strengths.
lead_paragraph: Liam Hendriks has read more books this season than he has saved games, though in fairness, he got a late start on the saves. Hendriks became the Oakland Athletics’ closer in late June. He has been an avid reader for much longer, and has read 23 books since he started keeping count this spring, to go with his 17 saves.

headline: ‘Saaho’ Review: Mayhem on an International Scale
abstract: Prabhas cuts a path of destruction in this convoluted Indian action movie.
lead_paragraph: The action-thriller “Saaho” opens “far from India,” a voice intones, in an almost sci-fi city of gleaming, antiseptic skyscrapers. It could be Hudson Yards or Abu Dhabi (where some recognizable exteriors were shot), but it’s a fictional place called Waaji City, ruled by a mob of natty Indian gangsters, eager to restake a claim back home. Cut to Mumbai, where the Waaji City kingpin returns, only to be killed on his first drive through town.

headline: As Grass-Roots Labor Activism Rises, Will Unions Take Advantage?
abstract: Worker organizing is often being done with little union involvement or help. “It’s an opportunity being squandered,” one former labor official said.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When a group of workers at the video-game maker Riot Games staged a three-hour walkout in May over the company’s handling of sex discrimination accusations, they had help from a labor organizer named Emma Kinema.

headline: Serena Williams Wins as Her Half of the U.S. Open Draw Thins Out
abstract: Williams beat Petra Martic on Sunday after No. 2 Ashleigh Barty and No. 3 Karolina Pliskova lost in the fourth round.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams had a very good day on Sunday. The weather was perfect, it was her daughter’s second birthday, and some potential traffic in her quest for a record-tying 24th Grand Slam singles title cleared out in front of her.

headline: ‘Angel Has Fallen’ Keeps Its Lead
abstract: The thriller was first at the box office for the second time in a row during a quiet Labor Day weekend.
lead_paragraph: “Angel Has Fallen” is still on top.

headline: Nicolás Leoz, FIFA Official Charged in Corruption Scandal, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Leoz, once the most powerful man in South American soccer, spent years fighting extradition to the United States to face charges of taking bribes.
lead_paragraph: Nicolás Leoz, the most powerful man in South American soccer for more than two decades, who had spent recent years under house arrest in Paraguay fighting extradition to the United States on corruption charges, died on Wednesday. He was 90.

headline: Dorian Hits Bahamas and Threatens U.S.
abstract: The storm hit the Bahamas over the weekend and then came to a near-standstill, inflicting major damage.
lead_paragraph: The storm hit the Bahamas over the weekend and then came to a near-standstill, inflicting major damage.

headline: The Last Single-Screen Theater in New York Goes Dark
abstract: The Paris was elegant and important. Does its passing matter?
lead_paragraph: The Paris Theater had its concession stand in the basement and a purple velvet curtain in front of the screen, and when it closed last week after 71 years, it was the last single-screen theater in New York City.

headline: Naomi Osaka Salvages Another Awkward Moment at the U.S. Open
abstract: With an act of kindness, Osaka, the world No. 1, helped 15-year-old Coco Gauff process her disappointment after she lost their third-round match.
lead_paragraph: Coco Gauff, at age 15 and in her first United States Open singles tournament, got it just right.

headline: Hezbollah Hits Back at Israeli Army but Without Casualties
abstract: The Iran-backed Lebanese militia said it fired missiles at an Israeli border post in retaliation for recent Israeli strikes.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Lebanese militia Hezbollah fired missiles at an Israeli military border post on Sunday in what it called payback for an Israeli airstrike a week earlier that killed two Lebanese operatives in Syria and a drone strike that damaged Hezbollah infrastructure in the Beirut suburbs.

headline: In Poland, Where History Is a Weapon, Leaders Commemorate World War II
abstract: World leaders gathered in Poland for the 80th anniversary of the outbreak of the deadliest conflict in human history.
lead_paragraph: WESTERPLATTE, Poland — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was not invited. President Trump abruptly canceled. And as other global leaders gathered in Poland on Sunday to commemorate the start of the deadliest conflict in human history, the event served to underscore the divisions in Europe and within Poland itself.

headline: At Arsenal, Rewriting the Story May Take a Bit More Time
abstract: A 2-2 draw against Tottenham includes some hopeful signs for Arsenal, but also a reminder of some bad habits.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One step forward, at times, can feel like more than two steps back. It can seem like a spiral, something irresistible and somehow unavoidable, dragging and twisting you no matter how hard you struggle, no matter how far you think you have come, all the way back to the start.

headline: Barbara Probst Solomon, Who Wrote of Spain Under Franco, Dies at 90
abstract: Admired for her observations on culture and politics, she was best known for a memoir about her involvement with the anti-Franco resistance movement.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Probst Solomon, an American memoirist and essayist known for documenting life in Spain during and after the regime of Gen. Francisco Franco, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.

headline: Sogyal Rinpoche Dies; Tibetan Buddhist Lama Felled by Abuse Accusations
abstract: A friend of the Dalai Lama’s, he wrote a popular book about life, death and the afterlife that updated “The Tibetan Book of the Dead.”
lead_paragraph: Sogyal Rinpoche, a charismatic Tibetan Buddhist teacher and best-selling author who abruptly retired after several of his students accused him of multiple acts of sexual, physical and emotional abuse, died on Aug. 28 in a hospital in Thailand. He was in his early 70s.

headline: Texas Is a Leader in Mass Shootings. Why Is the Governor Silent?
abstract: Greg Abbott’s failure to respond to shootings like the one in Odessa is a moral disaster.
lead_paragraph: Exactly how many dead Texans does it take for Gov. Greg Abbott to actually do something about the epidemic of gun violence sweeping his state? So far, no body count is too big for our governor, who seems determined to do exactly nothing.

headline: Racist and Anti-Semitic Graffiti Shock a Beachfront Oasis
abstract: “Gas chamber” was scrawled on a door, and a swastika and racial slurs covered nearby walls at Silver Gull Beach Club in Queens.
lead_paragraph: On the Friday evening before the final big weekend of summer, members of one of New York’s last private beach clubs, the Silver Gull in Queens, received an ominous email.

headline: U.S. Open Fines Mike Bryan for Making Gun Gesture to a Line Judge
abstract: Bryan was fined $10,000, the largest penalty in the men’s event, after he mimicked pointing a rifle at a line judge following an incorrect call.
lead_paragraph: The United States Open fined the doubles player Mike Bryan $10,000 on Sunday after he received an unsportsmanlike conduct warning in a second-round match early that morning for pointing his racket at an official, mimicking the pointing of a rifle.

headline: German Far Right Makes Election Gains, but Falls Short of Victory
abstract: The Alternative for Germany surged in two elections in the former East Germany, but the parties in Angela Merkel’s coalition managed to cling to power.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A far-right party made significant gains Sunday in two closely watched state elections, snapping at the heels of parties in Chancellor Angela Merkel’s governing coalition and highlighting a growing political divide between the country’s East and West, initial returns showed.

headline: Hollywood’s Shaky Summer Box Office Points to Larger Issues
abstract: The streaming era has taken hold, giving people more reasons to stay home, and spending on entertainment appears to be softening.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This was supposed to be the summer when Hollywood blew the doors off theaters. Stay home and stream? Not with Simba, Spider-Man, John Wick, Snowball, Buzz Lightyear, Aladdin, the X-Men and Godzilla on the way.

headline: Justin Verlander Joins the Three-No-Hitter Club
abstract: A throwback in terms of durability, Verlander took care of things himself while slamming the door on Toronto.
lead_paragraph: Justin Verlander has pitched in the majors for 15 seasons, long enough for his craft to evolve in ways he does not like. Verlander, 36, has led the majors in innings pitched three times. He wishes that teams still emphasized durability, but he has learned to adjust.

headline: Summer Olympics Contest
abstract: Zhouqin Burnikel warms us up for the solving week ahead.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — It is great to see Zhouqin Burnikel back in the lineup. Puzzle lovers can always depend on her to offer a smooth-solving and delightful puzzle.

headline: One Job Is Better Than Two
abstract: Millions of Americans have full-time jobs that don’t pay enough to make ends meet. So they have to work a second job, too.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy for most people to find a job in America on Labor Day 2019. The unemployment rate is very low; store windows are plastered with help wanted signs.

headline: Down, 4-3, Yankees Club Two Solo Homers in the 9th
abstract: Brett Gardner and pinch-hitter Mike Ford hit back-to-back home runs in the bottom of the ninth off A’s closer Liam Hendriks.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Boone is loath to overcelebrate any particular victory, let alone a series, but the Yankees weren’t exactly buying into his Zen after their dramatic conquests of the Oakland Athletics this weekend.

headline: ‘This Will Teach You Next Time,’ 911 Dispatcher Told Arkansas Woman Who Later Drowned
abstract: Debbie Stevens was delivering morning newspapers in her S.U.V. when she was swept away by floodwaters in Fort Smith, Ark.
lead_paragraph: It was still dark out in Fort Smith, Ark., as Debbie Stevens tended to her newspaper delivery route as she had for more than 20 years.

headline: A Change Is Gonna Come
abstract: The first signs of a changing season remind us that nothing — bad or good — is bound to last.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The hardwood trees are still bright green, and temperatures remain stubbornly in the 90s here, but the chipmunks have already lost their minds. If I spill the bird seed, it’s no time at all before they are up the spindles and onto the deck, stuffing their cheeks to the point of comedy and then rushing back to their burrows under the house, stocking up for winter.

headline: That Beloved Hospital? It’s Driving Up Health Care Costs
abstract: It’s easy to criticize pharmaceutical and insurance companies. But we spend much more on hospitals.
lead_paragraph: As voters fume about the high cost of health care, politicians have been targeting two well-deserved villains: pharmaceutical companies, whose prices have risen more than inflation, and insurers, who pay their executives millions in salaries while raising premiums and deductibles.

headline: Seahawks Acquire Jadeveon Clowney From the Texans
abstract: Seattle adds a disruptive force at a meager cost.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Seahawks bolstered one of the N.F.L.’s fiercest defensive fronts over the weekend by acquiring the Pro Bowl defensive end Jadeveon Clowney from the Houston Texans.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Osaka’s Credo: ‘Do It From the Heart’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 2, 2019
lead_paragraph: “For me, the definition of an athlete is someone who on the court treats you like your worst enemy but off the court can be your best friend. I think that’s what she did tonight.”

headline: Texas Shooting Brings New Urgency to Gun Debate in Congress
abstract: After shootings in Dayton and El Paso last month, the issue was already expected to top the agenda when lawmakers return from their recess next week. Now the pressure has intensified.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The deadly shooting spree in West Texas this weekend — the latest in an especially gruesome summer of massacres — has intensified pressure on congressional Republicans to take up gun safety legislation, giving fresh urgency to a debate that was already expected to be at the top of lawmakers’ agenda when they return to the Capitol next week.

headline: Corrections: September 2, 2019
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, September 2, 2019

headline: Italy’s Politics Go to the Beach
abstract: For decades, immigrant peddlers have been part of the familiar fabric of the Italian summer vacation. It’s no longer so simple.
lead_paragraph: ORBETELLO, Italy — The girls, tanning their arms and tattooed ankles, looked up from their phones to sift through the caftans hanging from the Moroccan peddler’s cart. The fathers and sons kicking around orange balls paused to check out the sun hats that a Bangladeshi had balanced on his head. Mothers, fresh from cooling their legs in the sea, were implored by their children to consider the plastic sand buckets and inflatable flamingos that a Senegalese had spread at their feet.

headline: ‘Succession’ Season 2, Episode 4 Recap: The Normo Conquest
abstract: After last week’s grueling episode, this week’s was tough to beat in terms of pure comedy.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s episode of “Succession” was pretty grueling, with a furious Logan Roy literally forcing his family and closest business allies to grovel on the floor. For sausages. By contrast, this week’s episode is … delightful? Is that the right word to use for an hour of TV featuring a funeral, a suicide and an entire office building on lockdown because of an active shooter?

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 5, Episode 2 Recap: Risky Moves
abstract: Helen and Janelle make some iffy choices. With the Joanie plot, the writers are, too.
lead_paragraph: In its closing minutes, this week’s episode of “The Affair” shows us a vision of Montauk, N.Y., a few decades from now. It’s nothing short of post-apocalyptic. Gutted buildings, flooded parking lots, shattered streets in which nothing moves but salt water fish brought in by the tide.

headline: Team ‘McCoco’ Takes a Turn in the Spotlight
abstract: A day after her loss in singles, Coco Gauff was back in a packed stadium playing doubles with her close friend Caty McNally.
lead_paragraph: It would have been understandable if Coco Gauff had come out flat, deflated by a loss the previous evening on tennis’s biggest court — a match memorable less for the thumping final score than for Gauff’s tears and the comfort she received from her opponent, top-ranked Naomi Osaka.

headline: Novak Djokovic, Hampered by Injury, Is Out of the U.S. Open
abstract: Djokovic, the No. 1 seed and defending champion, was trailing Stan Wawrinka by two sets to none on Sunday when he retired from their fourth-round match.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic entered the United States Open as the defending champion and No. 1 seed, having won four of the previous five Grand Slam tournaments. It seemed as if there was only a short list of opponents who could stop him from winning his 17th major title.

headline: U.S. Will Drill With Southeast Asian Navies, Echoing Move by China
abstract: The exercises, which come during a summer of heightened tensions in the South China Sea, highlight the complexities of the rivalry between the United States and China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Southeast Asian countries tend to be deeply reluctant to collectively challenge China’s growing military and economic prowess in their region. But this week, they appear to be doing just that — by holding their first joint naval drills with the United States Navy.

headline: Hurricane Dorian Batters Bahamas, Killing at Least 5: ‘a Historic Tragedy’
abstract: Dorian may be super-powerful, but it’s moving at a snail’s pace. That gives its torrential rains more time to produce floods, and its winds more time to destroy.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Hurricane Dorian, one of the most powerful Atlantic storms on record, hung over the Bahamas on Monday, thrashing the archipelago with high winds and surging seawater that flooded neighborhoods, submerged vehicles and shredded homes. The storm has left at least five people dead, officials said.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Steven Universe’ and ‘Untouchable’
abstract: “Steven Universe” gets a movie on Cartoon Network. And a documentary about Harvey Weinstein hits Hulu.
lead_paragraph: STEVEN UNIVERSE: THE MOVIE (2019) 6 p.m. on Cartoon Network. Rebecca Sugar became the first solo female show creator at Cartoon Network when she created “Steven Universe.” Since its 2013 debut, the show has won a Peabody Award, been nominated for five Emmy Awards and gained applause for being a standard-bearer in L.G.B.T.Q. representation in animation. The series gets the movie musical treatment here, with a story that involves Steven (voiced by Zach Callison) saving the world after the arrival of an alien threatens the continued existence of life on earth. Chance the Rapper, Gallant and Aimee Mann are among the musicians who collaborated on the movie’s original music; Patti LuPone and Christine Ebersole are among the vocal talent involved. “With the show, we like to take things that feel familiar and dig into them,” Sugar said in a recent interview with The New York Times. “So, I wanted to approach a ‘Steven Universe’ musical that way: These are things you recognize from other musicals, but with these characters.”

headline: Along Hurricane Dorian’s Tortured Path, Millions Are United in Fear
abstract: A powerful Category 5 storm has bound together a disparate community of people across states and nations.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Norma Lemon, the owner of a Caribbean-themed restaurant on the South Carolina coast, knows well the power of a hurricane to shatter both property and lives. She can recall the distinctive sound of roofs being ripped away by the winds of Hurricane Hugo as it tore though Charleston in 1989. She spent nearly three months restoring her Island Breeze restaurant after it was flooded by Hurricane Irma in 2017.

headline: Weight-Loss Surgery May Reduce Heart Risks in People With Type 2 Diabetes
abstract: A review of patient records finds startling differences, but critics say a clinical trial must be done.
lead_paragraph: Every year, hundreds of thousands of obese Americans undergo weight-loss surgery in a last-ditch effort to shed pounds and control their Type 2 diabetes.

headline: U.S.C. and the Art of Skating on Thin Ice
abstract: Coach Clay Helton is under immense pressure to turn things around for the Trojans. If he can’t, it might not be just him on the chopping block.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Perhaps owing to Trojan mythology, few in college football can manage a good bloodletting the way the University of Southern California can.

headline: Trump Administration Officials at Odds Over C.I.A.’s Role in Afghanistan
abstract: White House advisers want to expand the C.I.A.’s presence as troops leave Afghanistan, but the agency’s director and others expressed reservations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior White House advisers have proposed secretly expanding the C.I.A.’s presence in Afghanistan if international forces begin to withdraw from the country, according to American officials. But C.I.A. and military officials have expressed reservations, prompting a debate in the administration that could complicate negotiations with the Taliban to end the war.

headline: On the Job, 24 Hours a Day, 27 Days a Month
abstract: A home health aide for a 77-year-old man serves as social worker, diaper changer, dietitian, day planner, warden and more — all at dismal wages.
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, Conn. — Tuesday night was rough. A sharp scent drifted into Marjorie Salmon’s dream world at 4 a.m. She was still trying to rouse herself when its source, her 77-year-old client, pounded on her bedroom door, yelling that he wanted to go home.

headline: Hong Kong Students Begin School Year With Gas Masks, Class Boycotts and Protests
abstract: After a summer of demonstrating in the streets to demand greater rights, students brought their activism to school.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — High school students in Hong Kong starting the new school year on Monday arrived to class wearing gas masks and joined hands to form human chains. University undergraduates held a strike, waved flags and chanted protest slogans.

headline: Riot Police Officers Spread Across Hong Kong in Wake of Violence
abstract: Riot police took positions around schools and subway stations as Hong Kong students, many of whom participated in this summer’s demonstrations, returned to school.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A senior Hong Kong official on Monday warned for the first time that “elements of terror” were seen among the city’s pro-democracy protesters, as riot police officers took up positions around schools and spread out across Hong Kong’s subway system after a weekend of demonstrations punctuated by violence and vandalism.

headline: Ram Dass Is Ready to Die
abstract: “Soul doesn’t have fear of dying. Ego has very pronounced fear of dying.”
lead_paragraph: “Soul doesn’t have fear of dying. Ego has very pronounced fear of dying.”

headline: The W.N.B.A. Is Putting On Some of the Best Pro Basketball in America
abstract: Why aren’t more fans showing up?
lead_paragraph: On opening night in the W.N.B.A., three hours and 25 minutes until the Atlanta Dream’s home tipoff against the Dallas Wings, Brennan Galloway, who runs game operations, was standing in the breezeway beneath the seats of State Farm Arena, a cement colosseum where the Hawks, the city’s N.B.A. team, play from October until at least April. The Dream rents this downtown venue for its regular season, which runs from May into September, but its lease doesn’t give access to all the facility’s perks. The Hawks’ locker room, for instance, was off limits; the Dream players suit up where visiting opponents do (their opponents get a dressing room down the hall).

headline: Interventions to Prevent Psychosis
abstract: An impending psychotic break can be identified and prevented if it is recognized early and appropriate steps are taken to head it off.
lead_paragraph: Tiffany Martinez was a 17-year-old college freshman when she began hearing voices, seeing shadowy figures and experiencing troubling, intrusive thoughts. Her friends at the University of Southern Maine, where she was majoring in psychology, noticed that she was acting strangely and urged her to get help.

headline: Some Like It Hot. Not Me.
abstract: Here’s how I came to hate summer — and you can, too!
lead_paragraph: Here we are, at the end of another summer — at least symbolically, if not officially — and I couldn’t be happier.

headline: Mezcal by Women, and for Women’s Wallets
abstract: As the Yola Mezcal brand grows, the trio who built it are hiring mostly women, in both the U.S. and Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Yola Jimenez’s all-women mezcal business began with her grandfather. In the late 1960s, he bought a farm in Oaxaca near his home in San Juan Del Río, Mexico, and began experimenting with agave cultivation. It was a passion project that grew; eventually he spent more time making mezcal than he did at his day job.

headline: Make Shoes in U.S., or Pay Tariffs? A Footwear Company Seeks a Third Option
abstract: President Trump’s trade war is pressuring American companies to leave China, but many won’t be able to move their supply chains home.
lead_paragraph: Before the trade war threatened to upend everything, Lena Phoenix spent most of her hours puzzling over how to expand the thriving footwear business she and her husband had founded in their home in Colorado.

headline: What We Know About ‘Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker’
abstract: A roundup of details about the new “Star Wars” movie, which is set to put a cap on the nine-film “Skywalker saga.”
lead_paragraph: J.J. Abrams was biting his lip.

headline: With Crowdfunding, Game Inventors Advance to Go
abstract: Crowdfunding platforms give entrepreneurs the opportunity to introduce their games to backers, while retailers and toymakers are often waiting in the wings.
lead_paragraph: Barry McLaughlin and Jason Lautenschleger know games.

headline: ‘Spice World’ & Me
abstract: I went from loving the chaotic Spice Girls movie to dismissing it in college. Now, I appreciate it more than ever before.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1998 “Titanic” was six months into its marathon run in theaters, revelations about President Bill Clinton’s infidelity were hurtling him toward impeachment and I, a kid living in a small English village, was subjecting my younger brothers to weekly screenings of “Spice World” on DVD. I had recently turned 8 years old and believed, quite simply, that this film was the best thing adults had ever created.

headline: Blackbeard’s Ship Heads to Supreme Court in a Battle Over Another Sort of Piracy
abstract: The justices will decide whether an underwater videographer can sue North Carolina for posting his images of the wreckage of a sunken pirate ship.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A little more than 300 years ago, the pirate Blackbeard captured a French merchant vessel, renamed it Queen Anne’s Revenge, armed it with 40 cannons and used it to pursue his calling of pillage and plunder.

headline: The Studio That Turned Out to Be a Family Heirloom
abstract: When a New Orleans native goes apartment hunting in New York City, she happens upon a place where her mother lived in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Rosenblum, a New Orleans native, thought it was a happy coincidence when she realized that a West Village studio she was thinking about renting happened to be in a building where her mother and uncle lived in the late 1970s.

headline: The New Generation of Chefs Pushing Japanese Food in Unexpected Directions
abstract: With their fresh, freewheeling interpretations, these restaurants are challenging long-held ideas about what authenticity actually means.
lead_paragraph: IN 1906, THE YOKOHAMA-BORN scholar Okakura Kakuzo published “The Book of Tea,” a brief tract for Western readers on chanoyu, the centuries-old, highly ritualized Japanese tea ceremony. He argued that the aestheticization of the humble act of drinking tea — “the adoration of the beautiful among the sordid facts of everyday existence” — must be understood as an ethos underlying an entire culture, from its arts and literature to the “delicate dishes” of its cuisine. His intent was to demystify, but his words had almost the opposite effect, heightening the sense of opacity surrounding both the Japanese approach to food and the island nation itself, which from the early 17th century until 1853 was almost completely closed off from the rest of the world.

headline: After Times of Turmoil, ‘Transparent’ Goes Out Singing
abstract: The influential series, which fired the actor Jeffrey Tambor over sexual harassment allegations, will wrap up with a musical finale.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Last February, Jill and Faith Soloway were filming the final episode of “Transparent” here at Paramount Pictures, in the studio’s cavernous Stage 14. It was the last day of a 20-day shoot, and Judith Light, as the nettlesome matriarch Shelly Pfefferman, was tearing through “Your Boundary Is My Trigger,” a show tune-slash-primal scream about how thankless it is to be a mother, and how Shelly gives and gives and gives, and for what?

headline: Summer’s Not Over Yet! 8 Ways to Extend Your Vacation
abstract: With plenty of warm days left in September and beyond, Labor Day doesn’t have to mark the end of the traditional vacation season.
lead_paragraph: By most academic calendars, summer is over after Labor Day. But fall doesn’t officially begin until late September and continued warm weather in many destinations means you can effectively extend your summer vacations throughout the month, with the bonus of fewer tourists — and often, lower prices. So, whether you’re an empty nester, a millennial foodie or a seeker of hot spots without the crowds, here are eight ways to stretch your summer beyond Labor Day.

headline: Does Joe Biden Want to Be Doing This?
abstract: On certain days, Biden 2020 can feel more like a dutiful slog than the last march of a happy warrior.
lead_paragraph: “How badly do you want to be president?” Joseph R. Biden Jr. was asked after a recent speech in Prole, Iowa. The answer to such an inquiry would appear self-evident in the case of Mr. Biden, who began his running-for-president routine more than three decades ago; in other words, very badly, one would assume.

headline: Mom and Dad, It’s My (Digital) Life
abstract: According to your children, ‘sharenting’ undermines their autonomy.
lead_paragraph: The biggest challenge to children's online privacy can be a parent who overshares. “Sharenting” — when parents post pictures and details about their children on social media without their consent (if they’re old enough to give it) — and how it can cause rifts in parent-child relationships were subjects of a recent video Op-Ed.

headline: The Dignity of Disabled Lives
abstract: The burden of being perceived as different persists. The solution to this problem is community.
lead_paragraph: This essay is adapted from the author’s foreword to the new book “About Us: Essays From The New York Times Disability Series.”

headline: California University Steps In to Save Beloved Webcam
abstract: The San Francisco FogCam, believed to be the longest-running public webcam, was supposed to be turned off at the end of August. It has been running since 1994.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco FogCam, believed to be the longest-running public webcam, was supposed to shut down at the end of August, 25 years after it began broadcasting images of life at San Francisco State University (and, on occasion, the city’s trademark fog).

headline: Terror on Both Sides of the Rio Grande
abstract: Nothing can bring back the victims of the attack in El Paso, but the Mexican government knows that the way we label it matters.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — As schools resumed classes last week, teachers, students and parents arrived at Rafael Veloz Elementary in Ciudad Juárez wearing white, holding hands and weeping. The school’s head teacher, Elsa Mendoza Márquez, had been killed on Aug. 3 in the mass shooting in El Paso. The parents had to explain to their young children why she was missing. The assistant head told them that Ms. Mendoza would always be in their hearts.

headline: Life in an Internet Shutdown: Crossing Borders for Email and Contraband SIM Cards
abstract: Internet shutdowns have become one of the defining tools of government repression in the 21st century — but citizens bear the cost at work and at home.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — When Zimbabwe turned off the internet during a recent crackdown, Obert Masaraure, a prominent government critic, had no way of knowing when it was safe to emerge from hiding.

headline: ‘Untouchable’ Review: A Documentary of the Harvey Weinstein Case
abstract: Ursula Macfarlane takes a thorough look at developments so far in the most dramatic story of the #MeToo movement.
lead_paragraph: One by one, the women suffer for us. Pinned by the camera as if they were butterflies, they retell their stories. The narratives share a thread: A hopeful younger self just breaking into show business meets a big-name moviemaker, and the encounter devolves into threats, exhibitionism, unwanted physical contact or violence. Fighting back tears or shaking with anger, they talk about being trapped, disgusted, about freezing up, dissociating, hearing their career prospects are dead. When they speak, we squirm in sympathy.

headline: Seven Photographers Share Images of Their Summers
abstract: Naima Green, Alexander Coggin, Clara Cullen and more share some of the moments they captured this season.
lead_paragraph: Naima Green, Alexander Coggin, Clara Cullen and more share some of the moments they captured this season.

headline: So Long, Summer: 7 Photographers Remember the Season
abstract: Pictures of water-skiing, picnics and beach-going to commemorate three blissful months.
lead_paragraph: Though there are technically three more weeks of summer, Labor Day weekend always unofficially marks the season’s end — and serves as a time to look back on the months of beach-going and picnicking. To honor the occasion, T invited photographers to share some of the moments they captured — including shots of boat rides, garden walks and water-skiing. Click through our slideshow to see this and more.

headline: What to Do With a Day Off
abstract: Step one: Give yourself permission to actually take the day off.
lead_paragraph: If you’re fortunate enough to have Labor Day off from work, the most important thing on your to-do list today is to actually take the day off. Studies have shown that people send only 40 percent less email on holiday Mondays compared with regular Mondays. (Thank you, smartphones and tablets.) Not only that, but taking time to let your brain rest and recover “literally makes us more creative, better at problem-solving, better at coming up with creative ideas.”

headline: Teaching Resources for Bringing the World Into Your Classroom
abstract: Since 1998, The Learning Network has been helping people teach and learn with The New York Times. Here are tips for how to use our site.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Learning Network. Here are three quick facts about our site:

headline: Not Your Grandmother’s Embroidery
abstract: Using Instagram, the British designer Cressida Jamieson has built a following around the floral designs she stitches onto T-shirts.
lead_paragraph: When the British embroiderer and designer Cressida Jamieson is not tending flowers at her allotment — a community garden parceled into plots and rented to city-dwelling gardeners not blessed with the precious acreage — in Walthamstow, North London, she can be found stitching miniature renderings of her blooms (fiery nasturtiums, golden Californian poppies) in her Victorian, wisteria-clad house nearby.

headline: 2019 U.S. Open: Matches to Watch on Monday
abstract: Naomi Osaka faces another tough challenge in her title defense, and other top young players look to make their mark on the tournament.
lead_paragraph: In her first three matches, No. 1 Naomi Osaka has brushed aside concerns surrounding her injured knee in the early stages of the tournament, dropping only one set. On Saturday night, she easily pushed past Coco Gauff, the 15-year-old who has captured the world’s attention with stellar runs at Wimbledon and the United States Open.

headline: California Boat Fire Kills at Least 20; Haunting Pleas as Flames Erupt
abstract: Five crew members were rescued, but the Coast Guard said the passengers were believed to have been asleep below deck.
lead_paragraph: OXNARD, Calif. — The frantic knocking came well before dawn and jolted awake Bob and Shirley Hansen on their 60-foot fishing boat, The Grape Escape, moored for the night off the coast of Southern California.

headline: How The Times Uses FOIA to Obtain Information the Public Has a Right to Know
abstract: Our lawyer provides an update on why we’re still filing so many Freedom of Information Act lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to shed more light on how we work, The Times is running a series of short posts explaining some of our journalistic practices. Read more from this series here.

headline: 5 Dead in Bahamas After Powerful Hurricane Hits
abstract: The Category 3 storm came to a standstill as it pummeled the Bahamas. It is expected to move “dangerously close” to the Florida coast Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: [For the latest updates on Hurricane Dorian on Wednesday]

headline: Iran Acknowledges Space Center Blast, Days After Trump Shares Revealing Image
abstract: A government spokesman said that a technical failure had prompted the fire at the Imam Khomeini Space Center.
lead_paragraph: Iran acknowledged for the first time on Monday that an explosion had occurred at a satellite launch site in the country’s north after images of the aftermath of the blast circulated last week.

headline: Barbecue Ready
abstract: Fried pickles, potato salads, so many dips: Make the most of the day off, and cook.
lead_paragraph: Happy Labor Day! It’s still me, Melissa Clark in for the vacationing Sam Sifton, who should be back at the helm at the end of next week, belly full of Maine oysters if he’s lucky. (If you want to read more about why most summer oysters are now as crisp and fat as their winter counterparts, here’s an exhaustive piece about oyster breeding in The Atlantic that I found riveting, oyster sex life and all).

headline: And Now for Something Completely Different, in Women’s Tennis
abstract: Taylor Townsend and Bianca Andreescu, who played each other Monday night at the U.S. Open, are prime examples of a resurgence of stylistic variety.
lead_paragraph: These are boom times in women’s tennis, with multiple generations colliding.

headline: Should Work Be Passion, or Duty?
abstract: Too many of us expect our jobs to give meaning to our lives. There is a better way.
lead_paragraph: It’s worth noting on a national holiday extolling the value and dignity of labor that Americans are uniquely obsessed with work. Could any other nation come up with a product like Soylent, a meal substitute, not for the elderly, the poor or the malnourished, but for software engineers, Wall Street brokers, tech entrepreneurs and others who don’t want to be diverted from their work by the time consuming intricacies of a meal? Could you imagine the French conceiving such a thing?

headline: White Barn Owls Thrive When Hunting in Bright Moonlight
abstract: Something about the light from a full moon shining on the frightening face of a barn owl makes voles freeze a bit too long.
lead_paragraph: When the moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie, it may not be amore at all, but a ghostly white barn owl about to kill and eat you.

headline: Fall’s Finely Tailored Overcoats
abstract: This season, jackets in wool, camel and calfskin lend a sharp edge to everything from suits to sportswear.

headline: To Start Afghan Withdrawal, U.S. Would Pull 5,400 Troops in 135 Days
abstract: The lead American negotiator has told Afghan leaders that an agreement has been finalized “in principle” with the Taliban. It still needs approval from President Trump.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United States would pull 5,400 troops from Afghanistan within 135 days of signing an agreement with the Taliban, the American special envoy told Afghan leaders on Monday.

headline: Retreating for the Summer, but Not Heading Backward
abstract: Five theater-makers on whom they met, how they relaxed and what they got done during their warm-weather residencies.
lead_paragraph: I went to the O’Neill having had two readings of “it’s not a trip it’s a journey,” but without having had the opportunity to really workshop the play. The process at the O’Neill starts with what they call a dream design — when designers discuss ideas and questions that came up for them as they read the piece. This session was incredibly helpful to me as it unearthed themes that I had not consciously thought through before.

headline: How A.I. Is Constantly Evolving
abstract: Artificial intelligence has grown increasingly sophisticated.
lead_paragraph: Artificial intelligence has grown increasingly sophisticated.

headline: Don’t Eliminate Gifted Programs
abstract: Readers discuss a plan by Mayor Bill de Blasio to achieve integration in the New York City public schools.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tennis at the (Bathroom) Breaking Point
abstract: So many players were claiming restroom time during matches that … excuse us, we’ll be right back.
lead_paragraph: Tennis, a sport known for rapid-fire rallies, sprints to the net and fast-twitch lunges, is being slowed by the most basic of human needs: the bathroom break.

headline: 2020 Democrats Demand Gun Control, but Differ on Tactics
abstract: Joe Biden said there was no room for compromise with congressional Republicans, while Elizabeth Warren sounded more open to it and wanted a broad solution to gun violence.
lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren, two of the leading candidates for the 2020 Democratic nomination, made the case on Monday for muscular new gun control proposals, but differed on whether it was possible to reach compromise with congressional Republicans.

headline: Hurricane Dorian: Airport Closures and Cancellations Multiply
abstract: With the storm’s path uncertain, almost 600 flights have been canceled and airlines and hotels are waiving fees in a widening area.
lead_paragraph: [For the latest on Hurricane Dorian, follow our live coverage.]

headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘Lover’ Is No. 1, but Falls Short of a Million Sales
abstract: Her last four albums in a row had surpassed that mark. “Lover” reached the equivalent of 867,000 sales, still impressive in the streaming era.
lead_paragraph: For almost a decade now, Taylor Swift has defined the contemporary blockbuster music release, with four albums — from “Speak Now” in 2010 to “Reputation” in 2017 — that each opened with more than a million sales.

headline: Naomi Osaka Is Ousted From the U.S. Open by a Resurgent Belinda Bencic
abstract: Bencic’s fourth-round victory was also her third win this year against Osaka, the defending Open champion.
lead_paragraph: One year after winning the United States Open, and less than 48 hours after winning hearts worldwide from the same stadium, Naomi Osaka was knocked out of the tournament in the fourth round.

headline: Review: Public Works Finds the Heroism in ‘Hercules’
abstract: With shrewd casting and amateur performers joining professionals onstage, a middling 1997 animated Disney musical becomes a pageant of civic engagement.
lead_paragraph: When future cultural historians, should there be any, look back on the contemporary stage, I hope they are able to discern, amid the din of jukeboxes and the lumbering of overproduced apes, the real theater of our time.

headline: Masked Gunman Opens Fire on Police in Brooklyn Backyard
abstract: The man was killed when officers returned shots. It was one of four deadly incidents across the city early Labor Day morning.
lead_paragraph: Patrol officers in Brownsville, Brooklyn, spotted an unusual sight early Monday morning: a masked man walking on a quiet residential street.

headline: Faced With Criticism, Trump Administration Reverses Abrupt End to Humanitarian Relief
abstract: United States Citizenship and Immigration Services said it was reviewing a scaled back “deferred action” program to allow some migrants facing medical crises to stay in the country.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Trump administration on Monday announced that it would reconsider its decision to force immigrants facing life-threatening health crises to return to their home countries, an abrupt move last month that generated public outrage and was roundly condemned by the medical establishment.

headline: A Debut Novel Reimagines the C.I.A.’s Efforts to Promote ‘Doctor Zhivago’
abstract: In Lara Prescott’s “The Secrets We Kept,” young women participate in a covert plan to influence the Cold War using Boris Pasternak’s censored love story.
lead_paragraph: The true stories within Lara Prescott’s first novel, “The Secrets We Kept,” are by far the best thing about it. That’s saying a lot, because the job of weaving together bombshell espionage material long kept secret by the C.I.A. with the creation story of a now-dusty Russian novel and tartly-observed “Mad Men”-era feminism and sexual bigotry was tough. Prescott has managed to shape all of this into an above-average entry in the I-Knew-Hemingway genre.

headline: For Europe, the Threat of a No-Deal Brexit Comes at a Bad Time
abstract: With the German and Italian economies in trouble, a so-called “hard Brexit” could tip the entire continent toward a recession.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For a major economy, the best time to descend into befuddling uncertainty over the rules that govern trade is never. As the European Union now confronts the prospect that Britain may bolt its ranks without a deal, most likely triggering mayhem, this is an especially unfortunate moment.

headline: North Korea Missile Tests, ‘Very Standard’ to Trump, Show Signs of Advancing Arsenal
abstract: American intelligence officials and outside experts say that Kim Jong-un is capitalizing on President Trump’s downplaying of his weapons testing to significantly improve the North’s arsenal.
lead_paragraph: As North Korea fired off a series of missiles in recent months — at least 18 since May — President Trump has repeatedly dismissed their importance as short-range and “very standard” tests. And although he has conceded “there may be a United Nations violation,” the president says any concerns are overblown.

headline: Can Anyone Hold the Global Economy Together?
abstract: We are trapped between an erratic Trump, a dysfunctional Europe and an authoritarian China.
lead_paragraph: In the last few weeks, the world economy has seen worrying turmoil. Whether or not a recession is imminent, there has certainly been a collapse of confidence.

headline: A Plan to Diversify New York’s Segregated Schools
abstract: A commission appointed by Mayor Bill de Blasio has ideas worth considering.
lead_paragraph: New York’s public schools are among the most racially segregated in the country.

headline: Why Has Trump’s Exceptional Corruption Gone Unchecked?
abstract: “Drain the swamp” suggests that all political corruption is the same. It isn’t, and the distinctions matter.
lead_paragraph: Consider two scenarios about how Washington works. In one, a local activist decides to run for Congress. A friend hosts a fund-raiser for her at his law firm, where 10 partners each give the maximum legal individual donation, $2,800. After she wins, the host asks her to meet with a client, a constituent whose business would be affected by legislation her committee will soon vote on. She agrees to hear the company’s case against the bill. She never hears from anyone on the other side, which has no lobbyists, and she votes for an amendment that weakens the bill.

headline: Britain’s Boris Johnson Threatens Brexit Rebels With New Election
abstract: Rebels among the prime minister’s party are threatening a revolt. That may force a snap general election.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With a critical showdown over Brexit looming in Parliament, Britain’s mercurial new prime minister, Boris Johnson, took his opponents by surprise again Monday by threatening a snap general election if they defy him in a crucial vote to be held on Tuesday.

headline: Brexit, North Korea, Xinjiang: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Boris Johnson's next ploy.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Dr. Donald Lindberg, 85, Dies; Opened Medical Research to the World
abstract: As director of the National Library of Medicine, the world’s largest medical library, he digitized its holdings to make them available to experts globally.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Donald A.B. Lindberg, who as director of the National Library of Medicine — the world’s largest — computerized its vast holdings and made them accessible to researchers around the world, died on Aug. 17 at a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 85.

headline: The Great Tax Break Heist
abstract: The many, many fiascos of policy by tax cut.
lead_paragraph: Tax scams are the tribute policy vice pays to policy virtue.

headline: Argentina Restricts Access to Foreign Currency to Stave Off Financial Crisis
abstract: The imposition of currency controls is a remarkable about-face for Argentina’s president, who was elected on the promise of liberalizing the economy.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Trying to put the brakes on a financial crisis that has engulfed Argentina in recent weeks, President Mauricio Macri imposed new restrictions on access to foreign currency.

headline: For Kristie Ahn, Kind Words From Deep in Her Past
abstract: On her way to the fourth round, Ahn reconnected with Dinara Safina, the now-retired Russian player who beat her 11 years ago in her first U.S. Open singles match.
lead_paragraph: Kristie Ahn waited 11 years between her first United States Open singles appearance  and her next one, which began last week with three victories.

headline: Franco Columbu, Bodybuilder and Schwarzenegger Friend, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Columbu held titles like Mr. Universe and Mr. Olympia, and helped bodybuilding broaden its audience by appearing in action films and “Pumping Iron.”
lead_paragraph: Franco Columbu, an Italian bodybuilder whose herculean physique won him major titles in the 1960s, ’70s and ’80s, and who helped popularize the sport with his close friend Arnold Schwarzenegger, died on Friday at a hospital in Olbia, Italy. He was 78.

headline: Mocking Slave Owners and Celebrating Freedom
abstract: Take in the subversive beauty of J’ouvert, a Caribbean street party in Brooklyn. Revelers go all out.
lead_paragraph: A queen with devil horns, dressed in a rainbow of satin and shimmering gold tulle, sat on a throne along Brooklyn’s Empire Boulevard. Soon, Karen Herbert, 50, would return to being a retired company supervisor.

headline: Texas Gunman: From Small-Time Troublemaker to Mass Killer
abstract: The man who sprayed gunfire across West Texas on Saturday lived a kind of drifter’s life, fighting to stay employed amid workplace disputes and clashes with the law.
lead_paragraph: ODESSA, Tex. — Monette Rodriguez remembers the oil field truck-driver who lived at the Peppertree Place Apartments. He had the phrase “Oilfield Mafia” displayed on the back window of his blue Dodge Challenger. And he liked to party — neighbors complained that women made frequent visits at all hours of the night to his apartment.

headline: A Summer Rite Canceled by a New Reality: Fear
abstract: After explosive devices were discovered near a Labor Day parade in New Jersey, the event was called off.
lead_paragraph: There were to be jugglers, stilt walkers and puppets of giant butterflies, all marching down Maple Avenue in South Plainfield, N.J., in the town’s 62nd annual Labor Day parade.

headline: Yankees Could Face Some Tough Calls as Their Regulars Return
abstract: When injuries piled up, replacements led the Yankees to 90 wins. But as the playoffs approach, some names missing for months could make a case to play.
lead_paragraph: No body part was safe for the 2014 Texas Rangers. After five winning seasons in a row — including three trips to the playoffs and two American League pennants — those Rangers crumbled under a heap of injuries.

headline: Top Opposition Activists Are Arrested in Moscow After Wave of Protests
abstract: The lawyer Lyubov Sobol, the public face of recent rallies, and two others, were detained in Moscow in a sweep of opposition figures ahead of an election this Sunday.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Russian lawyer in the forefront of recent street protests in Moscow was arrested Monday evening in the Russian capital, along with a second opposition activist and an elected local councilor in what appeared to be a sweep by the authorities of protest leaders not already in detention.

headline: When Elizabeth Warren Agreed With Betsy DeVos
abstract: How a heterodox professor became a predictable candidate.
lead_paragraph: The most important campaign news of the summer was Elizabeth Warren’s surge. Early in the year, her campaign was foundering. She was in fifth place, with a mere 6 percent support.

headline: Pentagon to Divert Money From 127 Projects to Pay for Trump’s Border Wall
abstract: Regaining money for those projects will be up to Congress, which would have to approve new money to fund them. Democrats who control the House are loath to do so.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon will delay or suspend 127 military construction projects so that $3.6 billion can be diverted to shore up President Trump’s border wall, Defense Department officials said Tuesday.

headline: Live Maps: Tracking Hurricane Dorian’s Path
abstract: Mapping the hurricane’s strength, storm surge and expected path.
lead_paragraph: Mapping the hurricane’s strength, storm surge and expected path.

headline: How to Help Hurricane Dorian Survivors in the Bahamas
abstract: Here are a few of the organizations that are working to bring food, water, medicine and other essentials to the Bahamas after the hurricane.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian struck the northern Bahamas as a Category 5 hurricane on Sunday and stalled over the Abaco Islands and Grand Bahama Island for two days. The destructive winds, torrential rains and relentless flooding has likely destroyed more than 10,000 homes and wiped out much of the infrastructure, especially in the Abacos.

headline: Overloaded Fishing Boat Capsizes in Indiana, Leaving 4 Dead and 1 Missing
abstract: A family was celebrating Labor Day on the White River near Martinsville, Ind., when several family members were thrown into the water.
lead_paragraph: An overloaded fishing boat ferrying seven people back to their cars after a family picnic along the White River in Indiana capsized on Monday night, killing four people and leaving one missing, the authorities said Tuesday.

headline: Monfils and Svitolina: Taking Strides Together at the U.S. Open
abstract: Elina Svitolina and Gaël Monfils, who have been dating since late last year, are both flourishing at the Open.
lead_paragraph: As  Elina Svitolina advanced to the semifinals of the United States Open on Tuesday, the other half of tennis’ super couple watched intently from the front row of her player’s box.

headline: In Crunch for College Admission, U.S.C. Tracks Applicants’ Ties to Big Donations
abstract: New documents made public as part of the college admissions bribery case show officials at U.S.C. keeping donation information about applicants in spreadsheets.
lead_paragraph: The emails to the dean of admissions flagged students that the athletic department had taken a special interest in — not, apparently, for their prowess on the field or in the pool.

headline: Dimitrov Stuns Federer at U.S. Open, Adding to Chaos on the Men’s Side
abstract: Daniil Medvedev is off the hook as the bad guy of this year’s U.S. Open after Grigor Dimitrov, ranked 78th in the world, toppled the beloved Roger Federer.
lead_paragraph: On a day when Daniil Medvedev reached an amicable truce with fans at the United States Open, the real villain turned out to be Grigor Dimitrov.

headline: Review: Do You Believe in Miracles? ‘Felix Starro’ Does
abstract: A new musical about a Filipino faith healer bringing “psychic surgery” to America expands the frontiers of the form.
lead_paragraph: “If you have faith, then it must be true,” says the man who has just extracted slimy gobbets of flesh from a woman’s abdomen with his bare hands and no incision. The gobbets, he says, are disease-causing “negativities,” though we  know they are actually chicken guts marinated in fake blood.

headline: ‘Look at the Size of This Thing’
abstract: Patrick Blindauer has a treat for us.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Anybody else feeling hungry after solving Patrick Blindauer’s puzzle? Or maybe you were when you started, but if you finished the puzzle, you might find yourself feeling stuffed and with a bit of a sugar rush.

headline: Serena Williams Rolls Into U.S. Open Semifinals. Now Things Get Interesting.
abstract: Williams needed only 44 minutes to defeat Wang Qiang in the quarterfinals, but the real suspense of her pursuit for another Grand Slam title was always bound to appear in the latest rounds.
lead_paragraph: Sunsets have had more suspense than Serena Williams’s 6-1, 6-0 victory over Wang Qiang in the quarterfinals of the United States Open.
