abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 4, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like we just need to be rescued and put on another island to start over again. Complete devastation.”

headline: Does Your Life Ever Feel Too Busy?
abstract: Does living in the social media age mean that there is no such thing as free time?
lead_paragraph: How busy are you? What do you do in your unscheduled time? Do you ever purposefully slow down and stop being “productive”?

headline: Brexit, Syria, Hurricane Dorian: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Podcast From Adam McKay Examines Jeffrey Epstein and His World
abstract: Mr. McKay, director of “The Big Short” and “Vice,” has joined the podcast veterans Adam Davidson and Laura Mayer to explore the social context that allowed the financier to escape scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: The far-reaching story of Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier who was facing charges of sex trafficking when he killed himself four weeks ago, has been playing out for months. Now it will be the subject of a high-profile podcast, the latest entry in the heated market for audio storytelling.

headline: On Politics: The Would-Be Trump Candidate
abstract: Corey Lewandowski, President Trump’s former campaign manager, is echoing his onetime boss as he weighs a run for the Senate in New Hampshire. Some Republicans are shuddering.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Wu-Tang: An American Saga’ and ‘Our House’
abstract: A mini-series about the early days of the Wu-Tang Clan hits Hulu. And a perturbing Japanese drama is streaming on Mubi.
lead_paragraph: WU-TANG: AN AMERICAN SAGA Stream on Hulu. By the end of this year, audiences will have had two major chances to see the conception of the hip-hop collective the Wu-Tang Clan onscreen. “Wu-Tang Clan: Of Mics and Men,” a multipart Showtime documentary that aired in May, told the group’s story through archival footage and interviews with its members. The scripted mini-series “An American Saga” offers a factually looser version. It casts a group of actors (including Ashton Sanders, of “Moonlight” and the more recent “Native Son”) as the Wu-Tang Clan’s founding members, telling an embellished take on the story of their formation in New York City during the early 1990s. “The Wu-Tang story is vast and you really couldn’t contain it in a two or three hour movie,” the rapper RZA, who is one of the group’s founding members and a creator of the series, recently told The Associated Press. “Now, in a serial form, we can take our time and tell our story.”

headline: Word + Quiz: vainglory
abstract: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past two years.

headline: Late Night on Trump’s Hurricane Comments
abstract: “And I know we’re used to it by now, but it still amazes me how often the government has to tell you not to pay attention to the president,” Trevor Noah joked Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Scandals, Rivals and U.S. Tarnish Netanyahu’s Aura of Invincibility
abstract: While Israelis have learned never to count out their wily prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, his victory in the coming election faces serious hurdles.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Younger rivals in his Likud party are circling overhead. Bombshell exposés on the nightly news have returned his looming indictment on corruption charges to the forefront.

headline: Should a Single Test Decide a 4-Year-Old’s Educational Future?
abstract: The admissions process for gifted programs in New York City has led to a debate over how to desegregate the nation’s largest school system.
lead_paragraph: To get into a gifted and talented elementary school program in New York City, children must ace a single, high-stakes exam — when they are 4 years old.

headline: Pope Francis Arrives in Mozambique, With Renewed Focus on Poverty and Climate
abstract: After years spent grappling with the clergy sex abuse crisis and tussling with conservative clergy, in Africa Francis gets to be the pope he wanted to be.
lead_paragraph: MAPUTO, Mozambique — For a pope pulled against his will into his church’s sexual abuse maelstrom and tussles with conservative clergy, a trip to Africa that began on Wednesday may offer Francis a chance to be the pope he wanted to be.

headline: The Endless Intensity of Rafael Nadal
abstract: The laser-eyed focus that Nadal has displayed since he joined the professional ranks is starkly evident even on a practice court, even on an off day.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Nadal enters the court slowly, somberly, every ounce of him emanating stolid focus. He is locked in. One gets the feeling, watching him strut, that if he were to walk into a wall at this moment, it would be the wall that crumbles.

headline: Sports Betting Has Arrived to Transform the N.F.L. Or Not.
abstract: Unlike other professional leagues, the N.F.L. isn’t expecting a big bump from legalized gambling despite projections.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L.’s centennial season begins Thursday, an anniversary the league has already begun celebrating.

headline: Welcome to San Diego. Don’t Mind the Scooters.
abstract: A year ago, electric rental scooters were hailed as the next big thing in transportation. But their troubles in San Diego show how the services have now hit growing pains.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The first thing you notice in San Diego’s historic Gaslamp Quarter is not the brick sidewalks, the rows of bars and the roving gaggles of bachelorette parties and conferencegoers, or even the actual gas lamps.

headline: Hong Kong’s Leader, Carrie Lam, to Withdraw Extradition Bill That Ignited Protests
abstract: The move eliminates a major objection among protesters, but it was unclear if it would be enough to bring an end to intensifying demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Carrie Lam, Hong Kong’s chief executive, said Wednesday that the government would withdraw a contentious extradition bill that ignited months of protests in the city, moving to quell the worst political crisis since the former British colony returned to Chinese control 22 years ago.

headline: New Tennis Series Seeks to Improve Pathway to the Pros
abstract: Oracle, the computer technology company,  intends to create and fund a large circuit of lower-tier professional tournaments in the United States.
lead_paragraph: In a move expected to significantly increase opportunities for developing American tennis players, Oracle, the computer technology company,  intends to create and fund a large circuit of lower-tier professional tournaments in the United States.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Mysterious Vaping Illness That’s ‘Becoming an Epidemic’’
abstract: In this lesson, students explore the causes and effects of an outbreak in vaping-related illnesses.
lead_paragraph: Please note: Each current events “Lesson of the Day” (renamed from our old “Article of the Day” feature) aims to be usable in a single class period.

headline: Angel Olsen’s Songs Made People Cry. Now She Wants Them to Swoon.
abstract: The 32-year-old singer made a name on uncannily intimate work, but her latest album is thrillingly ornate. Here’s where the strings come in.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, the indie-folk singer Angel Olsen traveled to a dusty, bat-riddled barn in upstate New York to shoot a video that would prove something of a revelation for her. She went alone, taking two flights from her home in Chicago and rounding up her wardrobe before meeting with two filmmakers, Zia Anger and Ashley Connor. They were three young women equipped with only a Bolex camera, a single light source, two rolls of film and a detailed plan for how to create the effect Olsen wanted: a black-and-white clip that would have her disappearing and reappearing, double-exposed in patches of light. They spent tedious hours drawing lines on the floor to mark out positions, arranging and rearranging the camera and light, and filming, six times, Olsen mouthing the words of “Tiniest Seed,” a haunting waltz on which her voice trembles and flickers like a candle in a dark room. After each shot, they rewound the Bolex and did it again, unable to review the footage on site, hoping the different pieces would fit together, joking about getting rabies from the bats above them.

headline: A Recession Isn’t Inevitable: The Case for Economic Optimism
abstract: The worrisome leading indicators are real, but so are the sources of resilience that could keep the expansion going.
lead_paragraph: There is at least one bull market underway: in recession fears.

headline: The Secret History of the Push to Strike Iran
abstract: Hawks in Israel and America have spent more than a decade agitating for war against the Islamic Republic’s nuclear program. Will Trump finally deliver?
lead_paragraph: In July of 2017, the White House was at a crossroads on the question of Iran. President Trump had made a campaign pledge to leave the “terrible” nuclear deal that President Barack Obama negotiated with Tehran, but prominent members of Trump’s cabinet spent the early months of the administration pushing the mercurial president to negotiate a stronger agreement rather than scotch the deal entirely. Thus far, the forces for negotiation had prevailed.

headline: Meeting in the City
abstract: What story could this image tell?

headline: Is ‘Fredo’ a Movie Reference or an Ethnic Slight? Depends Who You’re Yelling At
abstract: A passing reference to “The Godfather” can sound like one thing to pop-culture buffs, something else entirely to Italian Americans.
lead_paragraph: A man walks into a bar and calls Chris Cuomo “Fredo.” It doesn’t go great.

headline: Considering a Sabbatical? The National Parks Want You
abstract: Amble, a crowd-funded start-up, organizes monthlong retreats that pair creative professionals with budget-strapped national park conservancies.
lead_paragraph: Two-thirds of all full-time employees in the United States are currently experiencing job burnout, according to a recent Gallup study. While we aren’t great at taking advantage of earned time off — a whopping 768 million vacation days go to waste every year — a survey by the American Psychological Association last year found that even a two-week getaway is merely a stopgap as work-related stress returns before our tans have faded.

headline: Aerobic Fitness May Trump Strength for Metabolic Health
abstract: Endurance affects metabolism substantially more than muscular strength does, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Stamina may trump strength for improving metabolic health, according to an interesting and provocative new study of the molecular effects of different aspects of fitness. The study, which was published in August in JAMA Network Open, finds that people’s aerobic endurance — or lack of it — can influence their metabolisms more potently than their muscular weakness or might, a result with implications for anyone wondering which types of exercise could be most beneficial for health.

headline: A Muslim Marine’s Trauma: I Was Set Up, Arrested and Acquitted
abstract: While stationed at Quantico, I was arrested for a crime for which I was later acquitted. But the scars of that ordeal stayed with me for years after.
lead_paragraph: When I enlisted in the Marine Corps, I knew it was possible that I would become a casualty of war. I just never imagined I would become a casualty of the war on terror without ever leaving American soil.

headline: Match Wits With Aristo on 5 Quiz Questions
abstract: Here are five questions that were presented to a computer system from the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence, a prominent lab in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: Here are five questions that were presented to a computer system from the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence, a prominent lab in Seattle.

headline: A Lemony Treat You Can Concoct in Summer and Tinker With All Winter
abstract: This parfait for all seasons gets its pucker from that sour tang of buttermilk and extra zing from carbonated soda water.
lead_paragraph: There was a guy named Eddie in my weeklong summer rental share this year who devoted one whole precious vacation day to making mole: hours of frying and dry-toasting and steeping and then wiping up the splatters. The other housemates wandered in and out from the deck or the beach where they’d been, doing a fat load of nothing: dozing in their chairs, people-watching, their books open but unread on their laps. A few sprints into the invigorating Atlantic surf punctuated their naps, during which they lovingly admired Eddie and looked forward to dinner.

headline: Immigration! Influencers! Climate Change! What to Expect This Fashion Month
abstract: A guide to everything you need to know about the ready-to-wear shows.
lead_paragraph: It’s back-to-school time: Parents and kids everywhere are filling their backpacks, charging their computers, readying their water bottles and making shopping lists. That this time of year coincides with fashion month has always seemed something of a cosmic joke, or a telling coincidence. The shows, after all, are effectively a back-to-work moment for all.

headline: Martin Weitzman, Virtuoso Climate Change Economist, Dies at 77
abstract: A pathfinder in environmental economics who insisted on factoring in the worst-case scenarios of global warming.
lead_paragraph: Martin Weitzman, an inventive economist who argued that governments would see climate change as a more urgent matter to address if they took more seriously the small but real risks of the most catastrophic of outcomes, died on Aug. 27 in Newton, Mass. He was 77.

headline: A Breakthrough for A.I. Technology: Passing an 8th-Grade Science Test
abstract: Researchers at the Allen Institute have hit an artificial-intelligence milestone: a machine that is ready for high school science. Maybe even college.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Four years ago, more than 700 computer scientists competed in a contest to build artificial intelligence that could pass an eighth-grade science test. There was $80,000 in prize money on the line.

headline: The Unstoppable Rise of the Zaddy
abstract: Youth will always have a place in fashion, but lately, men of a certain age rule the runway.
lead_paragraph: Men of a certain age have long come in and out of fashion. Throughout the 15th and 16th centuries, European portraiture immortalized tailored tunics and the older aristocrats who wore them. Prior to the Industrial Revolution, celebrating “breeching,” the practice of putting a boy in pants for the first time, was all the rage. Skip ahead to 2012, when, in its fall campaign, Prada balanced the winsome youth of the actors Jamie Bell and Garrett Hedlund with the steely eyed bravado of Gary Oldman and Willem Dafoe. Then, in 2016, there was the then 80-year-old model and viral sensation Wang Deshun, better known as China’s hottest grandpa, who appeared in advertisements for Ermenegildo Zegna.

headline: What’s Broadway Got to Do With It? More Pop Musicals
abstract: New York stages will bop to the songbooks of Bob Dylan, Alanis Morissette, Tina Turner and David Byrne this season. And that’s not counting the 70 songwriters of “Moulin Rouge!”
lead_paragraph: Put the blame on Abba.

headline: The Planets, the Stars and Brad Pitt
abstract: With two major performances this year, the 55-year-old actor and producer talks frankly about his future onscreen, masculinity and getting sober.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Faster alone, further together,” Brad Pitt murmured. Over his left shoulder hung Mars, reddish-brown and heartbreakingly small, while to his right, the much grander Jupiter was lit up like a disco ball.

headline: The Daily Indignities Faced by 2020 Long Shots
abstract: Low-polling Democrats who didn’t make this month’s debate are soldiering on, but fewer voters seem to be tuning in.
lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Dozens of reporters and photographers descended on the Hawkeye Downs speedway, all waiting for one man to appear at a local Labor Day picnic.

headline: Harry Potter Brought Him to Broadway. Now His Work is Everywhere.
abstract: Eccentric and prodigious, the writer Jack Thorne won a Tony for “Cursed Child.” Up next: “Sunday” at the Atlantic Theater Company, and “His Dark Materials” on HBO.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jack Thorne has no shortage of ways to characterize his own eccentricity. “I’m a slightly deranged adult.” “I’m not very good with other people.” “I’m mental.”

headline: ‘It’s About Time!’ Betye Saar’s Long Climb to the Summit
abstract: At 93, with major attention finally coming her way, an artist central to the black women’s revolution says she’s waited long enough.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — I ask the artist Betye Saar, who is 93 and set to open concurrent solo shows this fall at two major museums — the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art — if she has any theories as to why big-ticket attention is finally coming her way. She skips mentioning the obvious factors: She’s a woman; she’s black; she’s lived her whole life on what she calls “the other side of the planet” (Southern California). “Because it’s about time!” she says. “I’ve had to wait till I’m practically 100.”

headline: Sahara-Level Sand Dunes, Mediterranean-Blue Water: Welcome to Michigan
abstract: Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore is one of the Midwest’s most delightful surprises.
lead_paragraph: The Dune Climb is one of the most popular things to do in a remarkably beautiful, off-the-radar corner of northwest Michigan called Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore. Yet it had me suffering like a modern-day Sisyphus on a June afternoon. With each oxygen-sucking, uphill step, I slipped and slid backward on the sandy slope. My lungs burned, my bad knee ached, I was drenched with sweat — and I was only halfway to the top.

headline: Living In ... Westport, Conn.
abstract: The suburban backdrop to TV shows like “Bewitched” and “American Housewife” offers residents a rich cultural life and high-end shopping and dining.
lead_paragraph: The suburban backdrop to TV shows like “Bewitched” and “American Housewife” offers residents a rich cultural life and high-end shopping and dining.

headline: You Know Emily Doe’s Story. Now Learn Her Name.
abstract: After her Stanford University sexual assault case prompted public outrage, Chanel Miller, who remained anonymous throughout the proceedings, is ready to introduce herself.
lead_paragraph: For four years, the woman whose Stanford University sexual assault case caused a public outcry, has been known only as “Emily Doe.” In her new memoir, “Know My Name,” which charts her life since then, she reveals her real name: Chanel Miller.

headline: Westport, Conn.: A Historic Town With a Global Mind-Set
abstract: The suburban backdrop to TV shows like “Bewitched” and “American Housewife” offers residents a rich cultural life and high-end shopping and dining.
lead_paragraph: For Mike and Daniela Forde, building a home in Westport, Conn., was a major decision. It meant that, after four years of renting a house in nearby Old Greenwich, they would become property owners. It also meant remaining in the United States rather than returning to their native England.

headline: Cathay Pacific’s Chairman Resigns as China Pressures Hong Kong Business
abstract: The exit of John Slosar would be the second high-profile departure from the carrier, which has been rocked by protests in its home city, since last month.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The chairman of Cathay Pacific Airways said on Wednesday that he would resign, making him the second top executive of the embattled Hong Kong carrier to step down since protests began roiling the city.

headline: How Lizzo Does That
abstract: The star, with one of the biggest hits of the summer, clues us in on her beauty rituals.
lead_paragraph: The singer and rapper Lizzo, 31, is one of the buzziest acts in music right now, what with her fierce lyrics, outspoken personality and fashion presence. She is also about to cross over into film, with a role in “Hustlers,” out Sept. 13. Lizzo, who is an Urban Decay brand ambassador, lives in Los Angeles. Here, she dishes on her skin rehab, impossible standards and what she does first thing in the morning.

headline: Hurricane Dorian’s Impact on New York
abstract: Wednesday: The region isn't expected to sustain the storm's wrath, but big waves, gusty wind and some rain are possible.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Storm Could Swamp the Coast From Florida to Virginia
abstract: The National Hurricane Center warned of “life-threatening” storm surge along hundreds of miles of the Southeast coast, even before the storm’s high winds arrive.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian, which caused widespread devastation in the Bahamas, was churning on Wednesday off the Atlantic coast, and residents along hundreds of miles of shoreline were warned of its potential for life-threatening storm surge and dangerous winds.

headline: As Afghanistan Seeks Peace, Social Media Raises Fear of Reprisals
abstract: The spread of graphic imagery of killings in a war that reaches so deep into local communities threatens to fuel vengeance beyond any U.S.-Taliban deal.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In recent months, an increasing number of graphic images of atrocities in the Afghan war have circulated on social media — raising alarm that hatred sown deep into local communities would be difficult to resolve even if a peace agreement can be reached with the Taliban.

headline: Dorian, Brexit, Ariana Grande: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Former Slave Who Sued for Reparations, and Won
abstract: Henrietta Wood sued the man who had kidnapped her into slavery for damages and lost wages, offering lessons for today’s debate.
lead_paragraph: The debate over reparations has re-entered American politics. At congressional hearings, primary debates and across social media many people are talking about what reparations could look like and who might get them.

headline: The Sudden-Death Phase of the Democratic Primary
abstract: As the 2020 campaign ramps up and the Democratic field shrinks, we look at what’s different about this election cycle.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Four Things That Are Not White Nationalism
abstract: Conservatism’s racism problem is real. So is a pattern of media smears against non-racist conservatives.
lead_paragraph: The American right in the Trump era has a racism problem. It’s fed by a Republican president who race-baits, a media ecosystem whose guardrails have collapsed, the lure of far-right ideas after various center-right failures and the influence of toxic forms of internet community on impressionable minds.

headline: Want to Stop Right-Wing Populists? Then Don’t Do This
abstract: A flimsy coalition has sidelined Italy’s far-right populist, Matteo Salvini. He will seek revenge.
lead_paragraph: There’s a number of things any savvy politician who cares about liberal democracy should avoid: feeding the idea that the popular will is generally disregarded and political power is managed by unelected elites in smoked-filled rooms; forming politically incoherent alliances with the sole purpose of excluding populists; and fueling the perception that the most important decisions of a country are taken outside of its borders.

headline: Climate Town Hall: Several Democratic Candidates Embrace a Carbon Tax
abstract: At a CNN forum on climate change, the first such prime-time event in a presidential campaign, candidates vowed to take aggressive action to combat global warming.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democratic candidates promised unprecedented new action on climate change on Wednesday night in the first prime-time televised forum devoted to the issue in a presidential campaign, vowing to undo the Trump administration’s environmental policies, spend trillions of dollars to promote renewable energy and force companies to pay new taxes or fees.

headline: The Trump Voters Whose ‘Need for Chaos’ Obliterates Everything Else
abstract: Political nihilism is one of the president’s strongest weapons.
lead_paragraph: Over the four years during which he has dominated American political life, nearly three of them as president, Donald Trump has set a match again and again to chaos-inducing issues like racial hostility, authoritarianism and white identity politics.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Walmart’s C.E.O. Sets an Example for Corporate America on Guns
abstract: Doug McMillon’s move to further limit firearms sales is a watershed moment in the gun debate, and other corporate chiefs should take note.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning. Programming note: I’m going to be in conversation with Blackstone’s co-founder and C.E.O., Stephen Schwarzman, about his new book, “What It Takes: Lessons in the Pursuit of Excellence,” and about the global economy and philanthropy for a DealBook TimesTalk in New York on Sept. 16. Get your tickets here.  (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: A Murdered Spy’s Widow Relives Her Loss Onstage
abstract: Lucy Prebble’s new play, “A Very Expensive Poison,” dramatizes the assassination of Alexander Litvinenko. How did it feel for his wife, Marina, to watch?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In November 2006, Marina Litvinenko watched her husband, Alexander, die in a London hospital. The Russian spy-turned-whistle-blower — whom she called Sasha — had drunk green tea laced with the radioactive element polonium. President Vladimir V. Putin probably approved the murder, a public inquiry in Britain later said.

headline: How a Summer Festival Is Shaping New York’s Theatrical Winter
abstract: Seven of this season’s Broadway and Off Broadway shows come from an eight-week theatrical powerhouse in Williamstown, Mass.
lead_paragraph: The spit-and-plywood sets we built when I was a general assistant at the Williamstown Theater Festival were designed to last only as long as the two-week productions.

headline: Boris Johnson Loses to Democracy
abstract: The prime minister is effectively at war with the Parliament for which he once promised to “take back control.”
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Michael Rakowitz Wins Nasher Prize for Sculpture
abstract: The prize comes with $100,000, which Mr. Rakowitz would use for his continued work centering on Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Michael Rakowitz, a Chicago-based artist dedicated to resurrecting the past and drawing attention to the neglected, has been awarded the 2020 Nasher Prize, the Nasher Sculpture Center in Dallas announced on Wednesday. As a part of the award, which honors a living artist for their contributions to sculpture, he will receive $100,000.

headline: New Yorker Festival Will Host Two Democratic Candidates and Nancy Pelosi
abstract: This year’s festival will include Pete Buttigieg and Julián Castro at separate events, in addition to Pelosi and an array of artists and entertainers.
lead_paragraph: Days before several Democratic presidential nominees debate in October, people in New York will have an opportunity to see two candidates interviewed in person.

headline: U.K. Lawmakers Batter Johnson Again, Defying Him on Brexit and Election
abstract: After lawmakers seized control of Brexit from the prime minister, they doubled down by rejecting his request for an October election. Though a setback for Mr. Johnson, it may be only temporary.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson was battered again on Wednesday as lawmakers from his own party and the opposition pressed ahead to stop his plan for leaving the European Union without an agreement — and then turned down his call for an election.

headline: Still No Federer-Nadal Match for U.S. Open Fans
abstract: At 38, Federer has fallen short in New York for a decade.
lead_paragraph: Wimbledon hangover?

headline: Are African Artifacts Safer in Europe? Museum Conditions Revive Debate
abstract: Outdated facilities and disarray have activists and researchers concerned about the way German museums store items from Africa, Asia and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Is Africa’s cultural heritage better off in Europe or in Africa?

headline: Police Use of Facial Recognition Is Accepted by British Court
abstract: In a closely watched case, a judge ruled that live facial recognition does not violate privacy rights. There has been little legal precedent about its use.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In one of the first lawsuits to address the use of live facial recognition technology by governments, a British court ruled on Wednesday that police use of the systems is acceptable and does not violate privacy and human rights.

headline: Norway’s Viking Ships Defied Time, but Tourism May Be a Fiercer Foe
abstract: The Norwegian government has earmarked $200 million to restore and move two Viking longships under threat from a surge in visitors to their museum.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — Two of Norway’s greatest cultural treasures, the preserved Viking longships Oseberg and Gokstad, managed to survive sea voyages more than a thousand years ago, followed by centuries interred in burial mounds alongside various dignitaries and objects like a sled, board games and the remains of peacocks.

headline: Democrats Say Their Climate Plans Will Create Jobs. It’s Not So Simple.
abstract: Fighting climate change can create jobs, experts say, but politicians' estimates might not capture the complex reality of what that growth could look like.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Democratic presidential candidates are rolling out their plans to fight climate change, and one thing is clear: Averting catastrophe is only one selling point. So far, nearly every presidential candidate claims that cutting greenhouse gases will also lead to an economic bonanza.

headline: Brexit Rebels Have a Problem
abstract: There is majority support for … nothing.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Amid Vaping Crackdown, Michigan to Ban Sale of Flavored E-Cigarettes
abstract: The decision by Gov. Gretchen Whitmer comes amid a national uptick in illnesses tied to vaping and concern that companies are marketing to children.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan said Wednesday that she would outlaw the sale of flavored e-cigarettes in her state, part of a national crackdown on vaping amid a recent spike in illnesses tied to the products.

headline: What Was It Like Aboard the Conception?
abstract: Wednesday: Readers who have been on scuba diving trips recall their experiences. Also: U.S.C.’s entanglement in the college admissions scandal deepens with new court filings, and Gem-O-Rama.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Hong Kong’s Leader Partly Relents. Will the Protests Continue?
abstract: Carrie Lam said she would withdraw the extradition bill that set off demonstrations in the city. But protesters are now seeking bigger changes.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After nearly three months of protests that have rocked Hong Kong, the city’s leader, Carrie Lam, made a key concession on Wednesday in announcing her intention to formally withdraw a deeply unpopular extradition bill.

headline: Tracing Disinformation With Custom Tools, Burner Phones and Encrypted Apps
abstract: As the 2020 race heats up, here’s how Matthew Rosenberg, a politics reporter, is preparing for an onslaught of intentional falsehoods.
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Matthew Rosenberg, who covers political disinformation and is based in Washington, discussed the tech he’s using.

headline: Can You Draw This? Of Course You Can
abstract: Sketching is a form of visual thinking that exercises the mind and body, and it’s easy to turn your tablet into a portable art studio.
lead_paragraph: “Any one who can learn to write, can learn to draw,” John Gadsby Chapman wrote in his 19th-century instruction manual, “The American Drawing-Book.” This can-do sentiment dates back to an era when lead pencils and chalky pastels were standard. Today’s artists — and wannabe artists — also have the option of easy-to-use digital gadgets.

headline: What You Get for Around $600,000
abstract: A Gothic mansion in Newburgh, N.Y.; a 1926 cottage in Seattle; and a farmhouse in Wilton, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A Gothic mansion in Newburgh, N.Y.; a 1926 cottage in Seattle; and a farmhouse in Wilton, Conn.

headline: $600,000 Homes in New York, Washington and Connecticut
abstract: A Gothic Revival mansion in Newburgh, a 1926 cottage in Seattle and a farmhouse in Fairfield County.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Clarke Withers, a British-born architect who was a partner of Calvert Vaux, designed this Victorian home for David M. Clarkson, a horticulturalist. Originally called Glenbrook, it is in the hamlet of Balmville, two miles north of the restaurants, galleries and spas of Newburgh’s renovated waterfront district and across the road from the Powelton Club, a country club established in 1882. When the house was built, residents could see the Hudson River. New York City is 70 miles south.

headline: Bette Midler’s Penthouse Goes on the Market
abstract: The entertainer and her husband are downsizing from an airy triplex with views of Central Park.
lead_paragraph: The entertainer and her husband are downsizing from an airy triplex with views of Central Park.

headline: Peter Lindbergh, Photographer Who Captured Rise of the Supermodel, Dies at 74
abstract: He was known for cinematic and naturalistic portraits of models in black and white.
lead_paragraph: Peter Lindbergh, a pillar of contemporary fashion photography who played a key role in inaugurating the supermodel era in the 1990s, died on Tuesday in Paris, where he lived. He was 74.

headline: Google Is Fined $170 Million for Violating Children’s Privacy on YouTube
abstract: As part of a settlement, YouTube said it would also institute new privacy measures on children’s videos. Critics said the changes did not go far enough to protect children.
lead_paragraph: Google agreed on Wednesday to pay a record $170 million fine and make changes to protect children’s privacy on YouTube, as regulators said the video site had knowingly and illegally harvested personal information from children and used it to profit by targeting them with ads.

headline: Seven Bedrooms on the Mediterranean in Crete
abstract: This seven-bedroom villa on the northern coast of Greece is on the market for $1.3 million.
lead_paragraph: This seven-bedroom villa on the northern coast of Greece is on the market for $1.3 million.

headline: Hong Kong, Carrie Lam Didn’t Do It for You
abstract: The city’s leader finally makes a concession — caving to Beijing and big business.
lead_paragraph: At long last, on Wednesday Carrie Lam, the leader of Hong Kong, announced, along with a few other largely symbolic measures, the formal withdrawal of the contentious extradition bill that set off a summer of protests. But this is a totally unacceptable response to the crisis facing the city. And no less than her earlier steadfast refusal to concede anything to the protesters, the gesture — so minor and coming so late — only confirms what many of us suspected are the interests she really serves.

headline: House Hunting in … Greece
abstract: As the country emerges from a crippling debt crisis, the island of Crete remains popular with second-home buyers.
lead_paragraph: This seven-bedroom, four-bathroom home is in Plaka, a fishing village on the northwestern coast of Crete, the largest and most populous of the Greek islands. The property, known as Villa Ioanna, sits on a sloping, 1.23-acre lot near several olive groves and overlooks Souda Bay and the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: The Ezekiel Elliott Drama Ends: He’s Back With the Cowboys
abstract: Most N.F.L. holdouts end this way, with the player returning. But there are enough outliers to have caused anxiety in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: In the end, the superstar running back Ezekiel Elliott, after a protracted contract stalemate with the Dallas Cowboys, will suit up and play this season. It’s the way these high-profile N.F.L. holdouts tend to end, most of the time, anyway.

headline: Judging Margaret Atwood’s Top Secret New Novel
abstract: The committee that will award the Booker Prize had to take special precautions to make sure no details of “The Testaments” leaked out.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In July, the author Xiaolu Guo was expecting the delivery of a book that would not be published until September: Margaret Atwood’s “The Testaments,” the highly anticipated follow-up to “The Handmaid’s Tale.”

headline: Eggs for Dinner!
abstract: They always seem a little daring — like a special treat. Serve them jammy-yolked and under a coconut-onion-tomato sauce tonight.
lead_paragraph: Hello again … and goodbye! Here we are, post-Labor Day, which means it’s the end of summer hours and the more laid-back attitude that often goes with them. This also means that Sam Sifton’s return is imminent, and he’ll be back in your inbox on Friday. Thanks for reading, it’s been a blast!

headline: The Homes in Dorian’s Path Are in a High-Risk Area. Why Do They Cost So Much?
abstract: In “The Geography of Risk,” Gilbert Gaul explores the strange paradox that the value of coastal real estate has risen even as climate change presents new dangers.
lead_paragraph: THE GEOGRAPHY OF RISKEpic Storms, Rising Seas, and the Cost of America’s CoastsBy Gilbert M. Gaul

headline: White House to Relax Energy Efficiency Rules for Light Bulbs
abstract: In 2007, a bipartisan Congress said that requiring energy efficient light bulbs was the right idea. The Trump administration disagrees.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration plans to significantly weaken federal rules that would have forced Americans to use much more energy-efficient light bulbs, a move that could contribute to greenhouse gas emissions that cause global warming.

headline: Jacob Rees-Mogg Takes Brexit Lying Down
abstract: Mr. Rees-Mogg, the House of Commons leader, reclined on Parliament’s front benches during Tuesday’s debates, offering a target for the prime minister’s foes and inspiring internet memes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Not long after asking the House of Commons to “contemplate the current constitutional confusion and consider the chaos this concatenation of circumstances could create” on Tuesday night, the British lawmaker Jacob Rees-Mogg reclined on the front bench of the chamber until he was nearly horizontal.

headline: How I Learned to Fail Better
abstract: What the Bread Loaf Writers’ Conference taught me about invention and revision.
lead_paragraph: There we were, cavorting in a creaky old barn as a D.J. played Bruce Springsteen’s “Dancing in the Dark.” Some 200 authors raised their arms in unison and shouted, “I’m sick of sittin’ ’round here tryin’ to write this book.”

headline: U.S. Open Highlights: Berrettini Wins Marathon and a Date With Nadal
abstract: Rafael Nadal is among the final four at the Open for the eighth time. Matteo Berrettini, Bianca Andreescu and Belinda Bencic reached their first Grand Slam semifinals.
lead_paragraph: Gaël Monfils bent over at the waist, one hand on his knee and the other resting on the handle of his racket, which supported him like a cane as he tried to catch his breath inside a stifling Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: The Original Evil Corporation
abstract: The East India Company, a trading firm with its own army, was masterful at manipulating governments for its own profit. It’s the prototype for today’s multinationals.
lead_paragraph: The rise and rise of giant oil and tech companies, with their campaign contributions, commercial lobbying, predictive data harvesting and surveillance capitalism, has lent a certain urgency to old questions: How are we to cope with the power and perils of multinational corporations and how can a nation-state protect itself and its citizens from corporate excess?

headline: Teenager Dies in Kashmir Amid Protests After Autonomy Was Revoked
abstract: The Indian authorities acknowledged the death of a 16-year-old but they said they did not know the specific cause. Witnesses said he had been hit in the face with buckshot.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A 16-year-old Kashmiri boy has died after security officers hit him in the face with buckshot, several witnesses said — the first officially confirmed death linked to protests since the Indian government revoked Kashmir’s autonomy a month ago.

headline: ISIS, Weakened, Finds New Bombers: Cows Wearing Explosive Vests
abstract: The animals wandered into the outskirts of a village in Iraq, and when they seemed close to houses, the bombs were detonated remotely.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State has been reluctant to use humans to carry bombs because of the group’s reduced numbers, so it has tried out a new tactic: Bovine suicide bombers.

headline: Bob Newhart on His Secretly Sick Humor and Turning 90
abstract: The man who made the comedy special a thing is still performing and doesn’t mind that new shows borrow from him. See: “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Bob Newhart didn’t invent stand-up comedy, but more than any performer he can lay claim to giving birth to the modern industry of the comedy special.

headline: LeBron James, a Fan of Tacos, Seeks to Trademark ‘Taco Tuesday’
abstract: “It has nothing to do with stopping others from using the term,” a spokesman for the basketball star said.
lead_paragraph: It’s an undisputed fact that LeBron James loves tacos, especially on Tuesdays.

headline: Rosemary Kuhlmann, Singer in a TV Breakthrough, Dies at 97
abstract: In 1951 she sang a pivotal role in Gian Carlo Menotti’s made-for-TV opera, ‘Amahl and the Night Visitors,’ which became a classic.
lead_paragraph: Rosemary Kuhlmann, a mezzo-soprano who was a central part of an early television experiment that became a holiday classic, singing the role of Amahl’s mother in the 1951 world premiere of the opera “Amahl and the Night Visitors” on NBC and returning to the part for years afterward, died on Aug. 17 in Warren, R.I. She was 97.

headline: Thebe Magugu Wins LVMH Prize for Young Designers
abstract: The award marks the first time a designer from the African continent has won the industry’s most prestigious talent prize.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thebe Magugu, a 26-year-old South African designer known for powerful and politicized women’s wear collections inspired by the social complexities of his home country, has won the 2019 LVMH Prize for emerging talent. He is the first African designer to be awarded the prize, the most lucrative in the industry.

headline: Theresa May Endured Years of Brexit Criticism. Look Who’s Laughing Now.
abstract: For nearly three years, the former prime minister of Britain was the focus of the nation’s ire. This week, she was seen laughing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For the better part of three years, when Theresa May was prime minister of Britain, she was the focus of the nation’s ire as frustration over her inability to get lawmakers to approve her Brexit deal boiled over.

headline: Who’s Lying to Us and Who’s Telling the Truth? Malcolm Gladwell Has Some Ideas
abstract: In his newest book, “Talking to Strangers,” Gladwell looks at the challenge of figuring out whom we should trust — and whom we shouldn’t.
lead_paragraph: Deep into Malcolm Gladwell’s “Talking to Strangers,” his first book in six years, lies a precise arrangement of words that could function as a Rorschach test — a sentence that will strike you as reassuring if you love his best-selling books or exasperating if you don’t.

headline: Behold Mortichnia, the Death Trail of an Ancient Worm
abstract: A 500-million-year-old fossil offered a rare treasure: the imprint of an animal that literally died in its tracks.
lead_paragraph: More than half a billion years ago, in what is today southern China, a worm resembling an ear of wheat moved along a stretch of sediment underwater, paused, and left a detailed imprint of its undercarriage in the wet earth. Then it moved a little further and died. Its body, seven inches long and segmented, became a fossil. So did its near-final resting place, creating a mortichnia: a body preserved with its final “death march.”

headline: Meet Li’l Gus, a Dancing Alter Ego
abstract: For Gus Solomons Jr., puppets relate directly to dance: “There’s no real personality there, but as soon as they move, you see one.”
lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at @nytimes.

headline: Does America Care About Care? Not Enough
abstract: Some 41 countries across the globe guarantee their workers paid family leave to tend to children or elders. The United States doesn’t. That may be changing.
lead_paragraph: First of three articles.

headline: The Riotous, Internet-Speed Sound of 100 gecs
abstract: This duo’s debut album, “1000 gecs,” smashes electro-pop, dance music, punk and dozens of other rapid-fire reference points into something genuinely new and exhilarating.
lead_paragraph: Take in all of “1000 gecs” — the debut album by the band 100 gecs — in one sugar-rush gulp. Gorge on it. Let it pummel your ears from the outside, and rattle your brain from the inside. To listen to this album is to cede a certain amount of control, and to accept that letting go of the wheel is not only freeing, but maybe inevitable, too.

headline: Johns Hopkins Opens New Center for Psychedelic Research
abstract: The research center, with $17 million from donors, aims to give “psychedelic medicine” a long-sought foothold in the scientific establishment.
lead_paragraph: Since childhood, Rachael Petersen had lived with an unexplainable sense of grief that no drug or talk therapy could entirely ease. So in 2017 she volunteered for a small clinical trial at Johns Hopkins University that was testing psilocybin, the active ingredient in magic mushrooms, for chronic depression.

headline: Carmelo Doesn’t Deserve This
abstract: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein expresses hope for a better ending for Carmelo Anthony and gets personal about how he got into sportswriting.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: With New Cabinet, Italy’s Head-Spinning Political Turmoil Ends, for Now
abstract: Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte, who salvaged his position with an unlikely coalition with the rival Democratic Party, presented his new cabinet to the president.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Announcing his new cabinet on Wednesday, Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte of Italy ended what news reports here had called “the craziest crisis in the world,” brought on by the sudden collapse of the country’s government last month when one of his coalition partners pulled its support.

headline: ‘Indecent’ and ‘Absurd’: Project for Gare du Nord Divides Paris
abstract: The award-winning architect Jean Nouvel and others have warned that a €600-million renovation will turn Europe’s largest train station into a giant shopping center.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A group of leading French architects have denounced a plan to renovate the Gare du Nord, one of Paris’s main train stations, calling the designs that would turn the station into a glassy, mammoth, restaurant-filled shopping mall “indecent,” “absurd” and “unacceptable.”

headline: On-Demand Webinar: Teach Across the Curriculum With New York Times-Inspired Daily Prompts
abstract: Join us as we explore how to use our thousands of free writing prompts for everyday low-stakes writing practice across the curriculum.
lead_paragraph: Do you wish you could easily bring current issues and events into English, social studies, science or math class? For example, would you like your students to develop arguments using topics they care about, like social media, football, pop culture or the criminal justice system? Do you wish they could connect what they’re studying in class to themes and controversies relevant to today’s world, on issues from race, gender and identity to genetics and climate change?

headline: A Tomato Grows in the East River
abstract: A single tomato plant has sprouted on a piling by the Brooklyn Bridge. Who knows how it got there?
lead_paragraph: On a wooden piling in the waters off Brooklyn Bridge Park, a lone red fruit grows between Pier 1, right next to the Brooklyn Bridge, and Pier 2. Sure, it’s tomato season, but this one seems to have materialized without the aid of any planter or gardener.

headline: The Sculptor Who Reconceives Classical Myths
abstract: Yoko Kubrick’s marble works reference familiar tales while subverting the traditions that have defined her discipline.
lead_paragraph: TO UNDERSTAND the ethereal sculptures made by the American artist Yoko Kubrick, you have to know your Greek mythology: The quarrels and trysts of those gods and goddesses inform her work just as they’ve inspired sculptors since the Athenian master Phidias, who, in the fifth century B.C., carved anthropomorphic statues of Zeus, Athena and their cohort in fine detail, from their flared nostrils down to their sandaled feet. Kubrick, who works primarily in Tuscany, uses the same milky Italian marbles and handwork techniques as her mostly male predecessors, but to experience her abstract pieces is less to stare into the face of the divine than to encounter three-dimensional renderings of divinity’s ineffable essence.

headline: Another Texas Republican Congressman Will Not Seek Re-election
abstract: Representative Bill Flores announced his current term would be his last, joining a long list of Republicans who have said they will retire or seek other offices.
lead_paragraph: Representative Bill Flores of Texas said he would not seek re-election in 2020, joining a long list of Republicans retiring in a state that has become increasingly competitive.

headline: The Bahamas, Before and After Hurricane Dorian
abstract: Aerial images of flattened neighborhoods and a flooded airport give a first look at the large-scale damage there.
lead_paragraph: Aerial images of flattened neighborhoods and a flooded airport give a first look at the large-scale damage there.

headline: Winston Churchill’s Grandson Exits Politics and Chides Boris Johnson
abstract: Nicholas Soames, the grandson of the wartime leader Winston Churchill and a 45-year Tory veteran, has been booted from the Conservative Party for supporting a motion to prevent Britain from crashing out of the EU without a deal.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rising to speak before a half-empty House of Commons on Wednesday, Nicholas Soames, the grandson of Winston Churchill, choked up, fighting back tears.

headline: Pubic Hair Removal Does Not Raise Sexually Transmitted Infection Risk
abstract: Women who removed all pubic hair did not have higher rates of chlamydia or gonorrhea.
lead_paragraph: Women who remove their pubic hair do not increase their risk for sexually transmitted diseases, a new report suggests, despite a common belief and some recent research suggesting they do.

abstract: When the Inter Milan striker Romelu Lukaku was subjected to monkey chants during a match, even some of his own fans shrugged it off as business as usual.
lead_paragraph: To those present at Cagliari’s Stadio Sardegna on Sunday, the sounds were familiar.

headline: Jeffrey Epstein Case: Over 1,000 People Connected to Him in Address Book

lead_paragraph: A trove of sealed court records names hundreds of people who are connected to Jeffrey Epstein, and one unnamed man has already asked a judge not to release his name or the names of others accused in the documents of wrongdoing, arguing it could unfairly damage their reputations.

headline: The T List: What to See, Eat and Wear This Week

We hope you’ll join us for the ride. (Sign up here, if you haven’t already, and you can reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.)

headline: Big Tech Companies Meeting With U.S. Officials on 2020 Election Security

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Wednesday imposed sanctions on an elaborate shipping network that Iran uses to sell oil, and unveiled a $15 million reward to anyone with information that disrupts the scheme, stepping up its effort to exert pressure on the Iranian economy.

lead_paragraph: Should Uber be kneecapped for its long history of flouting the law, or can it possibly be reformed? Or am I a credulous dolt for even suggesting redemption for one of the sorriest companies ever to emerge from Silicon Valley’s tortured hothouse?

headline: Gregory Craig Acquitted on Charge of Lying to Justice Department
abstract: Jurors reached a verdict after only hours of deliberation. The trial of Mr. Craig, a former White House counsel, painted an unflattering portrait of Washington lobbying.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gregory B. Craig, one of Washington’s most prominent Democratic lawyers, was acquitted on Wednesday of a felony charge that he lied to federal authorities about work he did seven years ago for the Ukrainian government.

headline: When a Discarded Cat’s Whisker Becomes a Prized Possession
abstract: The artist Xylor Jane has spent more than a decade saving some of the hairs her pets leave behind.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, Emily Spivack, the author of “Worn Stories,” interviews creative types about their most prized possessions. The artist Xylor Jane combines color theory, science and math in her paintings; the resulting works are made up of elaborate grids and dots. Here, Jane, who is based in Greenfield, Mass., explains why she has been saving the discarded whiskers from her beloved cats for over a decade.

headline: Lagarde Vows to Put Climate Change on the E.C.B.’s Agenda
abstract: Lagarde calls climate change a “pressing global” challenge and promises the European Central Bank will focus on the risk when she arrives in November.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As the head of the International Monetary Fund, Christine Lagarde frequently warned of being “roasted, toasted, fried and grilled” if the world failed to act on climate change.

headline: Three North Carolina Judges Step In Where the Supreme Court Refuses
abstract: The Supreme Court’s conservatives said gerrymandering was not a matter for courts, leaving the job of protecting democratic self-rule to state judges.
lead_paragraph: Three state judges on a North Carolina trial court just did what a majority on the United States Supreme Court said was impossible only a few months ago — apply well-established legal standards to strike down some of the most egregious partisan gerrymanders in the country.

headline: Hurricane Dorian Makes Bahamians the Latest Climate-Crisis Victims
abstract: The country has a tiny carbon footprint but carries the burden of being ground zero for global warming.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Whoever thought Dorian might be a good name for a hurricane has some explaining to do. In the Bahamas, when we have to deal with difficulties, we try to make the saddest people among us laugh, knowing that they will return the favor in our hour of need.

headline: No, Netflix Is Not Abandoning Its Binge Format

lead_paragraph: There’s a chill in the air, and for a certain cozy-inclined television viewer, that means curling up with a cable-knit blanket to binge “The Great British Baking Show” on Netflix.

headline: Wells Fargo Is Reviewing Its Account-Closing Practices
abstract: The chief executive, C. Allen Parker, told Senator Elizabeth Warren that the bank had begun an “extensive review” of overdraft fees for such accounts in response to a New York Times article.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo has begun an “extensive review” of the way it closes customers’ accounts and the fees it charges some customers even after their accounts are supposedly closed, its chief executive, C. Allen Parker, said in a letter to Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts.

headline: How to Cook for Every Back-to-School Meal
abstract: Let Jenny Rosenstrach’s suggestions take the pressure off, whether you’re making breakfast, lunch, dinner, snacks (before and after practice) or that surprise fourth meal.
lead_paragraph: Anyone with children knows the particular brand of anxiety that can take hold as soon as you’re tasked with feeding them on a school night. No matter how long you’ve been cooking, you can walk in the door, open the refrigerator and not have a single idea about what to make. This was especially common for me when my daughters were little, and the list of recipes that pleased everybody and scored high on the fast-easy-healthy scale was absurdly slim. So I started a back-to-school ritual, writing a short list of winners on a Post-it note for the nights paralysis struck.

headline: Squirrels Relax When They Hear Birds Relaxing
abstract: Scientists show that squirrels have one ear tuned to the chatter of birds, and act on what they learn from eavesdropping.
lead_paragraph: It will come as no surprise to squirrel lovers — and haters, for that matter — that the twitchy, resourceful rodents are exquisitely attuned to the world around them.

headline: Nothing on Earth Can Replace Helium — and It’s in Peril
abstract: Liquid helium has helped build billion-dollar industries and generate multiple Nobel Prizes. Now our supply is running low.
lead_paragraph: Liquid helium is a quiet engine of American research and business. It is essential to a broad range of technologies, from cutting-edge quantum computing to M.R.I. scanners in hospitals. It has fostered the development of billion-dollar industries, fueled essential lifesaving medical tools, supported work leading to more than 5,000 patents and helped generate multiple Nobel Prizes. In short, it is crucial to innovation.

headline: Dawda Jawara, Founding Father of Gambia, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Jawara led Gambia to independence from the British, then presided over the country as it became one of the region’s longest-running democracies.
lead_paragraph: Dawda Jawara, a veterinarian-turned-politician who led Gambia to independence from the British and then presided over the country as it became one of Africa’s longest-running democracies, died on Aug. 27 at his home in Fajara, a coastal suburb of Banjul, the capital. He was 95.

headline: When Active-Shooter Drills Scare the Children They Hope to Protect

Sheehan High School in Wallingford, Conn., Mackenzie Bushey, a 15-year-old junior, came home upset that a teacher enforced a no-cellphones policy by confiscating students’ phones before class. She needed her cell, Mackenzie told her family last month, to notify police should a gunman attack her school.

headline: Fact-Checking Trump’s Claims About China’s ‘Worst Year’
abstract: China has experienced its “worst year” in 57 years, the president said Wednesday, a few years short of the 61 years he estimated last week and a couple of decades more than the 35 years he claimed last month.
lead_paragraph: First, the tariffs placed on Chinese imports have raised $27 billion, as of Aug. 28, and a number of recent studies have shown that the costs are borne by American companies and consumers, not by China. Analysts have estimated that the trade war would cost the average American family about $460 over a year.

headline: Estranged Husband Disposed of Body of Missing Mother of 5, Police Say
abstract: Jennifer Dulos’s blood was found in a car used by her husband, his arrest warrant says. She disappeared in a wealthy Connecticut suburb in May.
lead_paragraph: The estranged husband of a missing Connecticut woman was believed to have carried her body from her home in her own car hours after she was last seen alive, the police said in a warrant released on Wednesday.

headline: Trouble for the Pentagon: The Troops Keep Packing On the Pounds
abstract: Even though it has gone as far as eliminating fried food and sugary drinks from ships, a new study found that 22 percent of sailors now qualify as obese. The other services have seen climbing rates too.
lead_paragraph: The United States Navy has eliminated fried food and sugary drinks on its ships. It is keeping base gyms and fitness centers open all night. But its sailors keep getting fatter: A new Defense Department study found that 22 percent of them — roughly one in every five — now qualify as obese.

headline: Sally Floyd, Who Helped Things Run Smoothly Online, Dies at 69
abstract: In the early 1990s, Dr. Floyd was one of the inventors of Random Early Detection, which continues to play a vital role in the stability of the internet.
lead_paragraph: Sally Floyd, a computer scientist whose work in the early 1990s on controlling congestion on the internet continues to play a vital role in its stability, died on Aug. 25 at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 69.

headline: Brexit’s ‘Doomsday Politics’ Mean Voters May Be Last Chance to Resolve Crisis
abstract: A looming election seems to offer the last political mechanism left to end the brawl over Brexit. An inconclusive result could reinforce fears that the problem defies a democratic solution.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He jabbed his finger in the air and shook his head theatrically. He dared the opposition to back his call for an election and sneered that the Labour Party’s leader was a “chlorinated chicken.”

headline: 4 Jails in 5 Boroughs: The $8.7 Billion Puzzle Over How to Close Rikers
abstract: The City Council will weigh in on Thursday on a plan to move inmates into four new jails in New York City neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: The governor, the mayor and criminal justice advocates all agree that the Rikers Island jail complex, one of the country’s largest urban prisons, is irretrievably broken, with a long history of violence and abuse against a largely minority inmate population.

headline: Democrats Examining Impeachment Target Trump’s Pardon Offers to Immigration Officials
abstract: Democrats appear to be expanding the scope of their impeachment inquiry beyond Russian election interference and possible obstruction of justice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Judiciary Committee ordered homeland security officials on Wednesday to hand over records related to reported offers by President Trump to pardon aides willing to break the law to carry out his immigration policies.

headline: The Back-to-School Quiz
abstract: Try to remember the stuff you’ve already blocked out.
lead_paragraph: Try to remember the stuff you’ve already blocked out.

headline: That Assault Weapon Ban? It Really Did Work
abstract: Since the ban was lifted in 2004, gun massacres involving military-style weapons are way up.
lead_paragraph: Recent mass shootings have revived demands for meaningful gun control. But many opponents of a renewed federal ban on assault weapons, led by the National Rifle Association, say the earlier ban, from 1994 to 2004, made no difference. Our new research shows otherwise.

headline: Trump Insists He Was Right About Hurricane Dorian Heading for Alabama
abstract: Asked about a marking on the map that appeared to have been drawn to extend the storm’s possible path into Alabama, President Trump said he did not know how it got there.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump displayed a large map of Hurricane Dorian’s path in the Oval Office on Wednesday, it was hard to miss a black line that appeared to have been drawn to extend the storm’s possible path into the state of Alabama.

headline: This Is How a War With China Could Begin
abstract: First, the lights in Taiwan go out.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — If the United States gets embroiled in a war with China, it may begin with the lights going out here in Taipei.

headline: How to Get TB Patients to Take Their Pills? Persistent Texting and a ‘Winners Circle’
abstract: The drug regimens can be grueling, and patients often quit taking their medications. But turning it into a cellphone competition helps.
lead_paragraph: The hardest part of curing tuberculosis, doctors say, is getting patients to take all their pills every day for at least six months. Even the easiest regimens of four antibiotics can cause nausea, fevers, rashes and stomach pain.

headline: The Secret to Adam Ottavino’s Calm: A Little Black Notebook
abstract: The star Yankees reliever once couldn’t tame the thoughts and doubts running through his mind on the mound. Now, he meticulously documents them every day to stay mentally sharp.
lead_paragraph: Before every game, one of the linchpins of the Yankees’ talented bullpen, Adam Ottavino, finds a spot in the clubhouse to sit and write.

headline: 82-Year-Old Slipped by Doormen to Steal $400,000 in Jewelry, Police Say
abstract: He pretended to live in the ritzy buildings. His unassuming demeanor, simple clothes and large glasses supposedly helped.
lead_paragraph: The old man still had it in him.

headline: Spared by Dorian, Florida’s Bahamians Give Back to Islands
abstract: Bahamians helped build South Florida in the 1800s. Now the descendants of those early settlers are engaged in a frantic effort to help storm victims in the country many still cherish as home.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The home that Charles Bethel’s great-grandmother built in Miami’s Coconut Grove neighborhood in 1890 still stands, with a historical marker commemorating it as one of the first dwellings in the area owned by a settler from the Bahamas.

headline: The Battle Over the Files of a Gerrymandering Mastermind
abstract: The hard drives of Thomas B. Hofeller, a G.O.P. strategist who died last year, have upended lawsuits over the 2020 census and legislative maps. Lawyers argue the data is confidential.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of a decisive court ruling on Tuesday striking down North Carolina’s state legislative maps was evidence culled from the computer backups of the man who drew them: Thomas B. Hofeller, the Republican strategist and master of gerrymandering, who died last year.

headline: Representative Jim Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin, Republican Mainstay, Is Set to Retire
abstract: The announcement adds to what appears to be a growing exodus of House Republicans that promises to change the character of the chamber, regardless of whether the party wins back control.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Jim Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin, a Republican mainstay who found his way to the center of many of Washington’s most divisive political debates over the past four decades, said on Wednesday that he would not run for re-election next year.

headline: Pentagon Lists Projects That Will Be Delayed to Fund Border Wall
abstract: Nearly every facet of military life — from Oklahoma to Puerto Rico to Germany — will be affected by the transfer of $3.6 billion from 127 projects.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon plans to divert funds from military construction projects in nearly half the 50 states, three territories and 19 countries to the southwestern border wall as part of President Trump’s efforts to bypass Congress and redirect spending to his signature campaign promise.

headline: Jeffrey Katzenberg’s Streaming Platform Loses a Top Executive
abstract: Janice Min, the former editor of The Hollywood Reporter and Us Weekly, has left Quibi months ahead of its planned launch.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Seven months ahead of its planned launch, Quibi, the short-form video platform from the film executive Jeffrey Katzenberg, experienced some backstage drama on Wednesday with the departure of one of its top executives, Janice Min.

headline: Trump Heads Into 2020 With No Clear Policy Agenda. But It May Not Matter.
abstract: Mr. Trump’s primary focus, according to one Republican pollster, is to connect his actions as president to positive economic news “in such a way that people understand and see how it’s personally translating in their lives.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump heads into the closing months of the year before he faces re-election without a clear policy agenda and with an uphill path to achieving any major new accomplishments before he faces voters.

headline: Stop Lying About Gun Control
abstract: Beto O’Rourke is rare among politicians for speaking honestly of wanting aggressive limits.
lead_paragraph: Beto O’Rourke has easily emerged as my favorite presidential candidate on the issue of gun control.

headline: Judge Rules Terrorism Watchlist Violates Constitutional Rights
abstract: A ruling on Wednesday called into question the constitutionality of a major tool the F.B.I. and the Department of Homeland Security use for screening potential terrorism suspects.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that a federal government database that compiles people deemed to be “known or suspected terrorists” violates the rights of American citizens who are on the watchlist, calling into question the constitutionality of a major tool the F.B.I. and the Department of Homeland Security use for screening potential terrorism suspects.

headline: San Francisco Declares the N.R.A. a ‘Domestic Terrorist Organization’
abstract: The city’s lawmakers unanimously passed the resolution in response to recent mass shootings. The National Rifle Association called it a worthless “sound-bite remedy.”
lead_paragraph: Unsettled by recent mass shootings across the nation, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a resolution this week declaring the National Rifle Association a domestic terrorist organization.

headline: More Than, Less Than
