headline: His Family Had Money. Mine Didn’t.
abstract: Could our doomed relationship help explain Brexit?
lead_paragraph: Toffee Dating is an app recently started in the U.K., aimed exclusively at those who went to private schools, because, according to the founders, “we know people from similar backgrounds are likely to stick together.”

headline: American Airlines Mechanic Arrested on Sabotage Charge After Grounding Flight
abstract: The authorities said the employee had disabled navigation equipment because he was upset about an impasse over a union contract.
lead_paragraph: An American Airlines mechanic based at Miami International Airport was arrested on Thursday on a charge that he sabotaged the navigation equipment of a flight carrying 150 people, forcing it to be grounded just before takeoff, the authorities said.

headline: Carol Lynley, Star of ‘Blue Denim’ and ‘The Poseidon Adventure,’ Dies at 77
abstract: An actress whose career mirrored America’s shift from the Eisenhower era to the sexually frank 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Carol Lynley, a former child model who had an intense film acting career mirroring the country’s transformation from the modest Eisenhower era into the sexually frank 1960s, died on Tuesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 77.

headline: Greta Thunberg’s Climate Panic Has Our Attention. Now What?
abstract: The Fridays for Future movement is necessary, but not sufficient, to bring about necessary change.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — The most telling words about a country are often those that are impossible to translate. In the case of Germany, one such word is “Zweckpessimismus.” It means, roughly, pessimism on purpose — the attitude of expecting the worst in order to be able to feel relief when the worst, oh lucky us, does not occur.

headline: On Politics: Markets Soar on News of China Talks
abstract: Financial markets have swayed with each turn of President Trump’s trade war.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

headline: Robert Mugabe, Strongman Who Cried, ‘Zimbabwe Is Mine,’ Dies at 95
abstract: Until 2017, he was the only leader his country had known since independence in 1980. He presided over its long decline.

headline: Should Kissing Be Allowed in Professional Settings?
abstract: An unwanted kiss onstage at a charity event in Sydney has ignited a wider conversation about whether kissing of any kind is acceptable in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: The Australia Letter is a weekly newsletter from our Australia bureau. Sign up to get it by email. This week’s issue is written by Isabella Kwai, a reporter based in Sydney.

headline: Word + Quiz: quaver
abstract: This word has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Trump’s Dorian Tweets Continue to Baffle Late-Night Hosts
abstract: “The National Weather Service has to monitor the president’s tweets as closely as they monitor actual hurricanes,” Seth Meyers joked Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Looking Over the Edge
abstract: What is this image saying? Can you relate to it personally?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or our world today? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: She Sued the State Over Harassment. Then the Gaslighting Began, She Said.
abstract: New York paid Alexis Marquez’s salary. But when she sued over harassment, the state offered an unexpected defense: She was never a state employee.
lead_paragraph: For one month in 2017, Alexis Marquez went to work every day at a courthouse in Lower Manhattan, where she served as the principal court attorney for a New York State judge. Her salary was paid by New York State. Her tax forms listed the state as her employer.

headline: White Supremacists Targeted Her. Now She’s Fighting Hate Crime.
abstract: The new head of a city office to fight bias crimes, who keeps kosher, once found pork and shellfish stuffed into her mailbox.
lead_paragraph: The words “Heil Hitler" and “gas chamber” were scrawled on walls at the Silver Gull in Queens, one of the city’s last beach clubs. A rabbi walking through a park in Brooklyn was punched in the face and bashed with a rock. A gay pride flag outside a Harlem bar was set on fire.

headline: Matteo Berrettini: Late Bloomer and U.S. Open Semifinalist
abstract: In his teens, Matteo Berrettini was often kept off the court by his coach so he could develop a life outside tennis.
lead_paragraph: Matteo Berrettini rolled his eyes and shook his head as he recalled a humbling moment in his mid-teens. He was at an Italian tennis training facility going through a battery of athletic tests — comparing him with other young players in running, jumping, reaction time and stamina.

headline: In Tennis, Hugging at the Net Is the New Handshake
abstract: The congratulatory (or consoling) moment after a match has, for many players, evolved into an elaborate show of affection.
lead_paragraph: Not that long ago, Naomi Osaka was struggling to adapt to the shifting tradition in tennis of using hugs instead handshakes as the gesture of grace at the end of a match.

headline: How One Bahamian Town, Nearly Destroyed, Is Coping After Dorian
abstract: The small community of Treasure Cay, left without power, water or communication, is wrestling with the vast destruction wrought by the hurricane.
lead_paragraph: TREASURE CAY, Bahamas — Since Hurricane Dorian plowed through Stafford Symonette’s house, and with it much of his community of Treasure Cay, he has stopped by from time to time to visit the ruins of his home.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘New York City’s First Skateboarding Superstar’
abstract: In this lesson, students will discover the story of Tyshawn Jones, a skateboarder on the verge of stardom.
lead_paragraph: Please note: Each current events “Lesson of the Day” (renamed from our old “Article of the Day” feature) aims to be usable in a single class period.

headline: Fitch Downgrades Hong Kong Over China’s Stronger Hand
abstract: The ratings firm cited Beijing’s growing influence over the city, suggesting that the barriers separating their legal and financial systems were blurring.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong’s economy, already damaged by weeks of protests, was dealt a further blow on Friday when Fitch Ratings downgraded its credit rating on the territory, citing China’s growing influence in the territory’s affairs.

headline: In Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe’s Star Had Already Faded: ‘We Have Moved On Without Him’
abstract: As Zimbabweans learned of the death of their former leader, who held the country in his grip for decades after its independence, the reaction was muted.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — For years, the eventual death of Robert Mugabe, the leader who held Zimbabwe in his grip for decades after its independence in 1980, had obsessed his countrymen.

headline: Serena Williams Reaches for Margaret Court at the Top
abstract: On Saturday, Serena Williams can tie Margaret Court for the most Grand Slam titles. A look at the women at the top of the list.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Serena Williams can tie Margaret Court for the most Grand Slam titles. A look at the women at the top of the list.

headline: Who Owns the American West? And Who Should Profit From It?
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Which Came First, Trump or TV?
abstract: Gary Shteyngart reviews James Poniewozik’s “Audience of One,” which traces the simultaneous histories of two 20th-century creations.
lead_paragraph: AUDIENCE OF ONEDonald Trump, Television, and the Fracturing of AmericaBy James Poniewozik

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Crudo’ and ‘How Long ’til Black Future Month?’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: CRUDO, by Olivia Laing. (Norton, $14.95.) Kathy, the central character of this slim, gutsy debut novel, is Laing herself, but also Kathy Acker, the iconoclastic writer who died in 1997. Dropping in quotes from Acker and others as she tells the story of a London-based woman’s anxious adjustment to marriage and to momentous Trump- and Brexit-era political change, Laing writes with “bristling intelligence,” our reviewer, Katie Kitamura, said.

headline: See How the Shadows of New York Create a Second City
abstract: In photographs taken over 80 years, a look at the shifting architecture that emerges with the sun and disappears by nightfall.
lead_paragraph: In photographs taken over 80 years, a look at the shifting architecture that emerges with the sun and disappears by nightfall.

headline: The Role of Nurses When Patients Decide to End Their Lives
abstract: Some hospitals and hospices have policies that forbid nurses to be part of the process or even to discuss end-of-life options.
lead_paragraph: When Ben Wald, 75, was dying of cancer in 2012, he wanted to use Oregon’s Death with Dignity Act to receive a prescription for a lethal medication that would end his life. His hospice nurse, Linda, was part of the discussion and provided both information and support, said his wife, Pam Wald, of Kings Valley, Ore.

headline: How Do You Feel About Active-Shooter Drills in Schools?
abstract: Nearly every American public school now conducts lockdown drills. Do they make you feel more safe?
lead_paragraph: Do you have regular active-shooter drills at your school? If so, what happens during these drills? What are you expected to do? How do you feel about having to participate?

headline: Taking Out a Student Loan Is Better Than Dropping Out
abstract: New research shows that students who borrowed more defaulted less, probably because the additional credits they were able to complete led to more stable careers.
lead_paragraph: Student debt is spiraling, and young people are defaulting on their loans. You might think that students would be better off scraping by with no loans at all.

headline: The Polaris RZR, an Off-Road Thrill That Can Go Up in Flames
abstract: The Polaris RZR, a vehicle for recreational use, has been linked to scores of fires and four deaths. But its maker insists it is safe.
lead_paragraph: For almost two years, James Bingham’s off-road vehicle had provided endless fun on camping and hunting trips in Idaho. The vehicle, a four-seat Polaris RZR, could zip across the sand hills at up to 80 miles an hour.

headline: What Draws Atheists, Jews and Catholics to a Presbyterian Church
abstract: At Rutgers Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, social justice and environmental issues unite the congregation. There’s Bible stuff, too.
lead_paragraph: Observant Presbyterians are always part of gatherings at Rutgers Presbyterian Church. But much of the time, so are Roman Catholics and Jews, as well as a smattering of people who consider themselves vaguely spiritual. Valerie Oltarsh-McCarthy, who sat among the congregation listening to a Sunday sermon on the perils of genetically modified vegetables, is, in fact, an atheist.

headline: Russia’s Playbook for Disrupting Democracy
abstract: The Kremlin had a blueprint for upending American politics with tactics honed in Estonia nearly a decade earlier.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s brazen interference in the 2016 American presidential election shouldn’t have been a total shock. President Vladimir Putin’s government had done it before, almost a decade earlier in tiny Estonia, where Russian operatives provoked political violence and mounted malicious cyberattacks.

headline: The Rapid Rise of Pop Smoke, Brooklyn Rap’s Homecoming King
abstract: “Welcome to the Party” became one of hip-hop’s songs of the summer, but this 20-year-old with a throwback New York vibe is just getting started.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Pop Smoke was riding around downtown Manhattan looking to get a birthday outfit for a friend who was turning 18, so he and his crew headed to Patron of the New, where garments by Dior and Amiri flow freely.

headline: Tim Ferriss, the Man Who Put His Money Behind Psychedelic Medicine
abstract: The author of “The 4-Hour Workweek” is behind a surge in funding for clinical research into psychedelic drugs.
lead_paragraph: The announcement on Wednesday that Johns Hopkins Medicine was starting a new center to study psychedelic drugs for mental disorders was the latest chapter in a decades-long push by health nonprofits and wealthy donors to shake up psychiatry from the outside, bypassing the usual channels.

headline: The Heir to a Tofu Dynasty Finally Learns to Make Tofu
abstract: After leaving home to become an artist, the heir to a tofu factory returns to Chinatown to revive the family business. First problem: Find a recipe for tofu.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Paul Eng decided to confront a reality he had been facing most of his life: He was the heir to a tofu tradition who had no idea how to make tofu.

headline: Steven Gubser, a Bright Star in the Physics Universe, Dies at 47
abstract: He did groundbreaking work toward finding a “theory of everything.” He died in an Alpine rock-climbing accident.
lead_paragraph: Steven Gubser, a Princeton theoretical physicist who did groundbreaking work in trying to unite the two great fields of physics — quantum mechanics and general relativity — as part of a broad effort in the scientific community to devise “a theory of everything,” died on Aug. 3 in a rock-climbing accident in the French Alps. He was 47.

headline: ‘We’re at War’: A Covert Social Media Campaign Boosts Military Rulers
abstract: After protesters were killed in Sudan, an obscure Egyptian company ramped up a covert influence operation that spanned the Middle East and North Africa.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Days after Sudanese soldiers massacred pro-democracy demonstrators in Khartoum in June, an obscure digital marketing company in Cairo began deploying keyboard warriors to a second front: a covert operation to praise Sudan’s military on social media.

headline: The Sly Superpower of ‘Hustlers’
abstract: With casting that matched Jennifer Lopez and Constance Wu with Cardi B and Lizzo, the movie is being rushed to theaters. In the guise of a stripper tale, it still takes time to focus on women’s lives.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lopez apologized for how she smelled. That light waft of cigarette smoke, she said, gesturing with a faux-tattooed arm. Maybe it was her, maybe it was embedded in the white couches and plush carpeting, here on the 29th floor of a midtown Manhattan high-rise. Either way, the mood was set.

headline: Overlooked No More: Alice Guy Blaché, the World’s First Female Filmmaker
abstract: Even before women had the right to vote, Blaché, in her actions and in her films, expressed female drives, desires and self-determination.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Hip-Hop Festivals Are Locking Into Place
abstract: Rock festivals have historically saved little space for rap, but a crop of events foregrounding pop’s most powerful genre is booked for the fall.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few decades, festival culture has both exploded and grown stale. Beginning in the spring and running through summer into fall, there are dozens of gatherings across the country that at one point felt unique, but have largely congealed into one aesthetic formulation repeated ad nauseam.

headline: Coffee With the Man Who Used to Be My Wife
abstract: We were two kids once, a boy and a girl, making plans for the rest of our lives. Now we were two men in middle age, sharing memories.
lead_paragraph: He walked through the coffee shop door and scanned the crowd. A familiar smile bloomed as he recognized me, despite how my appearance had changed over the years. I’m bald and bearded now, and heavier. I wear an extra decade on my face, and I’m more careful about how I dress. I was almost late as I settled on the right shirt.

headline: The Dying Art of the Manager Meltdown
abstract: While umpires still get an earful from M.L.B. managers, technology has tempered the days of genuine contempt.
lead_paragraph: Yankees Manager Aaron Boone’s theatrical run-ins with umpires this summer might have surprised more than a few observers, given his otherwise mild-mannered demeanor. Still, the second-year manager’s mastery of the jabbing index finger, the in-your-face stance and a willingness to get ejected has earned roars of approval from  Yankee Stadium crowds.

headline: Behind the Curtain at the Paris Opera
abstract: Built nearly 150 years ago, the over-the-top Palais Garnier has become part of the identity of Paris.
lead_paragraph: The most breathtaking subway exit in the world may be the one at Place de l’Opéra in Paris. Its final steps lead to a postcard-ready view of the sensational Palais Garnier, the love-it-or-hate-it theater with a Baroque, Renaissance and all-around garish pastiche that overwhelms and enchants at every turn.

headline: California Allows Public to Refuse to Help Law Enforcement
abstract: A rarely invoked state law from 1872, removed last week, had made it a misdemeanor to turn down law enforcement officials asking for help with an arrest. Here’s a closer look at the history.
lead_paragraph: After 147 years, California residents are now free to turn down law enforcement officials who ask for help with an arrest.

headline: How High Tech Is Transforming One of the Oldest Jobs: Farming
abstract: From equipment automation to data collection and analysis, the digital evolution of agriculture is already a fact of life on farms across the United States.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of our ongoing Fast Forward series, which examines technological, economic, social and cultural shifts that happen as businesses evolve.

headline: What Thumbelina Meant to a Young Girl
abstract: The artist Celeste Mountjoy, also known as filthyratbag, retells the story of the very tiny lady, and how sympathies can shift as one grows older.
lead_paragraph: Celeste Mountjoy is also known as filthyratbag, which is also the name of her popular Instagram account where she shares her drawings and comics.

headline: The Second City Claims First in Architecture
abstract: Chicago’s leading provider of architecture tours has an expanded center, giving it a new visibility and a logical location, on the river.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny summer day in Chicago, visitors to the Chicago Architecture Center had only to cross busy Wacker Drive to board the tour boat that would take them past the architectural icons that line the Chicago River. On board, docents pointed out landmarks such as the white terra cotta Wrigley Building completed in 1924 and the corncob-shaped Marina City towers from 1967 designed by Bertrand Goldberg.

headline: How Ivy Mix, Cocktail Expert, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Yes, that’s her real name. On her day off, the award-winning bartender avoids politics but embraces a drink (or two).
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Vermont, Ivy Mix would rise at dawn to spend her Sundays riding horses. But when she became a bartender in New York City, Sundays were all about sleeping in.

headline: Want to Feel Like a Russian Ballerina? Start With the Tutu
abstract: A  trove of lush Soviet-era tutus can be found hidden in the back room of a small school near Chicago.
lead_paragraph: “We have some of the best costumes. Come, look,” Tatyana Mazur says as she guides me to the back closet of the small dance studio she runs with her husband, Roman Mazur, in the corner of an unassuming strip mall in Buffalo Grove, Ill.

headline: Is the N.Y.P.D. at War With Itself?
abstract: The police commissioner says the force has tried to rebuild trust since Eric Garner died after a chokehold. The patrolmen’s union would rather pick a fight.
lead_paragraph: On Labor Day, a 48-year-old retired sergeant with the New York Police Department was found dead in a car on Staten Island, apparently having shot himself. The department has been shaken by a rash of suicides; this case would mark the 10th in 2019 and the eighth since June, already double the number of suicides the department experiences on average each year.

headline: The City Poised to Become Europe’s Next Affordable Creative Haven
abstract: In the Albanian capital of Tirana, the country’s strange history and bright future collide.
lead_paragraph: Over the past five years, Albania has been discovered by travelers as that rare thing: a largely unexplored corner of Europe (one with some 265 miles of coastline). The small Balkan country sits just across the Adriatic and Ionian seas from Italy’s heel and a mere 45-minute ferry ride away from the Greek island of Corfu. It’s recently gotten its first high-end waterside resorts, and as the beach town of Sarande and the seaside city of Vlore have become more comfortable, so too has Tirana — the country’s capital, about 22 miles inland with a population of over half a million — grown more cosmopolitan, with new restaurants, shops and galleries joining the almost surrealist pastiche of testaments to the city’s past. For a good example of the way eras collide in Tirana, just visit Skanderbeg Square, recently renovated with new fountains and rosy granite paving, and home to an 18th-century mosque and minaret, a domed Albanian Orthodox church opened in 2012, a set of government buildings that echo the fascist architecture of Mussolini’s Italy and a Brutalist monolith that houses the National Historical Museum.

headline: So Your House Wants to Be a Star
abstract: The pros and cons of having a TV or movie crew take over your home.
lead_paragraph: For years, fliers from movie and television location scouts turned up in Alan Bennett’s mailbox. And for years, Mr. Bennett and his wife, Melanie Oser, reflexively tossed them. The couple had no interest in serving up their Dutch Colonial as a setting for a TV series or feature film.

headline: Andrew Yang’s Quest to ‘Make America Think Harder’
abstract: The entrepreneur turned presidential candidate is explaining automation to the masses. And as voters realize he is serious and substantive, he is gaining a passionate following.
lead_paragraph: PLAISTOW, N.H. — Meet Andrew Yang supporters and they often have a confession to make: When they first heard about Mr. Yang, they thought his plan to give every American adult $1,000 a month was a little crazy. But then, they will inevitably tell you, they heard him explain it, and it all started making sense.

headline: Horsing Around the Hamptons
abstract: Last week’s events included the Hampton Classic Grand Prix and a luncheon for the Museum at FIT.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s events included the Hampton Classic Grand Prix and a luncheon for the Museum at FIT.

headline: Escaping Berlin for the Watery Wonders of the German Outdoors
abstract: A kayak trip in the Spreewald — a wooded moorland that has been designated a Unesco-protected biosphere reserve — is an easy train trip from the city.
lead_paragraph: From its source in southeastern Germany, near the Czech border, the Spree River flows steadily to the northwest, until it joins the Havel River in the Berlin borough of Spandau. Before it reaches the Havel, the Spree slices Berlin in two: a jagged cut from east to west.

headline: Fall Movies 2019: Here’s What’s Coming Soon to Theaters
abstract: We’ve picked out the films you need to know about, from the most anticipated (“The Irishman,” “Star Wars”) to the most curious (“Cats,” paws down).
lead_paragraph: Here is a highly select list of noteworthy films due out this season. Release dates are subject to change and reflect the latest information as of deadline.

headline: From the Hamptons to Fashion Week
abstract: Last week’s events included the Hampton Classic Grand Prix and a luncheon for the Museum at FIT.
lead_paragraph: Capping off another Hamptons season, the Hampton Classic Grand Prix took place Sept. 1 in Bridgehampton, N.Y. And in a prelude to New York Fashion Week, the Couture Council of the Museum at FIT honored Christian Louboutin at its awards luncheon on Sept. 4 at Lincoln Center.

headline: Hurricane Dorian Swamps North Carolina’s Outer Banks
abstract: The Category 1 storm made landfall on the Outer Banks, where some people climbed into the attics of their homes to avoid surging floodwaters.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian, the storm that devastated the Bahamas and put much of the southeastern United States on edge, battered the coast of North Carolina with heavy rain, wind and flooding on Friday, after making landfall on the Outer Banks.

headline: A Better Rat Trap
abstract: The latest weapon in a centuries-long battle involves a bucket and vinegar and drowning.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Hiring Slowed in August, but Wage Gains Accelerated
abstract: The figures show that the economy continues to add jobs but at a more modest pace as the trade war intensifies and global growth slows.
lead_paragraph: The great American jobs machine is flagging, showing signs of its age and damage from an intensifying trade war with China and a slowing global economy.

headline: North Carolina, Robert Mugabe, Serena Williams: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Secret Push to Strike Iran
abstract: Israel and the U.S. have narrowly avoided war with Iran over its nuclear program. Will President Trump bring the crisis to a head?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Brought Together by Fate, and Three Finicky Cats
abstract: Maria Sartzis and Oscar Pellicier struck up a conversation in the pet aisle of a Target store in the Bronx, and haven’t stopped talking since.
lead_paragraph: In the six months that Maria Sartzis and Oscar Pellicier have known each other, their relationship can be characterized as more no-frills than fussy.  The two got to know each other under the glaring fluorescent lights of a Target store, and they chose a simple Spanish takeout restaurant for their first date.

headline: Dare We Dream of the End of the G.O.P.?
abstract: In a new book, the pollster Stanley Greenberg predicts a blue tidal wave in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of his new book, “R.I.P. G.O.P.,” the renowned Democratic pollster Stanley Greenberg makes a thrilling prediction, delivered with the certainty of prophecy. “The year 2020 will produce a second blue wave on at least the scale of the first in 2018 and finally will crash and shatter the Republican Party that was consumed by the ill-begotten battle to stop the New America from governing,” he writes.

headline: Why I Quit the Writers’ Room
abstract: The worst thing you can do to citizens of a democracy is silence them.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, I had just finished with the “Snowfall” writers’ room for the season when I took a similar job on a different show at a different network. I’d been in the new room for a few weeks when I got the call from Human Resources. A pleasant-sounding young man said, “Mr. Mosley, it has been reported that you used the N-word in the writers’ room.”

headline: The Saudi Crown Prince’s Digital Iron Fist
abstract: Mohammed bin Salman says he wants to bring his country into the 21st century. What does that mean for Saudis’ privacy?
lead_paragraph: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia makes no secret of his desire to transform his country. Since he began consolidating power in 2015, he has marketed himself to domestic and international audiences as a force of modernity, touting an agenda of cultural liberalization and economic reform. In 2016, he outlined his would-be revolution with the release of “Saudi Vision 2030,” an ambitious plan to establish Saudi Arabia as a “global investment powerhouse” and “a gateway to the world.”

headline: ‘I Am Always Asked if I Am Afraid’: Activist Lawyer Takes On Putin’s Russia
abstract: Amid attacks on her husband and herself, Lyubov Sobol has become the face of a revived Russian protest movement.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — After nearly losing her husband to an attack with lethal poison and surviving repeated clashes with burly Russian police officers, Lyubov Sobol looked on the bright side last week when she was targeted yet again in a long campaign of intimidation.

headline: China Injects $126 Billion Into Its Slowing Economy
abstract: The move comes as Beijing fights a costly trade war with the United States while looking for ways to keep its growth going.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s central bank moved on Friday to give the country’s slowing economy a jolt, saying it would essentially inject $126 billion into the financial system as Beijing fights an escalating trade war with the United States and contends with a dangerous addiction to debt at home.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Why WeWork’s I.P.O. Struggles Could Hurt
abstract: The co-working company had been counting on public-market investors to finance its global expansion. Any shrinking or delay of its public offering would be a body blow.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday. Howard Schultz, the former Starbucks C.E.O., called off his presidential bid. And don’t forget: I’m going to be in conversation with Blackstone’s Stephen Schwarzman about his new book, “What It Takes: Lessons in the Pursuit of Excellence,” at a DealBook TimesTalk in New York on Sept. 16. Get your tickets here. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: In Australia, Television ‘Content’ Designed for Your Phone
abstract: A new show from Australia’s national broadcaster is shot on smartphones and should be watched on one, too.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — When Que Minh Luu pitched a new comedy to her boss at Australia’s national broadcaster, the ABC, she asked a seemingly contradictory question: “Can I make a TV show that you can’t show on TV?”

headline: Howard Schultz, Former Starbucks Chief, Won’t Run for President in 2020
abstract: Mr. Schultz said he had concluded that an independent bid would pose too great a risk of helping President Trump win a second term.
lead_paragraph: Howard Schultz, the former chief executive of Starbucks who took steps earlier this year to prepare to run for president as an independent, announced Friday that he was abandoning those plans.

headline: Bianca Andreescu’s 2019: From No. 152 to U.S. Open Champion
abstract: Ranked out of the top 200 last summer, Andreescu capped her stunning ascent with a Grand Slam title on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: After Bianca Andreescu won her United States Open semifinal on Thursday night, Pam Shriver of ESPN told her in a postmatch interview that a year ago, “I don’t think I’d heard of you.”

headline: Architecture Award Honors Five Women
abstract: Dana Cuff, Sharon Johnston, Toshiko Mori, Claire Weisz and Mabel O. Wilson were chosen in categories ranging from activism to education.
lead_paragraph: The magazine Architectural Record is honoring five winners for outstanding achievement in the field in this year’s Women in Architecture Awards, which were announced  on Friday. The winners are: Toshiko Mori, Sharon Johnston, Claire Weisz, Mabel O. Wilson and Dana Cuff.

headline: The N.F.L. Season Has Begun. The Off-Field Games Started Weeks Ago.
abstract: A league with no shortage of messy controversies over money, safety and player’s rights.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The never-ending reality show known as the N.F.L. began its 100th season on Thursday when the Packers beat the Bears, 10-3, in the latest edition of one of the league’s oldest rivalries. Banners were raised, names like Halas and Lombardi were celebrated and an N.F.L. museum in Grant Park showed off a version of every Super Bowl ring.

headline: Trump Aides’ Poll Finds Gun Control Politically Problematic for the President
abstract: A poll shows gun measures would not help the president with his base, though he reassured Senator Joe Manchin III, a Democrat, that he was still considering them.
lead_paragraph: President Trump assured Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, on Thursday that he was still considering legislation that could include background checks for gun buyers. But White House aides said they had polling data showing that gun control was politically problematic for the president, according to two people briefed on the meeting.

headline: An Economist Ahead of His Time
abstract: Honoring Martin Weitzman.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: New Google and Facebook Inquiries Show Big Tech Scrutiny Is Rare Bipartisan Act
abstract: Democrats and Republicans at both the federal and state levels are uniting to investigate the power of Big Tech and, potentially, to rein in the dominant companies.
lead_paragraph: There is a major force uniting America’s fiercely partisan politicians: big technology companies. Democrats and Republicans at the federal and state levels are coming together to scrutinize the power of the Silicon Valley giants and, potentially, to rein them in.

headline: The Week in Tech: YouTube Fined $170 Million Over Child Privacy Violations
abstract: A settlement is about 1.7 percent of the parent company Alphabet’s profit in its most recent quarter.
lead_paragraph: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: After the Hurricane, Dealing With Insurance Claims
abstract: Homeowners shouldn’t expect the process to be easy. Insurers, one consumer advocate said, are increasingly shifting more risk to customers.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Dorian churned north this week, residents along the Atlantic coast were preparing to assess the possible damage to their homes, and to determine what their insurance policies will cover.

headline: Do D.I.Y. Cleaners Really Work?
abstract: Make-your-own cleaning products have elbowed their way onto Pinterest boards and entered the realm of self care.
lead_paragraph: In an age when practically anything can claim a spot on social media, the lowly kitchen spray is having its day — reimagined as a curated, crafty and oh-so-pretty countertop accessory.

headline: What to Know About the Ghost Ship Fire Verdict
abstract: Friday: A milestone, but not much closure for families of victims. Also: President Trump targets California’s pollution rules, and Billie Eilish.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Bette Midler’s Fifth Avenue Penthouse Goes on the Market for $50 Million
abstract: Ms. Midler’s “country house” in the city, a triplex at 1125 Fifth Avenue, comes with direct views of the Central Park reservoir and a lush rooftop garden.
lead_paragraph: Bette Midler is selling her longtime family home on the Upper East Side, an airy triplex with lush landscaped gardens, complete with composter and shed, and sweeping vistas of the Central Park reservoir and Midtown skyline.

headline: Francisco Toledo, Celebrated Mexican Artist and Arts Philanthropist, Dies at 79
abstract: He drew on his indigenous Zapotec heritage in his art and used his prestige to preserve the culture of his native Oaxaca.
lead_paragraph: Francisco Toledo, the celebrated Mexican artist and cultural philanthropist who drew on his indigenous pre-Columbian heritage to create striking works suffused with shamanistic animal imagery, died on Thursday. He was 79.

headline: Jeffrey Wright on ‘The Goldfinch,’ ‘Westworld’ and James Bond
abstract: While fans clamor to learn more about the next installments of the HBO series and spy film, this actor tries to just ride the wave.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, as word of a movie adaptation of Donna Tartt’s “The Goldfinch” started circulating, so did lists of dream casts. Names of elder statesmen like Michael Gambon, Jim Broadbent and even Jeff Bridges were bandied about to play one of the tale’s most endearing characters: James “Hobie” Hobart, a Greenwich Village antiques dealer described as a gentle giant with the heavy, haggard bearing and unhealthy pallor of an Irish poet or maybe a pugilist.

headline: Pence’s Stay at Trump Resort in Ireland and Trump’s G7 Plans Draw Democrats’ Scrutiny
abstract: The Democrats argued that the president could benefit financially if his administration spends taxpayer dollars on stays at his private company’s properties.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats, furious over President Trump’s continued promotion of his branded properties for government business, said on Friday that they would scrutinize whether two recent cases would violate the Constitution’s ban on presidents profiting from domestic or foreign governments.

headline: It’s ‘Opening Night’ for Two Shows That Pay Homage to Cassavetes
abstract: An Australian production features the same scene repeated 100 times, while a French version stars Isabelle Adjani in the Gena Rowlands role.
lead_paragraph: John Cassavetes’s “Opening Night” has long been catnip to theater fans. It’s easy to see why: The 1977 film is about an aging, hard-drinking actress, portrayed by Gena Rowlands, who becomes increasingly unhinged during a play’s out-of-town tryout.

headline: Grieving About Canceled Shows? Get Over It
abstract: The good news is you can find new ones to love.
lead_paragraph: I am still grieving for the loss of “Mozart in the Jungle.” Any chance that the audience fan base for this excellent series could bring the show back? — Rosemary

headline: How Did They Have Such Nice Apartments on ‘Friends’?
abstract: A designer from ‘Queer Eye for the Straight Guy’ weighs in on the eclectic décor of their Greenwich Village walk-ups.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 7, a pop-up exhibition of props, costumes and reimagined sets from the NBC series “Friends” opened at 76 Mercer Street in SoHo, where it will remain until Oct. 6.

headline: Sacha Baron Cohen Plays It Straight in ‘The Spy’
abstract: Cohen, best known for gonzo comedies like “Borat” and “Bruno,” discusses his dramatic turn in the new Netflix period thriller.
lead_paragraph: It’s easier to imagine the British comedian Sacha Baron Cohen, best known as bombastic cringe humor icons like Ali G and Borat Sagdiyev, playing a subtle dramatic role once you know that the character in question, in the Netflix mini-series “The Spy,” is also an undercover performer.

headline: The Twins Power to the Playoffs, Where ‘Anything Can Happen’
abstract: They’re still firmly below the Yankees and the Astros in the American League hierarchy, but the Twins think they have a blueprint for October.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In the bottom of the first inning on Wednesday night, Minnesota Twins Manager Rocco Baldelli noticed something strange in center field. Reaching down to collect a hit was Max Kepler, who was supposed to be in right field.

headline: Here’s an Early Glimpse of the Economic Backdrop for the 2020 Election
abstract: The numbers don’t suggest a recession is underway, but they aren’t consistent with rip-roaring growth.
lead_paragraph: In a vacuum, the latest numbers on the job market are pretty solid, even good.

headline: At Berlin Zoo, a Clamor to Name Twin Pandas ‘Hong’ and ‘Kong’
abstract: Readers of a Berlin newspaper sought to show solidarity with the pro-democracy protests in the semiautonomous Chinese territory.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When a Berlin newspaper asked its readers to help name two pandas born at the Berlin zoo last week, the contest quickly became weighted with political symbolism and risked the ire of Beijing, which has long treated the animals as surrogate envoys to friendly countries.

headline: 16 Ways Facebook, Google, Apple and Amazon Are in Government Cross Hairs
abstract: Investigations could eventually lead to the breakup of some companies, and to new laws that might alter the balance of corporate power.
lead_paragraph: Investigations could eventually lead to the breakup of some companies, and to new laws that might alter the balance of corporate power.

headline: ‘It Chapter Two’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Andy Muschietti discusses a sequence from his film featuring James McAvoy.
lead_paragraph: The director Andy Muschietti discusses a sequence from his film featuring James McAvoy.

headline: Maybe the Best Way to Find Love Is … Not on an App?
abstract: At new live events, young people tout the merits of their single friends like carnival barkers.
lead_paragraph: Here’s at least one sign that some young adults are disaffected with dating apps. On a sweltering Saturday evening not long ago, 250 men and women in their 20s and 30s packed into a Williamsburg bar without air conditioning to match-make via PowerPoint. Over two hours, a dozen presenters clicked through slides extolling the virtues, idiosyncrasies and dating criteria of their best friends. The event, called DateMyFriend.ppt, was sort of like Tinder meets “The Office.”

headline: Death by Diet Soda?
abstract: A new study that links artificially sweetened beverages to premature death is prompting public angst. Some scientists say it has significant flaws.
lead_paragraph: Does guzzling diet soda lead to an early demise?

headline: The Blackberry-Ginger Miracle
abstract: Macerate some blackberries with minced fresh ginger, and do with it what you like: crumbles, slabs, even kombucha.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. You miss me? I’ve been two weeks off the grid in Carhartts and XtraTufs, stained fishing shirts and a ragged ball cap, cutting firewood in the forest for the cookstove, collecting water, fishing hard for striped bass off the rocks. These were plentiful, thick-shouldered, ocean-run fish that struck my lures with vicious force, but I didn’t take one of them because there aren’t enough to do that anymore.

headline: How ‘It Chapter Two’ Revisits a Drain of Terror
abstract: The director Andy Muschietti discusses a creepy scene from his sequel, featuring James McAvoy.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: India Loses Contact With Chandrayaan-2 Moon Lander During Its Descent
abstract: The country will probably have to wait for a future mission to join the elite club of nations that have landed on the moon.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — India’s attempt to land a robotic spacecraft near the moon’s South Pole on Saturday appeared to end in failure.

headline: How Bruce Springsteen Unites the World
abstract: The songwriter and singer gave hope to working-class boys in towns thousands of miles from New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Britain are united in having political leaders who have insulted and mocked immigrants for electoral purposes. President Trump’s anti-immigrant tirades are well known, but Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain has voiced similar sentiments, including comparing Muslim women who wear face veils to “bank robbers” and “letter boxes.”

headline: We Deported Him to a Land He’d Never Seen, and Now He’s Dead
abstract: Jimmy Aldaoud lived almost his whole life in Michigan. When ICE sent him to Iraq, it was the first time he’d set foot in the country.
lead_paragraph: When you foresee a death, there’s no joy in being right. On June 4, I told my colleagues that Jimmy Aldaoud — a medically frail Michigan man who came to the United States in 1979 when he was an infant — was not going to survive. That was the day his sister Rita Bolis called to tell me he had been deported and was sleeping on a bench in an airport in Najaf, Iraq.

headline: Brunello Cucinelli, Renaissance Man
abstract: The designer, best known for what he calls “sportivo chic,” has maintained roots in his native Italy, improving and restoring the town where his brand is based.
lead_paragraph: Even as a child growing up in the rural Umbrian village of Castel Rigone, Brunello Cucinelli had strong opinions about clothes. “When I was 7, my mother gave me a pair of green velvet trousers for Christmas,” says the designer. “I buried them in the garden behind our house because I’ve never been too fond of green.” A decade later, he dropped out of engineering school and, in 1978, launched an eponymous line of women’s sweaters in punchy shades inspired by United Colors of Benetton but woven in fine cashmere and Shetland wool.

headline: The Playlist: Iggy Pop’s Jazzy Whimsy, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Camila Cabello, Tinariwen, Mallrat and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: There’s Another Tomato Plant in the East River
abstract: The discovery of a first plant this week posed a mystery and a social-media frenzy. What to make of a second?
lead_paragraph: At first, Matthew Frey thought someone was messing with him.

headline: ‘They’re All Idiots’: Amid Brexit Chaos, Britons Lose Faith in Politicians
abstract: Whether they wanted to leave or remain in the European Union, British voters agreed that politicians are a “joke,” particularly, it seems, Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
lead_paragraph: ROMFORD, England — Regardless of whether British voters chose to leave or remain in the European Union, the latest Brexit crisis in Westminster this week has united them on one front: They have lost all faith in their politicians.

headline: Is This the World’s Most Accessible Museum?
abstract: Those without disabilities might not notice the innovations, but a museum in London is winning plaudits for its design and content.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a recent afternoon, Clare Barlow, a curator at the Wellcome Collection, a museum of science and medicine here, gave a tour of its new permanent exhibition, “Being Human.”

headline: Radio Free Europe Is Poised to Return to a Less Free Hungary
abstract: The return of the Cold War-era service, which was used to combat authoritarianism, is likely to be taken as an affront by the Orban government and, perhaps, President Trump.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST, Hungary — During the Cold War, the United States beamed its own radio service to Eastern Europeans starved for any information that did not slavishly adhere to the line of their authoritarian leaders.

headline: Mike Isaac’s Uber Book Has Arrived
abstract: In “Super Pumped,” Mike Isaac describes the incredible rise and fall of Travis Kalanick, the chief executive of the world’s most infamous ride-sharing app.
lead_paragraph: SUPER PUMPEDThe Battle for UberBy Mike Isaac

headline: The Nature of Evil
abstract: What is evil? We sat down with two experts — one a religious scholar, the other a forensic psychologist — to discuss this eternal question. Their conversation will surprise you.
lead_paragraph: What is evil? We sat down with two experts — one a religious scholar, the other a forensic psychologist — to discuss this eternal question. Their conversation will surprise you.

headline: To Fight Anti-Semitism, Be a Proud Jew
abstract: Does safety for Jews come from trying to be more like everyone else — or from embracing what makes us special?
lead_paragraph: Since you are reading this, I probably don’t have to tell you that the news these days is not good for the Jews.

headline: How to Build Artificial Intelligence We Can Trust
abstract: Computer systems need to understand time, space and causality. Right now they don’t.
lead_paragraph: Artificial intelligence has a trust problem. We are relying on A.I. more and more, but it hasn’t yet earned our confidence.

headline: Justice Dept. Investigates California Emissions Pact That Embarrassed Trump
abstract: The investigation escalates a standoff between President Trump, California and the auto industry over one of his most significant rollbacks of climate regulations.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has opened an antitrust inquiry into the four major automakers that struck a deal with California this year to reduce automobile emissions, according to people familiar with the matter, escalating a standoff over one of the president’s most significant rollbacks of climate regulations.

headline: More House Republicans Ask: Why Win Re-election When You Can Retire Instead
abstract: A majority of the Republicans planning to leave the House could have easily held onto their seats — but they most likely didn’t want to suffer any more time in the minority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A succession of Republican retirements from Congress, including two announcements this week, is the latest sign of a sour mood in the party about its chances to win back the House in 2020. Party operatives believe even more departures are to come.

headline: Cases of Vaping-Related Lung Illness Surge, Health Officials Say
abstract: Indiana announced a third death linked to the illness on Friday, Minnesota a fourth and California a fifth. State and federal health officials are working urgently to understand the causes.
lead_paragraph: Medical experts and federal health officials on Friday warned the public about the dangers of vaping and discouraged using the devices as the number of people with a severe lung illness linked to vaping more than doubled to 450 possible cases in 33 states and the number of deaths rose to five.

headline: The Real Donald Trump Is a Character on TV
abstract: Understand that, and you’ll understand what he’s doing in the White House.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 1, with a Category 5 hurricane off the Atlantic coast, an angry wind was issuing from the direction of President Trump’s Twitter account. The apparent emergency: Debra Messing, the co-star of “Will & Grace,” had tweeted that “the public has a right to know” who is attending a Beverly Hills fund-raiser for Mr. Trump’s re-election.

headline: Fast and Fuss-Free
abstract: Ease back into the daily hustle with chicken piccata, chickpea stew and the juiciest BLT.
lead_paragraph: Hi and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. I’m back from vacation! It wasn’t exactly weeknight cooking, but I was cooking pretty fast and fuss-free, because who wants to pull out the mandoline at an Airbnb after a day of lazing around at the beach. (And, in fact, that wasn’t an option: My Airbnb didn’t even have kitchen knives.)

headline: Trump, TV and America
abstract: James Poniewozik discusses “Audience of One,” and Bina Venkataraman talks about “The Optimist’s Telescope.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Trump Administration Considers a Drastic Cut in Refugees Allowed to Enter U.S.
abstract: Two options administration officials will consider next week would all but end the United States’ status as one of the leading places accepting refugees from around the world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House is considering a plan that would keep most refugees who are fleeing war, persecution and famine out of the United States, significantly cutting back a decades-old program, according to current and former administration officials.

headline: How ‘Star Trek’ Pushed Cory Booker to Make It So
abstract: His favorite captain is Jean-Luc Picard. He thinks President Trump has a little Ferengi in him. A conversation with Senator Cory Booker about hope, “Star Trek” and his father.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — In the month before officially becoming a presidential candidate, Senator Cory Booker spent his nights rewatching all 172 episodes of “Star Trek: Voyager.”

headline: Women’s Soccer Takes the Stage (for One Weekend Only)
abstract: In Europe, women’s teams are taking advantage of the international break to play some high-profile matches in big stadiums.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to receive Rory Smith’s weekly newsletter on world soccer, delivered to your inbox every Friday.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Live From Lincoln Center’ and ‘Late Night’
abstract: See world-class musicians perform around Greece on PBS. Or watch Emma Thompson in “Late Night” on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: LIVE FROM LINCOLN CENTER 9 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). Midway through “Odyssey: The Chamber Music Society in Greece,” the camera brings us inside a tour bus snaking through a serene Greek countryside. Musicians from the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center sit quietly, reading from a phone or a laptop or pensively gazing out the windows as the landscape slides by. In other words: “Gimme Shelter” this is not. Instead, “Odyssey” is something like a rock ’n’ roll tour documentary for the chamber music crowd, following a group of world-class classical musicians as they perform at venues around Greece. The locales range from the historic (the First Ancient Theater of Larissa) to the cutting edge (the Renzo Piano-designed Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center). The musicians play Beethoven, Debussy, Bach and more.

headline: The Secret of Verdi’s ‘Otello’ and ‘Falstaff’? His Publisher
abstract: A new exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum reveals the crucial role Ricordi played in creating these late masterpieces.
lead_paragraph: The pair of operatic masterpieces that capped Verdi’s career almost didn’t happen.

headline: Fed Chair Powell Speaks and Leaves Investors Expecting a Rate Cut
abstract: The comments will likely confirm investor expectations that the Fed will cut rates at its next meeting on Sept. 17-18.
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, said on Friday that the central bank remained committed to keeping the United States economic expansion going, in remarks that signaled he and his colleagues are likely to cut interest rates for a second time at its coming meeting.

headline: Home Health Aides: Low Wages, Long Hours
abstract: Readers discuss the need for universal long-term care, cultural differences between aides and clients, unions and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Boris Johnson’s Do-or-Die Debacle
abstract: The Johnson government is already a primer in ineptitude — and he hasn’t even tried to buy Greenland.
lead_paragraph: Sam Gyimah was one of the purged. He’d been warned that if he supported a bill to prevent a no-deal Brexit, his political career in Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s Conservative Party would be dead. But like 20 other terminated Tories, he put country before career. “No deal would be catastrophic,” he told me. “The Boris project is coming off the rails.”

headline: A Brothy Pasta So Good You May Forget About the Mussels
abstract: This pasta with mussels, tomatoes and fried capers gives that heady broth, arguably the best part of mussels, a greater purpose.
lead_paragraph: The best part of a steaming pot of mussels just might be the broth. Garlic-flecked, wine-drenched and suffused with salty brine, it can be so good that sometimes I’ll forget about the mussels themselves. Instead, I’ll focus on mopping up the entire pool of liquid with whatever is in reach — chunks of bread, French fries, even the empty mussel shells if a spoon is out of reach (besides, the shells are more fun).

headline: Live Maps: Tracking Hurricane Dorian’s Path
abstract: Mapping the hurricane’s strength, storm surge and expected path.
lead_paragraph: Mapping the hurricane’s strength, storm surge and expected path.

headline: At the U.S. Open, Young Women Coming Into Their Own
abstract: Naomi Osaka. Coco Gauff. Bianca Andreescu. The women of the U.S. Open are holding their heads high.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading In Her Words, where women rule the headlines. This installment was written by Naila-Jean Meyers, The Times’s tennis editor. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox. Let us know what you think at inherwords@nytimes.com.

headline: The First Marine in My Battalion to Die by Suicide
abstract: Tim Ryan was 23, and he died on May 7, 2011, leaving us in a pursuit to understand why. It’s a question we still haven’t been able to answer.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading this week’s At War newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox every Friday. Email us at atwar@nytimes.com.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Catch up on a Canadian cult comedy and watch Sacha Baron Cohen get serious for a change.
lead_paragraph: ‘Letterkenny’

headline: Make T Something | Tomo Koizumi
abstract: The fashion designer incorporates his signature ruffles into a creation for T using a copy of The New York Times and a few select materials.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer incorporates his signature ruffles into a creation for T using a copy of The New York Times and a few select materials.

headline: Patty Abramson, 74, Supporter of Businesses Owned by Women, Dies
abstract: She helped create the Women’s Growth Capital Fund to overcome a barrier. But, she said, “We wouldn’t have done this if money wasn’t to be made.”
lead_paragraph: Patty Abramson, an entrepreneur who founded a venture capital fund that was among the first in the country to exclusively back businesses owned by women, died on Aug. 24 at her summer home in Nantucket, Mass. She was 74.

headline: Victoria’s Secret Had Troubles, Even Before Jeffrey Epstein
abstract: L Brands, the brand’s parent company, plans to detail an overhaul next week as it struggles with changing tastes and an embarrassing connection to the Epstein scandal.
lead_paragraph: A new catalog from Victoria’s Secret landed in mailboxes last month, igniting a flurry of texts and emails among former executives.

headline: Simple, Warming and So Loved
abstract: A New Mexican favorite, green chile stew doesn’t have to be relegated to the fall. It’s just best then.
lead_paragraph: Given the choice, I’d rather be in New Mexico at this time of year.

headline: A Blow to Gerrymandering in North Carolina
abstract: A reader praises a court decision. Also: Real estate industry evasions; a personality test.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Major Drug Maker Is Close to Settling Case to Avert First Federal Trial in Opioid Crisis
abstract: Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals announced a tentative agreement to pay $24 million to settle claims brought by two Ohio counties, and to give away $6 million of its drugs.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest makers of generic opioids in the United States has reached a tentative settlement of claims  to avoid the first federal trial of drug makers, distributors and retail chains for their roles in the opioid epidemic.

headline: Review: A Festival Brings the Musical World Back to School
abstract: The three-night Resonant Bodies Festival was a wide-ranging immersion in new vocal music.
lead_paragraph: There is a back-to-school feeling at the Resonant Bodies Festival, the immersion in new vocal music that arrives each year just after Labor Day. This week, singers, composers and musicians thronged the lobby and aisles of Roulette, in Brooklyn, chatting about where they performed over the summer and what’s coming up this fall.

headline: Hong Kong Protests Resume After Carrie Lam Offers Olive Branch
abstract: The protests on Friday were an early test of public reaction to Mrs. Lam’s four-point plan to ease the tensions that have plunged Hong Kong into crisis.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Tear gas, pepper spray and fire returned to the streets of Hong Kong on Friday, as police officers clashed with masked pro-democracy protesters in the first notable display of unrest since Hong Kong’s top leader announced on Wednesday that she would withdraw a deeply unpopular extradition bill.

headline: How One Journalist Covered Robert Mugabe’s Rise to Power: Cue the Carrier Pigeons
abstract: After the recent death of Zimbabwe’s longtime ruler, we look back at how a former correspondent covered the country’s independence.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Almost 2 Million Homes Are at Risk From Dorian. Most Lack Flood Insurance.
abstract: New data shows some of the major challenges facing United States disaster policy, even as climate change increases those risks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Most of the homes threatened by Hurricane Dorian do not have flood insurance, which means the damage from the storm may be long-lasting.

headline: What Hurricane Dorian Destroyed: Satellite Images of Great Abaco Island
abstract: Hurricane Dorian has wreaked havoc in the Bahamas. A new look from space reveals how extensive the devastation is.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian has wreaked havoc in the Bahamas. A new look from space reveals how extensive the devastation is.

headline: More Retail Chains Ask Customers Not to Carry Guns Openly
abstract: CVS, Walgreens and Wegmans joined Walmart and Kroger in asking customers not to openly carry firearms.
lead_paragraph: Several more of the country’s most ubiquitous retail chains said this week that they will ask customers to refrain from openly carrying guns in their stores. The requests, days after Walmart announced a similar policy, marked a notable shift in the debate about the presence of guns in everyday life in the United States.

headline: Looming Over the College Admissions Case: Will Parents Like Felicity Huffman Get Jail?
abstract: With the first set of parents soon to be sentenced in the wide-reaching case, prosecutors call incarceration “the only meaningful sanction.”
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — With the first sentencings on the horizon for a group of wealthy parents accused of paying big sums to get their children into prestigious colleges by cheating, the legal drama has come down to a simple question: Will they serve any jail time?

headline: I’m So Excited for 40th Grade
abstract: When we become adults, we lose the prompt to reboot our lives every fall. But we don’t have to.
lead_paragraph: When I was in elementary school, a classmate of mine once returned to campus in September to announce that henceforth, she would be going by her middle name. Goodbye Megan, hello Jules. Her friends spent a week quizzing her about her choice and then moved on. It was a new school year, and everyone was starting over. Someone had a new haircut and pierced ears; someone got glasses; someone stopped playing soccer and joined the band; someone switched lunch tables. Big deal.

headline: Hans Rausing, Swedish Packaging Magnate, Is Dead at 93
abstract: One of the wealthiest people in Europe, he took over his father’s company and helped bring Tetra Pak to supermarkets and breakfast tables around the world.
lead_paragraph: Hans Rausing, the former chief executive and chairman of Tetra Pak, the Swedish packaging company that filled supermarket aisles worldwide with paperboard containers of milk, juice and other products, died on Aug. 30 at his estate in Wadhurst Park, East Sussex, in the south of England. He was 93.

headline: Bill Hader Discusses Richie Tozier’s Secret in ‘It Chapter Two’
abstract: The actor says that he and the director, Andy Muschietti, debated how much to reveal and that they filmed several versions of a key scene.
lead_paragraph: [This article contains spoilers for “It Chapter Two.”]

headline: Who Are Trump’s Republican Challengers?
abstract: Bill Weld, the former governor of Massachusetts, was the first Republican to announce that he would run against President Trump for the party’s 2020 nomination. Mark Sanford and Joe Walsh have also joined the race. We look at their political résumés and their strategies.
lead_paragraph: Bill Weld, the former governor of Massachusetts, was the first Republican to announce that he would run against President Trump for the party’s 2020 nomination. Mark Sanford and Joe Walsh have also joined the race. We look at their political résumés and their strategies.

headline: G.O.P. Plans to Drop Presidential Primaries in 4 States to Impede Trump Challengers
abstract: State Republican parties in Arizona, Kansas, Nevada and South Carolina intend to cancel their presidential primaries. The president’s opponents denounced the move.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican Parties in Arizona, Kansas, Nevada and South Carolina intend to cancel the 2020 presidential primaries in their states, according to three people familiar with their plans, a move aimed at depriving President Trump’s long-shot challengers of chances to build support.

headline: NPR Selects Voice of America Boss as Its New Leader
abstract: John Lansing, who started his career as a teenage cameraman in Kentucky, will start his new job as chief of the public broadcaster in October.
lead_paragraph: NPR, the public radio and podcasting giant, has a new leader after years of growth and internal turmoil.

headline: Andrew Luck Walked Away From $58 Million, but That’s Not Necessarily Bad
abstract: Professional athletes may have big paychecks for a few years, but what happens when their careers end? Some plan for that day better than others.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Luck’s announcement that he was retiring from the Indianapolis Colts shocked football fans for two big reasons: He was at the top of his game, despite being repeatedly injured, and he was walking away from some $58 million in the final two years of his contract.

headline: For U.S., Latest Loss to Mexico Is Another Measuring Stick
abstract: Mexico beat the United States for the second time since July, the latest chance for a young American team to see how it measures up.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Mexico is the measuring stick. The United States men’s soccer team can try new things against Ecuador and Chile and learn lessons against Panama and Jamaica. But the true tests of where the team is, and where it wants to go, always come in matches against Mexico.

headline: What Is the Refugee Program and Why Does the Trump Administration Want to Make Cuts?
abstract: The refugee program, housed at the State Department, resettles displaced people from around the world into the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is looking to cut the number of refugees who come to the United States to escape persecution and humanitarian crises, a program that formally dates back to 1980, though the United States had long been accepting refugees and had established its image as a haven for people from around the world.

headline: Expressing Opinions
abstract: When a columnist goes on our show.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday’s episode, a Times colleague did something unusual — for “The Daily,” anyway: He expressed an opinion. The financial columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin told the story of his journalistic campaign to encourage the U.S. financial system — retailers, banks, investment houses — to change how it operates. Right now, few of them, if any, see it as their role to prevent gun violence or stop mass shootings. Andrew argued that they should, and has called on them to begin reporting suspicious transactions that might indicate a customer was planning a gun-related crime and to limit their financial relationships with companies that sell assault rifles. In his mind, it was in their capacity and was their moral obligation.

headline: Habits of Highly Effective Writers
abstract: Some always outline; others never do. Some write in cafes; others don’t leave the house. Here’s a peek at the writing routines of authors on this week’s best-seller lists.
lead_paragraph: Some always outline; others never do. Some write in cafes or Airbnbs; others don’t leave the house. Here’s a peek at the writing habits of authors on this week’s best-seller lists.

headline: What Makes This N.F.L. Season Different From Previous N.F.L. Seasons?
abstract: Sports betting has arrived to transform the N.F.L. Or not. Plus Bianca Andreescu, Justin Verlander and Matteo Berrettini.
lead_paragraph: Get the Sports newsletter in your inbox. And tell us what you want to read in this newsletter. Email your thoughts to sportsnewsletter@nytimes.com.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: A Nobel-winning economist goes to Burning Man. Linda Hamilton is back. Margaret Atwood is, too. And “Friends” is turning 25.
lead_paragraph: With the first week of September in the books, and the exhale of fall ahead of us, take a moment to catch up on some of our great journalism.
