headline: Jimmy Johnson, Studio Staple of Southern Soul and Pop, Dies at 76
abstract: As a guitarist and a recording engineer, he contributed to hit records by Aretha Franklin, Paul Simon, Wilson Pickett and many others.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Johnson, the session guitarist and studio engineer who contributed to hundreds of hit records while helping to define the sound of Southern pop and soul music in the 1960s and ’70s, died on Thursday in Florence, Ala. He was 76.

headline: ThinkProgress, the Progressive News Site, Shuts Down
abstract: The Center for American Progress, the think tank behind the editorial venture, said the lack of a buyer led to the shutdown.
lead_paragraph: The progressive site ThinkProgress shut down on Friday in yet another sign of how much the news media landscape has changed in the past decade.

headline: Mugabe’s Reign Began With Bob Marley and Good Schools. Despotism Soon Followed.
abstract: Robert Mugabe transformed from a hero of Africa’s liberation — and a self-proclaimed champion of universal suffrage — into a tyrant. Our writer was there at the start.
lead_paragraph: It was April 1980, and I was among the crowd serenaded by Bob Marley and the Wailers when Britain’s Union flag was lowered to be replaced by a new banner. A whiff of tear gas floated over a wall at the Rufaro soccer stadium in Harare, the capital of the nascent state of Zimbabwe.

headline: Could N.Y. Take Its Place Between Iowa and New Hampshire in 2020?
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo floated the idea of moving up the presidential primary, but legislative leaders were cool to it.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The possibility that New York might consider moving its presidential primary to February rocketed through Democratic circles on Friday, potentially casting the state among a handful that will set the tone in deciding next year’s nominee.

headline: Vaping, Moon Landing, U.S. Open: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Ciaran McKeown Dies at 76; Sought Peace in Northern Ireland
abstract: Mr. McKeown was inspired by the deaths of three children to help found the Peace People, a grass-roots organization that campaigned for an end to violence.
lead_paragraph: Ciaran McKeown, a reporter who abandoned newspaper work to help establish a peace movement that attracted thousands of marchers in the worst days of the so-called Troubles in Northern Ireland, died on Sept. 1 at his home in Belfast. He was 76.

headline: Yes, Texting While Walking Is Relatively Safe. (But Still Annoying.)
abstract: There’s ‘little concrete evidence’ to connect distracted walking to pedestrian deaths, a report said.
lead_paragraph: If you have crossed a street in a major city recently, the odds are good that you have bumped into someone staring at a phone.

headline: ‘No People Has a Greater Claim to That Flag Than Us’
abstract: Nikole Hannah-Jones discusses the 1619 Project and how it is reframing the way we look at American history.
lead_paragraph: The headquarters of The New York Times is in a busy area of Manhattan where the sidewalks are always bustling. But on the Thursday before the Labor Day weekend, there were larger-than-usual crowds in front of our entrance. And they were after copies of one of the most exciting pieces of journalism we’ve produced in a while.

headline: Mexico Says It Has Cut the Number of Migrants Heading to U.S.
abstract: The government, which had faced economic pressure from the Trump administration, said the flow had been cut in half since spring.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Under pressure from the Trump administration, Mexico’s foreign minister announced Friday that the country had reduced the flow of migrants heading to its northern border by more than 50 percent in the previous three months, an effort meant to keep damaging tariffs at bay.

headline: T Suggests: A New Beauty Counter in Los Angeles, Eccentric Chairs and More
abstract: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
lead_paragraph: It was one night around two years ago when Dennis “DJ” McNany — who formerly ran the Williamsburg, Brooklyn, wine institution Uva — went down to the neighborhood restaurant Marlow & Sons, where he saw its owner, his friend Andrew Tarlow, and the two decided they should open their own wine shop together. They had known each other since the mid-aughts, sharing both a social circle that revolved around Marlow and many wine-world connections: At the time, the two men (with their respective jobs) were among the only buyers in Brooklyn of the kind of biodynamic, organic, natural wine that has since changed contemporary drinking patterns and palates in nearly every city around the world — and which now fills the shelves of Stranger Wines, their Havemeyer Street storefront that opens this week. Here, inside a 1,000-square-foot space that was, in fact, previously a wine shop (they even kept the same shelves, lightening up the room by adding several Noguchi lanterns and buckets of white paint), McNany and Tarlow are selling bottles from people “who actually grow the grapes and farm the fruit,” says Tarlow, whose restaurant portfolio (Diner, Roman’s, Achilles Heel) has long heralded a similarly intimate, person-to-person ethos. “I would say 99.9 percent of all the bottlings here are done by people who tend to their own land.”

headline: Three SEAL Team Leaders Fired for Breakdowns in Discipline
abstract: The unusual move comes amid a flurry of high-profile incidents involving the SEAL teams, prompting attempts by Navy leadership to bring the elite commandos under control.
lead_paragraph: Naval Special Warfare Command fired the three senior leaders of SEAL Team Seven on Friday, saying their failure in leadership caused a breakdown of good order and discipline.

headline: A Gift From the N.F.L. Ignites a Firestorm Over Dreadlocks
abstract: The founder of a Chicago youth group, who shared a photo of herself cutting off a boy’s dreadlocks in 2016, says she meant no disrespect.
lead_paragraph: For several years, a small nonprofit operating out of a church on the South Side of Chicago has tried to reduce gang violence by getting kids involved in boxing, music and other programs.

headline: 6 Emerging Designers to Watch This Fashion Month
abstract: Meet the rising talents who will be showing their collections in New York, London, Paris and Milan.
lead_paragraph: John Targon, 36, New York

headline: When the A.I. Professor Leaves, Students Suffer, Study Says
abstract: After losing top professors, college students are less likely to create artificial intelligence start-ups and get less venture funding, the research says.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, big tech companies have used huge salaries, bonuses and stock packages to lure artificial intelligence experts out of academia. Now, a study released on Friday says that migration has hurt the post-college prospects of students.

headline: Nadal and Medvedev Will Play for the U.S. Open Men’s Title
abstract: Rafael Nadal will go for his 19th major championship against Daniil Medvedev, who gained infamy in the tournament for boorish behavior.
lead_paragraph: The remarkable summer of Daniil Medvedev continued at the United States Open on Friday night, as he fought his way into his first Grand Slam final.

headline: On Dorian-Battered Island, What’s Left? Virtually Nothing
abstract: “This ain’t no place for anyone at the moment,” said one resident of devastated Abaco Island in the Bahamas.
lead_paragraph: MARSH HARBOUR, Bahamas — No schools. No banks. No gas stations. No supermarkets. No restaurants. No churches. No pharmacies. No hardware stores. No water, no electricity and no phone lines.

headline: Episode 3: The Birth of American Music
abstract: For centuries, black music has been an expression of artistic freedom. No wonder everybody is always stealing it.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Google Podcasts | Via Stitcher

headline: ‘I’ll Just Have to Restart Everything’: Ocracoke Island Is Hit Hard by Dorian
abstract: The blow to the Outer Banks, a 120-mile strand of narrow barrier islands off North Carolina that is a magnet for hurricanes, was a reminder of the menacing power the storm retained.
lead_paragraph: NAGS HEAD, N.C. — Hurricane Dorian finally made landfall in the United States on Friday morning on North Carolina’s Outer Banks, where it knocked out power, flooded homes and businesses, and temporarily trapped residents of remote Ocracoke Island, where floodwaters reached up to seven feet.

headline: After Tyler Skaggs’s Death, M.L.B. Turns a Cautious Eye to Its Drug Policy
abstract: Baseball and the players’ union said the pitcher’s overdose death had caused them to re-examine the policy, which does not require testing for “drugs of abuse,” but any proposed changes could raise privacy concerns.
lead_paragraph: M.L.B. and the players’ association plan to re-evaluate their drug policy in the wake of the autopsy report last week on Tyler Skaggs, the Los Angeles Angels pitcher who had fentanyl, oxycodone and alcohol in his system when he was found dead in a Texas hotel room on July 1.

headline: With Voters Watching, Tough-Talking Diplomat Strikes Softer Tone in Kansas
abstract: The question of whether Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will run for Senate in Kansas “hangs over the race a little bit,” said the leading Republican candidate.
lead_paragraph: MANHATTAN, Kan. — His speech walked a line between diplomacy and politics, an exhortation of the United States as a global protector of human rights, mixed with nationalistic pride and a dash of Christian reverence.

headline: Robert Mugabe Was Zimbabwe’s Hero and Its Tyrant
abstract: The “icon of liberation” who led Zimbabwe to independence also drove the nation into poverty.
lead_paragraph: Obituaries of Robert Mugabe, the former leader of Zimbabwe who died in Singapore on Friday at the age of 95, tend to divide his history into three eras: the revolutionary leader of the liberation struggle against white minority rule; the statesman who negotiated with Britain and the white rulers for the creation of Zimbabwe and soon became its first leader; the despot who ruthlessly crushed his opponents and drove his land into penury.

headline: Britain’s Parliamentary Chaos: Can It Happen in Canada?
abstract: Thanks to former Canadian prime minister Stephen Harper, Canada already was acquainted with proroguing parliament to avoid a political setback.
lead_paragraph: If Boris Johnson has achieved nothing else during his brief time as Britain’s prime minister, it is this: Canada is no longer one of the only places in the world where nearly everyone knows what “prorogue” means.

headline: Elaine La Roche, a Power on Wall Street Despite Its Barriers, Dies at 70
abstract: She was one of the most influential women in investment banking in the ’90s, helping to orchestrate a landmark partnership with China.
lead_paragraph: Elaine La Roche, who became one of the most powerful women on Wall Street when women there were scarce — notably helping to orchestrate the first partnership between an American investment bank, Morgan Stanley, and the government of China — died on Aug. 25 at her farm in Sharon, Conn. She was 70.

headline: They Survived Dorian but Wonder How Many More Hurricanes They Can Withstand
abstract: Most residents in eastern North Carolina, where people rattle off the names of storms like old enemies, were spared the worst from Dorian. But they haven’t all recovered from last year’s flooding.
lead_paragraph: BURGAW, N.C. — Every other house along the dirt road hugging a stretch of Burgaw Creek sat empty — sold off or abandoned after years of hurricanes and worsening floods. Then there was Elizabeth Rivenbark’s place.

headline: A Cruel Parody of Antitrust Enforcement
abstract: The Justice Department is roughing up Mr. Trump’s political enemies and threatening the environment.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s Justice Department — for it is increasingly clear that the department has been reduced to an arm of the White House — has opened an antitrust investigation of four auto companies that had the temerity to defy the president by voluntarily agreeing to reduce auto emissions below the level required by current federal law.

headline: Fake Invasion, Real Defense Cuts
abstract: Trump has treated the Pentagon budget as sacrosanct, unless he can raid it to pay for his wall.
lead_paragraph: President Trump often boasts about his enthusiasm for robust Pentagon spending — now at more than $700 billion annually — and argues it should be even higher in the future.

headline: Maine Voters Will Rank Their Top Presidential Candidates in 2020
abstract: It was the first state to adopt ranked-choice voting for congressional elections, and it will now be the first to adopt it for presidential elections.
lead_paragraph: Maine will soon become the first state to adopt ranked-choice voting in presidential elections.

headline: How Vladimir Putin Falls
abstract: A dictator meets an opponent he can’t co-opt, corrupt, calumniate, cow or coerce.
lead_paragraph: The Russian human-rights lawyer Karinna Moskalenko once explained to me how Vladimir Putin’s machinery of repression works.

headline: Defying N.R.A., Texas Lieutenant Governor Favors Background Checks on Private Gun Sales
abstract: Dan Patrick, a Republican, has promoted his A-plus grade from the National Rifle Association.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick of Texas publicly endorsed expanding the state’s background checks to private gun sales on Friday, defying the National Rifle Association — a group that had previously given the conservative an A-plus grade for his Second Amendment bona fides.

headline: A Presidential Storm Leaves Forecasters Rebuked
abstract: The parent agency of the National Weather Service’s Birmingham, Ala., office issued a statement admonishing it for challenging President Trump’s claim about a hurricane threat to Alabama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The hurricane was accelerating away from the Mid-Atlantic coast. In the Bahamas, victims were picking through the devastation. In the Southeast, they were cleaning up debris. And in Washington, President Trump waged war over his forecasting skills.

headline: Young Thug Gets His Due, but Is It Too Late?
abstract: One of the decade’s most copied rappers finally reached No. 1 on the album chart, years after his aesthetic rubbed off on hip-hop.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the Atlanta rapper Young Thug, who has been releasing mind-bending and style-bending music since 2011, had his first No. 1 album on the Billboard chart, “So Much Fun.” It was a triumph for one of the most innovative — and most emulated — hip-hop artists of the 2010s.

headline: Enigmatic People
abstract: Trenton Charlson does his extravagant thing.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Once a month or so my poor brain makes a connection that makes me think this job is teaching me a little something. When I picked up this grid and saw its constructor, said brain said a little “opa!” and some neurons got fired up over Trenton Charlson and his lavish letter usage. In two and a half years and 15 puzzles, Mr. Charlson has debuted BBQ JOINT, FUZZY NAVEL, ZEBRA FINCH, ANTI VAXXER and DETOX DIET, among others.

headline: Fall River Mayor, No Stranger to Scandal, Is Charged With Taking Bribes From Marijuana Vendors
abstract: Jasiel F. Correia II shook down businesses for hundreds of thousands of dollars in return for his support, federal prosecutors said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The corkscrew political career of the mayor of Fall River, Mass., took another turn on Friday as federal prosecutors announced he had been charged with bribery and extortion in what they said was a scheme to shake down marijuana vendors in return for his support.

headline: Tomo Koizumi: Spring 2020
abstract: Tomo Koizumi 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: Tomo Koizumi 2020 Collection

headline: Jeremy Scott: Spring 2020
abstract: Jeremy Scott Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Scott Spring 2020 Collection

headline: Quotation of the Day: More House Republicans Ask: Why Win Re-election When You Can Retire Instead
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 7, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “When candidates would ask me, ‘What’s life like in the minority?’ I would say, ‘It’s great.’ But it’s not so great.”

headline: Corrections: September 7, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, September 7, 2019.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Phone Service Problems Leave More Than a Dozen Hospitals Unable to Take Calls
abstract: The hospitals, all in the New York City region, said there was no danger to patients and advised relatives to use cellphones instead.
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen hospitals in and around New York City lost phone service on Friday night, hampering their ability to answer the incoming calls of relatives who were seeking to speak with patients or check on their status.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Mary Queen of Scots’ and ‘WOW’
abstract: Women go head-to-head in the Oscar-nominated drama “Mary Queen of Scots” and in the women’s wresting show “WOW.”
lead_paragraph: MARY QUEEN OF SCOTS (2018) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. A year after Saoirse Ronan played a pink-haired, rebellious teenager in the indie drama “Lady Bird,” she returned to the big screen as the title character of this period drama, Mary Stuart. Adapted from a biography by John Guy, the film reimagines the decades-long tug of war between Mary and another queen, her Protestant cousin Elizabeth I (Margot Robbie). When a young Mary returns to Scotland from France in 1561 and claims the throne, she asserts she also has the right to Elizabeth’s crown. That sets off a deadly rivalry between the monarchs, which is heightened by dubious men who manipulate their rulers only to inch closer to royalty. The movie opened to mixed reviews; some critics argued the performances were uneven and that Ronan dominates the picture. And while historians may find faults in the plot, the visuals place you right in 16th-century Britain. (The film received Oscar nominations for costume design and makeup and hairstyling.) THE FAVOURITE (2018), another historical drama about women scheming for royalty, leads in at 5:55 p.m.

headline: The Week in Arts: A Mini-Festival of Music and a 9/11 Remembrance
abstract: Trinity Church Wall Street offers a rich selection of sound; Asbury Park hosts a weekend of dance and Mitski comes to town.
lead_paragraph: Sept. 11; fathomevents.com

headline: Help! There’s a Bear in My Airbnb
abstract: Lake Tahoe is home to some 300 bears in the summer, and cabins, campgrounds and cars often experience nightly Goldilocks-style break-ins. Time to call the Bear Lady.
lead_paragraph: Ann Bryant’s phone rings all season long. She has four phones, actually, in her Homewood, Calif., home office, and they ring 24 hours a day. “Sometimes all at once,” says the executive director of the Bear League, a community-based nonprofit that aims to educate the human public about their animal neighbors. Its tagline: “People living in harmony with bears.”

headline: A Judge Refused to Hire a Party Boss’s Aide. A Demotion Followed.
abstract: He said the Bronx Democratic chairman punished him for bucking the patronage system.
lead_paragraph: Three months after the Bronx Democratic Party announced its support for Judge Armando Montano in the 2017 election for State Supreme Court justice, the party’s chairman had a request: He wanted the newly elected judge to hire the chairman’s former aide as a confidential assistant.

headline: In Bianca Andreescu’s Box, a Four-Legged Fan Is the Star
abstract: Her poodle, Coco, has stolen hearts — and airtime — during her march to the U.S. Open final.
lead_paragraph: Although the teenage phenom Coco Gauff was eliminated from the United States Open, an entirely different Coco endures: a furry, 7-pound brown dog belonging to Bianca Andreescu.

headline: In St. Petersburg Election, Russia’s Political Rot Is on Full Display
abstract: A crony of President Vladimir V. Putin’s is a cinch to win in Sunday’s disputed elections, showcasing the farcical nature of Russian politics that ignited protests this summer.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Struggling to shake his image as a bumbling dolt before local elections on Sunday, the acting governor of St. Petersburg made a rare public appearance this past week to open three new subway stations that had taken six years and cost more than $500 million to build.

headline: The Perfect Divorce
abstract: The couple endured many changes in their long marriage. But the space between them grew when he took up sailing and she opened her own restaurants.
lead_paragraph: The couple endured many changes in their long marriage. But the space between them grew when he took up sailing and she opened her own restaurants.

headline: Francisco Toledo Embodied the Activist Soul of Oaxaca
abstract: The Mexican painter, who died Thursday, was as beloved for his advocacy as for his expressionistic art.
lead_paragraph: In his later years, the master artist Francisco Toledo, who died Thursday at 79, developed a fondness for making kites.

headline: A Music Genre Grows in Zimbabwe, Fueled by Rage Against Authority
abstract: A descendant of reggae is the dominant sound of the streets and charts the country’s political struggles since the fall of despot, Robert Mugabe.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — First came the bottles, then the cans. Before Winky D had even stepped onto the stage, the crowd was pelting him with garbage, forcing the Zimbabwean singer to escape to his car. It was Christmas Eve, and the gig was over before it had even begun.

headline: A Virginia University Offers Free Semester to Students in Bahamas Displaced by Hurricane
abstract: In the wake of Hurricane Dorian, Hampton University will open its doors to students from the University of the Bahamas.
lead_paragraph: More than 800 miles separate the University of the Bahamas and Hampton University in Virginia. But some students at the former, whose north campus was devastated by Hurricane Dorian, will be able to continue their education at no cost at the latter for a semester.

headline: Is Xi Mishandling Hong Kong Crisis? Hints of Unease in China’s Leadership
abstract: Beijing’s halting response to the protests in Hong Kong has raised questions about President Xi Jinping’s imperious style and authoritarian policies.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s leader, Xi Jinping, warned a gathering of senior Communist Party officials in January that the country faced a raft of urgent economic and political risks, and told them to be on guard especially for “indolence, incompetence and becoming divorced from the public.”

headline: The Last of the Dunk Tank Clowns
abstract: Turns out Americans don’t really enjoy being insulted anymore.
lead_paragraph: All David Simmons needs is a chuckle, a smile even, to set the hook and reel people back to his booth with more stinging insults — the weight of a man’s date, or the cheap finish of a woman’s fake gold hoop earrings.

headline: Climate Change Takes Center Stage: This Week in the 2020 Race
abstract: Half of the Democratic candidates took part in a CNN town-hall-style event on global warming, and several unveiled detailed plans to address the crisis.
lead_paragraph: A lot happened on the presidential campaign trail this week. Here’s our weekly catch-up on the 2020 election and the Democratic field, which is still 20 candidates strong.

headline: Cheating, Inc.: How Writing Papers for American College Students Has Become a Lucrative Profession Overseas
abstract: Amid the college admissions scandal, another type of cheating was overlooked: Students already in college who pay others to write their papers.
lead_paragraph: Tuition was due. The rent was, too. So Mary Mbugua, a university student in Nyeri, Kenya, went out in search of a job. At first, she tried selling insurance policies, but that only paid on commission and she never sold one. Then she sat behind the reception desk at a hotel, but it ran into financial trouble.

headline: When Climate Change Is Stranger Than Fiction
abstract: Amitav Ghosh, whose book “Gun Island” is set in an ecologically unstable world, wants literature to explore the environment as much as it does other crises.
lead_paragraph: How do you capture the realities of climate change in a novel — not just its causes and symptoms, but the ever-changing, ever-weirder ways it is manifesting, within the conventional framework of a story with a beginning, middle and end?

headline: Sashaying Their Way Through Youth
abstract: Meet the rising drag stars of America. They’re tweens.
lead_paragraph: “I’m excited!” screamed Desmond Napoles, a 12-year-old drag star who performs as Desmond is Amazing, punctuating his enthusiasm with mild profanity. His eyes darted to his phone. Then he backtracked. “Don’t put that in. Don’t put that in.” He would soon be grounded from Snapchat by his mother for what she called “sass.”

headline: Biden Wants to Work With ‘the Other Side.’ This Supreme Court Battle Explains Why.
abstract: In the clash over Robert H. Bork’s nomination, Joe Biden’s moderate instincts defined a winning strategy.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. was on the brink of victory, but he was unsatisfied.

headline: Two “Nice, Quiet” Vacations Upended by the Dogs
abstract: The couple, who each were on a solo vacation in Bellport, N.Y., met while walking their dogs on Main Street.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. William Howard Critzman and Patrick Willingham were married Sept. 7 at Old South Haven Presbyterian Church in Brookhaven Hamlet, N.Y. The Rev. Micah Bucey, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Crisscrossing Paths and Then a Connection on Campus
abstract: She mistook his confidence for cockiness until she finally got to know him better.
lead_paragraph: Michele Denise Hall and Stanford Divante Fraser were married Sept. 7 at the Newton White Mansion in Mitchellville, Md. Willie J. Epps Jr., a federal magistrate judge for the Western District of Missouri with chambers in Jefferson City, officiated.

headline: How to Handle Wedding-Planning Disputes With Parents
abstract: Some disagreements are small, but some could create a family rift. Deep breaths and a little common sense can help smooth the way.
lead_paragraph: Wedding planning can stir up conflict between marrying couples and their parents. Some squabbles are minor. Should the table linens be white or ivory? What should go inside the welcome bags for out-of-town guests? But disagreements can turn into a wedge between families.

headline: Russia and Ukraine Swap Dozens of Prisoners, in a ‘First Step to Stop the War’
abstract: Two dozen Ukrainian sailors detained by Russia in the Kerch Strait last year are among those being returned — as is the Ukrainian filmmaker Oleg Sentsov, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — After five years of grinding conflict stoked by Russia in eastern Ukraine, the two bitterly estranged neighbors swapped dozens of prisoners on Saturday in a long-anticipated exchange that Ukraine’s new president hailed as “the first step to end the war.”

headline: Canada Geese and a Golf Club Face Off in Vermont
abstract: The Quechee Club postponed plans to invite hunters on its property after animal rights groups and residents lobbed complaints.
lead_paragraph: Vermont’s hunting season for Canada geese began last week, and a local golf club planned to take advantage by culling an unwelcome gaggle.

headline: What Kids Can Learn From a Resilient Runner
abstract: A children’s book tells the true story of running 3,452 miles across the country as inspiration for finding a path to achieving your goals.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: A State Wrestles With Its Imagery: A Sword Looming Over a Native American
abstract: An effort to change the official seal of Massachusetts is gaining steam. Supporters say the imagery is threatening and denigrating to Native Americans.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When former State Representative Byron Rushing first looked closely at the Massachusetts state seal, he could not believe his eyes.

headline: What Happens When a Landlord Flouts the New Rent Laws?
abstract: New York’s new rules are ostensibly beneficial to tenants, but ambiguities in the fine print make some of them difficult to enforce.
lead_paragraph: Q: I recently applied to rent an apartment in a large Upper Manhattan complex. The management company requires a $95 background-check fee for every adult, employed member of the household. I thought the new rent laws limit background-check fees to $20. How is this fee legal?

headline: The ‘Political Anarchist’ Behind Britain’s Chaos
abstract: Dominic Cummings, Boris Johnson’s Rasputin, is happy to watch the country blow up if he gets what he wants.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of the rare occasions on which I’ve encountered Dominic Cummings, who may be the most important man in Britain right now, was at a private political dinner in 2016, just after the plan to hold a referendum on Britain’s membership in the European Union had been announced. Mr. Cummings, who a few years earlier had been a political adviser at the education ministry, had been invited to outline the argument that the Brexiteers would be making; a counterpart from the fledgling Remain campaign was there to present his.

headline: A Mountain Top Called ‘Little Man’ Falls in Norway, and Residents Weep
abstract: For five years, geologists in Norway had urgently warned that the top of a mountain called “Little Man” could collapse and destroy huge swaths of a nearby town. After the 16th warning, it fell.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — For five years, geologists in Norway had urgently warned that a mountaintop called “Little Man” could collapse because of the corrosive effects of heavy rain, destroying huge swaths of the nearby town of Rauma.

headline: Your Fall Cooking Bucket List
abstract: We’re ready for all the sweater-weather recipes.
lead_paragraph: It may be a bit early, but we’re dreaming of brisk evenings and apple cider. Join us in setting up our menus with recipes for apple skillet cake with salted caramel frosting (above), roast chicken with maple butter and all the recipes in the collection below.

headline: The First Trend of New York Fashion Week
abstract: It’s a new thing. But it’s probably not what you think.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week began with a lunch and a dinner — despite the fact that fashion people famously don’t eat.

headline: Doing It on Their Own
abstract: An unemployed designer who headed a fashion house can wait for another opportunity or just get on with it. Here are four big names going the small route.
lead_paragraph: When you have had the top job at a big brand — when you’ve been that designer, on that golden treadmill, in that spotlight — and you’ve lost it, for whatever reason (bad fit, liquidation, mutual consent), you have three options.

headline: Even Physicists Don’t Understand Quantum Mechanics
abstract: Worse, they don’t seem to want to understand it.
lead_paragraph: “I think I can safely say that nobody really understands quantum mechanics,” observed the physicist and Nobel laureate Richard Feynman. That’s not surprising, as far as it goes. Science makes progress by confronting our lack of understanding, and quantum mechanics has a reputation for being especially mysterious.

headline: When Reporting an Economics Article at Burning Man, Be Prepared for Things to Get Weird
abstract: I visited the annual Nevada bacchanalia with Paul Romer, a Nobel-winning economist who has come to see it as a model for urbanization. Everything about the experience was surreal.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Stands Out at New Hampshire Democratic Party Convention
abstract: Ms. Warren got the most enthusiastic response of the 19 candidates who appeared Saturday. Bernie Sanders, Pete Buttigieg and Cory Booker also attracted particularly energetic support.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s backers roared supportive slogans and banged on drums as they awaited his arrival outside Southern New Hampshire University Arena. Senator Bernie Sanders was welcomed by die-hard fans ready to cheer seemingly every sentence he uttered. Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Senator Cory Booker delivered one applause line after the next.

headline: For Rafael Nadal, the U.S. Open Has Become a Comfort Zone
abstract: On Sunday against Daniil Medvedev, Nadal, known as the king of clay, is seeking his fourth U.S. Open title since 2010.

headline: Variety: Going Too Far
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners, never stop.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — We had one of these back in January that was well-received (I checked), and I’m finding myself liking this kind of variety puzzle more every time I solve one. It has the grand payoff of an acrostic, if you’re solving for the quotation, and it’s a lot more accessible than some of our cryptics. It also has a little bit of “Marching Bands” in it, because the end of one answer leads right into the next, and you have to keep yourself focused through that.

headline: How Congress Passed an Assault Weapons Ban in 1994
abstract: Congress and the White House found a way to come together on guns 25 years ago. It is hard to see that kind of bipartisanship resurfacing in the current environment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Bill Clinton had just been ambushed by his own party. It was August 1994 and a coalition of House Democrats wary of any new gun restrictions joined Republicans to unexpectedly sink the administration’s big crime bill on a procedural vote that was usually a test of party loyalty.

headline: Is Seattle a Model for Fighting Drug Addiction?
abstract: Readers debate whether the city’s focus on social services rather than prosecution is the right approach.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Checking In at Trump Hotels, for Kinship (and Maybe Some Sway)
abstract: To ethics lawyers, the most extraordinary aspect of the daily merging of President Trump’s official duties and his commercial interests is that it has now become almost routine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a table in the lobby bar of the Trump International Hotel this week, the final details of a black-tie, 40th anniversary gala for the Concerned Women for America were being worked out by the conservative group’s staff.

headline: Two Men Kiss in a Comic Book, and a Mayor Orders a Raid
abstract: The raid drew a backlash from festival organizers, publishing houses, comedians and, finally, a Brazilian court, which barred the mayor from further seizure efforts.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The team of law-enforcement agents deployed by the mayor to “defend the family” descended on the international event and scoured the grounds for their target: copies of a comic book featuring two young men kissing.

headline: Antonio Brown, Released by the Raiders, to Sign With the Patriots
abstract: The seven-time Pro Bowl receiver requested his release after the team reportedly voided $30 million in guaranteed salary.
lead_paragraph: Even by the ruthless, ego-driven standards of the N.F.L. labor market, Antonio Brown’s half-year in Oakland with the Raiders was one for the books.

headline: Two Men in Wheelchair Divisions Can Complete Grand Slams at U.S. Open
abstract: Gustavo Fernandez of Argentina and Dylan Alcott of Australia are chasing sweeps in divisions that didn’t exist until recently for the four tennis majors.
lead_paragraph: One of the celebrations this year at the United States Open is the 50th anniversary of Rod Laver’s second Grand Slam, when the Australian won all four major men’s singles titles in 1969.

headline: Something Strange Is Going On With All Those Retiring Texans
abstract: A wave of G.O.P. House members leaving Congress is a political opportunity for hungry Democrats.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The Republican Party of Texas appears to be molting. Last week, Representative Bill Flores became the 10th Texas Republican in the House to announce his retirement since the 2016 election, and the fifth this year. Others are expected this year.

headline: Football Is Here to Stay
abstract: Despite the concussion controversy, things are looking up.
lead_paragraph: Sunday marks the opening weekend of the 100th season of the National Football League. Many can’t get enough professional football. During the 2018-19 prime-time TV schedule, three of the four top-rated shows among adults ages 18 to 49 were pro football games. Only “Game of Thrones” bested pigskin in the ratings, and that series concluded, while the N.F.L. goes on.

headline: Is the Celebrity Editor Becoming Extinct?
abstract: Carine Roitfeld thinks so: “Fashion has finished that chapter.”
lead_paragraph: Did you know that a woman can stroll topless in Manhattan without breaking the law? Carine Roitfeld has made it her business to know.

headline: Taylor Swift, Philosopher of Forgiveness
abstract: The pop superstar offers genuine insight about “moving on.”
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift is on fire. She just dropped her seventh album, “Lover,” and it’s already the top seller of 2019. She also dropped some wisdom that deserves to be as widely appreciated as her music.

headline: Iran Breaks With More Limits in Nuclear Deal as It Pushes for European Aid
abstract: Details suggest Iran is largely interested in increasing pressure on European nations to find a way around American-imposed sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s atomic energy agency said Saturday that it was deliberately violating another set of limits on its nuclear research and production that were imposed under the 2015 agreement renounced by President Trump last year.

headline: Military Stopover at Scottish Airport Includes a Stay at a Trump Resort
abstract: Questions about the overnight stays emerged after House investigators asked about the surge in stopovers at an airport near the Trump Turnberry golf resort in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — United States military personnel stayed at the Trump Turnberry golf resort in Scotland in March when an Air Force plane stopped at a nearby airport to refuel on the way to Kuwait from the United States, an Air Force spokesman and a Trump Organization representative confirmed Saturday, while defending the decision as a routine matter.

headline: Arizona G.O.P. Leader Said Party Would Stop Mark Kelly ‘Dead in His Tracks’
abstract: Mr. Kelly, a Democrat running for Senate, is married to Gabrielle Giffords, the former congresswoman who survived a gunshot to the head in a 2011 attack.
lead_paragraph: The chairwoman of the Republican Party of Arizona defended an email on Friday in which she had said the party would stop Mark Kelly, a Democrat running for United States Senate, “dead in his tracks.”

headline: Is Instagram Ruining Architecture?
abstract: The app can help expand our love of the designed world and incite our curiosity. Or it can turn us into sheep.
lead_paragraph: On my phone, Instagram is a series of squares and rectangles with pictures of babies, clogs, books, lakes and buildings, buildings and more buildings. But when I read or hear about Instagram, none of these — except for babies — seem to exist on the app.

headline: Images from Space Show Released Iranian Oil Tanker Near Syrian Coast
abstract: Gibraltar released the tanker last month after Iran promised it would not deliver its 2.1 million barrels of oil to Syria.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An Iranian oil tanker caught in the escalating feud between Iran, the United States and other Western nations has anchored off the coast of Syria, according to images released by a space technology company.

headline: Bianca Andreescu Wins the U.S. Open, Defeating Serena Williams
abstract: With a 6-3, 7-5 victory, Andreescu, a 19-year-old Canadian, captures her first Grand Slam title and denies Williams her 24th.
lead_paragraph: If you have been considering active visualization, this seems a fine time to start.

headline: The Lost Promise of Reconstruction
abstract: Can we reanimate the dream of freedom that Congress tried to enact in the wake of the Civil War?
lead_paragraph: Among the unanticipated consequences of the election of Donald Trump has been a surge of interest in post-Civil War Reconstruction, when this country first attempted to construct an interracial democracy, and in the restoration of white supremacy that followed. Many Americans feel that we are living at a time like the end of the 19th century, when, in the words of Frederick Douglass, “principles which we all thought to have been firmly and permanently settled” were “boldly assaulted and overthrown.”

headline: Hong Kong Protesters Return to Streets After Leader Announces Concessions
abstract: The city’s leader promised to withdraw unpopular legislation that ignited protests in June, but demonstrators’ demands have expanded since then.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pro-democracy demonstrators in Hong Kong clashed with the police for a second straight day on Saturday, despite a concession on Wednesday from the city’s embattled leader.

headline: The Age of American Despair
abstract: Are deaths from drugs and alcohol and suicide a political, economic or spiritual crisis?
lead_paragraph: This week CNN devoted seven hours of programming to climate change, bringing the leading Democratic candidates onstage to grill them on the issue. I have no complaints about the decision, but I wish that some network would set aside a similar amount of time for a more immediate crisis, one that is killing tens of thousands of Americans right now — more than the crack epidemic at its worst, more than the Vietnam War.

headline: The Republicans Are Dropping Like Flies
abstract: What do retiring members of Congress know that President Trump doesn’t?
lead_paragraph: There was no home for Representative Will Hurd in Donald Trump’s Republican Party.

headline: These Newborn Babies Cry for Drugs, Not Milk
abstract: For some Americans, the nation’s opioid crisis starts before birth.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — His body dependent on opioids, he writhes, trembles and cries. He is exhausted but cannot sleep. He vomits, barely eats and has lost weight.

headline: I Killed My Partner. It Saved My Life.
abstract: While she and her children slept, Arlene Adams was attacked by their abusive father. Defending herself, she killed him. She served her time, and is now rebuilding her life.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Sept. 15, 2010, my children and I were sound asleep when my partner arrived at our home in Brooklyn drunk after a night out, and flew into a violent rage.

headline: The Trick to Life Is to Keep Moving
abstract: What my friendship with a woman 51 years my senior taught me about growing up.
lead_paragraph: For many people, roommates and romances are the most important relationships of their late teens and early 20s. For me it was Cora Brooks, a poet and activist 51 years my senior. She taught me how to make bread without measuring the flour or water or yeast, to not fear improvising. Through Cora I learned slowness and grace.

headline: End Legacy College Admissions
abstract: A country struggling with deeply rooted inequality need not continue an affirmative action program for successful families.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a century, many American college and university admissions officers have given preferential treatment to the children of alumni.

headline: Director of M.I.T.’s Media Lab Resigns After Taking Money From Jeffrey Epstein
abstract: Joichi Ito had acknowledged taking $525,000 for the lab from Mr. Epstein, as well as more than $1 million for his own investment funds.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a month after his death, Jeffrey Epstein continues to haunt some of America’s most prestigious institutions.

headline: For Pope Francis, a Perfect Moment for an Unsettling Warning on the Environment
abstract: Francis has made the case to fight climate change and the Earth’s degradation for years. In Africa, he found a backdrop that was fitting if unnerving.
lead_paragraph: AMBATOMIRAHAVAVY, Madagascar — In a nature reserve on the banks of the clay-colored Katsaoka River, an eight-week-old crowned sifaka clung to its mother’s back as she leapt across tree branches. Nearby, other lemur species combed their young’s backs, nibbled on leaves or lounged in the sun.

headline: In Bahamas, Battered Residents Ask: Where Is Our Government?
abstract: The tiny island nation, with just 0.1 percent of the United States population, has been overwhelmed by the catastrophic storm. Its residents are losing patience with their government’s response.
lead_paragraph: MARSH HARBOUR, the Bahamas — In the hours and days after Hurricane Dorian tore through the Bahamas’ Abaco Islands, the first government rescuers many residents saw were American. Coast Guard helicopters cut through the sky to evacuate the sick and wounded.

headline: The Best of New York Fashion Week, in Pictures
abstract: The spring 2020 shows have come to a close in New York. Here, the most memorable moments from the runways, as captured by T’s photographers.
lead_paragraph: Marc Jacobs closed New York Fashion Week with a colorful parade of nostalgic optimism at the Park Avenue Armory. In a break from the traditional runway format, smiling models came out en masse at the start of the show and each of the 59 looks was completely distinct from the others. If there was a common thread it was a ’70s sensibility; velvet tailoring, flounced dresses and disco sequins read like a roll call of the decade’s greatest fashion hits. Jacobs said the collection was riposte to the “computer or the cloud or the transient archives of the internet.”

headline: Well, Well, Well, If It Isn’t …
abstract: Joe DiPietro!
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s grid is by Joe DiPietro, a Brooklynite and veteran constructor with more than three decades of puzzles under his belt. He also owns a bar in Manhattan, “one star” (which gets plenty of somewhat better reviews), where you can play trivia games on Saturday nights, and probably give feedback to Mr. DiPietro in person about this grid or at least leave him a note on a cocktail napkin.

headline: ‘Joker’ Takes Home Top Prize at Venice Film Festival
abstract: The international competition also bestowed an unexpected high-profile honor on “An Officer and a Spy,” a new film by Roman Polanski.
lead_paragraph: “Joker,” directed by Todd Phillips, was awarded the Golden Lion for best film at the 76th Venice International Film Festival on Saturday by a competition jury led by the Argentine filmmaker Lucrecia Martel. The film received fervent attention as well as critical praise for its portrayal of its troubled, murderous central figure, drawn from the DC Comics character and played by Joaquin Phoenix.

headline: Greece to Shed ‘Black Sheep’ Status, New Conservative Leader Asserts
abstract: The prime minister announced a series of tax cuts intended to bolster a country dogged by years of austerity and the vestiges of a decade-long financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The country’s new conservative prime minister, declaring that Greece was “no longer the black sheep of Europe,” on Saturday announced a series of corporate and individual tax cuts, along with a plan to encourage investment.

headline: What You Need to Know About Vaping-Related Lung Illness
abstract: Coughing, fatigue and shortness of breath are warning signs for anyone who has vaped within the last 90 days.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people across the country have been sickened by a severe lung illness linked to vaping, and a handful have died, according to public health officials. Many were otherwise healthy young people, in their teens or early 20s. Investigators from numerous states are working with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Food and Drug Administration in an urgent effort to figure out why.

headline: The Power of Serena Williams
abstract: What she and Venus have accomplished is far more important than future titles and broken records.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams’s legacy is sealed, whether or not she ever hits a tennis ball again. Of course it’s sad she didn’t beat Bianca Andreescu at the finals of the U.S. Open Championships and match Margaret Court’s record of 24 Grand Slam singles titles. But her contributions to the game are much bigger than reaching another Grand Slam final.

headline: Trump Says He’s Called Off Negotiations With Taliban After Afghanistan Bombing
abstract: The president said he had canceled a secret meeting at Camp David with Taliban leaders and the president of Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Saturday that he had canceled a secret meeting at Camp David with Taliban leaders and the president of Afghanistan and was calling off monthslong negotiations that had appeared to be nearing a peace agreement.

headline: Corrections: September 8, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, September 8, 2019.
lead_paragraph: ARTS & LEISURE

headline: Red Jeep Stranded on a Beach Becomes a Social Media Sensation
abstract: The vehicle, which the police in Myrtle Beach, S.C., found abandoned as Hurricane Dorian loomed, grew into a popular meme.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Feliciano got a message from a friend around noon on Thursday with a photo of a red 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokee stuck on Myrtle Beach in South Carolina getting pummeled by waves.

headline: Hiker Killed in 500-Foot Fall While Climbing Half Dome at Yosemite
abstract: Danielle Burnett, 29, was trying to reach the summit of the precipice, officials at the California national park said.
lead_paragraph: The thrill of trying to reach the top of Half Dome at Yosemite National Park turned fatal on Thursday for a hiker who fell 500 feet from the famed rock face as she was scaling the steepest part of the trail, the authorities said.

headline: While No Longer a Hurricane, Dorian Still Inflicts Damage on Canada
abstract: More than 450,000 homes and businesses in three provinces were without power on Saturday as the storm, downgraded from a Category 2 hurricane struck the coast.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Winds produced by the remnants of Hurricane Dorian tore roofs off buildings, downed trees, collapsed a construction crane and left hundreds of thousands of people without electricity in three provinces in Canada on Saturday.

headline: ‘She the North’: Bianca Andreescu Joins the Raptors in Canadian Sports Lore
abstract: In one summer, Canada gained its first N.B.A. championship and its first Grand Slam singles title in tennis.
lead_paragraph: When Gayle Benjamin invited a friend to travel from his home in Calgary, Alberta, to visit her in New York, she already had tickets to the United States Open women’s final. A devoted fan of Serena Williams, Benjamin never thought that Arthur Telesford, her Canadian friend, would become a liability.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Call to Have Massachusetts’ State Seal Lay Down Its Weapon
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 8, 2019
lead_paragraph: “Here’s a state that had gay rights, gay marriage and kept voting against the death penalty. But when you talked about changing the flag, people went bananas.”

headline: Brandon Maxwell: Spring 2020
abstract: Brandon Maxwell Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: Brandon Maxwell Spring 2020 Collection

headline: Vanessa Santi, John D’Andrea
abstract: The couple met in 2015, when he hired the Chicago company she worked for to produce an event for him.
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Jayne Santi and John D’Andrea were married Sept. 5 in Capri, Italy. Giovanni De Martino, the mayor of Capri, officiated at town hall. On Sept. 6, the couple had a ceremony at the Giardini di Augusto, also in Capri, that was led by Rosa Pauli, a wedding celebrant.

headline: Marcus Markle, Nathan Willis
abstract: When he proposed with twisty tie rings, his partner responded with two tungsten carbide ones he had at the ready.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Jay Markle and Nathan Scott Willis were married Sept. 2 at the Heceta Head Lighthouse Bed & Breakfast along the Pacific Coast in Yachats, Ore. Christopher Borniger, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Quita St. John, Loren Betts
abstract: The couple, who met at a Halloween party in 2015 in Kirkland, Wash., will use the surname St. Betts.
lead_paragraph: Quita Nicole Jennifer St. John and Loren Snow Betts were married Sept. 7 at the Normandy Park Community Club, an events space in Normandy Park, Wash. The couple were married in a Quaker ceremony that will be solemnized by Judge Mary E. Roberts of King County Superior Court, in Seattle.

headline: Amanda Jatho, Benjamin Foreman
abstract: The couple met in August 2012 when both were working for the Detroit Pistons National Basketball Association team.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Shreve Jatho and Benjamin Douglas Foreman were married Sept. 7 at a private home, rented for the occasion, overlooking Long Island Sound in Old Saybrook, Conn. Rabbi Andrea Frank officiated.

headline: Eleanor Mills, James Howe V
abstract: The couple met in 2010 as freshmen at the University of Vermont.
lead_paragraph: Eleanor Douglas Mills and James Harvey Howe V were married Sept. 7 in Washington at St. John’s Episcopal Church Georgetown Parish. Rev. Sarah Duggin, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Shelly Bendit, Sherif Ibrahim
abstract: The couple met in the eighth grade in 2005 at Christa McAuliffe School in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Shelly Flora Bendit and Sherif Adly Ibrahim were married Sept. 7 at the Estate at Farrington Lake, an events space in East Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Scott Matous officiated.

headline: Katherine Lewin, Alexander Stillman
