lead_paragraph: Katherine Kane Lewin and Alexander William Stillman were married Sept. 7 at the Storm King Art Center, an open-air sculpture museum in Cornwall, N.Y. Skyler Okey, a friend of the couple who became a minister with American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

headline: Amy Todd, Benjamin Sweeney
abstract: The couple met through a mutual friend in 2009 in Tbilisi, Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Amy Everett Todd and Benjamin Shubik Sweeney were married Sept. 7 at Clark Lookout, a nature preserve in New London, N.H. Virginia S. Sweeney, a sister of the groom, officiated, having been ordained through American Marriage Ministries for the event.

headline: Meridith Wailes, Joshua Dworkin
abstract: The couple, both officers in the United States Navy, met on OkCupid when they were both stationed in Norfolk, Va.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Meridith Anne Wailes and Lt. Joshua Carl-Louis Dworkin were married Sept. 7. The Rev. Dr. James R. Keck, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at First-Plymouth Congregational Church in Lincoln, Neb.

headline: Rebecca Sussman, Matthew Rosenthal
abstract: The couple met on their first day at Cornell Law School in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Ann Sussman and Matthew Ellison Rosenthal were married Sept. 7 at the Loeb Boathouse in New York. Judge Richard C. Wesley of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit officiated.

headline: Taylor Willis, Andrew McLaughlin
abstract: The couple met at Bucknell, and began dating a few months after graduating.
lead_paragraph: Gracia Taylor Willis and Andrew James McLaughlin were married Sept. 7. Sarah C. Seelye, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Tokeneke Club, a beach club in Darien.

headline: Alexandra Kass, Jeffrey Schatz
abstract: The couple met in 2014 in Manhattan through the dating app Hinge.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Alexandra Pearson Kass and Jeffrey Wolf Schatz were married Sept. 7 at the Bronx Zoo. Dr. Martin Wasserman, an uncle of the bride who became a minister with American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

headline: Volkswagen Hopes Fresh Logo Signals an Emission-Free Future
abstract: The carmaker is updating its familiar trademark at the same time it is beginning a push to make electric vehicles affordable to the masses.
lead_paragraph: WOLFSBURG, Germany — A crane recently lifted away the enormous VW logo that sat like a giant hood ornament atop Volkswagen’s 14-story headquarters in Wolfsburg. Sometime after dark on Monday, a crane will lower an updated one into place.

headline: How Top-Valued Microsoft Has Avoided the Big Tech Backlash
abstract: Its “Evil Empire” moniker, once a label favored by the company’s critics, has fallen by the wayside.
lead_paragraph: Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple are targets of government investigations and public outrage, facing accusations that they abuse their power in various ways, from exploiting personal information to stifling rivals.

headline: Linda Cieslak, Robert Sandoval
abstract: The couple met in 2015, when both were interns at the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Linda Marie Cieslak and Robert Santos Sandoval were married Sept. 7 at Ten Peaks, an events space at the Crested Butte ski resort in Mount Crested Butte, Colo. Judge William H. Orrick III of the Federal District Court in San Francisco, for whom the groom was a law clerk until February, officiated.

headline: Alexandra Barsky, Joshua Rosenfeld
abstract: The couple were introduced in February 2017 through JSwipe.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Rebecca Barsky and Joshua Eric Rosenfeld were married Sept. 7 by Rabbi Robert N. Levine at the Mandarin Oriental, a hotel in Manhattan.

headline: Kristen Holmes, Noah Gray
abstract: The couple met over the telephone in 2015, when he called her about a breaking news story, but they didn’t meet in person until a year later.
lead_paragraph: Kristen Elizabeth Romano Holmes and Noah William Gray were married Sept. 7 in Nantucket, Mass. Rabbi Jonathan Fisch officiated at a private home rented for the occasion.

headline: Zoe Sawka, James Stoeckle
abstract: The couple met on Bumble, the dating app, and had their first date two years ago in Boston, where they were both then living.
lead_paragraph: Zoe Marenia Sawka and Dr. James Hart Stoeckle were married Sept. 7. Sarah W. Brassard, an interfaith minister, officiated at a private residence, rented for the occasion, in Chatham, Mass.

headline: Kerry White, Mark Porter
abstract: The couple met on Match.com in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Kerry Elizabeth White and Mark Christian Porter were married Sept. 7 at the Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington. The Rev. Benjamin Hawley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jasmine Powe, Nicholas Ruschmann
abstract: Her college roommate was the linchpin in bringing them together.
lead_paragraph: Jasmine Liana Powe and Nicholas Michael Ruschmann were married Sept. 7 at the Baltimore Museum of Art in Maryland. The Rev. Rodney V. Rice, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Blaire Edgerton, James Wu
abstract: The couple met in 2013 while playing a game of pickup basketball at the International Student House of Washington.
lead_paragraph: Blaire Elizabeth Edgerton and James Wu were married Sept. 7 at the Carnegie Institution for Science in Washington. Mohammad H. Tahersima, a friend of the couple who received temporary authorization from the District of Columbia Marriage Bureau, officiated.

headline: Leona Rosenblum, Garrett Berntsen
abstract: She sent him photos of lemurs in the wild to prove she was in Madagascar.
lead_paragraph: Leona Fitzgerald Rosenblum and Garrett Thomas Berntsen were married Sept. 7 at Camp Puh’Tok, a nonprofit summer camp and learning center in Monkton, Md. Will Quinn, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Sophia Williams, Timothy Rousseau
abstract: The couple met in 2016 through the dating app Bumble.
lead_paragraph: Sophia Lynn Williams and Timothy Joseph Rousseau were married Sept. 7. Matthew Jackowitz, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for this event, officiated at the Otto H. Kahn House in Manhattan.

headline: Sally Symons, Nikolas Alexoff
abstract: The couple met in 2013, when both were in their first day of work at an advertising agency in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Daughtry Symons and Nikolas David Alexoff were married Sept. 7 in Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Michael B. Brown, a United Methodist minister, officiated at Reynolda Gardens, an estate of R. J. Reynolds that is now part of Wake Forest University.

headline: They Found the Perfect Moment of Absolute Harmony
abstract: The couple ran in similar music circles for years, only to meet at the very time they were both single and ready to date.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Jane Hinchman and Ted DeDee are to be married Sept. 8 at the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is to officiate.

headline: Tara Corrigan, Brian Paul
abstract: The couple met at Duke, from which each received an M.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Tara Colleen Corrigan and Brian John Paul were married Sept. 6 at St. Augustine Church in Washington. The Rev. Patrick A. Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. On Sept. 7, Hermoine Randolph, a friend of the couple, led a nondenominational ceremony at Long View Gallery, an art gallery in Washington.

headline: Connie Chang, James Blakemore
abstract: The couple met in 2009 at the University of Michigan, from which they both received law degree
lead_paragraph: Connie Chang and James Michael Blakemore were married Sept. 7 at Solitude Mountain Resort, a ski resort in Solitude, Utah. Michael Horn, a friend of the couple who is a Universal Life minister, officiated, with William I. Miller, the couple's professor at the University of Michigan Law School, taking part in the ceremony.

headline: Shima Dowla, Zaki Anwar
abstract: The couple met in 2018 on Minder, a dating site for Muslims.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Shima Afroze Dowla and Zaki Usman Anwar were married Sept. 7 at the Hoover Crescent Islamic Center, a mosque in Hoover, Ala. Shaykh Hossam Musa, the imam of the Islamic Center of Greater Cincinnati, officiated.

headline: Lauretta Charlton, Andrew Russeth
abstract: The couple met in 2014 on the dating app Tinder.
lead_paragraph: Lauretta Corene Charlton and Andrew Richard Russeth were married Sept. 7 at the Headlands Center for the Arts in Sausalito, Calif. Bradley Peterson, a friend of the groom’s family who was deputized as a temporary officiant by Marin County, officiated.

headline: Marc Schechter, Evan Seigerman
abstract: The couple met in 2016 while biking from Boston to New York as part of the Cycle for the Cause, the Northeast AIDS Ride.
lead_paragraph: Marc Louis Schechter and Evan David Seigerman are to be married Sept. 8 at the Foundry, an events space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Alan J. Stadtmauer is to officiate.

headline: This Week’s Wedding Announcements
abstract: All of the weddings right here on one handy page for you.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Jane Hinchman and Ted DeDee met in October 2015 at the Overture Center for the Arts in Madison, Wis., where Mr. DeDee had been the president and chief executive. Ms. Hinchman had traveled from Chicago to see a student perform there and was pleasantly surprised when a friend introduced her to Mr. DeDee.

headline: Ralph Lauren: Spring 2020
abstract: Ralph Lauren Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: Ralph Lauren Spring 2020 Collection

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Country Music: Live at the Ryman’ and a Valerie Harper Tribute
abstract: Ken Burns hosts a concert leading up to the premiere of his new PBS documentary. And MeTV airs a three-hour marathon in honor of Ms. Harper.
lead_paragraph: COUNTRY MUSIC: LIVE AT THE RYMAN (2019) 8 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). Next week Ken Burns will unveil his newest documentary series: “Country Music,” an eight-part, 16-hour chronicle of the genre’s evolution that honors artists like the Carter Family and Dolly Parton. Gear up for that sonic journey with this concert special. Hosted by Burns and filmed in Nashville, Tenn., the event features appearances by several country artists, including Dierks Bentley, Rosanne Cash and Rhiannon Giddens.

headline: Boris Johnson Finds His Party Loyalists Aren’t as Loyal as Trump’s
abstract: However distasteful Republicans may find President Trump, they largely back his agenda. In Britain, rebels in the Conservative Party have staged a dramatic insurrection.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain and the United States have often seemed lashed together amid the populist storms of the last few years — Brexit and the Trump White House echoing and amplifying each other across the Atlantic. But in one respect they have radically diverged.

headline: Seven Reasons the Giants and Jets Will Be Worth Watching This Season
abstract: We wouldn’t say they are playoff bound. But both teams look to rebound from sad sack 2018 seasons.
lead_paragraph: Neither the Jets (4-12 in 2018) nor the Giants (5-11) gave anyone much to look at last season. This year portends change: for the Jets, it’s on the sideline with the new coach, Adam Gase, and the new defensive coordinator, Gregg Williams.

headline: Serena Williams Lost, but Her Legacy Is Winning
abstract: She was plowing through the U.S. Open toward what seemed like a fitting victory. But the future she helped create caught up to her.
lead_paragraph: It felt like destiny, like Serena Williams was playing with the caress of fate.

headline: Protesters Besiege Hong Kong After Rally Near U.S. Consulate
abstract: Protesters carrying American flags sought support for a bill in Congress that would punish Chinese officials who suppress freedoms in the city.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A pro-democracy demonstration on Sunday near the United States Consulate in Hong Kong quickly devolved into vandalism and street chaos, suggesting that protesters were not mollified by a recent concession from the city’s leader.

headline: Stephen King Visits an ‘Institute,’ Where the Kids Who Enter Can’t Escape
abstract: In his latest, King tells the story of an institution where children with special powers are cultivated — but that’s just where the nightmare begins.
lead_paragraph: I was a big reader before I discovered Stephen King, but his books pressed a lever in me. The best of his early novels — “The Shining,” “The Stand,” “Carrie” — came out while I was in grade school, and I read them each six times in class tucked under my desk. I thought my enthusiasm made me a horror fan, but then I tried other horror writers and that wasn’t it at all. I was a Stephen King fan. In terms of being able to tell a story, he was all by himself out in the HOV lane. He was hooting as he blew past.

headline: Alexa Demie, a Breakout Star of ‘Euphoria,’ Has Hidden Talents
abstract: The young actress is producing a film, recording music and dabbling in fashion.
lead_paragraph: Name: Alexa Demie

headline: The Florida Activist Is 78. The Legal Judgment Against Her Is $4 Million.
abstract: Environmental activists fear that Maggy Hurchalla’s case against a rock-mining company could have First Amendment ramifications.
lead_paragraph: STUART, Fla. — Maggy Hurchalla’s piece of Florida heaven is a patch of pristine Atlantic shore accessible only by boat in St. Lucie Inlet Preserve State Park. She and her husband nicknamed it the “End of the World” when they first came upon it half a century ago, after paddling south along the barrier island to the water’s end. She still likes to skinny-dip at the beach.

headline: The One-Two Punch That Second-Tier Democrats Are Counting On
abstract: The shrinking calendar has those who are lagging the front-runners looking for new life in their campaigns. The rationale for staying in the race is that Joseph R. Biden Jr. will fade.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Amy Klobuchar is going to spend nearly all her time and money on Iowa, visiting each of the state’s 99 counties with hopes that old-fashioned retail politics can inject new life into her campaign there.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Dominic Cummings, Boris Johnson’s Rasputin, Is Feeling the Heat of Brexit
abstract: A serial provocateur and political assassin, Mr. Cummings is the architect of the British government’s scorched-earth policy on Brexit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the melee that was the British Parliament last week, at least one person seemed to revel in the brutal politics of the era of Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

headline: Previously Unknown Sources Come Forward in a New Book About Harvey Weinstein
abstract: “She Said,” by The New York Times reporters Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey, names some of the people who turned against the influential producer, as well as ones who helped cover up his alleged predation.
lead_paragraph: Two years before the allegations of sexual harassment and abuse against Harvey Weinstein became public, his own brother and business partner, Bob Weinstein, confronted him, pleading with him to get medical treatment for what he described as many years of “misbehavior.”

headline: Bahamas, Vaping, Serena Williams: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Saudi King Appoints a Son, Prince Abdulaziz, as Energy Minister
abstract: Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman is the first member of the royal family to oversee the kingdom’s vital oil sector, part of a wider shake up of top energy-sector jobs.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — King Salman of Saudi Arabia on Sunday named his son Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman as energy minister, putting a member of the royal family for the first time in one of the kingdom’s most important roles, as part of a wider shake-up of top energy-sector jobs.

headline: The Week in Books
abstract: Margaret Atwood fans welcome “The Testaments,” new information about Harvey Weinstein and more.
lead_paragraph: With news buzzing about Margaret Atwood’s sequel to “The Handmaid’s Tale” and other hotly anticipated titles, it was an especially great week to be a book lover. We take the weekend to highlight recent books coverage in The Times.

headline: ‘I Took a Folding Chair, a Book and a Glass of Wine Up to the Roof’
abstract: A small problem on a warm Saturday evening, riding the M104 and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Taliban Talks Hit a Wall Over Deeper Disagreements, Officials Say
abstract: The insurgents were resisting a grand plan for finalizing and announcing the deal, which would have brought them to Camp David along with Afghan president.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even as President Trump blamed a recent Taliban attack for his decision to call off nearly yearlong negotiations with the insurgents, officials suggested on Sunday it had more to do with the Taliban’s resistance to the American terms for a peace deal, and a rushed plan for a Camp David summit meeting.

headline: ‘The Deuce’ Jumps Ahead to the ’80s and Sees the Future
abstract: Ahead of the show’s final season premiere, David Simon and George Pelecanos talked about its abiding poignancy and the legacy of 42nd Street.
lead_paragraph: In the seedy shadow world of HBO’s “The Deuce,” home to the flophouses, brothels, nightclubs and peep shows that once littered 42nd Street in Manhattan, an illicit subculture operates with its own rules and vicious hierarchies. The actions of the powerful reverberate down the chain, from the mobsters who control the area to the sex workers at the bottom. Along the way, the pornographers and dealers and pimps take their cut. And that’s before City Hall has its say.

headline: India Says It Has Located Chandrayaan-2 Lander on Moon’s Surface
abstract: The chief of the Indian space agency told reporters that the spacecraft’s condition was unclear, but that he expected it had experienced a “hard landing.”
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A day after India lost contact with a robotic spacecraft that was launched toward the moon’s South Pole, the chairman of the country’s space agency said on Sunday that the lander had been detected on the moon’s surface.

headline: Boy Thrown From Tate Modern Is Making ‘Amazing’ Progress
abstract: A 6-year-old boy suffered fractures and a brain hemorrhage after falling about 100 feet at the London museum. A month later, he smiles and sometimes laughs, his family said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A 6-year-old boy who was thrown from a balcony at the Tate Modern museum in London last month, suffering fractures and bleeding on the brain, is making “amazing progress,” his family says.

headline: Make T Something | Jason Wu
abstract: The fashion designer dresses one of his collectible Fashion Royalty dolls with a copy of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer dresses one of his collectible Fashion Royalty dolls with a copy of The New York Times.

headline: Watch Jason Wu Make a Dress Out of Newspaper
abstract: The designer is the latest person to accept the challenge to make something for T.
lead_paragraph: When the designer Jason Wu was 10 years old, his mother bought him his first sewing machine. Soon, he was teaching himself pattern-making, fitting and other techniques that would shape his precocious fashion career — all while designing dresses for his dolls. “My mom would take me to the fabric store and I’d get a quarter-yard of fabric,” says Wu. “That was where I spent my allowance.” Of course, these were not simple shifts. One of his early creations was a miniature version of a Christian Lacroix couture dress, made from silk. “It came out pretty well,” Wu remembers.

headline: Mark Sanford Will Challenge Trump in Republican Primary
abstract: Mr. Sanford, the former governor and representative from South Carolina who has become a fierce critic of the president, said he would focus his campaign on fiscal issues.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina said on Sunday that he would challenge President Trump for the Republican presidential nomination, criticizing Mr. Trump’s stewardship of government spending and the global economy and questioning the financial ethics of his administration.

headline: The Week in Business: Walmart Takes a Stand on Gun Control, and Brexit Goes Off the Rails
abstract: Plus, YouTube promises to stop collecting data from children, and Apple unveils new iPhones.
lead_paragraph: Just when you thought things couldn’t get crazier with Brexit, the China trade war and online privacy issues — well, they did. Here’s a quick rundown of the biggest stories in business and tech, and what to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles

headline: Gus Van Sant’s Next Picture Will Be a Watercolor
abstract: The acclaimed film director will show his new paintings in his first solo exhibition in New York. And no, this is not a passing hobby.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If you asked the auteur film director Gus Van Sant how long he has been painting, he might tell you about winning first prize at the annual art show in his hometown Darien, Conn., when he was 12. He might relate the influence of Jackson Pollock on his style as an 8-year-old. (It wasn’t such a big deal, he’d say. “It was really just because you could throw paint and that was a painting.”) He might even explain how, as a dual painting and film major at the Rhode Island School of Design, he dropped the art course because film “was harder, and I just didn’t know about it. I knew about painting.”

headline: After Trump Calls Off Talks, Afghanistan Braces for Violence
abstract: There were many questions about why Mr. Trump suddenly scuttled talks with the Taliban just as they were nearing a conclusion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s decision to break off peace talks with the Taliban, at least for now, left Afghanistan bracing for a bloody prelude to national elections this month, while the administration declined on Sunday to rule out a withdrawal of American troops without a peace accord.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Make Melissa Clark’s recipe for pasta with mussels and tomatoes, David Tanis’s green chile chicken stew, or Colu Henry’s broccoli and anchovy toasts.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There are people who can spend weekends and holidays dozing, doing nothing but marking the passage of the sun across the sky, waiting for someone to bring out the cocktail shaker, waiting for the bell for dinner, waiting on nothing at all. Gabrielle Hamilton is not one of them. She — like me, like this guy Eddie who was in her house share this summer, and about whom she wrote this week in The Times, like many — likes to get things done.

headline: ‘She Said’ Recounts How Two Times Reporters Broke the Harvey Weinstein Story
abstract: The new book, by Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey, revisits their landmark sexual-assault investigation and exposes the powerful people who protected Weinstein for years.
lead_paragraph: SHE SAIDBreaking the Sexual Harassment Story That Helped Ignite a MovementBy Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey

headline: Democrats to Broaden Impeachment Inquiry Into Trump to Corruption Accusations
abstract: Lawmakers plan to examine claims that the president dangled pardons to aides and that his resorts illegally profited from government business.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats return to Washington this week poised to significantly broaden their nascent impeachment inquiry into President Trump beyond the findings of the Russia investigation, but they will confront a fast-dwindling political clock.

headline: Tom Steyer Qualifies for October Debates, Bringing Field to 11
abstract: Mr. Steyer has made the cut for the Democratic presidential debates in October, though he will not be onstage this week. Tulsi Gabbard is also close to securing a spot.
lead_paragraph: Tom Steyer, the billionaire and former hedge fund investor turned impeachment activist, became the 11th Democratic presidential candidate to qualify for the October debates on Sunday after a new poll showed him with 2 percent support in Nevada.

headline: Before 1st Day of School, a Quiz on How to Use Your Giant Schoolbag
abstract: As students all over the world begin new school terms, German pupils’ experiences are rooted in special rites and a philosophy that teaches independence.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The school ruler must be an exact length. Each child is required to have three pairs of shoes: one for the classroom, one for outdoor sports and a third, with non-marking soles, for indoor sports. Their schoolbags must be reinforced, stand upright on their own and be able to carry pounds of homework.

headline: What We Eat Makes a Big Difference
abstract: Poor diet contributes not only to obesity, but also to devastating amounts of anxiety and depression.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Politics, Some Things Really Are Rigged
abstract: Readers say there is plentiful evidence of influence peddling, back- room deals and conflicts of interest. Also: How to make children become lifelong readers; New York’s Paris movie theater.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Here’s What We Learned in N.F.L. Week 1
abstract: The Cowboys looked sensational, the Patriots and the Chiefs rolled and the Chargers survived. But the big story was Lamar Jackson leading the Ravens to 59 points.
lead_paragraph: Should people draw too many conclusions after just one week of regular season football? Of course not. Will they? Of course they will. There was some serious excitement on Sunday — especially in Baltimore — helping wash away memories of Thursday’s lackluster season-opener in Chicago. Here’s what we learned:

headline: The Red Sox Confront a New Curse
abstract: No team has won back-to-back World Series since the start of this century. And you can get ready to add Boston to that list.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Ask Alex Cora about the difficulty of winning consecutive championships, and you’re setting him up for a punch line.

headline: ‘Chhichhore’ Review: In Mumbai, Good Old-Fashioned Rules Days
abstract: Nitesh Tiwari’s follow-up to “Dangal” has a sweetly bland message and not much fizz.
lead_paragraph: Don’t worry if you don’t get an A+ in math, kids. You are more than your successes in life, and more than your failures.

headline: Stanley Love, Choreographer Who Celebrated Joy, Dies at 49
abstract: With his own company, he created works for dancers of all skill levels, embracing spectacle, pop music and social dancing.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Love, an experimental choreographer who built a loyal following by instilling his dances with joy, vibrant physicality and his wild imagination, was found dead on Aug. 22 at his home in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. He was 49.

headline: Review: In ‘Bad News!,’ an Evening of Show and Tell
abstract: JoAnne Akalaitis’s show at N.Y.U. Skirball assembles messenger speeches from Ancient Greek drama, with a nod to the present.
lead_paragraph: Don’t shoot the messenger. Or poison, stab or hang him. Or bake him into a pie. Or tear him apart, mistaking him for a mountain lion. The messenger deserves a break. Because we all know that old showbiz advice: Show, don’t tell. But sometimes even the telling is bad and hard enough. Here’s one messenger: “I tell these stories/Suffering twice: feeling terrible pains/In telling it, suffering again what was already suffered.”

headline: Tory Burch: Spring 2020

lead_paragraph: Tory Burch Spring 2020 Collection

headline: ‘It Chapter Two’ Dominates Box Office
abstract: The Stephen King adaptation opened to about $91 million in domestic sales this weekend, squelching all competition but falling short of its predecessor.
lead_paragraph: Like the lone entertainer at a desolate children’s birthday party, “It Chapter Two” and its killer clown effectively took over movie theaters this weekend, making more money than the rest of the top ten movies combined.

headline: How Each Big Tech Company May Be Targeted by Regulators
abstract: While Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google have all drawn attention to how they dominate markets, the reasons are as different as the companies.
lead_paragraph: Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google have been the envy of corporate America, admired for their size, influence and remarkable growth.

headline: Kamala Harris Apologizes for Her Reaction to ‘Mentally Retarded’ Remark About Trump
abstract: The California senator, who was holding a town hall in New Hampshire on Friday, had laughed and told a supporter, “Well said.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Kamala Harris of California apologized on Saturday after a man attending a town hall called President Trump’s actions “mentally retarded” and she responded with a chuckle.

headline: Trump Backs Down, Again and Again
abstract: In the face of protest or pushback, the president reverses himself.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 7, the Trump administration quietly changed its immigration policy to end medical deferred action, a program that allows a small number of gravely ill immigrants to remain in the United States to receive lifesaving treatment. United States Citizenship and Immigration Services began sending notices to applicants that it would “no longer consider” such petitions, except from service members and their families. Applicants were warned that they had 33 days to leave the country or risk being deported and rendered ineligible for re-entry.

headline: Quadroon? Moor? Virginia Sued for Making Those Who Wed Say What They Are
abstract: A state law in Virginia requiring applicants for marriage licenses to specify their race is useless, offensive and unconstitutional, a federal lawsuit says.
lead_paragraph: [Please sign up here to have the Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.]

headline: Janelle Monáe With a Side of Tuxedo Dressing
abstract: Fashion week swung into action at Ralph Lauren’s Jazz Age nightclub. These days, who wants reality?
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night in Manhattan, Ralph Lauren took over the Bank of New York building, a 1920s edifice on Wall Street just across from Cipriani and cater-corner to the stock exchange, transformed in 2015 from financial headquarters to cavernous event space. And inside he built a nightclub.

headline: Nissan Board Set to Meet as It Faces a Leadership Crisis
abstract: Nissan’s board of directors will meet on Monday as the company confronts increasing doubts about the future of its chief executive, Hiroto Saikawa.
lead_paragraph: Nissan’s board of directors is set to meet on Monday as the company’s top executive, Hiroto Saikawa, faces a widening crisis of confidence in his leadership.

headline: Dorothea Benton Frank, Whose Novels Depicted Strong Women, Dies at 67
abstract: She had been a fashion buyer and executive before declaring, “I’m going to write a book and I’m going to sell a million copies and I’m going to buy Momma’s house back.’’
lead_paragraph: Dorothea Benton Frank, a gregarious Southern novelist whose career started on a dare — that she could write a book that would earn enough money to buy back her family house in South Carolina after her mother’s death — died on Sept. 2 in a hospital in Manhattan. She was 67.

headline: Underwear Ads Lose the Macho: How Marketing Has Embraced Real Men
abstract: Is it "woke-washing” or social progress? Inclusive commercials for men’s products draw praise and scorn as they turn away from the square-jawed stereotype.
lead_paragraph: Are you a man who plays dress-up with your daughter? Do you enjoy bowling, and are you terrible at it? Do you have hopes and dreams and insecurities and flaws and a belly that looks more like baked alaska than Hawaiian rolls?

headline: Brexit, Hong Kong, Afghanistan: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: How did the Afghan talks fall apart?
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Marca Bristo, Influential Advocate for the Disabled, Dies at 66
abstract: Paralyzed in an accident at 23, she devoted her life to changing perceptions of the disabled and was a key player in passing the Americans With Disabilities Act.
lead_paragraph: When she was 23, Marca Bristo, a nurse in Chicago, was sitting with a friend on the shore of Lake Michigan. Her friend’s dog accidentally knocked a prized pair of Ms. Bristo’s shoes into the water and, without a second thought, she dived in to retrieve them.

headline: A ‘Funky Winkerbean’ Tragedy
abstract: The comic strip, a newspaper staple since 1972, has a story line for the fall that will end with the death of a central character.
lead_paragraph: “Funky Winkerbean,” the rare comic strip that allows its characters to grow and age, starts a 10-week story line on Monday that contains a tragedy. Fans of the long-running strip who would like to be surprised by what happens to a major character may not want to read further.

headline: The World Wastes Tons of Food. A Grocery ‘Happy Hour’ Is One Answer.
abstract: Groceries and companies in Europe are cooperating with consumers to reduce $680 billion in food waste each year. Food near expiration turns into bargains.
lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland — “Happy hour” at the S-market store in the working-class neighborhood of Vallila happens far from the liquor aisles and isn’t exactly convivial. Nobody is here for drinks or a good time. They’re looking for a steep discount on a slab of pork.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 9, 2019
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.

abstract: Joi Ito’s fall from grace for his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein was much deserved. But his style of corner-cutting ethics is all too common in tech.
lead_paragraph: Voldemort?

headline: A School for Scandal Is a Haven for Student Journalists
abstract: As part of an investigative journalism program at the University of Southern California, a student found dozens of new sexual abuse allegations against a former campus doctor.
lead_paragraph: Students at the University of Southern California got a crash course in investigative journalism this summer by reporting on a powerful, scandal-ridden institution: their own school.

headline: Camilo Sesto, Spain’s Romantic Hitmaker, Is Dead at 72
abstract: With more than 2 dozen albums and more than 50 No. 1 hits worldwide, he was a pop superstar, singing about love and heartache.
lead_paragraph: Camilo Sesto, a Spanish songwriter, singer and producer whose romantic songs have sold more than 180 million copies worldwide, died on Sunday in Madrid. He was 72 and lived in Madrid.

lead_paragraph: Sies Marjan Spring 2020 Collection

headline: All 4 Crew Members Trapped on Overturned Cargo Ship Are Rescued
abstract: The Golden Ray, a 656-foot vehicle carrier, overturned early Sunday. The Coast Guard was engaged in several hours of intense rescue efforts on Monday.
lead_paragraph: All four crew members trapped inside a cargo ship off the coast of Georgia have been rescued, the Coast Guard said on Monday evening, ending a 40-hour effort that began when the 656-foot vessel overturned.

headline: The Jets of Old Manage to Step All Over a New Season
abstract: A 16-0 second-half lead went up in smoke, ruining all the good vibes provided by Le’Veon Bell in his first game in green.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Le’Veon Bell finally played his first football game in 20 months on Sunday, and the Jets kept him busy, calling his number on eight of their first 10 plays from scrimmage. He later caught a touchdown pass, and then an improvised 2-point conversion toss.

headline: They Rode Out Dorian in the Outer Banks. Now Comes the Hard Part.
abstract: After Ocracoke Island, N.C., was evacuated, residents who stayed behind saw their village inundated by a storm surge. In its wake, they are taking stock of flooded homes, wrecked businesses and upended lives.
lead_paragraph: OCRACOKE, N.C. — The baby was playing on the flooded floor again.

headline: Trump Campaign Manager Sees President’s Family as Political ‘Dynasty’
abstract: The comments by Brad Parscale were scrutinized for clues as to whether Mr. Trump’s children are indeed planning their own political futures.
lead_paragraph: President Trump may be the only member of his family to win major elected office, but his campaign manager for the 2020 re-election effort is already envisioning a family political dynasty that will outlast his time in the White House.

headline: Purr-haps
abstract: Dan Schoenholz gets punny with us.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Dan Schoenholz, he was running the alphabet with us, but in this puzzle, he has found an interesting quirk of the English language.

headline: Democrats Plan Vote to Formalize Procedures for Impeachment Investigation
abstract: The procedures could elicit more information about instances of possible obstruction of justice and abuses of power by President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Judiciary Committee plans to vote this week to formalize procedures for a growing impeachment inquiry, clarifying its investigative authorities and granting President Trump new due process, a draft resolution shows.

headline: Europe Keeps Asylum Seekers at a Distance, This Time in Rwanda
abstract: The European Union is preparing to pay Rwanda to host migrants evacuated from Libya, extending an outsourcing policy that is already under criticism.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — For three years, the European Union has been paying other countries to keep asylum seekers away from a Europe replete with populist and anti-migrant parties.

headline: Better Government for New York
abstract: A state commission has the power to enact public financing, and make New York’s elections more competitive.
lead_paragraph: New York this fall has the best chance in years to adopt a strong system of public financing. Done right, this new policy could increase competition and amplify the voices of small donors in elections. That is, if career politicians don’t kill it first.

headline: Attack Leaves Wall Street’s Iconic Bull With a Gash on Its Horn
abstract: A witness said a vandal repeatedly cursed President Trump as he struck the statue with a makeshift banjo.
lead_paragraph: The piercing noise of metal striking metal echoed through Wall Street just after noon on Saturday: A man was battering the bronze, 7,000-pound Charging Bull statue with a makeshift metal banjo.

headline: As New Faces Emerge, Serena Williams Gets Acquainted With Failure
abstract: Her loss to Bianca Andreescu on Saturday marked her fourth consecutive defeat in a Grand Slam final. For the moment, at least, she soldiers on.
lead_paragraph: The handwriting was not only on the wall for Serena Williams in this instance. It was on the check.

headline: Democrats, Stop Helping Trump
abstract: The 2020 election is too important.
lead_paragraph: How important do Democrats think it is to beat President Trump in 2020?

headline: In North Carolina Do-Over Vote, a Reliable Republican District Is Up for Grabs
abstract: The election in the Ninth Congressional District on Tuesday will in many ways be the first test of the political terrain heading into 2020, and of the two parties’ dueling strategies.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Bob Dylan’s nasally voice singing of changing times blasted from the speakers and Democratic activists crowded the patio of a craft-beer emporium on Friday as Megan and Christopher Kubala explained why, after a lifetime of ignoring midterm elections, they had just voted to elect the first Democrat since the civil rights era to represent their North Carolina congressional district.

headline: This Texan Showed That Liberals Can Fight and Have Fun, Too
abstract: Molly Ivins was a one-woman humor mill who understood that “the best way to get” politicians was “to make people laugh at them.”
lead_paragraph: It’s hard for me to believe that it’s already time for a revival of the life and work of Molly Ivins, the Texas journalist and political commentator who died in 2007 at age 62. But that’s what is happening with a new documentary, “Raise Hell: The Life and Times of Molly Ivins.”

headline: Corpses Strewn, People Missing a Week After Dorian Hit the Bahamas
abstract: The total number of those missing and dead may not be known for weeks, even months. But a walk through one of the hardest hit areas showed several bodies still exposed.
lead_paragraph: MARSH HARBOUR, Bahamas — The corpse was lying on its back, dressed in black shorts and a red shirt, arms outstretched, face toward the sky.

headline: Maps Don’t Lie
abstract: Unless someone goes out of his way to try to make one do so.
lead_paragraph: I’m still stuck on Sharpie-gate. Sorry. But, so is Donald Trump.

headline: Trophy Hunter Seeks to Import Parts of Rare Rhino He Paid $400,000 to Kill
abstract: The federal government is considered likely to approve a Michigan man’s application for the animal’s skin, skull and horns to come into the United States.
lead_paragraph: A Michigan trophy hunter who paid $400,000 to kill a rare black rhinoceros in Africa in 2018 is seeking a federal permit to allow him to import its skin, skull and horns to the United States, according to government records.

headline: How Trump’s Plan to Secretly Meet With the Taliban Came Together, and Fell Apart
abstract: What would have been one of the biggest headline-grabbing moments of President Trump’s tenure was put together on the spur of the moment and then canceled on the spur of the moment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the Friday before Labor Day, President Trump gathered top advisers in the Situation Room to consider what could be among the profound decisions of his presidency — a peace plan with the Taliban after 18 years of grinding, bloody war in Afghanistan.

headline: Cowboys’ Long Drives Keep Giants’ Saquon Barkley Off the Field

lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Saquon Barkley spent most of the first three quarters Sunday on the Giants’ sideline. He was not hurt or benched. To the contrary: On their second play from scrimmage, he surged through a hole, shook a Dallas defender and sprinted down the sideline for a 59-yard gain.

abstract: Nadal holds on for a five-set victory against Daniil Medvedev and is now one major championship away from tying Roger Federer’s record.
lead_paragraph: Moments after winning one of the most grueling tennis matches of his life, Rafael Nadal sat in his chair, a few tears streaming down his face while the large video screen showed highlights of his remarkable career.

headline: Review: In ‘American Moor,’ an Insider’s Guide to ‘Othello’
abstract: A new play argues that no one knows more about Shakespeare’s great tragedy than a man “born black in America.”
lead_paragraph: Is there anything as maddeningly, inherently unfair to an actor as an audition? Anything besides a review, that is?

headline: ‘Succession’ Season 2, Episode 5: Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner?
abstract: In yet another visit to yet another lavish estate, Shiv can’t stop sabotaging herself.
lead_paragraph: The ongoing “Succession” world tour makes a stop this week at yet another lavish country estate, for two days of earnest haggling and phony congeniality. In “Tern Haven,” the Roy clan treks from Manhattan to the ancestral home of Nan Pierce (Cherry Jones), the matriarch of a media empire respected as a force for truth and justice. The result? A classic “Succession” clash between two titanic know-it-alls.

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 5, Episode 3: Singin’ in the Pain
abstract: The show’s soapy trappings can mask how well it maps to the messiness that is adult life.

headline: Pelosi and Schumer, in Push for Gun Safety Legislation, Urge Trump to Defy N.R.A.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top two Democrats in Congress called on Sunday for President Trump to defy the National Rifle Association and get behind legislation, already passed by the House but blocked in the Senate, to expand background checks to nearly all gun buyers.

headline: Thriving Hotel Industry Scrambles for Workers
abstract: With more travelers and fewer job seekers nationwide, the tight job market is squeezing the hospitality industry.
lead_paragraph: The hotel industry is booming in the United States in pretty much every way, except in one that might matter most to guests: staffing.

abstract: The Air Force conceded that the decision to place a crew at the luxury resort this year “might be allowable but not advisable.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Air Force has ordered a review of its procedures used to decide where personnel are put up during overnight layovers, after conceding on Sunday that the decision to place a crew at the luxury resort owned by the Trump family in Scotland this year “might be allowable but not advisable.”

headline: After a Doubles Win, an Awkward Trophy Ceremony
abstract: Aryna Sabalenka thanked her possibly former coach after claiming a U.S. Open women’s doubles title.
lead_paragraph: In a United States Open women’s doubles final between four top singles players on Sunday afternoon, Aryna Sabalenka and Elise Mertens defeated Ashleigh Barty and Victoria Azarenka, 7-5, 7-5.

headline: The Women’s Super League Thanks You for Attending. Please Come Again.
abstract: Women’s soccer took the main stage in Europe over the weekend. But those who took part know progress will come not in one-time showcases, but in hard work week after week.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Just before she headed back to the changing room, back to the celebrations, Ellie Roebuck had one more job to do. A member of Manchester City’s social media team handed her an iPhone and asked her to record a short message.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The Deuce’ and a Monday Night Football Anniversary
abstract: The third season of “The Deuce” premieres on HBO. And Monday Night Football celebrates 50 years.
lead_paragraph: THE DEUCE 9 p.m. on HBO; Stream on HBO platforms. After two seasons exploring the rise of the porn industry in New York in the 1970s, the third picks up in the mid 1980s. Things have changed since the characters began their journey from a corrupt and dangerous Times Square but they continue to struggle to break free from the past. In the season premiere, Vincent (played by James Franco) inches toward his estranged wife Andrea, whom he left in Season 1, while his twin brother Frankie (also played Franco) continues to display his self destructive streak despite being married and having children. But it’s not only the past that exerts a gravitational pull. The future also beckons. Candy (Maggie Gyllenhaal), a former street prostitute who became a porn film director, disagrees with Harvey (David Krumholtz), a fellow director, about the changes affecting the industry when they travel together to a convention in Las Vegas.

headline: Australia Bushfires Arrive Early, Destroying Historic Lodge in ‘Omen’ of Future
abstract: Officials warned that climate change and drought threatened to bring Australia its worst fire season on record.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The conservationists who built the secluded Binna Burra Lodge in Australia’s lush mountains more than 80 years ago hoped to protect and share the natural beauty of the surrounding rainforest.

headline: Pyer Moss: Spring 2020
abstract: Pyer Moss Spring 2020 Collection
