headline: LeBron James Tried to Trademark ‘Taco Tuesday,’ but Got Swatted Away
abstract: The United States Patent and Trademark Office said that the phrase was “commonly used in everyday speech.”
lead_paragraph: “Taco Tuesday” got bad news on Wednesday.

headline: Quotation of the Day: From Symbolizing a Nation’s Future to Being a Tale of the Past
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 12, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “Did they have to start there? That was my bedroom.”

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Mr. Inbetween’ and ‘The Victim’
abstract: “Mr. Inbetween” returns to FX for a second season. And a new British mini-series is streaming on BritBox.
lead_paragraph: MR. INBETWEEN 10 p.m. on FX. Toggling between work and family life can be a challenge no matter your profession, but it’s especially trying for Ray Shoesmith, the contract killer at the center of this series. Outside of work, Ray is also raising a young daughter and trying to foster a new, post-divorce relationship. Played by the Australian actor and writer Scott Ryan, Ray spent the first season both nurturing life and taking it away, easing his daughter into the news that Santa isn’t real in one scene and having a shootout in another. In his review of that season for The New York Times, Mike Hale referred to the show as “another dark comedy about the divided soul of the 21st century male, caught between rage and cuddly vulnerability — in dramatic terms, between Scorsese and ‘Everybody Loves Raymond.’” The story, Hale added, “deftly and dryly exploits the gap between Ray’s violent occupation and his efforts to be a good father, boyfriend, brother, ex-husband and mentor.” Ray will continue straddling that gap in the second season, which debuts Thursday.

headline: Looking to Washington for a Retirement Lifeline
abstract: This fall, Congress is working on shoring up Social Security and pensions and expanded saving opportunities.
lead_paragraph: It is going to be a busy fall for legislators and regulators dealing with retirement policy.

headline: What Are My Long-Term Care Options?
abstract: The choices are numerous and confusing. Whether you’re looking for yourself or your parents, here is some guidance.
lead_paragraph: We were so confused.

headline: The Military’s New Retirement Option
abstract: The armed forces have stepped back from the pension “cliff,” and those in uniform will now get the kind of plan that is familiar to many civilians.
lead_paragraph: Gary Bass was 17 when he joined the Marines. “I really wanted to get out of my small town, and make a difference in the world,” he said.

headline: Faith in a ‘Hidden Paycheck’ That Could Vanish for Good
abstract: Retirees across the country are feeling the effects of underfunded pensions from religious organizations.
lead_paragraph: Retirement should be carefree for Ralph and Rosemarie Bryden in their 500-square-foot bungalow in rural Rhode Island. They garden and bowl, but financial worries loom.

headline: My Work Life Is Over. What’s Next?
abstract: Some retirees find themselves without a plan as they look for a new sense of purpose.
lead_paragraph: When Jeff Hutchinson, 65, retired two years ago after four decades with  Dominion Energy in Richmond, Va., he took a gap year to figure out what he wanted to do.

headline: Switching Gears to Retirement
abstract: If retirement looks like a vast wasteland awaiting you, here are some ways to find your bearings.
lead_paragraph: Here are 10 tips for navigating the emotional aspects of retirement.

headline: What Kamala Harris Needs to Do at the Debate Tonight
abstract: She had a great June debate and lost steam over the summer. Her surrogates, donors and even some supporters hope that in Houston she can recapture the magic that initially won them over.
lead_paragraph: The good news for Senator Kamala Harris of California is that all the political ingredients are there. Her campaign launch in Oakland remains the largest rally of any Democratic candidate this year, her Senate committee videos go viral and she ignited the most talked-about debate moment to this point, when she confronted the front-runner, Joseph R. Biden Jr., regarding his Senate record on school integration.

headline: Scammers Look for Vulnerability, and Find It in Older People
abstract: Swindlers prey on people over 70, who lose millions each year to their shifting tactics.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, Kathleen Eaton of Amelia Island, Fla., went online to buy a dog. She found a miniature black schnauzer named Holly at a site she thought was puppyspot.com. She emailed the company and was told she could get the dog for a discounted price of $750.

headline: Gucci Vies to Be Even Greener
abstract: Amid growing scrutiny, the luxury house aims to have a fully carbon-neutral supply chain before the end of September.
lead_paragraph: The race to be the most sustainable fashion brand is on.

headline: A New Monopoly Game Celebrates Women, but What About the One Behind the Original?
abstract: Hasbro’s Ms. Monopoly will pay women more than men and celebrate female inventors, but it makes only brief reference to the feminist whose board game is credited with inspiring it all.
lead_paragraph: There’s a new version of Monopoly coming, one that celebrates women by paying female players more than men.

headline: João Félix Is in a Hurry. So Is Everyone Else.
abstract: Félix has gone from Benfica’s academy to Cristiano Ronaldo’s heir apparent with dizzying speed. But how fast is too fast?
lead_paragraph: João Félix did not have to do anything special to make people believe. There was no light-bulb moment that convinced his coaches at Benfica that he was destined for greatness, no single heroic performance that marked him for superstardom. Even as a teenager — braces clamped to his teeth, hair swept forward over his eyes, shoulders slight — Félix was a love-at-first-sight sort of player.

headline: Extreme Weather Displaced a Record 7 Million in First Half of 2019
abstract: A new report puts 2019 on pace to be one of the most disastrous years in almost two decades even before the effects of Hurricane Dorian on the Bahamas are tallied. But there was also good news.
lead_paragraph: Extreme weather events displaced a record seven million people from their homes during the first six months of this year, a figure that put 2019 on pace to be one of the most disastrous years in almost two decades even before Hurricane Dorian battered the Bahamas.

headline: Late Night Doesn’t Find It Hard to Believe Trump Forgot a Son
abstract: The president’s odd reference to one of his children was comedic fodder for the late-night hosts. “At least Darth Vader claimed his son,” one said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: 20th-Century Rogues’ Gallery Gets a Modern Twist
abstract: An adventurous production of “Liliom,” the play that spawned “Carousel,” captivates by making its landscape an inner one.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Sometimes a play needs a change of scenery.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Right Answer? 8,186,699,633,530,061 (An Abacus Makes It Look Almost Easy)’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about national abacus tournaments in Japan. Why are they so popular and what does it take to win?
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “The Right Answer? 8,186,699,633,530,061 (An Abacus Makes It Look Almost Easy)”

headline: Stargazing in a War Zone: Veterans on Natural Beauty in Dangerous Places
abstract: Veterans share the moments during deployments when natural beauty took their breath away, even if just for a moment.
lead_paragraph: When my ship pulled into port in Sydney, Australia, on my second deployment, I found a bookstore and bought a star-chart and a guidebook to the Southern Hemisphere. I thought of my high school teacher Mike Pakenham, who told us in an elective astronomy course that we should all witness the beauty of the Southern Cross below the Equator for ourselves one day.

headline: He Wanted a Little Charm Downtown — on a Budget. Which Place Did He Choose?
abstract: A first-time buyer hunts for a unique one-bedroom with a ‘homey vibe’ for under $650,000. Is that possible below 14th Street?
lead_paragraph: A first-time buyer hunts for a unique one-bedroom with a ‘homey vibe’ for under $650,000. Is that possible below 14th Street?

headline: Why Imani Perry Doesn’t Like Jane Austen’s Novels
abstract: The scholar and author, whose new book is “Breathe: A Letter to My Sons,” is “not engaged by books which I think of as ‘parlor people’ literature.”
lead_paragraph: The scholar and author, whose new book is “Breathe: A Letter to My Sons,” is “not engaged by books which I think of as ‘parlor people’ literature.”

headline: We Know It Harms Kids to See Smoking on TV. What About Rape?
abstract: Just as research suggests that we should shield young viewers from seeing fictional depictions of smoking and suicide, studies indicate that watching rape scenes can also do harm.
lead_paragraph: Recently, Netflix announced that it would not include depictions of smoking in any new programming aimed at younger viewers. In a similar vein, on the advice of medical experts, it has removed the suicide scene from the first season of its teen drama “13 Reasons Why.”

headline: Officers Said They Smelled Pot. The Judge Called Them Liars.
abstract: Courts in New York have long ruled that if a car smells like pot, the police can search it. But now, a backlash is mounting.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: What People Say About the Economy Can Set Off a Recession
abstract: Big economic changes come when popular narratives mutate and spread, infecting the decisions of millions of people, the economist Robert J. Shiller says.
lead_paragraph: When will the next recession arrive?

headline: How Jewish Should the Jewish State Be? The Question Shadows an Israeli Vote
abstract: The long-simmering conflict between Israel’s secular and religious Jews takes center stage in the national election on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For years, the resentment had been building.

headline: ‘You Oughta Know’: The Road to Making a ’90s Anthem a Broadway Hit
abstract: In the new musical “Jagged Little Pill,” Alanis Morissette’s song about romantic betrayal has become a showstopper.
lead_paragraph: Alanis Morissette wrote “You Oughta Know,” the first single from “Jagged Little Pill,” her breakthrough 1995 album, “because I needed to get it out of my body,” she said.

headline: The Most Instagrammable Neighborhood in America, Before It Was Cool
abstract: #dumbo
lead_paragraph: The view of the Manhattan Bridge from Dumbo has become so Instagram-famous that it has entered the realm of the Eiffel Tower and latte foam: People take pictures of it because people take pictures of it.

headline: ‘Simply Unacceptable’: Executives Demand Senate Action on Gun Violence
abstract: “Doing nothing about America’s gun violence crisis is simply unacceptable,” the corporate chiefs urged senators in a letter.
lead_paragraph: In a direct and urgent call to address gun violence in America, the chief executives of some of the nation’s best-known companies sent a letter to Senate leaders on Thursday, urging an expansion of background checks to all firearms sales and stronger “red flag” laws.

headline: ‘Little Women’: An Oral History of the 1994 Adaptation
abstract: Claire Danes’s wig caught fire and Winona Ryder put it out; Christian Bale taught castmates the “Newsies” dances; and studio executives were shocked, shocked that a girls’ tale worked.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, a year of testosterone-heavy films like “Pulp Fiction” and “The Shawshank Redemption,” a female director teamed up with a female producer, female writer and female-led cast to make a movie based on a book by a female author. Male studio executives wrote off “Little Women,” the third big-screen adaptation chronicling the 19th-century March sisters, as mere family Christmas sap ahead of its December release. But those involved in the project knew they were working on something special.

headline: 18 Years After 9/11, Giving ‘Light to the Fallen’
abstract: Thursday: Outside the official ceremony, people showed up to pay respects from afar.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Should Students Get Mental Health Days Off From School?
abstract: Two states recently passed laws that allow students to take time off for their mental health. Do you wish your school gave you the option?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever felt so overwhelmed, stressed, anxious or depressed that you thought you needed a day off from school to reset?

headline: Hong Kong Protesters, Without an Anthem to Sing, Create One Online
abstract: “Glory to Hong Kong,” created less than three weeks ago, has rapidly been adopted as a symbol of the pro-democracy movement.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — More than ever before, Hong Kong soccer fans were in no mood to hear the Chinese national anthem.

headline: 36 Hours in Geneva
abstract: At once deeply Swiss and intrinsically international, this city on the shores of Lake Geneva has carved out its own place in the world.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to forget that Geneva, a city that’s practically synonymous with international diplomacy, has an identity quite apart from its status as a global hub. But Geneva’s historic heart was already a couple of thousand years old when the United Nations came to town, and the city’s residents — newcomers and natives alike — still fiercely embrace traditions that have been celebrated here for centuries. Paris or Rome it isn’t, but then Geneva isn’t vying to be one of the megastars of Europe. At once deeply Swiss and intrinsically international, the city has carved out its own place in the world, which it occupies with pride.

headline: E-Cigarettes, Justify, Democratic Debate: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

headline: The Seminary Flourished on Slave Labor. Now It’s Planning to Pay Reparations.
abstract: The Virginia Theological Seminary is setting aside $1.7 million to atone for its role in American slavery.
lead_paragraph: By the time Phillips Brooks arrived at the Virginia Theological Seminary in 1856, the institution was thriving. Founded more than three decades earlier in the Sunday school room of a church in Alexandria, Va., the seminary sat on a 62-acre estate with lush meadows and views of the rising Washington Monument.

headline: Blue Skies Ahead for Cheap Flights, But Read the Fine Print
abstract: More no-frills carriers as well as major airlines are offering deals on international flights. Just book ahead and be wary of ancillary fees — they can really add up.
lead_paragraph: Turbulence in the budget airline industry continues to be expected. But for savvy leisure travelers looking for international flights, there are more ups than downs right now.

headline: How a Photographer Showed Lives Haunted by Military Sexual Trauma
abstract: Pictures of men who were assaulted in the military reveal a profound sense of trust between  Mary F. Calvert and her subjects.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Should You Spend, or Save, as if You’ll Live Forever?
abstract: How young you feel can influence how you handle your money, research shows.
lead_paragraph: Parents spending days chasing young children around will complain that they feel far older than their years. But their parents — if they have their health and a bit of wealth — are just as likely to say how young and vital they feel, better than they imagined 60, 70 or even 80 could be.

headline: Jane Goodall Keeps Going, With a Lot of Hope (and a Bit of Whiskey)
abstract: During her girlhood, Tarzan was her role model. When she realized how chimpanzee habitats were being destroyed, she turned into a crusader. At 85, she’s still preaching.
lead_paragraph: Jane Goodall nursed a glass of neat Irish whiskey. It was the end of a long day of public appearances, and her voice was giving out.

abstract: And is the Democratic Party doing too much to cull their presidential field?

headline: An Open Letter (and a Rant) on Age Discrimination at Work
abstract: One writer, in his 50s, has applied to more than 100 jobs. And a second has had it up to her silver bob with younger colleagues’ condescension.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, even if you want them withheld. Letters may be edited.

headline: Cindy Crawford, Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan: An ’80s Fashion Mystery
abstract: Thousands of slides tossed in the garbage a decade ago capture the golden age of New York fashion.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: ‘Cracked Up’ Review: A Master Mimic Searches for Himself
abstract: In this documentary, Darrell Hammond, a former stalwart of “Saturday Night Live,” emerges as a riveting, eccentric character.
lead_paragraph: When you perform a multitude of comic voices, it’s easy for your own to get lost.

headline: Striking Out
abstract: What story could this image tell?
lead_paragraph: What story could this image tell?

headline: Poem: axolotl
abstract: In an invocation for the endangered Mexican walking fish, the poet praises the intrinsic healing power of beings, a power greater than all governments or public pronouncements.
lead_paragraph: “I will not surrender my heart,” the tenderly ferocious poet ire’ne lara silva has said. “I will not surrender my art. My poems and my stories are what I have to give in this world.” Here, in her invocation for the endangered axolotl — Ambystoma mexicanum, also known as the Mexican walking fish (which is an amphibian resembling a smiling, translucent salamander) — she praises the intrinsic healing power of beings, a power greater than all governments or public pronouncements. It’s the gentle force of organic, elemental restoration; the song that keeps people singing even when the news grabs them by the throat. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: Word + Quiz: specious
abstract: This word has appeared in 42 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Art That Is Political and Personal
abstract: Shirin Neshat’s work touches on topics like exile, political revolution and Iran’s past and future.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a new series on Visionaries. The New York Times selected people from all over the world who are pushing the boundaries of their fields, from science and technology to culture and sports.

headline: Angelina Jolie Is Back as Maleficent. Her Wings Are, Too.
abstract: Angelina Jolie has a new mission and a new wardrobe in “Maleficent: Mistress of Evil”. The movie’s costume designer explains how the original film and the follow-up led to these looks.
lead_paragraph: The fairy tale continues, and the clothes are still fabulous.

headline: A Marathoner and His Amputee Sister Take to the Water
abstract: His two feet have carried him for thousands of miles. His sister has only one.
lead_paragraph: For the past half century, I’ve run thousands of hours with my brother, and with my sister Natalie’s husband and her son. We are all marathoners. Running is our thing. I’ve done no training with Nat; she can’t run. She was born with lymphangioma in the right foot and had a just-below-the-knee amputation at age 9. I was 15 at the time, her oldest sibling.

headline: Cynthia Erivo: We Need Harriet Tubman’s Story of Strength Right Now
abstract: The actress explains what she learned preparing to take on the title role in the first major biopic of the abolitionist.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to government delays, it might be a while before Harriet Tubman appears on the $20 bill, but in November the formidable abolitionist will burst onto movie screens.

headline: S.U.V. vs. Sedan, and Detroit vs. the World, in a Fight for the Future
abstract: In 2019 in the U.S., sport utility vehicles and pickups are grabbing a record 70 percent of the market. Asian and European automakers see things differently.
lead_paragraph: The humble family sedan was once inseparable from American culture, the prime mover of suburban commutes and summer road trips. But most Detroit automakers are ridding their lineups of sedans and diverting investment to S.U.V.s and crossovers, not to mention electric vehicles and self-driving tech.

headline: Over 50 and Freelancing to Fill the Gaps in Retirement Funds
abstract: Whether they chose to retire or were forced out of a job, a significant chunk of American workers over the age of 50 are finding they need to reinvent themselves.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, after 41 years of teaching business management, Charlotte Bishop decided to retire from her job at the Borough of Manhattan Community College. She was in her early 60s, had raised two sons as a single mother in the Bronx and wanted to spend more time with her grandchildren.

headline: You Call It the Gig Economy. California Calls It ‘Feudalism.’
abstract: A bill will drive a national debate over how to reshape labor laws so that workers get their fair share in a service and knowledge economy.
lead_paragraph: Labor leaders cheered in the balcony and lawmakers embraced on the floor of the California Senate on Tuesday as it passed a landmark measure that defines employees, a move that could increase wages and benefits for hundreds of thousands of struggling workers.

headline: Romancing the Feng Shui
abstract: Was I blocking love in my Harlem apartment? Could clearing out under my bed open the door to my love life?
lead_paragraph: There I was crying in my kitchen.

headline: Religious Crusaders at the Supreme Court’s Gates
abstract: Conservative justices appear eager to take on a subject at the heart of the country’s culture wars.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision in last term’s big religion case, on the constitutionality of a Latin cross that stands 40 feet tall on public land in Bladensburg, Md., left both sides in the religion wars unsatisfied. The court’s several opinions, adding up to seven votes to keep the cross in place, disappointed the secularists who brought the lawsuit seeking to have it removed. But the narrow holding, based on the history of this particular monument, was even more frustrating to those who hoped that the court, already tilting noticeably in favor of religion in particular contexts, would go further and adopt new rules for lowering the barrier between church and state across the board.

headline: A Strong Bipartisan Path to Tackle Gun Violence
abstract: A red flag law will reduce bloodshed and respect the rights of gun owners.
lead_paragraph: After a string of mass shootings this summer, Americans are demanding a response to curtail the violence. If we are looking to deliver a solution that reduces bloodshed and respects the rights of responsible gun owners, the only realistic action must be bipartisan.

headline: An Interview With Andrew Yang, an Outsider at Tonight’s Democratic Debate
abstract: Mr. Yang, a former tech executive, has qualified for a spot when several better-known lawmakers did not. What has made his campaign so unexpectedly compelling?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: What ‘Retirement’ Means Now
abstract: The vision of life after 65 for American workers has changed. So has what it takes to make it all happen.
lead_paragraph: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, by 2028 there will be 43 million people 55 and older in the work force — nearly one-quarter of all workers. Yet even as they age, the word retirement is becoming less and less clear. For starters, people have the potential to live well into their 70s and 80s and beyond, which often makes a plan of retiring in one’s 60s less necessary or desirable.

headline: DealBook Briefing: C.E.O.s Demand More Gun Control
abstract: The heads of 145 companies sent a letter to Senate leaders calling for an expansion of background checks to firearms sales and stronger gun laws.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning. I’m in Washington this afternoon for the DealBook D.C. Summit, where other NYT journalists and I will talk with business and policy leaders about trade, antitrust and more. You can watch my interview with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin at 5 p.m. Eastern here. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: At a Maternity Center Near a War Zone, 20 Births in One Day
abstract: A hospital in a remote area of Afghanistan is a haven for impoverished mothers and newborns in a country ravaged by war.
lead_paragraph: ANABAH, Afghanistan — He was a few minutes old; a fussy, wriggling baby in a heated bassinet. He let out a squawk when a neonatal nurse plunged a vitamin K injection into his thigh.

headline: ‘Moonlight Sonata’ Review: A Deaf Family Connected by Beethoven
abstract: Irene Taylor Brodsky makes a documentary about her son, her father and a master composer.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Moonlight Sonata: Deafness in Three Movements” places the work of Ludwig van Beethoven in an intimately modern context. Like the storied composer at the end of his career, the filmmaker Irene Taylor Brodsky’s 11-year-old son and her parents are deaf. In this sweet, but formally unimaginative film, deafness is observed through three generations: Brodsky’s child, her parents and, in brief animations, the long-gone artist.

headline: On Politics: It’s Debate Day
abstract: The top 10 Democrats will be on a single stage for the first time on Thursday. Here are the key dynamics to watch for.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning, and happy debate day. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

headline: ‘Ms. Purple’ Review: The Ties That Bind (and Sometimes Strangle)
abstract: A moody, downbeat drama that occasionally offers glimmers of hope, Justin Chon’s film follows two Korean-American siblings struggling to reconnect while their father is dying.

headline: ‘América’ Review: A Matriarch’s Illness Unites and Divides a Family
abstract: Filmed in Mexico, this tender and subtle documentary follows the struggles of three young men to care for their beloved aging grandmother.
lead_paragraph: Two near-constant features of “América,” an artful, winning documentary directed by Erick Stoll and Chase Whiteside, are the mostly contented chirping of birds and the light rustle of wind moving through the trees. They lend a sense of an idyll to a fraught family story that insists on the glory of living even as it shows its title character reconciling herself to the art of dying.

headline: ‘American Dreamer’ Review: Jim Gaffigan’s Cinematic Nightmare
abstract: Even Gaffigan’s creditable turn as a troubled rideshare driver can’t save this disaster of a crime film.
lead_paragraph: As an actor, comedian and author, the portly Jim Gaffigan (it’s O.K. to call him portly; he does so himself in his book “Dad Is Fat”) has made American male semi-loserdom one of his primary subjects. In “American Dreamer” he goes much harder.

headline: ‘Another Day of Life’ Review: A Memoir of War, in Full Color
abstract: The work of the storied journalist Ryszard Kapuscinski, who covered the Angolan civil war, among many other conflicts, is animated here.
lead_paragraph: Although “Another Day of Life” is coming to theaters from the animation distributor Gkids, it is in no way intended for children. Inspired by the book of the same title by the Polish journalist Ryszard Kapuscinski (1932-2007), the movie is a harrowing chronicle of his time covering the civil war in the former Portuguese colony of Angola, beginning in 1975. For ideological reasons, and because the country was rich in diamonds and oil, the conflict was drawn into Cold War geopolitics.

headline: Need a Hug? Just Ask the Yankees’ Cameron Maybin
abstract: The Yankees’ veteran outfielder loves to hug, and gives one out after every home run his teammates hit. This year, that’s meant a lot of hugs.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Brett Gardner isn’t a big hugger. Yet, like all of the Yankees this season, he has grown accustomed to the enveloping embrace of Cameron Maybin after a trip around the bases.

headline: ‘Monos’ Review: Teenage Fighters Tussle Over Discipline and a Cow
abstract: This sophisticated-looking film by Alejandro Landes is an allegory with little clarity about its subject matter.
lead_paragraph: High on a mountaintop in Colombia, a raggedy pack of teenagers who answer to names including “Rambo,” “Smurf,” “Wolf,” “Dog” and “Bigfoot” receive supervision, intermittently, from a little person on horseback. These boys and girls have guns, an adult hostage from the United States and, soon, a cow. Their overseer tells them to look after the cow with care, as it is a source of milk. Consequences will rebound if harm comes to the cow.

headline: ‘Depraved’ Review: Busy Body (Parts)
abstract: Larry Fessenden updates Mary Shelley’s classic tale, “Frankenstein,” producing possibly his most coherent and visually polished work yet.
lead_paragraph: Henry (David Call), the doctor in Larry Fessenden’s “Depraved,” isn’t actually called Frankenstein, but he’s the contemporary equivalent. A onetime Army surgeon, Henry suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder and a maniacal need to make positive use of his harrowing experiences. What he learned about death, he believes, he can use to create life.

headline: ‘The Sound of Silence’ Review: Plenty to Hear, but What Does It Mean?
abstract: Peter Sarsgaard and Rashida Jones star in a drama for your ears that brings big ideas but does more telling than showing.
lead_paragraph: There’s something about a movie that goes out of its way to embrace the quiet — to make the audience really listen and be fully aware of every snippet of sound or sliver of silence — that feels refreshingly rare. In a medium that can be so reliant on character banter and song-stuffed sound cues, it can be powerful to be forced to concentrate on hearing noiselessness, so that the little sound that does occur is that much more meaningful.

headline: ‘Redistribution’ Review: An Art World Figure Tries to ‘Evacuate Cinema’
abstract: The artist Seth Price’s documentary is showing as a movie, but that’s not really what it is.

headline: Russia Raids Offices and Homes of Navalny Allies
abstract: A wave of raids nationwide took aim at allies of Aleksei A. Navalny, the leading Putin critic, as the Kremlin tries to keep dissent from spreading beyond Moscow.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a nationwide crackdown to prevent discontent in Moscow from spreading to far-flung regions, Russian security forces on Thursday raided and searched hundreds of homes and offices of activists across the country who were affiliated with the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny.

headline: Elizabeth Warren’s Social Security Plan: Raise Benefits by $200 a Month
abstract: In her latest proposal to redistribute wealth in the United States, Ms. Warren calls for raising taxes on the rich to expand Social Security benefits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts unveiled a plan on Thursday to give all recipients of Social Security benefits an extra $200 per month and to pay for it by raising taxes on the rich, her latest economic proposal to redistribute wealth in the United States.

headline: Couple’s Trek Across Continents Ended in an Iranian Prison
abstract: Jolie King and Mark Firkin were on a once-in-a-lifetime journey from Australia to Britain. They documented it all on social media and a website, but then the posts suddenly stopped.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In 2017, Jolie King and Mark Firkin hit the road in a white Toyota Land Cruiser, beginning a journey that over the next two years would take them from their home in Perth, Australia, across large stretches of Asia as they meandered toward Europe.

headline: Demi Moore Lets Her Guard Down
abstract: After years of scrutiny for her career, relationships and setbacks, the movie star hopes the public sees another side in her memoir, “Inside Out.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A few days after I visited Demi Moore in her home high above Beverly Hills, her daughter Tallulah Willis told me, “My mom was not raised, she was forged.”

headline: E.C.B. Acts to Head Off Recession Threat in Europe, With a Caveat
abstract: The bank announced measures to stimulate eurozone growth, but will face questions about what else it can do if the economy fails to respond.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank took unexpectedly aggressive steps on Thursday to head off a downturn before it gained momentum, but the bank signaled that it was reaching the limits of what it could do to stimulate the eurozone economy.

headline: The Rebirth of New York Fashion
abstract: Marc Jacobs beautifully acknowledges an end, and marks a beginning.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week came to an end in 2001 with a Marc Jacobs show because of tragedy: The morning after his extravaganza on Pier 54, complete with disappearing walls to access the after-party and Donald Trump in the audience, the planes hit the Twin Towers and the world changed.

headline: Alison Cheek, Pioneering Episcopal Priest, Is Dead at 92
abstract: In a controversial 1974 ceremony, she and 10 other women became priests. Then she became the first to celebrate the Eucharist in an Episcopal church.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Alison Cheek, who in 1974 was one of 11 women who defied the male hierarchy of the Episcopal Church to be ordained as priests, then later that year became the first female priest to celebrate the Eucharist in an Episcopal service, died on Sept. 1 at her home in Brevard, N.C. She was 92.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Westport, Conn., and Armonk, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Westport, Conn., and Armonk, N.Y.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are this week’s properties are in Prospect Heights, Jackson Heights and Carnegie Hill.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are this week’s properties are in Prospect Heights, Jackson Heights and Carnegie Hill.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Westport, Conn., and Armonk, N.Y.

abstract: This week’s properties are in Prospect Heights, Jackson Heights and Carnegie Hill.

headline: Trump Administration Rolls Back Clean Water Protections
abstract: The administration is expected to complete the  repeal of a major Obama-era regulation that  put limits on  chemicals that could be used near streams, wetlands and water bodies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Thursday announced the repeal of a major Obama-era clean water regulation that had placed limits on polluting chemicals that could be used near streams, wetlands and other bodies of water.

headline: How to Do Better Than Merely Getting Ahead
abstract: Outracing the pack is overrated. But defining enough and then stopping there? It may be the best life shift you’ve made in ages.
lead_paragraph: Getting ahead is overrated as a goal. In fact, it might even be just plain stupid.

headline: Trump Wants Big Diplomatic Wins. Here Are the Odds.
abstract: John R. Bolton has left the Situation Room — and has left a series of gambles behind that President Trump must manage between now and Election Day.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John R. Bolton has left the Situation Room, and President Trump is left at the table with a giant set of chips set on hot spots around the world.

headline: Elizabeth Warren’s Plan for Social Security Looks Smart
abstract: The elderly have also suffered from extreme inequality.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Where Are People Buying New Condos in New York?
abstract: Manhattan led the way in sales among new developments, with Brooklyn and Queens in the running.
lead_paragraph: Although sales of new condominiums in New York City have been relatively slow in 2019 — the luxury market peaked around 2016 — apartments in brand-new buildings continued to move in the first six months of this year, especially in Manhattan.

headline: Stocks Climb Toward Record as Trade Tensions Ease Further
abstract: Other financial markets are also showing signs that investors are less panicked about a recession in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Stocks in the United States closed in on a record high on Thursday, as Washington and Beijing took steps to reduce the tensions between them over trade.

headline: Writer’s Voice: ‘Intolerance and Love in Jamaica’
abstract: Ideas for helping students find and write in their own real voices, with an example from The Times’s “Lives” column to help.
lead_paragraph: Our new Mentor Text series spotlights writing from The Times that students can learn from and emulate.

headline: Dropping the Reader Into a Scene: ‘A Wedding Dress I Never Expected: A Sari’
abstract: Experimenting with a technique that can grab the reader’s attention, with an example from the Lives column to help.
lead_paragraph: Our new Mentor Text series spotlights writing from The Times that students can learn from and emulate.

headline: For Poison Dart Frogs, Markings Matter When It Comes to Survival
abstract: An experiment found that white-striped frogs were less effective at scaring off predators than frogs with yellow stripes. Yet both populations are thriving.
lead_paragraph: The fanciful colored markings of poison dart frogs are a warning to predators: If you eat me, you’ll regret it.

headline: Writing Dialogue: ‘The Missing Piece Son’
abstract: Considering the role of dialogue in a narrative, with an example from The Times’s Lives column to help.
lead_paragraph: Our new Mentor Text series spotlights writing from The Times that students can learn from and emulate.

headline: Review: In the Entrancing ‘Undone,’ Life Is but a Dream State
abstract: The Amazon series is the latest to use otherworldly animation to explore the aftermath of trauma.
lead_paragraph: “Is this a dream?” Alma (Rosa Salazar) asks her father, Jacob (Bob Odenkirk), in the second episode of “Undone.”

headline: What Time Is the September Democratic Debate?
abstract: Everything you need to know about the presidential primary debate in Houston.
lead_paragraph: Quick, name the most substantive discussion of foreign policy you have heard during the nearly 10 hours of debates so far. Struggling? Yes, foreign affairs has played a minimal role so far in the Democratic primary debates but that could change on Thursday night.

headline: 10 Months of Classical Concerts You Won’t Want to Miss
abstract: Yes, many musicians are celebrating Beethoven’s 250th birthday this season, but there’s much more. (Even a viola festival!)
lead_paragraph: Dates are subject to change.

headline: Don’t Miss These Art Shows and Events This Fall
abstract: Mark your calendar. From a revamped MoMA and the fearless Pope.L to Renaissance sculptors and female modernists, here are more than 100 shows that define the new season.
lead_paragraph: It’s a season of debuts for artists — from Renaissance masters never before seen in New York to jazz pianists with breakout museum shows — and also for real estate. In addition to the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council’s 40,000-square-foot arts center at Governors Island and Pace Gallery’s new flagship tower in Chelsea, both slated to open in September, the Museum of Modern Art reopens after an extensive renovation and expansion on Oct. 21. You’ll find these highlights, and more than 100 others, below, including watercolors, pastels, immigrant stories, fairs and a full year of women-centered art shows in Baltimore.

headline: Coming to TV This Fall: Everything
abstract: Here’s our exhaustive new-show roundup of a very crowded season.
lead_paragraph: There may never have been a fall television season as jam packed as the one we’re about to endure. New titans are arriving, dropping their generously financed catalogs into an already saturated market. The new wave of potential Netflix killers begins with the arrivals of the Apple TV Plus and Disney Plus streaming services on Nov. 1 and Nov. 12, each debuting with a small but buzzy roster of original series.

headline: All the Ways to Fall for Dance This Autumn
abstract: Ready for a “Nutcracker” set to Duke Ellington? The season offers new twists on old classics, as well as a multitude of premieres across genres.
lead_paragraph: Dates are subject to change.

headline: A Fashion Designer Begins Anew in Detroit
abstract: Tracy Reese, whose dresses were worn by Michelle Obama, starts a sustainable brand in the city where she grew up.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — If you come from a place that has exported its tastes in design, architecture, fashion and music to a welcoming audience for well over a century; a place steeped in art made of broken glass and low-slung homes with triple-thick brick walls; a place where the bottom fell out in a dizzying way, but where retailers and hoteliers and college students and everyday workers are walking the comeback trail together, you have a healthy respect for adversity, and for problem solving.

headline: Overlooked No More: Mihri Rassim, Feminist Artist in the Ottoman Empire
abstract: In conservative Turkey, she sought the same artistic freedoms that men were granted, championed art education for women and ultimately left for the United States to pursue her ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Overlooked is a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: House Judiciary Committee Inches Toward Impeachment
abstract: The panel set rules to explore possible impeachment of President Trump, hoping to show courts and impatient Democrats that it is building a case.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Judiciary Committee on Thursday took its first recorded vote to press forward with a possible impeachment of President Trump, putting aside Democrats’ internal divisions for the time being in a bid to strengthen its hand in investigating whether he committed high crimes and misdemeanors.

headline: 77 Pop and Jazz Albums, Shows and Festivals Coming This Fall
abstract: Buzzy artists (King Princess, Young M.A), enduring performers (Neil Young, Madonna) and musicians dabbling in fresh mediums (Tegan and Sara, Sturgill Simpson) are coming in the new season.
lead_paragraph: This fall’s music calendar will feature emerging artists, established legends and unearthed gems. Dates are subject to change. You can listen to a playlist of songs on Spotify from the fall preview here.

headline: Beekeepers Confront the E.P.A. Over Pesticides
abstract: Leaders in the beekeeping industry have sued the environmental agency over its approval of the use of a pesticide that has harmed colonies.
lead_paragraph: Honeybees and other pollinating insects are crucial helpers in putting food on American tables. But the bees’ colonies have declined over the years, leading concerned beekeepers and scientists to speculate about the causes.

headline: Kim Clijsters Announces (Another) Return to Tennis
abstract: The former U.S. Open champion, 36, says she will end her second retirement from the sport next year.
lead_paragraph: As if women’s tennis did not have enough rich story lines at the moment, Kim Clijsters added another on Thursday by announcing her intent to return to competition in 2020.

headline: Misha Nonoo, Close Personal Friend of Meghan Markle, Speaks
abstract: When your friend becomes a royal, the clothing designer said, “nothing changes.” You just can’t discuss logistics.
lead_paragraph: You are likely either to know at least two or otherwise none of the following things about Misha Nonoo:

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Sept. 18, 2019
abstract: Women’s professional tennis includes four annual Grand Slam tournaments: Wimbledon, the United States Open, the French Open and the Australian Open.
lead_paragraph: This graph originally appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com. By Friday morning, Sept. 20, we will provide the “Reveal” — the graph’s free online link, additional background and questions, shout outs to student comments and headlines, and Stat Nuggets.

headline: No One Saw America as Clearly as Robert Frank
abstract: The work of this legendary photographer is proof that a photograph never lies about the photographer.
lead_paragraph: There are just a few photographers who create a body of work that commands your attention. For me, the legendary Robert Frank was one of them.

headline: Four Key Things You Should Know About Health Care
abstract: Yes, it’s a complicated issue. But clarifying these fallacies will help voters understand it.
lead_paragraph: Health care, so far perhaps the biggest issue in the Democratic primary, is also the most complicated issue facing government and the public. Unfortunately the debate is filled with persistent misconceptions, from the role insurance company profits play in health care costs to who is actually paying for workers’ health coverage.

headline: ‘We Never Moved Back to Kashmir, Because We Couldn’t’
abstract: A writer tries to make a home everywhere to dull the pain of losing hers after militants targeted the Hindu minority when the insurgency against India erupted.
lead_paragraph: We vacation hard, my family. Ideally three weeks, and always a home rental, never a hotel. We settle in like we own the place, and have always owned the place. We start with a grocery store, a thrift shop for toys, a visit to the local library. We scope out playgrounds and children’s classes, make some friends, set up play dates.

headline: Transformative? New Device Harvests Energy in Darkness
abstract: It doesn’t generate much power, but it works during the one time of day that solar cells can’t: night.
lead_paragraph: Aaswath Raman was driving through a village in Sierra Leone in 2013 when an idea came to him as suddenly as, perhaps, a light bulb switching on.

headline: What’s Modern Love? A Column. A Book. A Podcast. And Now, a Television Show.
abstract: For 15 years, Modern Love has brought personal essays about love, loss and redemption to readers of The New York Times. Four years ago, it became a podcast. And now the column has inspired an eight-episode series on Amazon Prime Video.
lead_paragraph: For 15 years, Modern Love has brought personal essays about love, loss and redemption to readers of The New York Times. Four years ago, it became a podcast. And now the column has inspired an eight-episode series on Amazon Prime Video.

headline: A French Worker Died After Sex on a Business Trip. His Company Is Liable.
abstract: Labor law in France has strong protections in such cases, even if the accident or injury had little to do with the employee’s job.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A court in France has ruled that a man who died from a heart attack after having sex during a business trip had suffered a work-related accident and that his employer was liable.

headline: Beto O’Rourke Urges Banks to Cut Services for Gun Sales
abstract: The candidate said he wanted credit card companies and other financial institutions to stop providing services for sales of assault-style weapons, among other measures.
lead_paragraph: Beto O’Rourke, the Democratic presidential candidate, on Thursday called on banks and credit card companies to address gun violence by refusing to provide services for some firearms sales.

headline: Sam Gilliam Unfurls an Exuberant Rainbow at Dia:Beacon
abstract: Is it a painting or a sculpture? It’s both. The octogenarian artist keeps surprising.
lead_paragraph: BEACON, N.Y. — Sam Gilliam, an abstract painter of 85, proves that optical prettiness can have depth. A longtime resident of Washington, he is loosely associated with color-field painting, which once turned our nation’s capital into a capital of contemporary art. There is no easy way to explain how a city whose architecture and statuary can seem consistently colorless became, in the ’60s, the locus of an art “ism” that spewed bright color in every direction.

headline: Inside the Military’s 5-Star Layovers at a Trump Resort in Scotland
abstract: There is little evidence that stays by military personnel at President Trump’s resort in Scotland are part of a scheme to enrich him. But they have raised ethical and political questions.
lead_paragraph: TURNBERRY, Scotland — The middle-aged golfers had finished their last single-malt whiskies late one night this July, and the bartenders were closing up.

headline: Saudi Princess Convicted in French Assault Case: ‘This Dog Must be Killed’
abstract: Hassa bint Salman, the half sister of the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, was accused of ordering her bodyguard to hit a contractor working in her Paris apartment in 2016.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French court on Thursday found a Saudi princess guilty of being complicit in the assault of a contractor in her Paris apartment three years ago, a case in which he had accused her of saying of him, “This dog must be killed.”

headline: Deliveroo Ad Implying Delivery Anywhere (Even Space) Is Banned in U.K.
abstract: A British regulator said the commercials were misleading because the food delivery service is not available throughout the country.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A cyclist pedals furiously in space with only one mission: delivering a sushi order to a hungry astronaut. A man gets a pizza in a field after seemingly tunneling underground to escape from prison, and a woman receives a delivery during a car chase.

headline: ‘Protecting Our European Way of Life’? Outrage Follows New E.U. Role
abstract: Ursula von der Leyen is under pressure to ditch the title “vice president for protecting our European way of life” for the person in charge of migration policy.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — When Ursula von der Leyen, the incoming chief of the European Union’s powerful administrative branch, unveiled her top team at a news conference on Tuesday, one new job title provoked a sea of puzzled faces: “vice president for protecting our European way of life.”

headline: An Interview With Caroline Calloway’s Ghostwriter, Natalie Beach
abstract: “There’s many layers of fictionalization within this true story.”
lead_paragraph: In its top left corner, Instagram invites you to share “your story.” The platform’s savviest users log on not to share what’s happening with them spontaneously, but to create the story of themselves.

headline: On-Demand Webinar: Use Photos to Practice Critical Thinking and Literacy Skills
abstract: In this professional development workshop, we hear from educators on how to use “What’s Going On in This Picture?” in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a free teaching activity that:

headline: When a Private British Corporation Ruled India
abstract: William Dalrymple’s “The Anarchy” describes the transformation of a corporation with a security force into a mighty army with a trading division.
lead_paragraph: THE ANARCHYThe East India Company, Corporate Violence, and the Pillage of an EmpireBy William Dalrymple

headline: ‘Freaks’ Review: A Child’s-Eye View of a World Gone Mad
abstract: Emile Hirsch stars as the paranoid father of a cloistered girl in this sci-fi debut feature.
lead_paragraph: Bringing a small budget and a big heart to a dystopian story so familiar it could nestle comfortably inside the “X-Men” franchise, Adam Stein and Zach Lipovsky’s “Freaks” wears its derivativeness with pride. Appealing, partly because it’s so unembarrassed by its genre's done-to-death social-injustice themes, this undercooked blend of science fiction and family drama virtually dares you to turn up your nose.

headline: Sam Darnold Out Indefinitely With Mono
abstract: The virus will keep the Jets quarterback sidelined during a brutal stretch in the team’s schedule.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — A new coach, a marquee running back and a second-year quarterback brought renewed hope to the Jets this season. But one week in, that optimism has quickly diminished.

headline: Here’s the Democratic Debate Lineup — and What’s at Stake for Those Onstage
abstract: The top 10 candidates in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination will take the stage for three hours Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: And then there were 10.

headline: For Mike Pompeo, a Moment of Singular Influence
abstract: President Trump confirmed that he spoke with his secretary of state about also serving as national security adviser, and they ruled it out. But the discussion underscored Mr. Pompeo’s clout.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It took about five minutes after John R. Bolton’s unceremonious fall from grace this week before Washington’s official whisper factory started floating a surprising suggestion for a replacement: Mike Pompeo.

headline: Google Says a Change in Its Algorithm Will Highlight ‘Original Reporting’
abstract: As tech companies try to make amends with publishers, Google changes its search engine to address an old complaint.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of reporting, a journalist breaks a story. Moments after it goes online, another media organization posts an imitative article recycling the scoop that often grabs as much web traffic as the original.

headline: 12 Top-Tier (but Undervalued) Burgundy Producers
abstract: Though prices for prized Burgundies are orbiting the moon, you can still enjoy many bottles at more down-to-earth rates (relatively speaking).
lead_paragraph: Burgundy is glorious. Everybody knows it. And that is a problem.

headline: Older Parent to Adult Child: Don’t Decide for Me
abstract: A reader objects to adult children who feel they have the right to intervene in their parents’ lives.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: All Alone With Ronald K. Brown’s Moves
abstract: “I have to take everything that I’ve learned from him,” Annique Roberts says of this Brown solo. “For me it’s kind of a coming-of-age moment.”
lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at @nytimes.

headline: Google Settles With U.S. Over Workers’ Complaints It Stifled Dissent
abstract: As part of its settlement with the National Labor Relations Board, the search giant will remind workers of their rights to discuss workplace issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Google said Thursday that it had reached a settlement with the National Labor Relations Board over complaints from multiple employees who say the company has stymied dissent, including one who has said he was fired for being an outspoken conservative.

headline: Russ & Daughters History Goes on Display
abstract: “Russ & Daughters: An Appetizing Story,” from the American Jewish Historical Society, offers a taste of New York’s rich food and cultural history.
lead_paragraph: Don’t expect a platter of herring and bialys. But prepare to be hungry anyway at the new “Russ & Daughters: An Appetizing Story” exhibition produced by the American Jewish Historical Society at the Center for Jewish History in Manhattan.

headline: Should Colleges End Legacy Admissions?
abstract: An editorial argued that these admissions are anachronistic and anti-meritocratic. Readers offer their opinions. Also: Diversity of thought on campus.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Vanilla Planifolia’s Secret Power
abstract: The vanilla plant, prized for its scent, also brings a surprising rejuvenator to skincare.
lead_paragraph: The vanilla plant, prized for its scent, also brings a surprising rejuvenator to skincare.

headline: Why Newspapers Are Fighting California’s Landmark Labor Bill
abstract: Thursday: The collateral effects of a bill aimed at protecting gig economy workers. Also: A move forward for a statewide rent cap; and natural wine
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: On the Williamsburg Waterfront
abstract: A new 45-story tower rises on the northern end of the Domino Sugar refinery site.
lead_paragraph: A new 45-story tower rises on the northern end of the Domino Sugar refinery site.

headline: A New Tower Opens on the Domino Site in Williamsburg
abstract: The 45-story building has two legs, with offices in one and rental apartments in the other.
lead_paragraph: Domino Park opened last summer to rave reviews on the site of the former Domino Sugar refinery in Williamsburg, and the transformation of the sprawling industrial site continues this month with the opening of a 45-story, mixed-use tower on the edge of the East River.

headline: Orwellabama? Crimson Tide Track Locations to Keep Students at Games
abstract: Coach Nick Saban gets peeved at students leaving routs early. An app ties sticking around to playoff tickets, but also prompts concern from students and privacy watchdogs.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Sweat from an afternoon under a unrelenting sun and in stifling 100-degree heat had soaked through parts of Taylor Pell’s fraternity pledge uniform: khaki pants, blue blazer, white shirt and crimson tie.

headline: With Trade Talks Looming, U.S. and China Move to Relax Tensions
abstract: President Trump announced that China would resume purchases of American farm goods after a day of cooling tensions, raising hopes of averting the next round of tariff increases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The trade war between the United States and China showed signs of easing on Thursday, as China reportedly made its first large purchase in months of American soybeans after President Trump agreed to briefly delay his next round of tariffs.

headline: Thoughts, Prayers and Video Games
abstract: Politicians blame video games for violence — but the data doesn’t back them up.
lead_paragraph: Politicians blame video games for violence — but the data doesn’t back them up.

headline: Thoughts, Prayers and Video Games
abstract: Politicians blame video games for violence — but the data doesn’t back them up.
lead_paragraph: Today is National Video Games Day, an opportunity to stop bashing video games and instead celebrate millions of American gamers who participate in a national industry that is valued at an estimated $36.9 billion. In the video Op-Ed above, the gamer and game commentator Charlie Goldberg debunks the claims of politicians who blame video games for mass shootings. He argues that leaders who point the finger at games, like President Trump and Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick of Texas, are just distracting their constituents from reality.

headline: Fact-Checking Trump’s Statements on Increased Military Strikes in Afghanistan
abstract: A survey of military operations seems to indicate that, at best, the president is exaggerating the pace of current operations, even if they have increased in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since the Afghan peace talks collapsed last weekend, President Trump has repeatedly said that the American military was striking the Taliban harder than it has for a decade, or even since the start of the war in 2001.

headline: Daniel Johnston’s Essential Songs: Listen to 12 Tracks
abstract: The singer and songwriter, who was acclaimed as one of America’s most gifted outsider voices, died at 58.
lead_paragraph: In his home in rural Texas, on the eve of his final tour in 2017, the singer-songwriter Daniel Johnston told me that he wanted to have a big song someday, what he called “a real hit.” That smash eluded him, but the cascade of poignant, often slyly funny songs he compulsively churned out over the past four decades garnered him a  cult fan base that included Kurt Cobain, Beck, Jeff Tweedy and Lana Del Rey. His lyrics chronicled universal themes like loneliness, despair and unrequited love, but did so on almost uncomfortably personal terms. His struggles with mental illness were rarely far from the surface, and though he wrote about his world with childlike wonder, the emotions coursing through his music were often complex and heartbreaking. Here are 12 of his essential songs.

headline: Amy Sherald’s Shining Second Act
abstract: After her famous portrait of Michelle Obama, the artist is bringing her new works to New York. “Every painting is a kind of communion,” our critic says.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a presidential portrait makes. Two years ago, Amy Sherald’s painting career was slowly if belatedly picking up steam. She was 44 and after a four-year hiatus from art — for family illness and her own heart transplant — had had a handful of solo shows, including a four-day pop-up affair on New York City’s Lower East Side in March 2017.

headline: N.F.L. Settles Lengthy Fight with Insurance Company Over Concussions
abstract: Many of the league’s insurers have claimed they did not have to pay for the concussion settlement with players because the N.F.L. had not disclosed the dangers of the game.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. ended its seven-year fight with an insurance company that had refused to cover its portion of the costs of the league’s more than $1 billion settlement reached in 2013 with retired players found to have cognitive and neurological problems.

headline: Big Fashion Books of Fall
abstract: You may not get a front-row seat at the shows, but these glossy tomes could be the next best thing.
lead_paragraph: Every September, the glitterati descend upon New York, London, Milan and Paris for fashion month in a swarm of stilettos. Like death and taxes, the circus of Fashion Week is inevitable, and often inaccessible unless you’re watching Instagram.

headline: Ken Burns’s ‘Country Music’ Traces the Genre’s Victories, and Reveals Its Blind Spots
abstract: The eight-part, 16-hour documentary tells the genre’s story, from Appalachia to arenas.
lead_paragraph: Tell a lie long enough and it begins to smell like the truth. Tell it even longer and it becomes part of history.

headline: Secure Your Digital Life in 7 (Easy) Days
abstract: Stop dragging your feet and take control of your online security. Get a weeks worth of simple, straightforward steps you can take to lock down your digital accounts and protect your online privacy.
lead_paragraph: Stop dragging your feet and take control of your online security. Get a weeks worth of simple, straightforward steps you can take to lock down your digital accounts and protect your online privacy.

headline: Reality TV Comes to the White House
abstract: Readers agree with an article describing President Trump as a character on TV.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Distinctly American Ethos of the Grifter
abstract: As stories of theft and deception have come to dominate the cultural conversation, it can often feel like grift is a modern phenomenon — but it isn’t.
lead_paragraph: EVERY AGE HAS its defining minor characters, those who briefly light up the public’s imagination not for their achievements but for how they personify our anxieties and most fervent human desires. Consider the half-Chinese, half-Malay Princess Caraboo, who in 1817 was kidnapped by pirates from her native island of Javasu in the Indian Ocean and sold from ship to ship around the globe until finally she jumped overboard and swam ashore, up the Bristol Channel to the parish of Almondsbury in what is today South Gloucestershire, England. Or so went the story that kindly strangers were able to coax out of the young woman who showed up on a cottage doorstep speaking “gibberish” and wearing a dress “in imitation of the Asiatic costume,” as chronicled in a leaflet published later that year. For 10 weeks, she regaled admirers with reminiscences — of a mother with blackened teeth and a bejeweled nose, and a father of such rank petitioners approached him only on their knees — before she was exposed as a cobbler’s daughter and illiterate servant, born Mary Willcocks in Devonshire. She went on to sustain a living supplying a local infirmary with — poetic justice — leeches.

headline: Bach Was a Musician’s Companion to Tragedy
abstract: In a memoir by Zuzana Ruzickova, the Czech harpsichordist who died in 2017, art persists through the Holocaust and Communist rule.
lead_paragraph: It is night. A young girl and her mother have just been transported to Auschwitz. The wind howls, guards scream, dogs bark, people push and shove. The girl is holding something.

headline: New York City Is Ending a Ban on Gay Conversion Therapy. Here’s Why.
abstract: The City Council fears that if a federal lawsuit challenging the ban were to reach the Supreme Court, the panel could issue a ruling that protected the practice.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two years ago, the New York City Council celebrated when it passed a far-reaching ban on conversion therapy, a discredited practice to change a person’s sexual orientation or gender identity.

headline: Here’s When Your Favorite Shows Are Returning This Fall
abstract: From “American Horror Story” to “Marvel’s Runaways,” here’s a chronological list of notable returning series.
lead_paragraph: If your only question when a new television season rolls around is, “When are my shows coming back?,” here are the answers. (If you’re more interested in what’s next, check out our comprehensive guide to the fall’s new shows.) From “American Horror Story” to “Lost in Space,” here’s a chronological list of notable returning series.

headline: ABC Tells Democrats to Keep Debate Clean. Looking at You, Beto.
abstract: There will be no delay on the broadcast so no chance to censor any obscenities, should a candidate let loose.
lead_paragraph: There was a time in American history when candidates for president did not need to be reminded to avoid using obscene and inappropriate language in front of millions of people.

abstract: Remember that Beer Test? We have something better.
lead_paragraph: Remember that Beer Test? It’s not enough. That’s why this election season, we bring you: Still Processing’s Rubric for Leadership and Democratic Excellence.

headline: Film Club: ‘Where Are All the Bob Ross Paintings? We Found Them.’
abstract: What makes someone a cultural icon?
lead_paragraph: What makes someone a cultural icon?

headline: Talk of the Middle-School Car Pool Line
abstract: A reader would love for people to stop commenting on her parenting, after one unfortunate incident.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I separated last spring. It was ugly and featured lots of screaming and yelling, some of it in public places. One afternoon, at our son’s middle school, we were arguing about who was supposed to pick him up that day. My son got involved, and I grabbed him — admittedly, roughly — and pulled him away with me. Over the summer, my husband and I spoke with a counselor, and things are smoother in our separation now. But a mother at my son’s school is still telling everyone that I’m abusive to my child. I grabbed him one time! Any advice?

headline: The Maybe Comet From Another Star
abstract: Now zinging through Cancer: a glob of light from interstellar space?
lead_paragraph: The universe comes calling.

headline: Hillary Clinton Reads Her Emails at Venice Art Show
abstract: The former presidential candidate dropped in on an exhibition of the emails that fed a controversy which dogged her 2016 campaign.
lead_paragraph: In a moment that combined political theater and performance art, Hillary Clinton was reunited with her emails at an exhibition in Italy this week.

headline: Britain Outlined the Impact of a No-Deal Brexit. It’s Not Pretty.
abstract: While Prime Minister Boris Johnson has minimized the potential damage of a no-deal Brexit, an internal document warns of many of the same dislocations the critics have talked about.
lead_paragraph: Food shortages, skyrocketing fuel prices, scarcities of some medications, days-long waits at the border. Those are the potential impacts of a no-deal Brexit as outlined by the British government in an internal policy paper.

headline: B.J. Habibie Dies at 83; Ushered in Democracy in Indonesia
abstract: Though he served as the country’s president for only 17 months, he played a crucial role in ending a harsh 32-year dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — B. J. Habibie, who as president of Indonesia ushered in an era of democracy that ended the brutal and corrupt rule of Suharto, whose 32-year dictatorship was one of the most brutal and corrupt of the 20th century, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Jakarta. He was 83.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Joking About Your Wife’s Flatulence
abstract: Is this O.K. to do at an open mic? What if her whole family is there?
lead_paragraph: Sara writes: My husband does stand-up and promised that he would never tell jokes about me onstage without prior approval. Then he told a fart joke during a set that my family attended. I had made sure there would be an audience for him, and he rewarded me with humiliation. He says that the contract was unenforceable because there was no sacrifice on my part.

headline: Lyric Opera of Chicago Picks a New Music Director
abstract: Enrique Mazzola, a specialist in bel canto, French repertoire and early Verdi, will follow Andrew Davis’s two-decade tenure.
lead_paragraph: For Enrique Mazzola, the path to the conductor’s podium began when he was a boy in the children’s chorus of the Teatro alla Scala in Milan.

headline: U.S. Poised to Send 150 Troops to Patrol Northeastern Syria
abstract: The new deployment is part of an expanding series of military and diplomatic steps the United States has taken to defuse tensions with Turkey, a NATO ally.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is preparing to send about 150 troops to northeastern Syria to conduct ground patrols with Turkish forces, reversing at least temporarily a withdrawal from Syria that President Trump ordered last December.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Has Long Lacked Asian Players. One Just Joined the Cast.
abstract: Bowen Yang, a staff writer for “Saturday Night Live,” joins the slim ranks of Asian-American comedians who have acted on the show.
lead_paragraph: For all the comedians and actors who have come and gone from “Saturday Night Live” in its four decades, there has been a near-complete absence of Asian performers onscreen.

headline: What Students Are Saying About: Summer Memories, Gifted and Talented Programs and Going Back to School
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to another year of Current Events Conversation, in which, each week, we honor our favorite student comments posted to our writing prompts.

headline: Chester Williams, Rugby Champion Who Signaled Apartheid’s Defeat, Dies at 49
abstract: Williams was the only nonwhite on the Springboks when it won the 1995 World Cup and was embraced by Nelson Mandela in a message of reconciliation.
lead_paragraph: Chester Williams, the only nonwhite player on the South Africa rugby team that won the Rugby Union World Cup in 1995, a victory on home soil that marked a historic moment of reconciliation just a year after apartheid fell, died on Sept. 6 in Cape Town. He was 49.

headline: Justice Dept. Rejects Andrew McCabe’s Bid to Avoid Charges
abstract: The move would typically foreshadow an indictment of Mr. McCabe, a longtime target of President Trump, but it is not clear whether prosecutors have asked a grand jury to vote on one.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department rejected a last-ditch appeal from defense lawyers for the former F.B.I. deputy director Andrew G. McCabe, people familiar with the matter said on Thursday, as prosecutors have appeared close to charging him in a criminal case.

headline: What if We Didn’t Dread Menopause?
abstract: The end of a woman’s fertile years has gotten a bad rep. What if we finally gave it the respect it deserves?
lead_paragraph: When most people say “menopause,” they mean more than just the end of female reproductive functions and more, even, than just the accompanying hormonal changes. They mean the cornucopia of symptoms — hot flashes, vaginal dryness, psychological problems like “irritability” — thought to accompany those changes. Type “menopause and” into Google and it will autocomplete with “weight gain,” “depression,” “hair loss,” “anxiety.” Magazines and websites like Woman’s Day or HuffPost publish helpful guides on spotting the first, ominous signs — “You May Experience Menopause Symptoms a Lot Sooner Than You Think,” they warn.

headline: A Diverse Nation Demands Collaboration
abstract: There are opportunities for both Republicans and Democrats to focus on building coalitions across racial lines.
lead_paragraph: Our country’s demographics keep changing fast, and major shifts have already happened in places across the nation — including in Texas, where the Democratic presidential candidates will hold their debate on Thursday night.

headline: Wait — What’s All the Drama?
abstract: This week: Modern Love on TV; Caroline Calloway and Natalie Beach; the good news about where fashion is going.
lead_paragraph: The trailer for “Modern Love” is out! Yes, Modern Love — the column and podcast — will be a TV show too.

headline: El Paso Shooting Suspect Indicted on Capital Murder Charge
abstract: Prosecutors say they will be seeking the death penalty for the massacre that left 22 dead last month.
lead_paragraph: The suspect in the mass shooting at an El Paso Walmart that left 22 dead was indicted by a grand jury on Thursday on a charge of capital murder, according to the district attorney’s office. Prosecutors said they would be seeking the death penalty.

headline: Facebook Suspends Netanyahu Campaign Bot for Hate Speech
abstract: A message sent out by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s campaign accused Israel’s Arab politicians of wanting “to destroy us all.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Facebook suspended a chatbot operated by the official account of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Thursday for violating hate speech rules after it sent a message saying that Israel’s Arab politicians “want to destroy us all.”

headline: The Disappearing Schools of Puerto Rico
abstract: Over the past three years, hundreds of schools have closed across Puerto Rico. Their ruins are among the most visible evidence of the island’s vicious circle of poor governance, neglect by Washington and environmental catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: Over the past three years, hundreds of schools have closed across Puerto Rico. Their ruins are among the most visible evidence of the island’s vicious circle of poor governance, neglect by Washington and environmental catastrophe.

headline: Cardinal Roger Etchegaray Dies at 96; Skilled Papal Emissary
abstract: He was in charge of the Vatican department that dealt with peace efforts, and was sent by Pope John Paul II to Cuba, Iraq and China.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Roger Etchegaray, a skilled diplomat and troubleshooter dispatched by his friend Pope John Paul II to negotiate for the Roman Catholic Church with Fidel Castro, Saddam Hussein and leaders of the Chinese Communist Party, died on Sept. 4 in his native French Basque country. He was 96.

headline: Protect Your Digital Self in a Few Minutes a Day
abstract: With our “Secure Your Digital Life in 7 (Easy) Days” challenge, we will help you put your online accounts and devices under lock and key.
lead_paragraph: Is your email password “letmein,” “starwars” or “password?” Do you find yourself ignoring the “Update Your Device” message that pops up on your computer or phone? Have you ever lost your laptop and had the painful realization that whoever found it most likely had access to everything on it because you had never bothered to secure it properly?

headline: Amid Bipartisan Outcry, White House Agrees to Release Ukraine Aid
abstract: Two lawmakers said the administration would release $250 million, which is intended partly to train and equip Ukrainian forces defending against Russian incursion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Thursday dropped its resistance to releasing a package of military assistance to Ukraine, amid a bipartisan outcry from lawmakers and an open investigation into whether President Trump and his allies were distorting the United States foreign aid program for their own political benefit.

headline: Before California Boat Fire Killed 34, Entire Crew Was Asleep, N.T.S.B. Finds
abstract: The finding suggests that the crew had failed to uphold a commitment to have someone awake.
lead_paragraph: All six crew members of the Conception were asleep when the scuba diving boat caught fire and sank off the coast of Southern California early on Sept. 2, killing 34 people, according to a federal report released on Thursday.

headline: Neanderthal Footprints in France Offer Clues to Group Behavior
abstract: The 80,000-year-old prints fill in gaps left by fossils and artifacts.
lead_paragraph: A group of Neanderthal children scampered around the Normandy coast in France 80,000 years ago. Their footprints quickly became covered by windblown sand, preserved as ghostly signs of their passage.

headline: Two Men in Japan Dared to Take Paternity Leave. It Cost Them Dearly, They Say.
abstract: The men bucked norms that parental leave is for women and say that, when they returned to work, their companies punished them with demotions and pay cuts.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — On paper, Japan has one of the best paternity leave policies in the world. In practice, very few men — less than one in 16 — take advantage of their legal right, often because they fear retribution.

headline: Brexit, Japan, Democratic Debates: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Fathers in Japan fight for paternity leave.
