headline: Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax of Virginia Sues CBS for Defamation, Seeking $400 Million
abstract: He filed the lawsuit in response to interviews on “CBS This Morning” with two women who accused him of sexual misconduct.
lead_paragraph: In a rare legal broadside by a politician against a major news organization, Lt. Gov. Justin E. Fairfax of Virginia sued CBS on Thursday for defamation, saying the network’s news division smeared him by airing interviews with two women who accused the lawmaker of sexual assault.

headline: Summer Debate Recap: How Did the Top Four Candidates Perform Last Time?
abstract: Joe Biden, Kamala Harris, Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren are the leading Democrats in the presidential primary. We take a look back at their debate performances.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Ahead of Thursday’s debate, we looked back at how the leading Democratic candidates — Joseph R. Biden Jr., Kamala Harris, Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren — performed in the first two debates.

headline: There’s More Driving Toyota City Than Just Cars
abstract: Japan’s “Motor City,” a 50-minute train ride from Nagoya, offers scenic hikes, art museums and yes, many tributes to its automotive heritage.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, the city of Toyota in Japan’s Aichi Prefecture wants to show visitors that it is more than just a “car town.” Home to the auto manufacturer from which the city of 420,000 takes its name, Toyota City this autumn is hosting major art exhibits and four matches — including two marquee games featuring the Japanese and New Zealand squads — of the Rugby World Cup. These events are something of a coming out for Toyota City, whose reputation as a manufacturing center belies its rich history and mountain scenery. The city makes for an up-and-coming addition to any Japan travel itinerary.

headline: M.I.T. President Says He Thanked Jeffrey Epstein for Gift in Letter
abstract: L. Rafael Reif said top administrators at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology had allowed donations as long as Mr. Epstein gave anonymously.
lead_paragraph: M.I.T.’s president acknowledged Thursday that he had signed a letter thanking Jeffrey Epstein for a donation in 2012 and said senior members of his administration had approved gifts from the disgraced financier as long as they remained anonymous.

headline: N.F.L. Week 2 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: An N.F.C. championship rematch, a game with an 18.5-point spread and the Ravens trying to live up to last week’s explosion are among the week’s highlights.
lead_paragraph: Last week was a crash course in quick reversals of expectations: For example, the Cleveland Browns failed to deliver on their hype, and Lamar Jackson of the Baltimore Ravens proved far better at passing than some had expected.

headline: New Lawsuit Against Uber Is Set to Test Its Classification of Workers
abstract: A class-action suit on behalf of drivers in federal court in California, filed on Wednesday, accused Uber of wrongly classifying drivers under the state’s employment test.
lead_paragraph: Uber insisted on Wednesday that it may not have to reclassify its drivers as employees despite a newly passed California bill that would appear to require just that. Hours later, the ride-hailing company learned it would soon get a chance to test its argument in court.

headline: Agonizing Summer Leaves U.S. Basketball Much to Ponder
abstract: The Americans lost to Serbia at the World Cup, ensuring they would play for seventh place, their worst showing ever in a tournament featuring N.B.A. players.
lead_paragraph: DONGGUAN, China — When they huddled on the floor before tipoff Thursday night, Coach Gregg Popovich of the United States slipped some colorful language into his greeting for his Serbian counterpart Sasha Djordjevic.

abstract: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
