lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Car executives are paid to be optimists, but behind the pomp and salesmanship at the Frankfurt International Motor Show this week lurked an unmistakable sense of angst.

headline: The Latest Debate: 10 Democrats, Vying to Take Command
abstract: Readers discuss the Democrats’ “circular firing squad,” Medicare for All, open borders, record players and assault weapons.

headline: New York Uncovers $1 Billion in Sackler Family Wire Transfers

headline: Political Ad Attacking AOC: ‘Beyond the Pale’
abstract: A Catholic nun is shocked that ABC would run an ad with “horrific images” during the Democratic debate.

lead_paragraph: Kanye West knows how to attract attention. Just not always the kind from adoring fans.

headline: Liz Cheney, Tart-Tongued Fighter, Is Warring With Rand Paul Over Who’s Trumpier
abstract: Ms. Cheney, the No. 3 House Republican, has supplanted her father, Dick Cheney, as the most combative Cheney in Washington. She usually attacks Democrats, but not this time.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After becoming the highest-ranking Republican woman in Congress, Representative Liz Cheney, the sharp-tongued lawmaker from Wyoming, wasted little time establishing her reputation as one of her party’s most combative partisan brawlers.

headline: What Will It Take to Get Your Vote in October?
abstract: Canadian election campaigns have shifted public opinion in recent years. We want to know what it will take to get your vote on Oct. 21.
lead_paragraph: With the storm recovery underway in Atlantic Canada and suitable congratulations offered to Bianca Andreescu for making Canadian sports history at the U.S. Open, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau made the required trip to Rideau Hall this week to launch the federal election.

headline: Dior Finally Says No to Sauvage
abstract: Why luxury fashion and cultural appropriation are on a collision course.
lead_paragraph: A stubbled white loner in a serape, a deep ocean blue shirt and multiple beaded chains and bracelets stares moodily at desert landscape lit by the blood reds of sunset. A Native American in classic regalia dances atop a mesa.

headline: The Critters Doing $114 Million in Damage to Brooklyn’s Piers
abstract: Marine borers have come roaring back in New York Harbor, threatening almost anything in the water made of wood.
lead_paragraph: No signs, fences or entreaties can keep these vandals away from the sprawling waterfront park at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: After Fleeing North Korea, Women Get Trapped as Cybersex Slaves in China
abstract: A growing number of North Korean women are smuggled from their country and trafficked into the sex trade in China, and forced to perform sex acts online for clients.
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos — For more than two years, Lee Jin-hui, 20, was never allowed to leave a three-room apartment in northeast China. Seven days a week, she had to sit at a computer from noon to 5 a.m., performing sex acts before a webcam for male clients, mostly from South Korea.

headline: Iger Departs Board of Apple, Disney’s New Streaming Competitor
abstract: Robert A. Iger, Disney’s chief executive and chairman, had been on the board since 2011. But both companies will debut streaming services next month.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Robert A. Iger, Disney’s chief executive and chairman, has resigned from the board of Apple, whose growing Hollywood operation would have made it harder for him to fully engage as one of its directors.

headline: Trump’s Dorian Tweet Whips Up a Fight Over a Science Powerhouse
abstract: The controversy has dragged one of the country's preeminent research agencies, famous for being anonymous, into the spotlight it long avoided.
lead_paragraph: SILVER SPRING, Md. — On Friday morning in the suburbs of Washington, D.C., government scientists in khakis and sensible shoes bustled to work — beneath a towering bronze sculpture of a hand releasing seabirds — heading for a  small scientific agency caught up in a political mess triggered by President Trump’s tweet about Hurricane Dorian.

headline: Sackler Family, Felicity Huffman, Peanuts: Your Friday Evening Briefing

headline: For His First Museum Show in 15 Years, John Currin Turns His Gaze to Men
abstract: The artist, who made his name with his polarizing but masterly portraits of women, discusses his lesser-known paintings.
lead_paragraph: John Currin is best known for painting women, and he has spent his summer on Mount Desert Island, Maine, doing just that: laying the groundwork for a new series of portraits of female subjects whose smiles are stretched by lines of anxiety, whose eyes blaze with to-do lists. He based the faces on models from Sears catalogs and stock photos, but calls the type a “Redbook Juggler,” after the supermarket glossy that advises women on how to cook, shop and dress. While Currin’s exaggerated compositions blow his figures up to kewpie-doll proportions or deflate them into a jumble of jutting elbows and toothy smiles, he renders each inch of flesh in laborious, glowing brushwork that has earned him comparisons to Dutch masters. He was, in fact, exhibited alongside the celebrated Golden Age Dutch painter Cornelis van Haarlem, at the Frans Hals Museum in the Netherlands in 2011, just two decades after his first solo show at the Andrea Rosen Gallery in 1992 (where his provocative portraits of bold older women elicited accusations of sexism but nevertheless sold out). Currin’s works still draw that criticism on occasion, but not much that he depicts emerges solely from his own imagination. His subjects wash in from the flotsam of American life — kitschy souvenirs and cringey ads, screenshots and centerfolds — and it’s by polishing this lowbrow commerical imagery with a high-art sheen that he manages to make obvious what others might be happy to ignore about our culture.

headline: Top Immigration Judge Departs Amid Broader Discontent Over Trump Policies
abstract: The judge gave no reason for his departure, but it comes on the heels of a shake-up among the top leaders of the immigration courts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s immigration judges lost a key leader this week, the latest in a string of departures at the top of the system amid a backlog of cases and a migrant crisis at the southwestern border.

headline: Bahamas says undocumented Haitians are safe, for now
abstract: More than 2,000 people evacuated to Nassau from ravaged islands, almost all Haitian, are in shelters with nowhere to go. ‘Some dogs are living better.’
lead_paragraph: NASSAU, Bahamas — Kerline Mildor escaped the wreckage of Hurricane Dorian with her three children and the clothes on her back.

headline: Anne Rivers Siddons, Novelist Whose Muse Was the New South, Dies at 83
abstract: She found inspiration in her Georgia upbringing and in Atlanta’s evolution into a major postwar city.
lead_paragraph: Anne Rivers Siddons, whose popular novels, set largely in the South, took female characters on emotional journeys that touched on the region’s racial and social attitudes, died on Wednesday at her home in Charleston, S.C. She was 83.

headline: Antonio Brown Remains Eligible to Play for Patriots
abstract: The league will continue to investigate allegations of rape and sexual assault made against the receiver but will not prevent him from making his Patriots’ debut on Sunday against the Miami Dolphins.
lead_paragraph: Wide receiver Antonio Brown is eligible to make his debut with the New England Patriots on Sunday while the league investigates accusations of rape and sexual assault made this week in a lawsuit by a woman who once worked as his trainer.

headline: With Markers and Straws, Trump’s Campaign Sells Defiance as a Lifestyle
abstract: Trump-branded products celebrate the president’s urge to fight back.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The message the president is selling to his supporters is clear.

headline: After Toronto, Is Tarantino Still the Oscar Favorite?
abstract: A lot of major contenders just debuted at film festivals, but none may be strong enough to dislodge the front-runner “Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood.”
lead_paragraph: For the last seven years, you could count on the eventual winner of the best picture Oscar to emerge from the three big film festivals that unofficially mark the start of award season.

headline: Shane Gillis’s Jokes Went Too Far. Should That End His ‘S.N.L.’ Career?
abstract: The new cast member’s offensive remarks about Chinese people and others raise questions about the show’s vetting and what, if anything, the show should do with him.

headline: Juanita Abernathy, a Force in the Civil Rights Movement, Dies at 87
abstract: The wife of the Rev. Dr. Ralph Abernathy, she was an activist in her own right in the struggle to end segregation and to secure the vote.
lead_paragraph: Juanita Abernathy, who helped organize the Montgomery bus boycott and took part in other pivotal protests at the outset of the civil rights era alongside the Rev. Dr. Ralph Abernathy, her husband and a leader of the movement, died on Thursday at a hospital in Atlanta. She was 87.

headline: Chicago Man Fraudulently Accrued 42 Million Delta SkyBonus Points, U.S. Says
abstract: Gennady Podolsky used his position as a travel agent to cheat Delta Air Lines out of $1.75 million worth of loyalty points, according to an indictment.
lead_paragraph: Where would you go if you had more than 40 million points with an airline? Hawaii 96 times? Seoul 40 times? Federal District Court in Atlanta?

headline: An America Commensurate to the Capacity for Wonder
abstract: What 9/11 destroyed, and what it did not.
lead_paragraph: Another perfect day, not a cloud in the September sky, as if to elide time and compress 18 years into a moment.

headline: 14 Million Watched Democrats Debate in Houston
abstract: The New York Times will join CNN in co-sponsoring next month’s debate in Ohio, another sign of the paper’s expanded public profile.
lead_paragraph: More than 14 million people tuned in Thursday for the clash of 10 presidential candidates in Houston on ABC News and Univision, the second-largest audience to date for a Democratic primary debate.

headline: Impeachment Inquiry or Just Plain Oversight? It Depends on Whom You Ask
abstract: Democrats say they have started a full impeachment investigation. Republicans disagree. A judge may have the final word.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An impeachment investigation to potentially try to remove the president of the United States for high crimes and misdemeanors would seem to be fairly clear-cut.

headline: Time to Build a National Data Broker Registry
abstract: A federal clearing house would help separate the good and bad actors who deal in data.
lead_paragraph: It’s time for a national data privacy law, one that gives consumers meaningful rights — to know who has their data, how it is used and how to opt out. It’s in our country’s best interest to have a national standard that, done thoughtfully, benefits both consumers and businesses by providing transparency, uniformity and certainty without deterring innovation and competition.

headline: MoviePass Ending Its Run, 2 Years After Millions Signed Up
abstract: A low subscription fee in 2017 attracted subscribers but resulted in huge losses. It continued to burn through cash while struggling to find a business model that worked.
lead_paragraph: MoviePass, the fast-growing but troubled subscription service that offered movie buffs a variety of plans at discount prices to see films, said Friday that it was shutting down.

headline: Biden and Warren Avoid Direct Conflict — But for How Long?
abstract: They have staked out diverging political paths, but have mostly refrained from attacking each other. Now a more combative phase of the race seems inevitable.
lead_paragraph: If Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Elizabeth Warren are headed for a showdown, neither of them appears in a hurry to get there.

headline: Trump Has Tamed the G.O.P. (for Now)

lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening, President Trump traveled to Baltimore — a city he’d recently disparaged as a “disgusting, rat and rodent infested mess” where “no human being would want to live” — to give a pep talk to House Republicans. The lawmakers were gathered for their annual strategy retreat, the first since losing control of the House in the midterms, and high on the list of hot topics was how to reclaim the majority.

headline: Blessed Are the Refugees
abstract: Under Donald Trump, America is ceasing to be the last best hope.
lead_paragraph: A woman and her young daughter, no older than 6 or 7, are shopping for groceries in a corner store of a bombed-out city. It’s sometime around 1947. The war is over, the Germans are gone, the Gestapo is no longer hunting Jews. Some of their local henchmen have been imprisoned or shot. Many just took off their uniforms and returned to their former lives.

headline: Cody Bellinger Spins Disappointment Into an M.V.P. Candidacy

Collins constructs a ton of themed puzzles, and we see him every few months on the weekends; today’s felt as if he had been saving up some 15-letter doozies for an epic chance to piece them together.

headline: Restoring Black Cowboys to the Range
abstract: At the Black Cowboy Museum in a storefront near Houston, one man celebrates the lives of African-Americans in the West’s most iconic role.
lead_paragraph: A pack of red cattle dogs bayed with excitement as Larry Callies drove his pickup truck down a Rosenberg, Tex., ranch road one morning. He pulled up to the barn and stepped a booted foot from the cab to the dirt, and the dogs keened even more wildly, eager to get out on the range: The dogs knew a cowboy when they saw one.

headline: Why Does Everything Smell, So Peacefully, of Lavender?
abstract: A plant’s journey from calming to common.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago Erin Wexstten, the 35-year-old founder of Oxalis Apothecary, a plant-based skin care brand, ticked off all the ways she uses lavender in her life.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Unbelievable’ and ‘Maigret’
abstract: Merritt Wever and Toni Collette hunt down a rapist in a new crime series on Netflix. And Rowan Atkinson plays Georges Simenon’s detective in “Maigret.”
lead_paragraph: UNBELIEVABLE Stream on Netflix. This limited series, based on a real case, follows the story of Marie (Kaitlyn Dever), a young woman in Washington State who reports that she has been sexually assaulted by a home intruder, only to recant later after detectives investigate and believe that she made up the events.  Years later, two female detectives (played by Toni Collette and Merritt Wever) from different police departments near Denver, Colo., team up when reports of two rapes in their jurisdictions point to a similar attacker. Their pursuit of an assailant unexpectedly leads them back to Washington, where Marie, who’s been branded a liar, has lost faith in her own memory. Like other female-focused dramas like “The Sinner,” “The Tale” and “Share,” the series explores the ways in which memory and credibility are sometimes called into question in cases involving sexual assault and trauma.

headline: A Ride Through the Streets of Boston, and to Their Future
abstract: The couple met while at Harvard Law School. Then they decided to attend a festival with others in Boston’s North End.
lead_paragraph: Alexa Marie Kissinger and Gareth Thomas Rhodes were married Sept. 14 at Toro, a Manhattan restaurant. New York Governor Andrew M. Cuomo officiated. On Sept. 12, a second ceremony, led by Rick Rector, the mayor of Hudson, N.Y., took place at the home of the couple’s friends, Vernon Evenson and Paul Cassidy, in Stuyvesant, N.Y.

headline: Their Romance Took Off After He Landed
abstract: She went with his good friend to pick him up at Newark airport, and a few years later they decided to get married at Kennedy Airport.
lead_paragraph: Adriana Xhakli and Perry Petra-Wong were married Sept. 14 at the TWA Hotel at JFK in Jamaica, Queens. Richard Desroche, a friend of the groom’s mother who was ordained through the American Marriage Ministries, officiated.

headline: Notre-Dame’s Toxic Fallout
abstract: Flames engulfed 460 tons of lead when Notre-Dame’s roof and spire burned, scattering dangerous dust onto the streets and parks of Paris.
lead_paragraph: Flames engulfed 460 tons of lead when Notre-Dame’s roof and spire burned, scattering dangerous dust onto the streets and parks of Paris.

headline: What We Found About Notre-Dame’s Lead, and What It May Mean for You
abstract: Every expert consulted by The New York Times said it was still safe to visit Paris, though they differed on what precautions should be taken.
lead_paragraph: The fire at Notre-Dame in April destroyed the cathedral’s roof and spire, which were covered with 460 tons of lead tiles. Tiny particles of some of that lead mixed with the plume of smoke that drifted over Paris.

headline: Running a Race Vs. Racing It
abstract: Sometimes you give it your all, and sometimes you just run.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Two Major Saudi Oil Installations Hit by Drone Strike, and U.S. Blames Iran
abstract: Yemen’s Houthi rebels claimed responsibility. But Secretary of State Mike Pompeo accused Tehran and said the strikes were not launched from Yemen.
lead_paragraph: Drone attacks claimed by Yemen’s Houthi rebels struck two key oil installations inside Saudi Arabia on Saturday, damaging facilities that process the vast majority of the country’s crude output and raising the risk of a disruption in world oil supplies.

headline: In First, California Would Require Public Universities to Provide Abortion Pills
abstract: The bill, if signed by the governor, would mark a new way of giving women access to abortion as conservative states tighten restrictions.
lead_paragraph: At a time when conservative states are sharply limiting abortion access, California signaled a new frontier in abortion-rights on Friday with the passage of legislation that would require all public universities in the state to provide medication abortion on campus.

headline: The Stranger in a Bar
abstract: Lessons from a chance encounter.
lead_paragraph: A dull stare. Those were the words that formed, clearly, in my mind, though I must only remember them so well now because of what followed.

headline: The Obscenity of Curves
abstract: Oversexualizing female athletes is dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a 17-year-old champion swimmer in Anchorage was disqualified at a swim meet because of how her team swimsuit fit her body. After successfully beating her opponent in a race, Breckyn Willis of Dimond High School was stripped of her victory because her suit was deemed to have violated code: Her buttocks were exposed.

headline: My Neighbors Can See Into My Bedroom. What Can I Do?
abstract: You can’t force your neighbors to decorate for your benefit, but there are ways around an awkward meeting of the windows.
lead_paragraph: Q: We live in an Upper West Side co-op, and our bedroom faces the dining area of an apartment in an adjacent building. A family recently moved in with two young daughters who often sit at the dining table beneath a bright, garish light fixture and face their window, which has no curtains. We have blinds on the upper part of our window, but do not want to close them all the way because our apartment is dark. I am not an exhibitionist and I am sure the parents do not want their children to see me walking around my bedroom seminude or worse. I asked our superintendent to speak to theirs about the situation, but he never heard back. How do we fix this?

headline: Top Canadian Intelligence Official Charged With Leaking Secrets
abstract: Cameron Ortis, a senior official with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police’s intelligence unit, faces three charges under a 2012 security of information law.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A top intelligence official with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police who had access to a wide array of highly sensitive information gathered by Canada and its allies has been charged with passing along or offering secrets.

headline: Homeless Residents Got One-Way Tickets Out of Town. Many Returned to the Streets.
abstract: As cities offer transportation passes to get homeless people to a more stable destination, some worry whether they are sending people to insecurity in a new place.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The solution is cheap and simple: As cities see their homeless populations grow, many are buying one-way bus tickets to send people to a more promising destination, where family or friends can help get them back on their feet.

headline: Maple Butter Roast Chicken Is Everything
abstract: Make this sweet-and-salty recipe soon.
lead_paragraph: This delicious recipe combines maple and rosemary with melted butter, which is basted over the bird as it cooks. Enjoy it alongside brussels sprouts with walnuts and pomegranates before an apple skillet cake, or make any of the recipes in the collection below.

headline: Netanyahu’s Fate May Depend on Israeli Arab Voters. Will They Turn Out?
abstract: Arab citizens make up a sixth of the Israeli electorate. They could determine whether the prime minister is re-elected, but few voted in the last election.
lead_paragraph: BAQA AL GHARBIYEH, Israel — Arab citizens of Israel have no love lost for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who routinely resorts to fear-mongering against them to rally his right-wing Jewish base. But when they had a chance to help toss him from office in April, fewer than half of eligible Arabs voted — a record low.

headline: The Senate: Still Great at Deliberating, but Less So at Legislating
abstract: Today’s Senate, devoted almost only to confirming the president’s nominations, is hardly a hotbed of legislative activity. Members of both parties would like that to change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell says he is awaiting President Trump’s proposal on new gun safety rules before swinging his chamber into action. Some of his colleagues think he’s got it backward.

headline: Molly Goddard: Spring 2020
abstract: Molly Goddard Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: Molly Goddard Spring 2020 Collection

headline: Opioid Defendants Seek to Disqualify Judge Overseeing 2,300 Cases
abstract: In a surprising move, drug distributors and pharmacy chains on the eve of a landmark federal trial argued that the judge already believed that defendants should pay.
lead_paragraph: Scarcely five weeks before a landmark federal civil trial in the opioid epidemic, the giant retail pharmacy chains and drug distributors that are defendants in the bellwether Ohio case are seeking to disqualify the judge from overseeing it and nearly 2,300 other opioid-related lawsuits before him.

headline: U.S. Defeats Poland at Basketball World Cup. But for 7th Place.
abstract: When does a victory feel like defeat? When an American team with N.B.A. players exits the tournament without a medal.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As he trudged back to the locker room in the bowels of Cadillac Arena, needing to deliver one last post-game address to his humbled United States men’s basketball team, Coach Gregg Popovich looked up and felt a need to stop.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon are flying south for the winter.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC  — Our inimitable constructors, team Cox/Rathvon, are in a green mood; this is the second excerpt in a row from a naturalist literary work and I feel like there have been a lot of other instances this summer.  It could also be selective memory on my part because I like this kind of writing so much.

headline: Golden, Going, Gone: 18-Karat Gold Toilet Is Stolen
abstract: The toilet, the work of the conceptual artist Maurizio Cattelan, had been installed only two days earlier at Blenheim Palace, west of London.
lead_paragraph: The golden loo is gone.

headline: Assisted Living: Is It the Right Choice?
abstract: Readers discuss the pros and cons of assisted living and the options for elder care.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Is Trump’s America Tougher on Asylum Than Other Western Countries?
abstract: President Trump’s plan to bar migrants from seeking asylum in the United States is similar to a scheme employed by Australia since 2012. Europe tried a comparable scheme in 2016, but it didn’t work.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The Supreme Court this week allowed the Trump administration to move forward with a plan to bar most migrants, particularly Central Americans, from seeking asylum in the United States.

headline: The Best of London Fashion Week, in Pictures
abstract: All the highlights from the spring 2020 shows, as captured by T’s photographers.
lead_paragraph: Richard Quinn has a knack for staging theatrical shows, and his latest outing closed London Fashion Week with a definitive bang. The designer enlisted London’s Philharmonic Orchestra and the Bach Choir to perform live inside East London’s York Hall, where models paraded across a bubble-gum-pink carpet in big, bold, after-dark dresses. There were polka-dot puffball looks, exaggerated leg-of-mutton satin sleeves, latex bodysuits under cheongsam-style dresses and, of course, the designer’s signature screen-printed florals in long columnar shapes. The supermodel Jacquetta Wheeler led a bevy of feathered schoolgirls across the floor to close the show, swiftly followed by the unveiling of a tableau vivant of Quinn’s bridal collection against a backdrop of foliage. Unsurprisingly, the audience went wild.

headline: Iraq Faces a New Adversary: Crystal Meth
abstract: Growing addiction is the most recent manifestation of how Iraq’s social order has frayed in the years following the 2003 U.S. invasion.
lead_paragraph: BASRA, Iraq — Hussein Karim sold his three cars, he sold the land where he planned to build a house, and he spent his savings — several thousand dollars — all on his crystal meth habit.

headline: Brett Kavanaugh Fit In With the Privileged Kids. She Did Not.
abstract: Deborah Ramirez’s Yale experience says much about the college’s efforts to diversify its student body in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Deborah Ramirez had the grades to go to Yale in 1983. But she wasn’t prepared for what she’d find there.

headline: More Than 2,200 Preserved Fetuses Found at Property of Dead Doctor, Officials Say
abstract: There was no evidence that medical procedures were performed at the Illinois property where the remains were found, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The family of a doctor in Illinois discovered more than 2,200 medically preserved fetuses at his property a little over a week after his death, the authorities said.

headline: Trust Our Weather Forecasters, Not Trump
abstract: What if you knew a skyscraper was going to topple in the wind, but no one believed you?
lead_paragraph: All through the summer of 1978, Harold Gibson, the meteorologist in charge of the National Weather Service in New York, would recall, he was “sweating blood.”

headline: Let’s Debate: Are Democrats Doomed?
abstract: Trump changed the game forever.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He’s in our heads.

headline: Thousands More Jeffrey Epsteins Are Still Out There
abstract: They operate with impunity, continuing to sexually exploit children.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Epstein got away for years with raping underage girls, and the public is properly outraged that powerful people seemed to shrug and let him off easy.

headline: How My Boyfriend Made Me Fall in Love With Gaming
abstract: It became a form of bonding for us, not a source of strain.
lead_paragraph: When my boyfriend moved into my shoe-box one-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn, he brought along three uninvited friends: his Xbox 360, his PlayStation 4 and the Nintendo Wii. Within a week, he insisted on buying a second television in order to game at his leisure, and avoid badgering from me. In fairness, I was the stereotypical video game-phobic girlfriend.

headline: There Is No Tech Backlash
abstract: Worse, we think there is one.
lead_paragraph: It’s fun, and increasingly fashionable, to complain about technology. Our own devices distract us, others’ devices spy on us, social media companies poison public discourse, new wired objects violate our privacy, and all of this contributes to a general sense of runaway change careening beyond our control. No wonder there’s a tech backlash.

headline: It’s Evening. It’s Late Summer. What Now?
abstract: The evening is your own.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — The window overlooks a neglected backyard where a few shrubs grow with their backs to the wall. Under the washing lines, grasses heavy with seed pods all incline slightly southward, and among the grasses a lone yellow plant, maybe a ragwort.

headline: The Only Way to End ‘Endless War’
abstract: First, America has to give up its pursuit of global dominance.
lead_paragraph: “We have got to put an end to endless war,” declared Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., during the Democratic presidential primary debate on Thursday. It was a surefire applause line: Many people consider “endless war” to be the central problem for American foreign policy.

headline: Margaret Atwood’s Dystopia, and Ours
abstract: In the sequel to “The Handmaid’s Tale,” the truth saves. If only that still worked in real life.
lead_paragraph: After Donald Trump’s election, sales of “The Handmaid’s Tale,” Margaret Atwood’s canonical 1985 novel of theocratic totalitarianism, spiked, along with other dystopian classics like George Orwell’s “1984.” Atwood’s book takes place in a world where a clique of Christian fundamentalists have overthrown the United States government and instituted the rigidly patriarchal Republic of Gilead. Environmental calamity has left many people infertile, and an unfortunate class of women who can have children, the Handmaids, are stripped of their identities and consigned to reproductive slavery for the elite.

headline: Fearing ‘Spy Trains,’ Congress May Ban a Chinese Maker of Subway Cars
abstract: A Chinese train maker, the world’s largest, has contracts in Chicago, Los Angeles and Boston, but Congress may block it from securing any new contracts in the United States.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — America’s next fight with China is unfolding at a glistening new factory in Chicago, which stands empty except for the shells of two subway cars and space for future business that is unlikely to come.

headline: Does Hispanic Heritage Month Need a Rebrand?
abstract: For starters, why is “Hispanic” still part of the name?
lead_paragraph: El Espace is a column dedicated to news and culture relevant to Latinx communities. Expect politics, arts, analysis, personal essays and more. ¿Lo mejor? It’ll be in Spanish and English, so you can forward it to your tía, your primo Lalo or anyone else (read: everyone).

headline: Build the Donald J. Trump Tunnel
abstract: A silly fight over vital infrastructure has gone off the rails. Let’s make a deal.
lead_paragraph: Last year when President Trump visited Mount Vernon, the plantation home of the country’s first president, he remarked that the founding father had missed a golden opportunity.

headline: The Slow Road to Catholic Schism
abstract: Even Pope Francis is talking about schism. But a real one is still some distance off.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, when I was younger and somewhat more excitable, I wrote a series of essays about Pope Francis’s liberalizing efforts, arguing that the supreme pontiff’s choices risked a schism in the Catholic Church.

headline: At Home With the Losers
abstract: What were the rest of the Democratic candidates thinking on debate night?

headline: Get Your Mind Out of the Gutter
abstract: Andrew Kingsley brings us a puzzle. There are rules.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I’m not letting any cats out of any bags by telling you this puzzle is about bowling, right? That’s the gutter pun in the headline! There’s a bowling ball in the top center nine squares on the paper grid, and there’s supposed to be something in the electronic versions today. The first thing that comes to mind when I think about bowling is Andrew Kingsley, who just got his master's from the University of Pennsylvania this year and already has a teaching job at Riverdale Country School in the Bronx, teaching the art of the duckpin. Just kidding, he’s teaching middle and high school English. When I think about bowling I think of The Big Lebowski, but none of the scenes in that movie are appropriate to mention here.

headline: Planned Parenthood and Fired Former Chief Mired in Escalating Dispute
abstract: Leana Wen, who was fired in July as Planned Parenthood president after less than a year on the job, is at odds with the group over the terms of her departure and the group’s direction.
lead_paragraph: Leana Wen, the recently fired former president of Planned Parenthood, appears headed toward an increasingly contentious exit, after accusing the organization’s leadership of trying to “buy my silence” in a dispute that threatens to prolong and magnify an acrimonious transition at the top of the nation’s best known women’s health care and reproductive rights group.

headline: G.M. and Autoworkers in Talks on New Labor Contract
abstract: G.M. is looking for ways to cut costs, while the union hopes to reopen a factory in Lordstown, Ohio. The contract expires at 11:59 tonight.
lead_paragraph: General Motors and the United Automobile Workers were working Saturday to hammer out a new labor agreement in the final hours before their current contract expires.

headline: Bernie Sanders, in Las Vegas, Previews Plan for Affordable Housing

lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Senator Bernie Sanders introduced a $2.5 trillion housing policy plan on Saturday that would include ending homelessness and limiting rent increases across the country by imposing a national rent control standard.

headline: This Week’s Wedding Announcements
abstract: All of the weddings right here on one handy page for you.
lead_paragraph: In July 2012 Adriana Xhakli got an earful about Perry Petra-Wong from her high school friend, Nick Boscamp. When he mentioned that Mr. Petra-Wong, his college friend, would be flying to New York from Los Angeles for a visit, she took for granted he would pick him up at the airport and offered the use of her SUV for what she thought would be later that week.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: Chelsea Handler and Roasting Alec Baldwin
abstract: Handler sets out to have tough conversations in “Hello, Privilege. It’s Me, Chelsea,” and Baldwin subjects himself to ridicule from Robert De Niro and Caitlyn Jenner.
lead_paragraph: HELLO, PRIVILEGE. IT’S ME, CHELSEA Stream on Netflix. In 2016, the comedian Chelsea Handler shifted toward documentary storytelling with her four-part series, “Chelsea Does,” to explore questions she had about marriage, Silicon Valley, drugs and racism. In his review of that show for The New York Times, Neil Genzlinger likened it to documentaries “that ramble and lack focus and are more akin to visiting with a topic than to making a point about it.” But Handler has decided to delve back into the subject of race in “Hello, Privilege,” a full-length documentary in which this former talk show host confronts the ways she’s directly benefited from white privilege and the way others experience it. She sets out to meet with ordinary Americans, community leaders and fellow comedians like Kevin Hart and Tiffany Haddish, to have tough discussions about how those like herself can be better allies to people of color.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Wisconsin Raid Shows the Risk of Illicit Vapes
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 15, 2019
lead_paragraph: “The counterfeit handbag you buy on the corner is not going to kill you but the counterfeit vaping device you buy has a chance to kill you.”

headline: Here Comes the Bride. And the Bride. And the Bride. Mass Weddings Boom in Lebanon.
abstract: As economic pressures prevent young couples from affording marriage ceremonies, powerful benefactors have stepped in to sponsor mass weddings. What’s in it for them? Children for the cause.
lead_paragraph: BKERKE, Lebanon — Classical music swelled as the bride stepped from a white sedan onto a red carpet, took the arm of her tuxedoed groom and walked down the aisle, both grinning as their relatives cheered nearby.

headline: Vaping Bad: Were 2 Wisconsin Brothers the Walter Whites of THC Oils?
abstract: As the authorities work to understand the spate of vaping-related lung illnesses, a small-town drug bust offers a closer look at the vast black market for vaping supplies.
lead_paragraph: BRISTOL, Wis. — The drug bust shattered the early-morning stillness of this manicured subdivision in southeastern Wisconsin. The police pulled up outside a white-shuttered brick condo, jolting neighbors out of their beds with the thud of heavy banging on a door.

headline: The Jets Take On Odell Beckham Jr. (and the Other Browns)
abstract: After calling MetLife Stadium home for five seasons as a Giant, Beckham will return on Monday night for his first game there as a Cleveland Brown.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets safety Jamal Adams was a high school recruit visiting Louisiana State University the first time he met Odell Beckham Jr.

headline: Horse Racing’s Tough Year Keeps Getting Tougher
abstract: A spate of horse deaths. An upended Kentucky Derby. And now questions about a Triple Crown winner and performance-enhancing drugs.
lead_paragraph: Horse owners, trainers and racetrack executives are supposed to take care of their athletes, equine and human. When they do not, both are at risk. As we saw earlier this year, 30 horses had to be euthanized after sustaining devastating injuries at Santa Anita Park in Southern California. Their riders, fortunately, were not seriously injured.

headline: Abused by Soldiers and Militants, Kashmiris Face Dangers in Daily Life
abstract: Residents of Kashmir face strains from both separatists and Indian security forces, worsening a sense of siege as a crackdown continues.
lead_paragraph: SOPORE, Kashmir — Four men carrying pistols and wearing black masks knocked a week ago on the Hamidullah family’s gate. Furious that the wealthy apple traders had violated their ban on doing business, the militants announced that there was a price to pay.

headline: Hong Kong Protesters Hurl Gasoline Bombs at Government Offices
abstract: A day that began with a peaceful, if unauthorized, march by tens of thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators quickly descended into pitched street battles.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Black-clad protesters hurled gasoline bombs at government offices in central Hong Kong on Sunday, as a day that began with a peaceful march by tens of thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators descended into clouds of tear gas deployed by the police and ugly brawls between civilians.

headline: Travel Disasters Happen. Our New Columnist Is Here to Help.
abstract: In Tripped Up, Sarah Firshein, a seasoned travel writer, seeks solutions and restitution for readers’ terrible trips — and tells you how to avoid the same fate.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Maybe We’re Not All Going to Be Gig Economy Workers After All
abstract: Companies like Uber are hitting the turbulence of government regulation, worker resistance and labor market reality.
lead_paragraph: Not too long ago, the “gig economy” looked as if it just might be the future of work in America.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: ‘People Actively Hate Us’: Inside the Border Patrol’s Morale Crisis
abstract: Overwhelmed by desperate migrants and criticized for mistreating the people in their care, many agents have grown defensive, insular and bitter.
lead_paragraph: One Border Patrol agent in Tucson said he had been called a “sellout” and a “kid killer.” In El Paso, an agent said he and his colleagues in uniform had avoided eating lunch together except at certain “BP friendly” restaurants because “there’s always the possibility of them spitting in your food.” An agent in Arizona quit last year out of frustration. “Caging people for a nonviolent activity,” he said, “started to eat away at me.”

headline: A Big New Biography of Susan Sontag Digs to Find the Person Beneath the Icon
abstract: Benjamin Moser’s “Sontag” explores the life and work of the vaunted writer and public intellectual, including her long-term relationship with the photographer Annie Leibovitz.
lead_paragraph: UTRECHT, Netherlands — When asked what she was best known for, Susan Sontag, the formidable 20th-century public intellectual, essayist, novelist and political activist, often told people, with just a hint of irony: the white streak in her dark hair.

headline: Counter Service Tipping: Who Gives?
abstract: Those customer-facing, touch-screen payment systems in restaurants are confounding customers in the U.S. and beyond.
lead_paragraph: It was 2015 when I first began to grapple with tipping when ordering at a counter-service restaurant. I had ordered a fried chicken sandwich at Pine State Biscuits in Portland, Ore., and a friend chided me for not tacking on a gratuity to my credit card payment. I hadn’t even considered it.

headline: Bottled Water Is Sucking Florida Dry
abstract: The state’s aquifers are shrinking, yet corporations want to appropriate even more of them.
lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — Florida has the largest concentration of freshwater springs in the world, but they are being devastated by increasing pollution and drastic declines in water flow. Some springs have dried up from overextraction; others have shown signs of saltwater intrusion and harmful algae blooms.

headline: How to Cook Every Day This Week
abstract: It’s time to get busy: Make granola, crispy gnocchi with brussels sprouts, or even satisfying sloppy Joes.

headline: Minnesota Police Arrest Man in Synagogue Fire
abstract: The Duluth police said they had found no evidence that hate or bias motivated the fire that destroyed the Adas Israel synagogue last week.

But the police said they had not found evidence to suggest that the crime was motivated by hatred or bias.
