abstract: See the looks from the Fendi: Spring 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Fendi: Spring 2020 Collection.

headline: Rock Star Patti Smith, Making Paris Swoon
abstract: She is working toward a third act as a novelist, and her new book, “Year of the Monkey,” blends fact and fiction.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The more Patti Smith rips her French audience, the more they love her.

headline: Imelda Turns Streets Into Rivers in Eastern Texas
abstract: Areas that were hit by Hurricane Harvey in 2017 are now facing heavy rainfall and flooding as Tropical Depression Imelda churns through the Houston region.
lead_paragraph: Areas that were hit by Hurricane Harvey in 2017 are now facing heavy rainfall and flooding as Tropical Depression Imelda churns through the Houston region.

headline: A Wide-Ranging Thai Menu
abstract: The chef at Boran in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, avoids cutting corners in his cuisine.
lead_paragraph: The chef at Boran in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, avoids cutting corners in his cuisine.

headline: Thai Flavors Without Shortcuts at Boran in Carroll Gardens
abstract: The chef makes his own shrimp paste for the fried rice dish khao kluk kapi.
lead_paragraph: The fermented shrimp paste known in Thailand as kapi is notoriously funky, an exaggerated expression of just two ingredients: shrimp and salt. It is also an essential ingredient in the fried rice dish khao kluk kapi.

headline: 20 Under $20: Minimal Effort, Maximum Pleasure
abstract: On those nights when you just need to flop, find a wine that’s alive, interesting, easy to enjoy and moderately priced. It is the reward you deserve.
lead_paragraph: Weeknights are a state of mind. More accurately, they are a state of fatigue.

headline: Amazon Accelerates Efforts to Fight Climate Change
abstract: Pledging that the retailer would be carbon neutral by 2040, Jeff Bezos, the C.E.O., said it was ordering 100,000 electric delivery trucks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Amazon committed on Thursday to meeting the goals of the Paris climate agreement 10 years ahead of schedule and be carbon neutral by 2040, in the company’s most ambitious push yet to combat climate change.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Sept. 25, 2019
abstract: The change in the population across the country has varied considerably in the past decade.
lead_paragraph: The graph originally appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com. By Friday morning, September 26, we will provide the “Reveal” — the graph’s free online link, additional background and questions, shout outs to student comments and headlines, and Stat Nuggets.

headline: What Do Pants Have to Do With Professionalism?
abstract: A woman thinks that her female colleague’s low-cut slacks are inappropriate for the workplace. Should she say something?
lead_paragraph: I am a woman who works at an all-boys high school with a predominantly male faculty and no senior female administrators. (I begin this way because I don’t think women at the school have any extra professionalism points to lose.) A female department head, who does excellent work, often wears pants that are so low-cut that her butt crack becomes visible when she bends over or leans forward from a seated position. I have witnessed this in meetings with male colleagues and students. It makes me uncomfortable. Should I say something to her? She must be aware of the situation, or maybe not?

headline: This Season’s Most Anticipated Books, With Just a Few Spoilers
abstract: The artist Katja Seib illustrates what happens inside fall’s novels (and one poetry collection). Plus, a few other releases on our radar.
lead_paragraph: From the book:

headline: Whistle-Blower Complaint Is Said to Involve Trump and Ukraine
abstract: The complaint, from a member of the intelligence community, remained opaque but involved at least one of the president’s communications with a foreign leader.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A potentially explosive complaint by a whistle-blower in the intelligence community said to involve President Trump emerged on Thursday as the latest front in a continuing oversight dispute between administration officials and House Democrats.

headline: Do We Really Have Only 12 Years to Avoid Climate Disaster?
abstract: The widely recited “12-year deadline” is wrong — and right.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years is at once an eternity and right around the corner. Just ask any parent watching their kids grow up. So it hits home when a growing chorus of often young voices — from proponents of the Green New Deal to the global Youth Climate Strike — says forcefully that the world has 12 years left to avoid disastrous climate change. This is just the latest dire warning about time running out issued over the past 20 years. But this deadline is different — it’s both entirely wrong, and oh so right.

headline: Trump Lawyers Argue He Cannot Be Criminally Investigated
abstract: The president’s legal team is trying to block a subpoena seeking his tax returns, claiming that any criminal investigation of Mr. Trump is unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for President Trump argued in a lawsuit filed on Thursday that he could not be criminally investigated while in office, as they sought to block a subpoena from state prosecutors in Manhattan demanding eight years of his tax returns.

headline: Is It Still Possible to Pay for College?
abstract: For many, the cost of college is far greater than tuition. We asked students and parents to share their experiences.
lead_paragraph: For many, the cost of college is far greater than tuition. We asked students and parents to share their experiences.

headline: Have Images of Trudeau in Blackface and Brownface Affected How You Will Vote in October?
abstract: We want to hear from Canadians on their reactions to the prime minister wearing blackface and brownface.
lead_paragraph: Several images have emerged of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada in blackface and brownface makeup. When the first image surfaced of him in brownface, Mr. Trudeau confirmed that he was in the photo and was dressed as Aladdin. He apologized, saying “It was something that I didn’t think was racist at the time, but now I recognize it was something racist to do, and I am deeply sorry.”

headline: Film Club: ‘If You Didn’t ‘Sharent,’ Did You Even Parent?’
abstract: Are parents endangering their children by sharing images and information about them on social media?
lead_paragraph: Are parents endangering their children by sharing images and information about them on social media?

headline: It’s a Dirty Job, but Someone Has to Do It and Not Get Eaten
abstract: Cleaner shrimp appear to have developed a strategy that protects them from predators they get very close to.
lead_paragraph: If you want to run a successful business, it’s important to provide a valuable service, advertise it well and do your best to get out what you put in. You should also try to make sure your customers don’t eat you.

headline: I Buy Kegs for the Office. Do I Have to Buy Tampons, Too?
abstract: Here’s the difference between “nice to have” and “need to have” products at work.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, even if you want them withheld. Letters may be edited.

headline: India Is Building a More Prosperous Kashmir
abstract: Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan can run his own economy into the ground, but not those of his neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few weeks, we have seen a plethora of comments from Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan and senior officials of his government painting an apocalyptic picture of India’s reorganization of its province of Jammu and Kashmir — and raising the threat of conflict, including nuclear war, with India.

headline: Vaping Illnesses Increase to 530 Probable Cases, C.D.C. Says
abstract: More than three-fourths of those sickened are male, health officials said, and half are under 25. Missouri reported the eighth death linked to vaping during this summer’s crisis.
lead_paragraph: The number of vaping-related lung illnesses has risen to 530 probable cases, according to an update on Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and a Missouri man became the eighth to die from the mysterious ailments.

headline: States Warn Residents About Rare Mosquito-Borne Illness That Has Killed 6
abstract: Health authorities are investigating other cases of Eastern equine encephalitis, a virus transmitted through a mosquito bite, which has left at least six people dead in three states this year.
lead_paragraph: Health authorities have warned residents to protect themselves against bites from mosquitoes that can transmit a rare virus that has killed at least six people in three states this year.

headline: Yeehaw
abstract: How “Old Town Road” became our song of the year.
lead_paragraph: How “Old Town Road” gave us hope without making us cringe, and became our song of the year.

headline: The Best of Milan Fashion Week, in Pictures
abstract: All the highlights from the spring 2020 shows.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here for the T List newsletter, a weekly roundup of what T Magazine editors are noticing and coveting now.]

headline: ‘Ad Astra’ Review: Brad Pitt Orbits the Powers of Darkness
abstract: The latest from the director James Gray centers on an astronaut whose mission into deep space becomes a voyage of self-discovery.
lead_paragraph: In “Ad Astra,” an adventure tale weighed down by the burdens of masculinity, Brad Pitt plays an astronaut in flight. The film is a lovely, sincere and sometimes dopey confessional about fathers and sons, love and loss that takes the shape of a far out if deeply inward trip. As in many expeditions, the journey doesn’t simply progress; it stutters and freezes and periodically backslides. Yet each step — the story begins on Earth and soon rockets to the dark side of the moon — is a reminder that in order to get found, you need to get lost.

headline: Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, 83, Tunisia Autocrat Ousted in Arab Spring, Dies
abstract: His oppressive rule set off uprisings that spread throughout the Arab world. He died in exile in Saudi Arabia, which had refused to extradite him.
lead_paragraph: Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, Tunisia’s former autocratic president whose extravagant life and oppressive rule inspired the first Arab Spring revolts of 2011, died on Thursday in exile in Saudi Arabia. He was 83.

headline: ‘Rambo: Last Blood’ Review: Death Country for Old Men
abstract: While the killings in this continuation of Rambo saga are zestfully depicted, the movie overall is rote.
lead_paragraph: Mexico is a North American country of over 700,000 square miles, comprising 31 states. At least that’s the case in our reality. In the reality of “Rambo: Last Blood,” starring Sylvester Stallone as the titular vengeful killing machine, Mexico is a very, very bad neighborhood that’s about a 40-minute drive from the peaceful Arizona ranch where our hero will, if the title of this movie is to be trusted, make his final stand.

headline: Survey Shows Broad Opposition to Trump Trade Policies
abstract: An increasing share of Americans say the tariff fight with China will be bad for the United States, and the concern crosses party lines.
lead_paragraph: Economists and business leaders have been warning for months that President Trump’s trade war could damage the economy. The American public increasingly shares those concerns.

headline: Outside Prison Walls: Waiting, Spinning, Flying
abstract: In a park next to Sing Sing, an aerial dance performance focuses on the experiences of women with jailed loved ones.
lead_paragraph: Though it sits right next to a prison, Louis Engel Waterfront Park in Ossining, N.Y., is a family-friendly place. There, on the shore of the Hudson River, are picnic tables, a playground, a splash pad — and, this weekend only, a circular platform that rotates and wobbles like a Tilt-a-Whirl. People attached to it by cables can fly.

headline: The Fashion Week Diary of Sandy Liang, Fleece Phenom
abstract: ‘Gorpcore’ jackets and ’90s-inspired comfort items have made her one of the most sought-after designers in New York.
lead_paragraph: Sandy Liang hates Fashion Week. She hates the hype and the parties and the pressure, the murmurings about how so-and-so made an appearance at such-and-such. “But when my show is happening, I’m like, ‘This is all worth it,’” Ms. Liang said.

headline: The Surprise of Jaap van Zweden’s Philharmonic Tenure? Surprise
abstract: Starting his second New York season, this conductor has been more innovative than our critic had expected.
lead_paragraph: It turned out to be a wonderful idea for the New York Philharmonic to open Jaap van Zweden’s second season as its music director by inviting Kelli O’Hara, a reigning Broadway star, to sing Samuel Barber’s poignant and profound “Knoxville: Summer of 1915.”

headline: ‘Where’s My Roy Cohn?’ Review: A Fixer’s Progress
abstract: A documentary traces the life and times of a notorious lawyer whose career stretched from Joseph McCarthy to Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: In a television interview near the end of his life, Roy Cohn predicted that his obituaries would lead with Senator Joseph McCarthy. He wasn’t wrong. Thanks partly to the televised Army-McCarthy hearings, Cohn’s role as the Wisconsin senator’s youthful counsel was imprinted on the public memory and seemed, when Cohn died of AIDS in 1986, to be the most significant episode in a contentious public career.

headline: South Sudan Oil Consortium Funded Militias Accused of Atrocities, Report Says
abstract: The report by a watchdog group linked Dar Petroleum Operating Company to the president and outlined other major players it said were complicit in violence and corruption.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A South Sudanese oil consortium directly financed militias accused of committing atrocities in the country’s civil war, according to an investigative report released on Thursday amid growing calls for accountability for the conflict’s human rights abuses.

headline: Smart Lights Enhance Home Security and Shine a Light on Crime
abstract: Smart lighting brightens up your home and makes life more convenient. But it’s also an easy and effective way to enhance home security.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to makeshift home security strategies, some people go with a yappy terrier, some choose a battery of fake cameras and others rely on a generic alarm-company badge staked in the front yard.

headline: U.S. Orders Duke and U.N.C. to Recast Tone in Mideast Studies
abstract: The Education Department is investigating a Middle East studies program run by Duke and the University of North Carolina, citing, among other issues, how Judaism is discussed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Education Department has ordered Duke University and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill to remake the Middle East studies program run jointly by the two schools after concluding that it was offering students a biased curriculum that, among other complaints, did not present enough “positive” imagery of Judaism and Christianity in the region.

headline: DealBook Special Section: DC Strategy Forum
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin hosted newsmakers from the worlds of business and policy earlier this month to try to solve problems from student debt to carbon emissions.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Ross Sorkin hosted newsmakers from the worlds of business and policy earlier this month to try to solve problems from student debt to carbon emissions.

headline: Female Artists Made Little Progress in Museums Since 2008, Survey Finds
abstract: In the past decade, only 11 percent of all work acquired by the country’s top museums was by women.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, there has been a sense in the art world that gender equity was on the horizon: Emerging female artists were landing high-profile solo shows, museums were staging women-themed exhibitions, grants were being awarded to boost female artists, and long-neglected artists were being given overdue recognition.

headline: Siberian Shaman on Trek to ‘Cast Out’ Putin From the Kremlin Is Arrested
abstract: Jittery about unrest, Russian security forces detained the mystic on his self-proclaimed mission to drive out President Vladimir V. Putin, whom he called a “demon.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Increasingly jittery over all forms of public protest, Russian security forces on Thursday cut short a trek of thousands of miles to Moscow by a Siberian shaman who has been walking for six months on a mission to drive President Vladimir V. Putin and “demonic” forces from the Kremlin.

headline: Is It Time to Quit Vaping?
abstract: Health officials have recommended that people refrain from using e-cigarettes as they investigate a severe lung illness that has killed eight people. Here are some things to consider.
lead_paragraph: Allegations of illegal marketing tactics. More than 500 cases of severe lung illness in 38 states. Eight deaths. A proposed federal ban of most flavored e-cigarettes, and new efforts in many states to counter an epidemic of youth vaping.

headline: ‘Loro’ Review: A Corrupt Leader, and the People Who Love Him
abstract: Toni Servillo plays the former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi in Paolo Sorrentino’s extravagant portrait.
lead_paragraph: Even before he shows up onscreen, about 20 minutes into “Loro,” Silvio Berlusconi is the center of attention. His face is tattooed on a woman’s lower back, and he is talked about constantly, though rarely by name. When people say “him,” chances are they mean, well, him, and to dispel any ambiguity they sometimes double up the masculine pronoun. The prime minister of Italy for most of the 1990s and early 2000s (and currently a member of the European Parliament) is twice the man anyone else could hope to be: he’s “him him.”

headline: Officer Who Guarded El Chapo’s Wife Is Accused of Dealing Drugs
abstract: The 12-year police veteran worked off-duty providing security to the Mexican drug lord’s wife during his trial.

headline: What Students Are Saying About: Mental Health Days, Self-Doubt and Their Fashion Idols
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: This past week in our writing prompts, we invited students to share their thoughts on forgiveness and self-doubt, video games and fashion, their family cooks and their hometown’s shortcomings, plus much more.

headline: The Saudis Are Keeping the Oil Flowing, but It’s Not Easy
abstract: Saudi Aramco is using up its reserves and buying some oil products in a bid to keep customers happy while damaged facilities are repaired.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, the top officials of the Saudi oil industry held a news conference and delivered a very upbeat message. Saudi Arabia’s production capacity, which had been crippled by last weekend’s aerial attack, would be “fully restored” by the end of September, according to Saudi Aramco, the national oil company.

headline: Joe Biden’s Positions on Race Over the Years
abstract: One reader calls Charles M. Blow’s critique “character assassination” while another views it as “incisive.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Cuts $100 Million in Aid to Afghanistan, Citing Government Corruption
abstract: The funding cut was announced a week before Afghanistan holds national elections, and in the wake of failed peace talks with the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department cut $100 million in aid for Afghanistan on Thursday as the Trump administration’s chief peace negotiator briefed House lawmakers on the failed efforts to strike a deal with the Taliban and wind down the 18-year war.

headline: Can Kamala Harris Persuade the American Jury?
abstract: Despite her “stellar résumé,” a reader writes, she has not yet made a persuasive case. Another chides her for saying or doing what is expedient.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Birds Are Vanishing From North America
abstract: The number of birds in the United States and Canada has declined by 3 billion, or 29 percent, over the past half-century, scientists find.
lead_paragraph: The skies are emptying out.

headline: The Crisis for Birds Is a Crisis for Us All
abstract: The mass disappearance of North American birds is a dire warning about the planet’s well-being.
lead_paragraph: Nearly one-third of the wild birds in the United States and Canada have vanished since 1970, a staggering loss that suggests the very fabric of North America’s ecosystem is unraveling.

headline: Dia:Chelsea to Offer Free Admission
abstract: When the exhibition space reopens in 2020 with a project by Renata Lucas, all five of Dia’s New York City sites will be free.
lead_paragraph: When Dia:Chelsea reopens in September 2020, with a new site-specific project by the Brazilian artist Renata Lucas, it will be with free admission. The Chelsea space will join four other Dia sites in New York City, including Walter De Maria’s “The New York Earth Room,” that are currently free. A sixth admission-free space, Dia:SoHo, will open in fall 2022.

headline: Yankees’ Domingo German on Leave Amid Domestic Violence Inquiry
abstract: German will be unable to play while M.L.B. conducts an investigation into an incident that was said to have occurred this week.
lead_paragraph: Domingo German, one of the Yankees’ best starting pitchers this season, was placed on administrative leave on Thursday under M.L.B.’s domestic violence policy, the league office announced. The move, which temporarily bars German from playing, is a precursor to a larger investigation, which could lead to a suspension.

headline: Airbnb Says It Plans to Go Public in 2020
abstract: Making a public statement about a stock market debut in a particular year is unusual among technology start-ups, which typically keep their plans secret.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb said on Thursday that it planned to go public in 2020, becoming one of the last of a generation of prominent technology start-ups to aim for the stock market, even as some of its brethren have struggled since listing their shares.

headline: Scientists to Drift With Arctic Ice to Study Climate Change
abstract: The Mosaic expedition, a $155 million undertaking five years in the making, aims for a better understanding of how global warming will affect the Arctic.
lead_paragraph: TROMSO, Norway — Just days before the German icebreaker Polarstern sets sail on the largest and most ambitious climate-change research expedition the Arctic has ever seen, an air of quiet pandemonium prevails aboard ship.

headline: Scientists Identify Neurons That Help the Brain Forget
abstract: In mice, cells in the hypothalamus clear out old memories while the animals sleep.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in April 1929, a journalist from a Moscow newspaper turned up in Alexander Luria’s office with an unusual problem: He never forgot things.

headline: The Met Will Stage Its First Opera by a Black Composer
abstract: The company is making plans to bring Terence Blanchard’s “Fire Shut Up in My Bones” to New York.
lead_paragraph: In its 136-year history, the Metropolitan Opera has never staged an opera by a black composer. But that will finally change: The company said on Thursday that it would present “Fire Shut Up in My Bones,” by the composer and jazz trumpeter Terence Blanchard, in a coming season.

headline: New York City Ballet Is Back, and the Real Jewels Are the Dancers
abstract: The company returns with two sides of George Balanchine: the lustrous “Jewels” and a haunted-house fright (and delight).
lead_paragraph: There are certain New York City Ballet performances that have a way of making you feel you’ve danced yourself, even as you sit, quiet and still, in your seat. On Tuesday, George Balanchine’s “Jewels” — a visceral journey through three schools of dance, from the French romanticism of “Emeralds” to the jazzy, American tour de force of “Rubies” to the Russian majesty of “Diamonds” — did just that.

headline: Tekashi 69 Testifies on Kidnapping, Jim Jones and Cardi B
abstract: It was the third day of testimony by Tekashi 69, who has sat for hours, detailing the inner workings of the gang and hip-hop industry.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Ed Buck Faces Federal Drug Charge in Death of Man in His Home
abstract: The authorities outlined a disturbing pattern in which they say that Mr. Buck traded drugs and money for sexual favors. They said there were at least 11 victims.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Federal prosecutors said Thursday that they had charged Ed Buck, a small-time Democratic donor and political activist, with a federal drug crime in the death of  one of two men who died of overdoses in his West Hollywood home.

headline: Name a New Rail Tunnel After Trump?
abstract: Readers react to an editorial. Also: Turnover in the White House; a car buyer’s resolution.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Worse Than Anyone Expected’: Air Travel Emissions Vastly Outpace Predictions
abstract: The findings put pressure on airline regulators to take stronger action to fight climate change as they prepare for a summit next week.
lead_paragraph: Greenhouse gas emissions from commercial air travel are growing at a faster clip than predicted in previous, already dire, projections, according to new research — putting pressure on airline regulators to take stronger action as they prepare for a summit next week.

headline: ‘It’s Not Full Citizenship’: What It Means to Be Puerto Rican Post-María
abstract: In his new book, “Fantasy Island,” Ed Morales recounts the history of the island’s relationship with the United States.
lead_paragraph: El Espace is a column dedicated to news and culture relevant to Latinx communities. Expect politics, arts, analysis, personal essays and more. ¿Lo mejor? It’ll be in Spanish and English, so you can forward it to your tía, your primo Lalo or anyone else (read: everyone).

headline: Is America’s Health Care System a Fixer-Upper or a Teardown?
abstract: To understand the competing Democratic health care plans, consider an elaborate home construction metaphor.
lead_paragraph: Imagine the United States health care system as a sort of weird old house. There are various wings, added at different points in history, featuring different architectural styles.

headline: To Raise Wages, Make Companies Compete for Workers
abstract: After a 2008 Oregon law made it easier for workers to take a job with a different company, wages increased significantly.
lead_paragraph: It’s a truism that capitalists don’t like competition — especially for workers. In recent decades, American companies have tried to limit this problem by requiring millions of employees to sign contracts prohibiting them from moving to rival firms.

headline: Ady Barkan Won’t Let Dying Stop His Activism
abstract: Democratic presidential candidates are flocking to California to meet Mr. Barkan, who is dying of A.L.S. But the sicker he gets, the more famous he becomes.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — First there was the viral video from an airplane, where he confronted former Senator Jeff Flake about the Republican tax bill. Then he was arrested, in his wheelchair, in the rotunda of the Russell Senate Office Building protesting the Supreme Court nomination of Brett M. Kavanaugh. And in the past few months, Democratic presidential candidates have flocked to California to sit down with him and discuss “Medicare for all.”

headline: The Director of the New York Film Festival Is to Step Down
abstract: Kent Jones, who is also a filmmaker, has served as the event’s director since 2012. He will also depart as the chairman of its selection committee.
lead_paragraph: For several years, Kent Jones has been a high-profile director in two senses of the word. Soon, he will simply be one kind.

headline: Car Plows Into Amish Horse-Drawn Buggy, Killing 3 Children
abstract: The Michigan crash underscored a risk faced by a sect that eschews cars and other modern technology.
lead_paragraph: Three Amish children died on Wednesday in Michigan after a car plowed into the back of their horse and buggy, underscoring an all-too-common danger faced by the sect, which rejects automobiles and other modern technology.

headline: Bottega Veneta M/W: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Bottega Veneta M/W: Spring 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Bottega Veneta M/W: Spring 2020 Collection.

headline: House Approves Short-Term Spending Bill That Would Stave Off Shutdown
abstract: The bill, which the Senate is also expected to pass before funding lapses on Oct. 1, would extend funding for all federal government departments and agencies through Nov. 21.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday approved a short-term spending bill that would stave off a government shutdown until just before Thanksgiving, allowing lawmakers additional time to resolve disputes over annual spending legislation without a funding lapse.

headline: Maurice Ferré, Miami’s First Hispanic Mayor, Dies at 84
abstract: He led the city through a defining period of growth and tumult for 12 years. But he could ultimately not withstand its demographic transformation.

headline: The Empire State Building: Renewing the Affair
abstract: A revamped tower wants your love. It’s offering King Kong, flying steel girders — and a vertiginous ride to the 102nd floor. The city’s first supertall building also offers grand views of the new New York.
lead_paragraph: How do you take the measure of a New York City more physically transformed than at any time since the 1920s? The new glass “downtowns” that have exploded in the last decade and a half in Long Island City and over in Jersey City. Hudson Yards’ crystalline shafts to the far west. Residential towers marching in lock step along the Queens and Brooklyn edges of the East River. The skinny supertalls slicing into the view of Central Park.

headline: The Views From the Top: How They Measure Up
abstract: We compare Top of the Rock, One World Observatory and Edge.
lead_paragraph: While there are plenty of private observatories at rooftop bars across the boroughs, Manhattan offers three public decks with distinct views and experiences: Top of the Rock, One World Observatory and, of course, the Empire State Building’s observation deck. The Edge, a wedge-shaped deck cantilevered from a Hudson Yards skyscraper, will soon join them. (One Vanderbilt, a commercial supertall topping out at 1,401 feet, and still under construction along Vanderbilt Avenue across from Grand Central Station, also plans a deck.) Here’s how the views compare.

headline: Justin Trudeau, Kashmir, Climate Change:Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Trudeau's brownface scandal grows.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Should You Keep Taking Zantac for Your Heartburn?
abstract: Versions of the drug have been found to contain low levels of a carcinogen. But it’s still on pharmacy shelves. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: This article was updated on Sept. 20 to reflect actions taken by other countries.

headline: One Part Gangster, One Part Philosophical Clown
abstract: “Night Boat to Tangier,” by Kevin Barry, features two battered old Irish drug smugglers right out of Beckett.
lead_paragraph: NIGHT BOAT TO TANGIER By Kevin Barry

headline: Is Manhattan’s Flea Market Culture Dying?
abstract: The antiques zone where Andy Warhol shopped for curios is shrinking. And with it, a quirky basement gathering spot.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: He Captured a Clandestine Gay Culture Amid the Derelict Piers
abstract: Alvin Baltrop’s photographs of the abandoned Hudson River piers and the people who populated them in the 1970s and ’80s have been all but ignored. Until now.
lead_paragraph: New York City is a gateway for fresh art talent but it’s also an archive of art careers past. Some are visible, in the “active” file. Most are buried deep. A few surface only after artists have departed, as is the case with the American photographer Alvin Baltrop, who was unknown to the mainstream art world when he died in 2004 at 55, and who now has a bright, tough monument of a retrospective at the Bronx Museum of the Arts.

headline: After Resisting, McConnell and Senate G.O.P. Back Election Security Funding
abstract: Stung by the “Moscow Mitch” moniker, Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, threw his weight behind an infusion of $250 million for states to bolster election security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing mounting criticism for blocking proposals to bolster election security, Senator Mitch McConnell on Thursday threw his weight behind a new infusion of $250 million to help states guard against outside interference in the 2020 voting.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: This weekend offers the Emmys, a great British dramedy and a new Netflix documentary series on Bill Gates.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.

headline: Attacks Expose Flaws in Saudi Arabia’s Expensive Military
abstract: The Saudi military could not protect a prized asset — oil installations — from an attack by low-flying cruise missiles that caused a significant spike in crude oil prices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the past half-century, the United States has trained and supplied the Saudi military, selling the wealthy kingdom more than $150 billion in dazzling high-technology weapons, including fighter jets and air defense systems.

headline: 8 Things to Do With Your Kids in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

abstract: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

abstract: Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.

lead_paragraph: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

lead_paragraph: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: Nike Drops Antonio Brown Amid Sexual Assault Lawsuit
abstract: It is the second sponsor to end its relationship with the Patriots receiver.
lead_paragraph: The sportswear giant Nike confirmed on Thursday that it had ended its sponsorship of Antonio Brown in the wake of a lawsuit accusing the New England Patriots wide receiver of rape.

headline: Moschino: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Moschino: Spring 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Moschino: Spring 2020 Collection.

headline: The New York Restaurant That Feels Like an Italian Farmhouse
abstract: For 25 years, Il Buco has served perfect pasta and Umbrian charm to the loyal customers who have returned again and again to its small cobblestoned block.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.

headline: Hard Times in Silicon Valley? Not for the Payments Start-Up Stripe
abstract: Known for its quiet and steady growth, Stripe said on Thursday that it received new funding that made it worth $35 billion.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Even though high-flying start-ups have met a cool reception on Wall Street in recent months, the willingness of investors to make big bets has not exactly slackened.

headline: The Downfall of Canada’s Dreamy Boyfriend
abstract: For Americans, Justin Trudeau’s undoing has been swift. For Canadians, it has been a long time coming.
lead_paragraph: “He is getting so embarrassing, tbh.”

headline: How to Wear Fall’s Polished Pieces Without Looking Stuffy
abstract: From mid-length skirts to polo shirts, preppy staples have returned to the runways — but they needn’t feel too buttoned-up.
lead_paragraph: When Hedi Slimane showed his take on ’70s-era bourgeois dress codes for Celine in March, with its tweed skirts and pussy bow blouses, he solidified a polished, preppy look that had been taking shape on the runways for the past several seasons. Think polo shirts, loafers and plaids. But while these pieces might call to mind country clubs and college campuses, they can look fresh, too, especially when worn in unexpected ways. Here, a roundup of classic, preppy wardrobe staples — from twin sets to pearl necklaces — styled with a subtle street-inspired edge, to carry you into the cooler months.

headline: Are Biden and Sanders Too Old to Be President?
abstract: Jimmy Carter seems to think there should be an age limit for the highest office.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Jimmy Carter on a Presidential Age Limit and Almond vs. Peanut Butter
abstract: Speaking two weeks before his 95th birthday, Mr. Carter said he wouldn’t be up to the rigors of the nation’s top job if he were 15 years younger.
lead_paragraph: In widely circulated remarks, Jimmy Carter, the longest-living president in United States history, weighed in on a range of issues, including the appropriate age for a commander in chief, Democrats’ 2020 prospects and the relative merits of various nut products.

headline: Mark von Hagen, Critic of Times’s Stalin Coverage, Dies at 65
abstract: A historian, he was asked by the paper to judge whether a correspondent’s Pulitzer Prize should be revoked because of biased reporting. He said it should be.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times had long distanced itself from Walter Duranty’s reporting from the Soviet Union in 1931 when it received a letter in 2003 from the Pulitzer Prize board asking whether the prize awarded to Mr. Duranty for that coverage should be rescinded.

headline: Justin Trudeau, Vaping, Birds: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Canadians Ask if They Can Forgive Trudeau
abstract: Canadian readers debate whether to support the prime minister in a national election only weeks away.
lead_paragraph: A series of revelations that Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has worn blackface and brownface has rocked his re-election campaign and forced the country to confront questions about race and forgiveness.

headline: Brownface, Blackface and About-Face. Is Trudeau Who He Says He Is?
abstract: Many Canadians saw Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s record in office as evidence in his favor, if not enough to exonerate him for recent photos and video showing him wearing dark makeup.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canadians from Newfoundland to British Columbia struggled with the past misdeeds of their leader this week when images surfaced of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in blackface and brownface makeup.

headline: Hurricane Jerry Strengthens to a Category 2 in the Atlantic
abstract: The storm is expected to weaken over the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Jerry strengthened to a Category 2 storm on Friday with maximum sustained winds of 100 miles per hour. It was one of several storms churning at the midpoint of the Atlantic hurricane season, as Texas reels from the effects of the former Tropical Storm Imelda, which made landfall this week, and the Bahamas digs out from the devastation of Hurricane Dorian this month.

headline: Purdue Pharma Warns That Sackler Family May Walk From Opioid Deal
abstract: The company said the cost of fighting lawsuits brought by states could jeopardize its owners’ ability to contribute $3 billion to a national opioids settlement.
lead_paragraph: Members of the Sackler family could withdraw their pledge to pay $3 billion as part of a nationwide deal to address the opioid crisis if a bankruptcy judge does not block outstanding state lawsuits against them and their company, Purdue Pharma, Purdue lawyers said in a legal complaint.

headline: Trump Declares War on California
abstract: It’s a liberal state, so it must be punished.
lead_paragraph: I’m on a number of right-wing mailing lists, and I try to at least skim what they’re going on about in any given week; this often gives me advance warning about the next wave of manufactured outrage. Lately I’ve been seeing dire warnings that if Democrats win next year they’ll try to turn America into (cue scary background music) California, which the writers portray as a socialist hellhole.

headline: A Brief History of the Warren Presidency
abstract: A look back at American politics from the year 2050.
lead_paragraph: A crisis of legitimacy swept across American politics in the second decade of the 21st century. Many people had the general conviction that the old order was corrupt and incompetent. There was an inchoate desire for some radical transformation. This mood swept the Republican Party in 2016 as Donald Trump eviscerated the G.O.P. establishment and it swept through the Democratic Party in 2020.

headline: De Blasio to Developers: Donate to My Nonprofit. $125,000 Came.
abstract: Three developers were fined tens of thousands of dollars for potentially violating lobbying laws by donating to Mayor Bill de Blasio’s nonprofit group.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Sean’s Spicy Salsa
abstract: Behind the neon-green ruffles, a manifestation of a reality TV presidency.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox.

headline: Attack on Saudi Oil Facilities Tests U.S. Guarantee to Defend Gulf
abstract: The American hesitation to take military action may signal a weakening of its commitment to protect the Arab Persian Gulf and could embolden Iran.
lead_paragraph: The oil-rich monarchies of the Persian Gulf have relied for decades on the promise of protection by the United States military, a commitment sealed by the rollback of the 1990 invasion of Kuwait and reinforced by a half dozen American military bases that sprang up around the region.

headline: Teachers in New York City Barred From Attending Climate Protest
abstract: The decision underlines the difficulties in separating the politics of climate change from teaching about the science of it.
lead_paragraph: [Live coverage of the climate strike in New York City.]

headline: Man Trained by Hezbollah Scouted Times Square as Target, Prosecutors Say
abstract: He is accused of spending years gathering intelligence on sites in New York, including airports, tunnels and bridges.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Colt to Suspend Production of AR-15 Rifles for Consumers
abstract: The gun manufacturer said the market had an adequate supply of sporting rifles and it would focus on its military and law enforcement contracts instead.
lead_paragraph: The gun maker Colt said on Thursday that it would effectively suspend production of sporting rifles, including the AR-15, for the civilian market but continue to manufacture rifles for government weapons contracts.

headline: Bezos and Zuckerberg Take Their Pitches to Washington
abstract: The Amazon and Facebook leaders were there for different reasons, but the appearances highlighted their companies’ need to reshape the public debate about their practices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two of the technology industry’s leading figures descended on Washington on Thursday as their companies face growing political pressure.

headline: For D.C. Statehood Advocates, a Hearing Marks Another Step Forward
abstract: With Democrats in control, the House gave the long-suffering movement for statehood a hearing for the first time in more than 20 years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Washington residents lined the Capitol Hill hallways, waving the red and white District of Columbia flag. They stood outside the Metro handing out buttons that declared, “I AM a citizen,” and stickers that said, “I showed up 4 D.C. statehood.”

headline: YouTube Reverses Position, Decides Top Creators Can Remain Verified
abstract: YouTube said it would remove verified status from many large accounts. Creators were baffled and upset. And then YouTube changed its mind.
lead_paragraph: YouTube channels that currently have verification will now remain verified, the company announced on Friday evening in a tweet by its chief executive.

headline: Deportation Exemptions to Resume for Immigrants Needing Medical Treatment
abstract: In a policy reversal, the Trump administration said it would allow some immigrants to avoid deportation while undergoing lifesaving medical treatment.
lead_paragraph: In a policy reversal, the Trump administration on Thursday said it would resume a program that enabled some immigrants to remain in the country without fear of deportation while undergoing lifesaving medical treatment.

headline: Trump to Host Australian Prime Minister on a Rare State Visit
abstract: When it comes to diplomatic visits, the president seems to prefer being the guest rather than the host.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When it comes to diplomatic visits, President Trump seems to prefer being the guest rather than the host.

headline: ‘Urgent Concern’ About the President
abstract: A whistle-blower’s report has alarmed the intelligence agencies’ watchdog. Why won’t the administration share it with Congress?
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that a whistle-blower in the intelligence community files a complaint about the president of the United States. But it seems to have happened last month, when an unidentified intelligence employee alerted the inspector general of the intelligence community, Michael Atkinson, to multiple acts by President Trump, including a promise he is said to have made to a foreign leader during a phone call.

headline: For Some in Texas, Imelda’s Heavy Rain Feels Like Harvey 2.0
abstract: Tropical Depression Imelda was nowhere near as widespread as Hurricane Harvey. But in some areas, the flooding was worse.
lead_paragraph: ANAHUAC, Tex. — Sitting in a chair next to a green cot inside a disaster shelter, his small dog on his lap, Edmund Hann was in a daze. Two years ago, Hurricane Harvey flooded his home in Winnie, Tex. On Thursday, Tropical Depression Imelda did the same.

headline: F.B.I. Agent Testifies That He Sent Questions for C.I.A. Detainees
abstract: In a pretrial hearing for the accused 9/11 plotters at Guantánamo Bay, the agent acknowledged previously unconfirmed collaboration with the interrogation program.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: Milton’s Shakespeare Was Just a Trans-Atlantic Tweet Away
abstract: A scholar in England suspected annotations in a First Folio at the Free Library of Philadelphia were John Milton’s, so he connected the dots with someone who had studied the work for a decade.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Jason Scott-Warren recalled the intense emotions he felt when he started to suspect that the scribbled notes in the margins of a copy of Shakespeare’s First Folio owned by the Philadelphia Free Library were written by none other than John Milton.

headline: Corrections: September 20, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, September 20, 2019.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day: Whistle-Blower Sets Off Battle Involving Trump
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 20, 2019
lead_paragraph: “I don’t think this is a problem of the law, I think the law is written very clearly. I think the law is just fine. The problem lies elsewhere.”

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Immigrants. Emigrants. Refugees. Exiles. People move all the time, for all different reasons, and it’s not easy even when they speak the language and escape political notice: Just ask anybody who’s ever been the new kid at school. This week we recommend a number of books about the migrant experience, from an expansive new anthology (“The Penguin Book of Migration Literature”) to a deeply reported portrait of one Filipino family (“A Good Provider Is One Who Leaves”) to a story collection about the Haitian diaspora and a novel about immigrant workers in Malaysia.

headline: For Trump, a Time of Indecision
abstract: In discussions with his staff, Mr. Trump has made clear he wants to accomplish something big, but seems stymied as to what it might be, according to interviews with a half-dozen aides and advisers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaking to a Fox News reporter near the Mexican border on Wednesday, President Trump seemed taken aback when asked if the White House was preparing to roll out gun control proposals the next day, a timeline administration officials had suggested was likely.

headline: Yankees Win the A.L. East for the First Time Since 2012
abstract: Despite setting a major league record for players on the injured list, the Yankees used both their payroll and modern baseball acumen to climb back to the top of their division.
lead_paragraph: A month into the 2019 season, the Yankees were a sliver above .500 and their lineup was jarring. As the team faced the San Francisco Giants on April 26, five Yankees who had started on opening day were on the injured list, including the star outfielders Aaron Judge and Giancarlo Stanton. Key pitchers such as Luis Severino and Dellin Betances had been out since spring training.

headline: Generosity
abstract: Luke Vaughn makes us rub our temples, in a thoughtful manner.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Happy end of the week, everyone! Deb is working on something secret (but relevant to crosswords) and I’m pinch hitting a bit here and there. I’m ripping through these columns as I’m preparing for a trip, so if any of you shining stars elucidate my omissions it will be greatly appreciated, as always.

headline: Review: ‘Novenas’ Offers Prayers for a Hospital That Died
abstract: The epicenter of New York’s AIDS epidemic, St. Vincent’s (1849-2010) is the subject of a memorial service that’s also a play.
lead_paragraph: All is sweetness in the church courtyard off West 11th Street where the prologue to “Novenas for a Lost Hospital” takes place. A woman sings a pretty song; another plays the flute; several people with bright smiles and diaphanous garments dance. When a pitcher and bowl are passed around, and the audience of 60 is encouraged to wash hands, it’s a pleasure but a mystery: Are we about to engage in a new-age Christian ritual or a medical procedure?

headline: How Rugby Became a Touchstone for a Reporter Abroad
abstract: As the Rugby World Cup kicks off today, one correspondent reflects on how the sport made her feel closer to home.
lead_paragraph: The Australia Letter is a weekly newsletter from our Australia bureau. Sign up to get it by email. This week’s issue is written by Jamie Tarabay, a correspondent with the Australia bureau.

headline: Wishing the World Could Be More Soft
abstract: She expected to give birth on Christmas Day. What happened instead was too hard to explain.
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, shortly before my 34th birthday and during an early cold snap in the Adirondack Mountains of upstate New York, my husband and I bought two cemetery plots. Only one was for us (to share). We had gone there to purchase another and added ours only because the cemetery was having a sale: Buy one plot, get a second at half price.

headline: Climate Strike, YouTube, Saudi Arabia: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Voces’ and ‘Between Two Ferns: The Movie’
abstract: A documentary on PBS revisits a 1918 Texas massacre. And a “Between Two Ferns” movie hits Netflix.
lead_paragraph: VOCES 10 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). “For years after the massacre, horses would rear and wouldn’t go near the spot where those bodies lay.” That’s from “Porvenir, Texas,” an hourlong documentary that will air Friday night as part of this PBS program dedicated to Latino culture. The documentary takes as its subject a 1918 Texas massacre that left 15 people of Mexican descent dead and involved Texas Rangers and United States Army cavalry soldiers. The event serves here as a way to discuss the period from the mid-19th century into the 20th century during which thousands of Latino men, women and children were killed by lynch mobs in the American West.

headline: As Narendra Modi Heads to U.S., Controversy Follows Him
abstract: Activists urged the Gates Foundation not to recognize India’s prime minister with a prestigious award. They accuse him of leading India into “deadly chaos.”
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — As Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India prepares for a big trip to the United States, human rights groups and three Nobel Peace Prize winners have criticized the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation for its plan to bestow a prestigious award upon Mr. Modi next week during his visit.

headline: China Detains FedEx Pilot Amid Rising U.S.-China Tensions
abstract: The seizure of the pilot, allegedly because air-gun pellets were found in his luggage, marks the latest difficulty for foreign travelers and companies in China.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The authorities in southern China have detained an American pilot who works for FedEx, the latest in a series of difficulties for American travelers and companies in China.

headline: Word + Quiz: rejoinder
abstract: This word has appeared in 51 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: Late Night Shocker: A Canadian Scandal!
abstract: Trevor Noah’s take on the revelation that Prime Minister Justin Trudeau wore blackface: “I’m just sad to see another black man being brought down.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Bears (and Lynx and Rhinos) Are Officially ‘Dangerous,’ N.Y. Says
abstract: A spate of attacks on people prompted the state to expand its list of harmful animals to include more snakes, monkeys and others.
lead_paragraph: Thursday was a tough day to own a Eurasian lynx.

headline: Hurricane Maria, 2 Years Later: ‘We Want Another Puerto Rico’
abstract: From the ruins of the storm rose a grass-roots movement that unseated a governor. But what happens now?
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — The giant protests are gone now from the streets of Puerto Rico, much like the old governor they ousted in what came to be known as “la revolución de verano,” the summer revolution.

headline: In Pac-12 Football: Empty Seats, TV Woes and Recruiting Gaps
abstract: The chasm is growing between the Pacific-12 Conference and its Power Five counterparts. And its rescue hopes are pinned on a new TV deal in 2024.
lead_paragraph: When Larry Scott, the Pacific-12 Conference commissioner, began jumping through hoops for television money, he envisioned nights like Friday, a prime-time audience on national television for a compelling game: No. 10 Utah, the conference’s highest-ranked team, against U.S.C., its most storied program.

headline: ‘Between Two Ferns: The Movie’ Review: Taking a (Web) Show on the Road
abstract: Zach Galifianakis’s popular “Funny or Die” series has been turned into a road pic. Should it have been?
lead_paragraph: “Between Two Ferns,” for those out of the loop, is a popular series of “Funny or Die” videos, in which the comedian and actor Zach Galifianakis plays the preposterously stupid host of a public-access talk show. The result is an uproariously funny intersection of celebrity roasting, absurdist humor and typo-ridden chyrons — perfect fodder for five-minute YouTube consumption.

headline: This Week’s News Quiz: Justin Trudeau, Israel, Cokie Roberts
abstract: Did you stay up to date this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you stay up to date this week?

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘The Creepy Anglerfish Comes to Light. (Just Don’t Get Too Close.)’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the mysterious and strange anglerfish. What can we discover about its adaptation to the deepest and darkest parts of the ocean?
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “The Creepy Anglerfish Comes to Light. (Just Don’t Get Too Close.)”

headline: As Taiwan Loses Influence, China Gains Ground in Race With U.S.
abstract: Two Pacific nations severed ties with Taiwan in favor of Beijing this week, boosting China in its contest with the United States for influence in the region.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In its contest with the United States for influence in the Pacific, China is quickly gaining momentum.

headline: Soccer at the Edge of the World
abstract: Greenland crowns its national champion in the shortest season on earth, a year’s worth of matches, injuries, controversies and celebrations crammed into a single week.
lead_paragraph: SISIMIUT, Greenland — The boat journey along Greenland’s wild, rocky coast lasted three days. It was long and slow, calling in at what felt like every village on the way to pick up passengers and drop off supplies.

headline: With ‘The Water Dancer,’ Ta-Nehisi Coates Makes His Fiction Debut
abstract: Coates’s book, about a slave who has the ability to vanish from one place and appear in another, has echoes of work by Gabriel García Márquez, Colson Whitehead and Stephen King.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, Ta-Nehisi Coates has emerged as an important public intellectual and perhaps America’s most incisive thinker about race. In his three books of nonfiction — “The Beautiful Struggle,” “Between the World and Me” and “We Were Eight Years in Power” — he seemed to be almost single-handedly waking the consciousness of his country. With his left hand, Coates also writes comic books, including a Black Panther series for Marvel. When word leaked that he was writing a novel, one had to wonder: What would that be like?

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Older Athletes, Amnesia and What Children Should Drink
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Silicon Valley Goes to Therapy
abstract: Bummed out by the world and their role in it, tech workers are seeking help — and founding some start-ups along the way.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley told itself a good story, the best one, really: It was saving the world. For nearly a decade, this gave the modern tech worker purpose, optimism and self-confidence.

headline: Tinder Created a Show to Give Its Users Something to Hook Up About
abstract: A choose-your-own-adventure series is designed to give young Tinder swipers something to talk about.
lead_paragraph: For all of their success, swipe-y dating apps like Tinder or Bumble face a problem once their users have matched: It’s hard to find things to discuss with total strangers. What exactly are you supposed to say in response to “👋🏼”?

headline: In the Salary Race, Engineers Sprint but English Majors Endure
abstract: Technical skills taught in college have a short shelf life, while a liberal arts education prepares graduates for jobs that haven’t been invented yet.
lead_paragraph: For students chasing lasting wealth, the best choice of a college major is less obvious than you might think.

headline: Tipping
abstract: Do you leave a tip whenever you’re asked to?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever bought a cup of coffee, a sandwich or a smoothie at a place that uses a customer-facing touch-screen payment system and been confronted with the question of whether you’d like to tip? If so, did you do it, at least in part, to avoid the embarrassment that might come from hitting “No tip” and then having to face the server?

headline: Should College Be Free?
abstract: New Mexico unveiled a plan to make its public colleges and universities free. Should all states follow?
lead_paragraph: Do you plan to attend college?

headline: Uber and Lyft Drivers Gain Labor Clout, With Help From an App
abstract: A nascent group in California offers a model for organizing a far-flung work force, and wielding political influence, through innovative technology.
lead_paragraph: When California lawmakers passed a worker-protection bill essentially requiring Uber and Lyft to treat drivers as employees, it was thanks in part to a little-known group called Rideshare Drivers United.

headline: Secret F.B.I. Subpoenas Scoop Up Personal Data From Scores of Companies
abstract: The practice, which the bureau says is vital to counterterrorism efforts, casts a much wider net than previously disclosed, newly released documents show.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. has used secret subpoenas to obtain personal data from far more companies than previously disclosed, newly released documents show.

headline: They Tried to Unionize the Park Slope Food Coop. Guess What Happened.
abstract: Progressives and organized labor should get along famously. So why is there a disconnect on today’s left?
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Why America’s Abortion Rate Might Be Higher Than It Appears
abstract: Evidence suggests more American women are “self-managing” their abortions.
lead_paragraph: The number of abortions performed in American clinics was lower in 2017 than in any year since abortion became legal nationwide in 1973, new data showed this week. But that does not count a growing number of women who are managing their abortions themselves, without going to a medical office — often by buying pills illicitly.

headline: How Hong Kong’s Unrest Is Spilling Onto N.Y. Campuses
abstract: Tensions are mounting: protest installations are being torn down, and bottles are getting thrown at marchers.
lead_paragraph: In August, Howard Wong, a Hong Kong native and graduate student at Baruch College in Manhattan, shared a social media post in support of the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. One of his friends from mainland China took offense.

headline: Train vs. Plane: And the Winner Is ... Well, It Depends
abstract: An analysis of six trips in North America evaluates which method is quicker, cheaper and easier.
lead_paragraph: From Chicago, there are a number of ways to travel the 300 miles to St. Louis. American, Southwest and United Airlines fly direct in about an hour and 15 minutes, with fares recently running $165 to $350 round trip. Normally, I drive the rear-numbing route through the corn fields, which takes about five hours and leaves me exhausted. But on my last trip, I took Amtrak, a five-hour-and-20-minute trip at $62 round trip that deposited me downtown near my hotel.

headline: Roundup Weedkiller Is Blamed for Cancers, but Farmers Say It’s Not Going Away
abstract: After a blockbuster acquisition, Bayer may lose billions over claims that the No. 1 agricultural chemical is unsafe. But its market niche seems secure.
lead_paragraph: From his farm in northwestern Wisconsin, Andy Bensend watched as first one jury, then another and another, delivered staggering multimillion-dollar verdicts to people who argued that their use of a weedkiller sold at nearly every hardware and home-improvement store had caused their cancer.

headline: Seven Ways Telecommuting Has Changed Real Estate
abstract: As more people are able to work from home, housing priorities have changed, and different places and types of housing have become more popular.
lead_paragraph: As wireless technology changes how and where people do their jobs, giving many the freedom to work remotely at least part of the time, so too is it changing their thinking about real estate.

headline: Our Anniversaries Matched Their Gifts
abstract: Traditional gifts for a fourth anniversary are fruit and flowers. Things with short lives; things easily bruised.
lead_paragraph: The morning of my fourth wedding anniversary, I banged my knee on the stationary bike at the gym. It purpled and swelled, tender, like a plum.

headline: Boris Johnson Is in Trouble With Brexit. Many Voters Don’t Mind.
abstract: Despite multiple setbacks, Boris Johnson could still win a general election. Analysts say that, like President Trump, he has played to his core.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — By any standards it has been a miserable start for Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, who stands accused of subverting the country’s unwritten constitution and has yet to win a vote in Parliament.

headline: Brands Beware: Influencer Impostors Want Your Free Stuff
abstract: A niche form of identity theft is sweeping Instagram.
lead_paragraph: There’s a well-established agreement between brands and influencers: We send free products, you post about them on Instagram. Often it’s a happy arrangement; influencer feeds fill with promotional material, followers click and merchandise sells. But sometimes the posts never appear.

headline: For the Incarcerated, Drawing Is a Lifeline
abstract: An exhibition at the Drawing Center looks at how artists have used the pencil to envision their freedom during captivity.
lead_paragraph: Valentino Dixon served more than 26 years in prison for a murder in Buffalo, although another man had publicly confessed to the crime. Encouraged by his uncle to use his childhood artistic talent to help cope with his incarceration, Mr. Dixon began drawing, up to 10 hours a day, for the last 20 years he spent behind bars. He used vibrantly colored pencils to create imagined golf courses, inspired by magazine pictures of a game he had never played.

headline: Anti-Immigrant Venom Killed Their South African Dreams
abstract: Hundreds of Nigerians fleeing mob attacks have been airlifted out of South Africa, leaving behind their jobs and stores, homes and hopes.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — They fled mob attacks and the torching of their stores and arrived with nothing but their children and their suitcases. More than 300 Nigerians landed in Lagos on a flight from Johannesburg late Wednesday because their old lives — as immigrants living in South Africa — had become untenable.

headline: Young Voters Still ‘Feel the Bern,’ but Not Just for Bernie Sanders Anymore
abstract: The Vermont senator benefited from a wave of enthusiasm from young people in 2016. Many still love him, but not him alone.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — College students are back on campus. Bernie Sanders is, too.

headline: The New Hangout in Columbus? Distilleries
abstract: One of the country’s fastest-growing cities has seen a surge in homegrown distilleries that are drawing customers with tasting rooms, restaurants and bottle shops.
lead_paragraph: Columbus, Ohio, is no longer the meat-and-potato city of decades ago. Yes, there are the big restaurant chains. Wendy’s, White Castle and Sbarro, to name a few, have national headquarters here. But the state capital is now one of the country’s fastest-growing cities, and it has dynamic art projects, good restaurants and a revitalized riverfront. Recently, it also has been getting buzz for its spirits, with a fresh crop of homegrown micro distilleries elevating the city’s drink scene.

headline: How a Paleozoic Rock Became a $3 Million Real Estate Prospect
abstract: The Cooper Street Rock, in Upper Manhattan, sat undisturbed for millenniums. Now it’s on the market — or at least half of it is.
lead_paragraph: It is one thing to try to sell a 30,000 cubic foot rock in a hot real estate market; it’s another thing entirely to try to sell half of one.

headline: When Dictionaries Wade Into the Gender (Non)Binary
abstract: Merriam-Webster announced an additional definition for “they”: a third-person, singular pronoun for nonbinary people. And Oxford has been criticized for its entry under “woman.”
lead_paragraph: Inspo. Dad joke. Fabulosity! Rhotic. These are among the 533 new terms and definitions that Merriam-Webster added to its dictionary this month.

headline: For Salvatore Ferragamo’s Paul Andrew, Shoes (Still) Come First
abstract: The British-born designer — who now splits his time between Florence, London, Manhattan and Connecticut — starts each of his collections with footwear.
lead_paragraph: The son of an upholsterer to Queen Elizabeth II, Salvatore Ferragamo’s creative director, Paul Andrew, spent his childhood in Berkshire, England, surrounded by exquisite textiles and trims. “Almost everything at Windsor Castle is upholstered — the furniture, the beds, the walls — and watching my dad gave me a real appreciation for craftsmanship,” he says. As a teenager, the designer hung pages torn from fashion magazines on his walls and sought out copies of Vogue Patterns, prompting his grandmother to lend him her sewing machine. Next came the Berkshire College of Art and Design, where the now 40-year-old studied fashion. Yasmin Sewell, then the buying director of the influential London boutique Browns, bought Andrew’s entire Paul Poiret-inspired graduation collection and introduced him to Alexander McQueen, who brought him on as an apprentice in 1999. From there, Andrew designed accessories for Narciso Rodriguez, Calvin Klein and Donna Karan before launching his own line of shoes in 2012. Inspired by the palettes of abstract painters like Robert Motherwell, Pierre Soulages and Conie Vallese, his color-saturated, ’70s-inflected designs caught the attention of the Ferragamo family, who named him head of women’s shoe design in 2016 and its creative director last winter.

headline: For These Black Women in Texas, Rodeo Is a Way of Life
abstract: Raising children, keeping a job and riding horses for a cheering crowd — life on the all-black professional rodeo circuit.
lead_paragraph: Azja Bryant is a pharmacy technician. Jazmine Bennett works for UPS. Krishaun Adair works for state of Texas as an agriculture inspector. But they also call themselves cowgirls.

headline: How the ‘The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel’ Costume Designer Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Donna Zakowska surrounds herself with vintage garments and accessories, dreaming up outfits for retro characters (and puppets).
lead_paragraph: “My mother was a crazy person with the ’60s hats,” said Donna Zakowska, the Emmy-nominated costume designer for “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,” the popular Amazon series about a woman who dives into the New York comedy scene of the 1950s.

headline: Young Black Voters to Their Biden-Supporting Parents: ‘Is This Your King?’
abstract: An organic effort by black millennials and Gen Z-ers to influence older family members against Mr. Biden may be important in the Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A groan erupted at a debate watch party at Texas Southern University last week as former vice president Joseph R. Biden Jr. got a question about slavery and racism and gave an answer about Venezuela and record players.

headline: 65 Block Parties, 5 Boroughs, 1 New York Summer
abstract: Friday: Celebrating the tradition of New Yorkers spilling out onto the concrete.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Arabic Readers in Israel Have to Hope the Border Guards Are Sloppy
abstract: Books by famed Arab authors, and Arabic translations of writers like Orwell and Joyce, are scarce because of an Israeli ban on imports from Lebanon, Syria and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For three years now, Asmaa Azaizeh has run a popular Arabic-language book festival in Haifa, a mixed city that has become a vibrant culinary and cultural capital for Palestinian citizens of Israel.

headline: Climate Strike, Whistle-Blower, Iran: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Who First Circled the Globe? Not Magellan, Spain Wants You to Know
abstract: The Spanish officer Juan Sebastián Elcano completed the voyage after the Portuguese explorer died halfway. Five centuries later, it’s a matter of national pride — and national rivalry.
lead_paragraph: GETARIA, Spain — On Sept. 20, 1519, the Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan set out on what was to become the first circumnavigation of the world.

headline: Are You Joining the Climate Protests? We Want to See Your Sign!
abstract: We want to share young people’s illustrations and videos with the world.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of young people around the globe went on strike on Sept. 20 to demand action on the climate crisis. They know that if we don’t solve this crisis now, we may soon have an unlivable climate. And they refuse to accept the idea that our politicians won’t do anything about it.

headline: The Coaches’ Game Plan: Beat Cancer, Get Married
abstract: Aloysia Jaques and Marc Rybczyk, both college basketball coaches, shared a lifestyle and a strong determination.
lead_paragraph: Marc Rybczyk admits that before he met Aloysia Jaques in January 2014, he had some misguided ideas about women’s basketball.

headline: Roy Cohn Is How We Got Trump
abstract: From McCarthyism to the mob to Trump, Cohn enabled evil. Why did elites embrace him?
lead_paragraph: Near the beginning of “Where’s My Roy Cohn?” the new documentary about the lawyer and power broker who mentored Donald Trump, an interviewee says, “Roy Cohn’s contempt for people, his contempt for the law, was so evident on his face that if you were in his presence, you knew you were in the presence of evil.” He wasn’t being hyperbolic.

headline: Why Republicans Play Dirty
abstract: They fear that if they stick to the rules, they will lose everything. Their behavior is a threat to democratic stability.
lead_paragraph: The greatest threat to our democracy today is a Republican Party that plays dirty to win.

headline: Anatomy of a Warren Rally
abstract: Drawing huge crowds, Senator Elizabeth Warren’s rallies have become a defining feature of her presidential campaign. We attended one this week to find out why.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: I’m Not Only Striking for the Climate
abstract: Thousands of students like me are protesting today. We know that we can’t solve the climate crisis without addressing the root causes of oppression.
lead_paragraph: I’m 17 years old, and I’ve been a climate justice organizer since I was a freshman in high school. I started as a community organizer with “Plant for the Planet” in Seattle, giving climate action presentations to middle and high schools, testifying at bill hearings in my state legislature, and lobbying my City Council to adopt warning labels on gas pumps.

headline: Losing an Inheritance Is Easy, Because Saying No Is Hard
abstract: Most inheritances are about $50,000. Whether you come into a little money or a lot, waiting to make any moves is one of the best things to do first.

headline: Protesting Climate Change, Young People Take to Streets in a Global Strike
abstract: Anxious about the future and angry about the failure to curb the crisis, millions joined an urgent call for action against climate change.
lead_paragraph: Anxious about their future on a hotter planet and angry at world leaders for failing to arrest the crisis, masses of young people poured into the streets on every continent on Friday for a day of global climate protests. Organizers estimated the turnout to be around four million in thousands of cities and towns worldwide.

headline: Tod’s: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Tod’s: Spring 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Tod’s: Spring 2020 Collection.

headline: Getting the Garden Ready for Fall
abstract: Summer may be over, but your garden beckons and still needs you.
lead_paragraph: Summer is behind us, yet I spent the better part of last weekend crouched in my hedges, weeding and mulching, wondering why I was still out here when the leaves on the trees had already started dabbling in yellows and oranges.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Is Saudi Arabia Twisting Arms to Help Aramco’s I.P.O.?
abstract: The government is reportedly putting pressure on some of the country’s richest families to invest in Aramco’s forthcoming stock sale, the FT reports.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: De Blasio Quits Presidential Race; Trump Gloats
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City, whose run for the Democratic nomination was often described as quixotic, never gained traction.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who entered the Democratic presidential race on the premise that his brand of liberal urban leadership in New York City could appeal on a national scale, said on Friday that he was ending his candidacy.

headline: Indonesia’s President Halts Bill That Would Ban Sex Outside Marriage
abstract: Parliament had been expected to pass a sweeping overhaul of the penal code, much of which mirrored Shariah. President Joko Widodo said it needed “further study.”
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Sweeping legislation that would have criminalized sex between unmarried people, including gays and lesbians, was pushed back on Friday by Indonesia’s president, Joko Widodo, days before it had been expected to pass.

headline: A Love Letter to Canned Food
abstract: Ingredients like canned artichokes, pumpkin, chickpeas and coconut milk can turn a weeknight meal into a semi-homemade form of art.
lead_paragraph: Like many ingredient-obsessed cooks, I hit the farmers’ market once or twice a week. I eat my brussels sprouts and squash in October, my asparagus and rhubarb in June, and not a whole lot beyond potatoes and onions in February. Fresh, local and organic is my kitchen mantra.

headline: Saving Money, and Your Sanity, on College Visits (Hint: Resist the Swag)
abstract: Most counselors suggest starting near home and visiting a mix of college types, like an urban college, a large public university and a small, liberal arts campus.
lead_paragraph: College application season is approaching, and that means prospective students are in the midst of campus visits.

headline: The Week in Tech: An Emerging Twist on Antitrust
abstract: If regulators and lawmakers are serious, they’re going to have to rethink a traditional approach to monopolies.
lead_paragraph: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Funny or Die Finds New Life in the Streaming Era
abstract: The company, which began as a comedy website, has branched out to podcasts and feature films, including “Between Two Ferns: The Movie,” which debuts on Netflix on Friday.
