lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Will Ferrell found himself seated next to Michelle Obama at a White House Christmas party in 2010 when she leaned over and began quoting lines from Funny or Die’s “The Landlord” — the viral video featuring a 2-year-old girl shouting profanities at Mr. Ferrell for not turning in his rent money on time.

headline: I.R.S. Offers Deal to Small Insurance Companies Under Scrutiny
abstract: The offer pertains to captive insurance, a way to insure against risks not covered by traditional means. But it has created an incentive for tax avoidance.
lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service has offered a small group of taxpayers a deal it hopes they won’t refuse: Pay all their back taxes, plus interest, and their case will be closed without penalties.

headline: N.F.L. Week 3 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
abstract: The Ravens will try to prove themselves against the Chiefs, the Rams will try to win in Cleveland and the Cowboys and Patriots will try to stay awake in likely blowouts.
lead_paragraph: Does everyone like backup quarterbacks? At least seven teams — potentially eight, depending on the health of Cam Newton — enter Week 3 with a training camp backup in the top spot. It’s a situation that ranges from exciting (the Giants’ Daniel Jones) to seemingly fine (New Orleans’s Teddy Bridgewater) to terrifying (the Jets’ Luke Falk being asked to play at New England.)

headline: ‘I Can’t Do This’: Imelda Left Texas With at Least 5 Deaths and Historic Rainfall
abstract: One woman was still looking for a missing son after the seventh-wettest tropical cyclone in U.S. history. “He can’t swim,” she said.
lead_paragraph: BEAUMONT, Tex. — The flooding rose as high as Archie Pugh’s wheelchair.

headline: A Ghost Town and Hot Springs: An Eastern Sierra Road Trip
abstract: Friday: An itinerary for an adventure in the mountains and lakes of California. Also: A profile of the activist Ady Barkan, and a Silicon Valley telltale heart.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘Is It Theater or Is It Real?’
abstract: At Moschino, Bottega Veneta and Fendi, inquiring minds want to know.
lead_paragraph: In May, when the Metropolitan Museum of Art unveiled its mega Costume Institute show, “Camp: Notes on Fashion,”  Jeremy Scott, creative director of Moschino and founder of his own line, was the single most represented name in the show. It featured 15 or so of his pieces, including a prosciutto dress from early in his career and the TV-dinner gown from the Moschino show last season — and that, in its train/tray, beef-’n’-mash glory, became a talking point for almost anyone who went to the museum, whether or not she had ever paid attention to the fashion show.

headline: Americans Trust Police More Than Congress, Study Finds
abstract: The most trusted leader of them all? The public school principal, according to a Pew Research Center study on Americans’ faith in powerful people and institutions.
lead_paragraph: Americans trust police officers, military leaders and local public officials more than members of Congress, tech leaders and journalists, according to a study published by the Pew Research Center on Thursday.

headline: Ben Platt Unleashes His Inner Egomaniac in ‘The Politician’
abstract: The actor, singer and former “Dear Evan Hansen” star discovers that Ryan Murphy, Richard Linklater and Stephen Sondheim are speaking the language he wants to hear.
lead_paragraph: After two years as the poster child for teen angst in “Dear Evan Hansen,” Ben Platt was over the accolades and ready to move on.

headline: What Happens When Extreme Action Meets Elusive Language?
abstract: In Elizabeth Streb and Anne Bogart’s “Falling & Loving,” dancers and actors share the stage with the Guck Machine, which emits a waterfall of food andother objects.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The choreographer Elizabeth Streb has found herself in foreign territory. First, she is collaborating, which is not her usual way of making art. And in teaming up with Anne Bogart, a director of the theater group SITI Company, she has something else to contend with: words.

headline: Graduate Students, After Gains in Union Efforts, Face a Federal Setback
abstract: The National Labor Relations Board has moved to reverse a 2016 ruling that eased the way for organizing at private universities.
lead_paragraph: On an October evening in 2017, Natalia Piland, a graduate student at the University of Chicago, gathered with classmates at a popular Hyde Park bar to celebrate what seemed like a turning point: Teaching and research assistants at the university had voted to unionize.

headline: Pressed by Public Outcry, Russia Releases Jailed Actor
abstract: A widely seen video contradicted the assault case against Pavel Ustinov. The resulting outrage showed the growing power of social media.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Struggling to calm bubbling discontent, the Russian authorities on Friday freed a jailed actor whose conviction just days earlier for a supposed attack on a police officer had prompted pickets in front of the Kremlin’s executive office and a rare public show of solidarity from fellow entertainers, priests and teachers.

headline: ‘We Will Never Back Down’: Scenes From the Global Climate Protests
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of young people around the world took to the streets on Friday to protest government inaction on the climate crisis.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of young people around the world took to the streets on Friday to protest government inaction on the climate crisis.

headline: ‘Ad Astra’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: James Gray narrates a moon rover sequence from his film, starring Brad Pitt.
lead_paragraph: James Gray narrates a moon rover sequence from his film, starring Brad Pitt.

headline: University Denounced for Showing Sign Language for ‘Jewish’ as a Hooked Nose
abstract: A Flemish university in Belgium has declined to remove videos called offensive, saying it is merely hosting a sign-language dictionary, not adding “value judgment.”
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A university in Belgium has refused demands to “immediately” strip its website of Flemish sign-language videos displaying stereotypical and anti-Semitic symbols for Jews, saying it was merely hosting a dictionary of signs without adding “value judgment.”

headline: The Best Baked Apples
abstract: Dorie Greenspan’s dream dessert is a take on her mother’s recipe.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Dorie Greenspan can picture her mother in her cashmere wrap coat, in a cocktail dress covered with sequins, and in Capris and kitten heels, but never in an apron. “I don’t remember her cooking,” she wrote for The New York Times Magazine this week. “A child of the Depression and a working woman of the ’50s, my mother was grateful for a freezer and TV dinners that she’d serve as though she were offering us caviar.”

headline: Watch Brad Pitt in a Chase on the Moon in ‘Ad Astra’
abstract: The director James Gray narrates a moment that uses actual images of the moon as the setting for a harrowing rover action sequence.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Colson Whitehead, Marlon James in Running for National Book Awards
abstract: Whitehead, who won in 2016, was nominated this year for “The Nickel Boys,” one of 10 novels longlisted.
lead_paragraph: Colson Whitehead’s novel “The Nickel Boys,” based on the horrific history of a Florida reform school, was nominated for the National Book Award for fiction on Friday, three years after the writer won the prize for his book “The Underground Railroad.”

headline: Trump Announces New Sanctions on Iran
abstract: The sanctions targeting the Iranian national bank add to the pressure on Iran, which the United States accuses of attacking Saudi oil facilities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday announced a new round of sanctions against Iran’s national bank, escalating economic pressure on the country as the president’s national security advisers review a list of targets for a potential strike in retaliation for recent attacks on Saudi Arabian oil fields.

headline: North Korean Envoy Hails Bolton’s Ouster and Trump’s Talk of a New Approach
abstract: Kim Myong-gil praised the U.S. president’s “wise political decision” to take a fresh tack in nuclear talks after dismissing his national security adviser.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s new envoy to nuclear talks with the United States on Friday welcomed the ouster of President Trump’s former National Security Adviser, John R. Bolton, and the president’s suggestion that Washington would use a “new method” in negotiating with the North.

headline: Sink Into the Season’s Softest Furniture
abstract: Begone, hard lines — cushy, squat and deeply comforting are the interior design requirements for fall.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here for the T List newsletter, a weekly roundup of what T Magazine editors are noticing and coveting now.]

headline: 5 Lessons the ‘Downton Abbey’ TV Team Learned About Filmmaking
abstract: Julian Fellowes, the show’s creator, and the producer Gareth Neame had a lot of characters to work with and a lot of fans to satisfy. Here’s how they navigated the challenge.
lead_paragraph: “The Simpsons” did it. So did “Sex and the City” — twice. And “Breaking Bad” and “The Sopranos” are about to. Though we may be living in a golden age of television, the small screen isn’t a large enough canvas for some showrunners. IMDb.com is littered with beloved TV shows that made the leap to the big screen, some more valiantly than others. While it’s a tactic that has paid off for plenty of properties, for every hit Muppet or “Star Trek” movie, there’s also a “Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas.”

headline: Patriots vs. Jets: Le’Veon Bell Has a Heavy Load to Carry
abstract: After an 0-2 start, the Jets head to New England with a stripped-down offense that relies heavily on its new running back.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Before the first game of the season, Jets running back Le’Veon Bell told Coach Adam Gase not to hold him back.

headline: Area 51 Raid: They Come in Peace, So Far, in Search for Aliens
abstract: What started as a joke has attracted visitors from all over the world to tiny, desolate Nevada towns.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people in search of aliens, bragging rights or just a good time have descended on a desolate Nevada town, answering the call of a meme-inspired Facebook event encouraging them to “storm Area 51.”

headline: Invasion of the Clowns
abstract: All of a sudden, they’re everywhere. Why?
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2007, the comedian and actress Mo’Nique uttered 11 words that would change the course of history. “See, when you do clownery,” she said, “the clown comes back to bite.”

headline: What Omnivores Get Wrong About Vegetarian Cooking
abstract: When you (or your kid, partner or roommate) goes vegetarian, you’ll need to change up your weeknight cooking strategies.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 1 of this year, I began cooking as a vegetarian. Not because I became vegetarian — that would be professionally untenable — but because my younger child did, thus upending most of my hard-won weeknight cooking strategies.

headline: The Whistle-Blower Report Is a Test for Congress
abstract: Lawlessness vs. fecklessness.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Russell Coutts Likes Sailing Races With Big Money at Stake
abstract: One of the great sailors in history now runs an elite racing series for high-speed yachts. SailGP will end its season this weekend with $1 million on the line.
lead_paragraph: Russell Coutts can make a pretty good argument for being history’s greatest yachtsman. His achievements include being a part of five teams that won the America’s Cup and winning an Olympic gold medal in 1984.

headline: Barron Hilton, Hotel Magnate and Founding A.F.L. Owner, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Hilton successfully expanded the hotel chain founded by his father, but he said his happiest days were when he owned the Chargers football team.
lead_paragraph: Barron Hilton, who oversaw the vast expansion of his father’s hotel empire and took part in changing the pro sports landscape as an original club owner in the American Football League, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. The last survivor of the A.F.L.’s founding ownership, he was 91.

headline: Climate Strike N.Y.C.: Young Crowds Demand Action, Welcome Greta Thunberg
abstract: “I feel hopeful seeing the power of all these people here today,” one teenager said of the protest, which drew tens of thousands of demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: [Read more live coverage of the climate strikes.]

headline: De Blasio’s Back: Here Are 6 Major Problems He’s Facing
abstract: He has more than two more years left as mayor to build on the progressive track record he promoted in his aborted presidential run.
lead_paragraph: [Read more about the mayor’s decision on Friday to end his bid for the Oval Office.]

headline: India’s Chandrayaan-2 Lander Found on the Moon
abstract: The spacecraft was the latest in a 60-year series of moon crashes.
lead_paragraph: The spacecraft was the latest in a 60-year series of moon crashes.

headline: David Cameron Is Sorry. Really, Really Sorry.
abstract: The former British prime minister, David Cameron, a self-described “doubter and worrier and niggler,” is sorry about a lot of things, but most of all about Brexit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — David Cameron, Britain’s former prime minister, is sorry. He is sorry that the Brexit referendum did not turn out the way he wanted. He is sorry that Britain is paralyzed by political dysfunction and that no one seems to know what to do next. He is sorry that people (including, it now seems, the queen) are mad at him.

headline: High Lead Levels Still Being Found Near Notre-Dame
abstract: A contractor’s test at an apartment near the cathedral and law enforcement measurements at Police Headquarters both found levels far above safety guidelines, an environmental group revealed.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Months after fire engulfed Notre-Dame and the 460 tons of lead on its roof and spire, alarming levels of lead are still being found after decontamination efforts, including at the Paris Police Headquarters — raising new concerns that the authorities have not fully tackled the problem.

headline: Meet 8 Youth Protest Leaders
abstract: Around the globe, young people are demanding action on climate change in a day of protest. Meet eight of the local leaders.
lead_paragraph: Their cities are running out of water. Droughts are driving their friends off their farms. Mosquitoes are showing up in places where they had never seen them. The future of the planet seems so uncertain that they confess to being afraid and anxious.

headline: California Sues the Trump Administration in Its Escalating War Over Auto Emissions
abstract: California, joined by 23 other states, sued to block the administration’s unprecedented  reversal of the state’s authority to set its own rules on climate-warming car emissions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — California and nearly two dozen other states on Friday filed suit against the Trump administration’s unprecedented legal reversal of the state’s authority to set its own rules on climate-warming tailpipe emissions.

headline: 6ix9ine’s Testimony: The Rapper’s Rise, Beefs and Crash, in His Own Words
abstract: This week in federal court, a polarizing musician was an eager witness, describing how his career was tied to his association with the Nine Trey Gangsta Bloods. These are excerpts from his days on the stand.
lead_paragraph: This week, in a federal courtroom in Manhattan, 6ix9ine, one of the most polarizing and combustible rappers in recent memory, proved as eager a star witness as he was a viral sensation.

headline: Host Japan Shows Its Nerves in Rugby World Cup Opener
abstract: The Japanese rallied after a shaky start and subpar kicking to beat Russia behind the South Africa-born winger Kotaro Matsushima.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — As the first Asian team to host the Rugby World Cup, Japan knew it was on the game’s biggest stage on Friday night, and during the opening act it seemed most of its players were suffering from stage fright.

headline: The Vegetarian Recipes You’ve Got to Make (Plus Something for the Meat-Eaters, Too)
abstract: Our cheesy white bean-tomato bake, seared eggplant with pearl couscous, pasta with mushrooms and, naturally, The Stew.
lead_paragraph: Hi and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. A significant share of the emails I get from you all are about vegetarian recipes: You love them, you want more of them. Me too. As a meat-eater who is trying to cook meatless more often, I am in need of reasonable strategies and fresh ideas. And so here is my hero Julia Moskin, with a new story about what omnivores get wrong about vegetarian cooking. A little preview: You cannot only make pasta! (Julia’s favorite weeknight vegetarian dish on NYT Cooking: this cheesy, white bean mozzarella bake, featured below.)

headline: The Beauty of the Ordinary
abstract: We treasure autumn days as reminders of everything we must not take for granted.
lead_paragraph: NARA, Japan — Falling in love is the easiest thing in the world. But staying in love, we all know, can be one of the hardest. How do we keep the glow, the sense of unending discovery, alive once we’ve pledged ourselves to familiarity? And how to sustain the sense of anticipation that deliciously quickened the honeymoon? Put differently, how might we be enchanted by discovery’s opposite — routine — and find in constancy a stimulation as rich as novelty provides? The story of every marriage, perhaps, is the story of what happens after the endless summer ends.

headline: Trump Pressed Ukraine’s Leader on Inquiry Into Biden’s Son
abstract: Mr. Trump has been prodding the Ukrainian government to investigate Mr. Biden and his family, but the new whistle-blower complaint has drastically raised the stakes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump pressed the Ukrainian president in a July call to investigate former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s son, according to a person familiar with the conversation, an apparently blatant mixture of foreign policy with his 2020 re-election campaign.

headline: Steve Dalachinsky, Avant-Garde Poet, Is Dead at 72
abstract: A familiar sight in downtown New York clubs as both a spectator and a performer, he often read his poems to jazz accompaniment.
lead_paragraph: To write about the life of Steve Dalachinsky, one first has to decide what to call him. “Poet” comes to mind, given all of his books of poetry, the poetry awards and the countless times he read his work, often accompanied by jazz musicians, in the avant-garde clubs of New York and environs.

headline: How to Be Brave
abstract: It’s a muscle that needs consistent flexing.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading In Her Words, where women rule the headlines. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox. Let me know what you think at inherwords@nytimes.com.

headline: After the Fed’s Second Rate Cut, Hints of Another to Come
abstract: Vice Chair Richard Clarida signaled another cut could be coming but stopped short of promising one, saying the Fed is taking decisions one by one.
lead_paragraph: Days after the Federal Reserve lowered borrowing costs for a second time since July, a top Fed official signaled Friday that further interest rate cuts could come before year-end.

headline: U.S. Agreement With El Salvador Seeks to Divert Asylum Seekers
abstract: An agreement between the United States and El Salvador will prevent migrants from crossing the southwestern border by requiring them to seek protection in El Salvador first.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration signed an agreement with the government of El Salvador on Friday that could force Central American migrants traveling through El Salvador to seek refuge in that violent and dangerous country instead of in the United States.

headline: Tammy Abraham and Chelsea’s Lost Boys
abstract: Chelsea is hailing the emergence of three academy products this season, but how many others missed their moment?
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to receive Rory Smith’s weekly newsletter on world soccer, delivered to your inbox every Friday.

headline: Look to the Skies to See the Bat-Signal in Cities Worldwide
abstract: In a celebration of Batman started by DC Comics, sites including the former Domino Sugar building in Brooklyn will be emblazoned with his symbol on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Look! Up in the sky! It’s a bird! It’s a plane! It’s the bat-signal!

headline: Trudeau Tries to Change Conversation From Blackface. It Doesn’t Quite Work.
abstract: The prime minister of Canada wanted to talk about a ban on military-style rifles in Canada. Reporters wanted to talk about the possibility of new images of him emerging.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada wanted to talk about something else.

headline: Ukraine Pressured on U.S. Political Investigations
abstract: Pressure on the Ukrainian government by President Trump’s personal lawyer, Rudolph W. Giuliani, has been an open secret in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, for months.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Months before a whistle-blower’s complaint came to light this week, raising alarms over dealings between the Trump administration and Ukraine, the issue was roiling politics in Kiev.

headline: Facebook’s Suspension of ‘Tens of Thousands’ of Apps Reveals Wider Privacy Issues
abstract: The scale of suspensions, following the Cambridge Analytica scandal, was far larger than the social network had previously revealed.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook said on Friday that it had suspended tens of thousands of apps for improperly sucking up users’ personal information and other transgressions, a tacit admission that the scale of its data privacy issues was far larger than it had previously acknowledged.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger, Zendaya and Tom Hiddleston on the Gala Circuit
abstract: Benefits were held for Save the Children, the American Theatre Wing and the High Line.
lead_paragraph: Benefits were held for Save the Children, the American Theatre Wing and the High Line.

headline: Save the Children Turns 100
abstract: Benefits were also held for the American Theater Wing and the High Line.
lead_paragraph: Save the Children celebrated its 100th year with an event at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Sept. 12. The American Theater Wing held its gala at Cipriani 42nd Street on Sept. 16. And the High Line held a dinner for its public art program on Sept. 17.

headline: Germany Unveils $60 Billion Climate Package
abstract: Angela Merkel’s government is seeking to meet the country’s climate-protection goals with new measures.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government on Friday agreed to support a $60 billion package of climate policies aimed at getting Germany back on track to meet its goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 2030.

headline: Al Gore: The Climate Crisis Is the Battle of Our Time, and We Can Win
abstract: We have the tools. Now we are building the political power.
lead_paragraph: Things take longer to happen than you think they will, but then they happen much faster than you thought they could.

headline: ‘Highest Sanctions Ever Imposed,’ Trump Says of Action Against Iran
abstract: President Trump announced a new round of economic sanctions against the Iranian national bank.
lead_paragraph: President Trump announced a new round of economic sanctions against the Iranian national bank.

headline: My Quest for Lunchbox Supremacy
abstract: A perfect school lunch requires some advance planning at dinner, a little humility and a good guru.
lead_paragraph: I treat my child’s lunchbox like it’s a restaurant for one. On the drive home after school, I feign interest in all the things a parent is supposed to care about — homework, volleyball, science projects, blah blah blah — until I can ask the question I really want the answer to: How was your lunch?

headline: Antonio Brown Is Released by the New England Patriots
abstract: Brown’s brief, rocky tenure with New England ended the same day that N.F.L. officials spoke with an artist who accused the star wide receiver of unwanted sexual advances.
lead_paragraph: The New England Patriots released Antonio Brown on Friday afternoon, ending his brief but turbulent tenure with the team as the N.F.L. was investigating him for multiple accusations of inappropriate sexual behavior, including rape.

headline: Hacker Who Revealed Soccer Secrets Is Charged With 147 Crimes
abstract: Rui Pinto ran a website called Football Leaks and won praise as a whistle-blower. Portugal’s authorities consider him a criminal.
lead_paragraph: A computer hacker whose efforts revealed often troubling practices that shape the multi-billion-dollar global soccer industry was charged with 147 crimes this week by Portugal’s national prosecutor.

headline: Reporting, Fact-Checking, Sorting Mail ... and a Bid for Citizenship
abstract: My job as a Times news assistant followed me through every step of the naturalization process.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: A Whistle-Blower’s Claim Against Trump
abstract: Readers voice concern about possible improper conversations with a foreign leader and refusals to share details with Congress.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Program to Prevent Suicide by Veterans Earns Bipartisan Support
abstract: More than 6,000 veterans took their own lives each year between 2008 and 2017, and roughly 20 a day since 2014, according to statistics released Friday.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Gloribel Ramos sunk slightly under the weight of her 32-pound body armor and gingerly gripped a plastic facsimile of an M4 rifle as she prepared to watch a video of a roadside bomb detonated in Iraq, all so she could better understand the experience of war and its impact on people who have fought in one.

headline: Marni: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Marni: Spring 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Marni: Spring 2020 Collection.

headline: Liszt’s ‘Harmonies,’ More Intimate Than Ever
abstract: The pianists Jenny Lin and Adam Tendler explain why “Poetic and Religious Harmonies” is better underground than at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: If you haven’t heard of Liszt’s “Poetic and Religious Harmonies,” you’re not alone.

headline: The Violence That Followed Iraq’s Post-Invasion Spiral
abstract: James Verini is out with “They Will Have to Die Now,” a book about the battle of Mosul and its consequences.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading this week’s At War newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox every Friday. Email us at atwar@nytimes.com.

headline: Bringing the Colors Back to a Mystic’s Music
abstract: George Gurdjieff arranged traditional chants and dances as piano miniatures. Now a fuller instrumentation is returning.
lead_paragraph: The traditional ethnic hymns, chants and dances that the Armenian mystic George Ivanovich Gurdjieff collected around the turn of the 20th century, and later transcribed with the help of the Russian composer Thomas de Hartmann, are among the most entrancing works ever written for piano. Many are simple: a slender melodic line, curled here and there into arabesques, above a prayer-bead string of repeated notes in the bass. Each piece is brief — the length of a pop song — and powerfully hypnotic.

headline: Want to Hold Your Own 2020 Caucus? Now You Can (if You’re an Iowan)
abstract: Iowa Democrats are trying to make the state’s first-in-the-nation presidential nominating contest more accessible by allowing some voters to organize satellite caucuses.
lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Iowa Democrats will allow some voters to organize their own presidential caucuses in 2020, part of a plan to make the state’s first-in-the-nation nominating contest more accessible for people who cannot attend one of the party’s 1,678 designated caucus sites.

headline: The Playlist: Green Day’s Time Warp, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Soccer Mommy, Celine Dion, Gang Starr and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Keke Palmer Breaks Out Her Hip-Hop Dance Moves
abstract: A star of “Hustlers” and host of “Good Morning America” brushes up on her popping in a Times Square studio.
lead_paragraph: “Whenever I dance, I’m always thinking about attitude,” said Keke Palmer, the newly announced host of the third hour of “Good Morning America” and a star of the movie “Hustlers.” “I’m always thinking about being confident.”

headline: ‘Something I’m Always Trying to Do Is Get You to Hang Out With Dead Bodies’
abstract: Caitlin Doughty, the mortician, self-described death activist and “funeral industry rabble-rouser,” has a new book, “Will My Cat Eat My Eyeballs?”
lead_paragraph: “I will never get tired of saying that the dead body is not dangerous — unless Mom had Ebola,” says Caitlin Doughty, the mortician and self-described death activist and “funeral industry rabble-rouser” whose new book, “Will My Cat Eat My Eyeballs? Big Questions From Tiny Mortals About Death,” enters the nonfiction list this week at No. 8.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Looking for Lorraine’ and ‘Evolution’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: LOOKING FOR LORRAINE: The Radiant and Radical Life of Lorraine Hansberry, by Imani Perry. (Beacon, $17.95.) This portrait of the African-American playwright captures Hansberry’s emotional and political power and charts her major influence in theater and beyond. Praising its analysis of “A Raisin in the Sun” and of Hansberry’s role as a public intellectual, our reviewer, Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, called the book “necessary.”

headline: Walmart to End Sales of E-Cigarettes as Vaping Concerns Mount
abstract: Vaping-related lung illnesses have been on the rise, and federal and state health departments are investigating the risks.
lead_paragraph: Walmart said on Friday that it would stop selling e-cigarettes at its stores in the United States,  dealing a new blow to the vaping industry as concerns mount over the health risks of the products and their soaring popularity among teenagers.

headline: The Man Behind a Toxic Slogan Promoting White Supremacy
abstract: Renaud Camus’s phrase, “the great replacement,” which characterizes Muslim immigrants as invaders bent on conquest, has become a rallying cry for white supremacists in many countries.
lead_paragraph: PLIEUX, France — Though the writer had already lived in his castle for a quarter of a century, it was only three years ago that he finally restored it to its original purpose as a fortress.

headline: For Diplomacy, Not War, in the Persian Gulf
abstract: “An attack that could spark a regionwide war will protect no one,” a policy expert says. Also: Voices of the young; term-paper cheats.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Considering Margaret Atwood and Uneasy Sisterhood
abstract: In Margaret Atwood’s 1993 novel “The Robber Bride,” three women encounter the glamorous and destructive college friend they thought had died five years earlier. Lorrie Moore reviewed it.
lead_paragraph: Michiko Kakutani reviews Margaret Atwood’s latest novel, “The Testaments,” in this week’s issue. In 1993, Lorrie Moore reviewed Atwood’s novel “The Robber Bride,” in which three women encounter the glamorous and destructive college friend they thought had died five years earlier.

headline: ‘I Do Not Know the Identity of the Whistle-Blower,’ Trump Says
abstract: President Trump told reporters that he did not know who was behind the whistle-blower complaint against him, adding, “I just hear it’s a partisan person.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump told reporters that he did not know who was behind the whistle-blower complaint against him, adding, “I just hear it’s a partisan person.”

headline: The 19th-Century Troll Who Hated Dirty Postcards and Sex Toys
abstract: Before Gamergate, Anthony Comstock was the original anti-feminist crusader.
lead_paragraph: In the 1870s, New York City was a haven for artists and radicals. But it was also the nursery for a new kind of moral activism. Led by Anthony Comstock, the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice became a media sensation by targeting feminists in a culture war over obscenity and birth control. He then used his fame to lobby Congress for laws that arguably halted the progress of reproductive rights for almost a century. His tactics — a combination of media manipulation and ruthless legal strategies — are a precursor to those used by anti-feminists on social media and in Washington today.

headline: U.S. Drone Attacks ISIS Fighters in Southern Libya
abstract: The American military carried out an airstrike Thursday against Islamic State fighters in southern Libya in a reminder of the terrorist group’s resilience.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States military carried out an airstrike against Islamic State fighters in southern Libya on Thursday in a reminder of the terrorist group’s continuing operations and resilience far from its main guerrilla strongholds in Iraq and Syria.

headline: T Suggests: Photographs of ’70s California, a Family-Made Olive Oil, and More
abstract: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
lead_paragraph: Out this month — to accompany a show at the McEvoy Foundation for the Arts in San Francisco — is a beautiful monograph of the work of the photographer Michael Jang. Born in 1951, Jang is Chinese-American, and grew up in Marysville, Calif., which is right outside Sacramento. From the start, he showed a natural affinity with the camera — his earliest pictures are of the Jang family in intimate moments: gathering at Christmas, watering the garden, doing the laundry. The pictures are playful, full of curiosity and laughter. Later, while attending school at Cal Arts, Jang found ways to rub shoulders with movie stars and politicians and other celebrities at the Beverly Hilton Hotel — he photographed figures such as Ronald Reagan, Jack Lemmon and David Bowie. Other moments, with crowds or bellhops, show how people and faces were fascinating for Jang. Afterward, he moved north to San Francisco, where he began to capture scenes on the street or out at night. It was the ’70s, and there’s something electric about seeing San Francisco through Jang’s eyes. I grew up in the Bay Area a decade and a half later, not too far from where Jang wandered around (and still does) — and though his pictures feel very familiar to me, that’s not why I find them so compelling. There’s something to admire in how technically precise Jang is in working in black and white — he seems to understand intuitively the depth of a picture before he even takes it, and I admire him more for how incredibly witty he can be, catching visual puns or simply revealing the humor of a particular moment: the college kid who has passed out sucking his thumb; the expression on the Sex Pistols’ Johnny Rotten’s face caught by surprise while lying low at Japantown’s Miyako Hotel. “Michael Jang’s California” is on view from Sept. 27, 2019 to Jan. 18, 2020 at McEvoy Foundation for the Arts in San Francisco. The book “Who Is Michael Jang?” $65, is available now at atelier-editions.com. — THESSALY LA FORCE

headline: Trump Calls China a ‘Threat to the World’ as Trade Talks Approach
abstract: The president says he will not accept an interim trade deal and accused China of building up its military with funds earned through unfair trade practices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Friday that China was a “threat to the world” and suggested Beijing was eager to make a trade deal because his tariffs were hurting the Chinese economy, coarsening his tone as the two countries prepared to resume negotiations.

headline: G.M. Walkout Begins to Pinch Suppliers and Canada Plants
abstract: The strike by the United Auto Workers, in its fifth day, is causing layoffs in related operations but has not yet resulted in shortages at dealers.
lead_paragraph: The strike that has shut down General Motors plants in the United States since Monday is starting to ripple through the automaker’s supply chain, causing layoffs and production stoppages by parts makers and components manufacturers across the Midwest.

headline: David Jones, Health Care Entrepreneur Behind Humana, Is Dead at 88
abstract: Mr. Jones and a partner built large chains of nursing homes and hospitals. He later turned Humana into a major force in health insurance.
lead_paragraph: David A. Jones, who with a partner built Humana from a single nursing home into a health insurance behemoth, died on Wednesday at a rehabilitation facility in Louisville, Ky. He was 88.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: What really brought down the Boeing 737 Max? IPhone 11 and 11 Pro review. Pam Grier on longevity in showbiz. Block parties in pictures. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. It’s the one where we honor the best in TV, with the Emmys. It’s also the last one of summer for those of us in the Northern Hemisphere. No matter what you’re doing, carve out some time to read these great stories.

headline: When Lesbian Publishing Made It Big
abstract: A graphic tribute to the landmark Naiad Press.

headline: Annette Kolodny, Feminist Critic and Scholar, Dies at 78
abstract: She was a pioneer in the field of ecofeminism, in which she drew parallels between the ravaging of the environment and the ravaging of women.
lead_paragraph: Annette Kolodny, a literary and cultural critic who was a pioneer in the field of ecofeminism, drawing parallels between the subjugation of the environment and the subjugation of women, died on Sept. 11 at her home in Tucson. She was 78.

headline: With India, Trump Practices the Art of the Mini-Deal
abstract: The administration’s prospective deal with India could be a boon to some farmers and businesses, but it is much smaller than a traditional trade pact.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Call it the art of the mini-deal.

headline: ‘Nerd,’ ‘Nonsmoker,’ ‘Wrongdoer’: How Might A.I. Label You?
abstract: ImageNet Roulette, a digital art project and viral selfie app, exposes how biases have crept into the artificial-intelligence technologies changing our lives.
lead_paragraph: When Tabong Kima checked his Twitter feed early Wednesday morning, the hashtag of the moment was #ImageNetRoulette.

headline: Why the Whistle-Blowing Process Is Breaking Down
abstract: The separation of powers has become increasingly subservient to the separation of parties.
lead_paragraph: There’s still a lot that the public doesn’t know about the emerging and evolving legal and political scandal arising out of a whistle-blower complaint from a member of the intelligence community. We don’t know the exact substance of the complaint. Anonymous sources aside, we don’t know the specific details of the activity that triggered the complaint. And thanks to the Justice Department’s creative (and almost certainly erroneous) interpretation of the relevant federal statute, the Intelligence Community Whistleblower Protection Act, we don’t know where we go from here.

headline: Hollywood Is Fighting, but the Emmys Show Will Go On
abstract: The popular “Game of Thrones” and the critically adored “Fleabag” are among the nominees at a time of canceled parties and a legal fight between TV writers and their agents.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s the most celebratory weekend in television, a time for red-carpet looks, thank-you speeches and lavish parties. But as the 71st Primetime Emmy Awards approached this week, Hollywood seemed glum.

headline: Thanks a Billion
abstract: The show reaches a milestone, and we’re grateful to you.
lead_paragraph: Since our first episode in February 2017, “The Daily” has featured 224 of our Times colleagues in at least 30 countries across 691 episodes. It has also featured 25 elected officials (4 openly disillusioned), 1 out-of-work coal miner, 1 former white nationalist, 1 former ISIS member, 1 current Russian troll, 1 fired F.B.I. director, 1 border sheriff, 2 undocumented immigrants, 3 White House interviews, 1 Times publisher and 1 set of 10-year-old twins — to name a few.

abstract: The crash of a tour bus with 31 people aboard happened near Bryce Canyon National Park, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: At least four people were killed and more than two dozen were injured in a tour bus crash in rural Utah on Friday afternoon, officials said.

headline: Alyssa Thomas Is One of a Kind of a Big Deal in the W.N.B.A.
abstract: Thomas, a forward on the Connecticut Sun, has powered her team to the cusp of the finals with back-to-back double-doubles against the Los Angeles Sparks.
lead_paragraph: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — In theory, it should be possible to slow down or even stop Alyssa Thomas, the hybrid 6-foot-2 forward for the Connecticut Sun.

lead_paragraph: Suzanne Whang, an actress, comedian and former host of HGTV’s “House Hunters,” died Tuesday after a long battle with breast cancer,  her longtime agent, Eddie Culbertson, said Friday. She was 56.

headline: What’s Next for Israel?
abstract: Probably not “peace,” or a Palestinian state any time soon. But certainly political changes and most likely a lesser role for Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: Political predictions are always risky, but downright dangerous in Israeli politics. With a plethora of political parties and factions in ever-shifting coalitions, an election in Israel is normally the starting gun for weeks of elaborate and unpredictable horse-trading before a government emerges — or fails to. The process is barely underway since Tuesday’s vote. Yet even at this early stage, some trends bear watching.

headline: At School, ‘Everyone Vapes,’ and Adults Are in Crisis Mode
abstract: An alarming outbreak of ailments has put teachers and principals into crisis mode.
lead_paragraph: CRYSTAL LAKE, Ill. — In Alabama, a school removed the doors from bathroom stalls to stop students from sneaking inside to vape. In Colorado, a school decided to forfeit a volleyball game after finding “widespread vaping” and other infractions by the team. And in Pennsylvania, at a school where administrators have tried installing sensors to detect vaping in bathrooms and locker rooms, students caught with vape devices face a $50 fine and a three-day suspension.

headline: President Must Tape Testimony for Trial Over 2015 Protest at Trump Tower
abstract: A Bronx judge says the president must testify by videotape in a lawsuit brought by protesters who say his guards assaulted them.
lead_paragraph: A Bronx trial judge on Friday ordered President Trump to provide videotaped testimony for an upcoming trial over a lawsuit brought by protesters who say that his private security guards assaulted them on a public sidewalk in front of Trump Tower and stole a protest sign.

headline: Twitter Suspends Account of Former Adviser to Saudi Crown Prince
abstract: The account was one of thousands with ties to governments in the Middle East that were taken down by the social media company.
lead_paragraph: Twitter said on Friday that it had removed or suspended thousands of accounts with ties to governments in the Middle East, including the account of Saud el-Qahtani, a former close adviser to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia.

headline: When Anti-Immigration Meant Keeping Out Black Pioneers
abstract: In the 1850s, Midwestern states used harsh laws to deny free African-Americans wealth and property.
lead_paragraph: William Brown managed to get across the river safely, finding work in a small rural Illinois community close to the state’s border with Indiana. He would have known of the new anti-immigration laws, but must have been willing to risk breaking them for a better life. But a sheriff named John Watts soon arrested Mr. Brown for making his illegal crossing. When Mr. Brown could not pay the $50 fine the State of Illinois required of him, Sheriff Watts put him in chains on the Lawrence County courthouse steps and tried to sell him at auction to the highest bidder.

headline: Intelligence Whistle-Blower Law, Explained
abstract: Congress and the Trump administration are in a standoff over a secret complaint related to President Trump and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress is in a sharply escalating standoff with the Trump administration over its refusal to share a whistle-blower complaint with lawmakers that is said to be at least in part about President Trump’s communications with Ukraine.

headline: Iranian Students Set to Start at U.S. Universities Are Barred From Country
abstract: The students, who were mostly headed to schools in the University of California system, had visas in hand when they were blocked from their flights this month.
lead_paragraph: At least a dozen Iranian students who were set to begin graduate programs in engineering and computer science say their visas were abruptly canceled and they were barred from their flights to the United States this month.

headline: Rare Protests Against Egypt’s Leader Erupt in Cairo and Elsewhere
abstract: Hundreds of young people, responding to online calls for demonstrations against President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, chanted “Down with Sisi” and “Leave now.”
lead_paragraph: Rare protests against President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi erupted in central Cairo and several smaller Egyptian cities on Friday night as hundreds of young people, responding to online calls for demonstrations against government corruption, chanted “Down with Sisi” and “Leave now.”

headline: The Beauty of Being Bilingual
abstract: The bittersweet discovery that language, and the stories it carries, is not a straight path.
lead_paragraph: My parents refused to let my sister and me forget how to speak Spanish by pretending they didn’t understand when we spoke English. Spanish was the only language we were allowed to speak in our one-bedroom apartment in Miami in the late 1980s. We both graduated from English as a second language lessons in record time as kindergartners and first graders, and we longed to play and talk and live in English as if it were a shiny new toy.

headline: As ‘Moscow Mitch’ Rings in His Ears, McConnell Backs Election Security
abstract: Even if it took a taunt to do it, he approved $250 million for voting protections.
lead_paragraph: We come to praise Mitch McConnell, not to bury him.

abstract: The administration is not ruling out military strikes. But for now, President Trump is content to remain within the parameters of defense, not offense.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is sending a modest deployment of American troops to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, along with air and missile defense systems, in response to the attacks on Saudi oil facilities, which the administration blames on Iran.

headline: Giuliani Revels in Another Cable Dust-up Defending Trump
abstract: Mr. Giuliani’s unconstrained television appearances have long raised concerns with the rest of Mr. Trump’s legal team, as well as White House officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a television appearance on CNN Thursday night, Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, appeared to acknowledge that Mr. Trump had tried to pressure Ukraine into investigating Joseph R. Biden, Jr., the former vice president and Democratic presidential candidate.

headline: Lawmakers Court Trump on Gun Safety, With Some Appealing to His Ego
abstract: President Trump is expected to decide next week whether to defy the N.R.A. and embrace a bill expanding background checks for gun buyers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a phone call with President Trump about gun safety legislation last week, Senator Joe Manchin III made an unusual offer: If Mr. Trump signed onto a background check bill that he and Senator Pat Toomey have been pushing for six years, the president could claim the naming rights for himself.

headline: The Bygone Baggage of Joe Biden
abstract: The politics that created the conditions for Trump cannot be the politics that defeat him.
lead_paragraph: The genius of Barack Obama lay in the fact that Americans looked at him and could believe in almost anything. The left of the Democratic Party saw the revolutionary incarnation of hope, the promise of sweeping social change, and, in a black president, the overturning of America’s original sin. The center saw a measured product of Harvard Law School, a prudent reformer, a man of mixed identity and the middle ground.

headline: Israel’s Democracy Is Doing Just Fine
abstract: In an age of demagogues, Israelis showed that demagogy doesn’t work.
lead_paragraph: For many years, but especially recently, analysts and pundits have predicted or proclaimed the death of Israel’s democracy.

headline: Very Rich
abstract: Joon Pahk e Erik Agard, cosa stai facendo, bambini?
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Two veteran weekend constructors, Erik Agard and Joon Pahk, combine forces today and slap a zingy grid on the table. If you’re familiar with these names, then you know to expect complexity and a high cool factor.

headline: Behind the Whistle-Blower Case, a Long-Held Trump Grudge Toward Ukraine
abstract: The president and his allies have been pressing Ukraine for months to investigate Joseph R. Biden Jr., complicating relations between the two countries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months this spring and summer, Ukraine’s newly elected president, Volodymyr Zelensky, tried to deflect pressure from President Trump and his allies to pursue investigations into former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., Mr. Biden’s son and other Trump rivals.

headline: Two Trudeaus, Two Challenging Elections
abstract: Justin Trudeau experienced a dramatic campaign setback with the revelation of blackface photos from his past, he faces many re-election challenges Pierre Trudeau faced in 1972
lead_paragraph: If nothing else, it was a week of Canada being at the center of worldwide attention, if not for desirable reasons.

headline: Yankees’ Domingo German Is Likely to Miss Rest of the Season
abstract: German, who was placed on administrative leave on Thursday under the M.L.B. domestic violence policy, could return, but the Yankees are making plans to play without him.
lead_paragraph: It was business as usual at Yankee Stadium on Thursday as the team prepared for an evening game against the Los Angeles Angels. Then, at 1:36 p.m., Major League Baseball announced that Yankees pitcher Domingo German had been placed on administrative leave under its domestic violence policy — a precursor to a larger investigation and a possible suspension just days before the postseason.

headline: In Shadow of Ukraine Scandal, White House Hosts Second State Dinner of Trump Era
abstract: Scrutiny over President Trump’s behavior with world leaders was a hard-to-avoid theme of the day for the Australian prime minister.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Scott Morrison, the Australian prime minister, was invited for a rare state visit to the White House on Friday with a red-carpet welcome that included a twinkling Rose Garden dinner, a cordial news conference and a televised presidential screed about the latest scandal involving his administration.

headline: From Underwear to Cars, India’s Economy Is Fraying
abstract: The country once had the world’s fastest-growing economy, but it has been battered by global and domestic forces. India’s troubles are a warning sign for other developing countries.
lead_paragraph: TIRUPUR, India — When Alan Greenspan ran a consulting firm and wanted to know where the economy was headed, he would often look at sales of men’s underwear as a guide.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 21, 2019
lead_paragraph: “Adults are, like, ‘Respect your elders.’ And we’re, like, ‘Respect our futures.’ You know, it’s a two-way street, respect, and I’m angry that I have to be here.”

headline: Corrections: September 21, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, September 21, 2019.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Escaping the Nxivm Cult’ and a Bill Gates Documentary
abstract: A mother tries to free her daughter from Keith Raniere’s group, and a Netflix documentary examines the humanitarian efforts of the co-founder of Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: ESCAPING THE NXIVM CULT: A MOTHER’S FIGHT TO SAVE HER DAUGHTER 8 p.m. on Lifetime. This June, Keith Raniere, the leader of an organization known as Nxivm, was convicted on racketeering and sex trafficking charges, ending a trial that exposed the secretive group’s inner workings. Nxivm presented itself as a personal fulfillment program, but some of its female members say they were recruited into a secret society within the group, known as D.O.S., where they were branded, threatened with blackmail and assigned to have sex with Raniere. It’s no wonder, then, that the operations of the enclave, which prosecutors likened to that of a “horror movie,” serve as the inspiration for this made-for-TV film. Based on the tell-all memoir “Captive,” by the actress Catherine Oxenberg, the film follows Oxenberg’s struggle to free her daughter, India, from the group’s secret society. Peter Facinelli plays the enigmatic Nxvim leader, and Sara Fletcher plays Allison Mack, the “Smallville” actress who pleaded guilty to charges of racketeering and racketeering conspiracy related to her involvement in the group.

headline: Mixing Politics and Piety, a Conservative Priest Seeks to Shape Poland’s Future
abstract: The Rev. Tadeusz Rydzyk has delivered millions of votes for Poland’s governing right-wing Law and Justice party, which in turn has helped him build a business empire.
lead_paragraph: TORUN, Poland — From the martyrs of World War II to the heroes who led the fight against communist rule, priests in Poland have long played an outsize role in shaping the political life of this deeply Catholic country.

headline: In Ann Patchett’s New Novel, a Glass House and a Family With Things to Hide
abstract: “The Dutch House” is about a brother and sister whose lives are changed when a stepmother enters their family.
lead_paragraph: By Ann Patchett’s own admission, she has been writing the same story throughout her nearly 30-year career. A group of strangers are flung together by a catastrophe of some sort — a hostage situation, perhaps, as in the Orange Prize-winning “Bel Canto,” but usually a sudden death (“State of Wonder,” “Run,” “The Magician’s Assistant”). They must learn to trust each other to survive.

headline: Inside a Deadly American Summer
abstract: Mass shootings came one after another, sometimes only hours apart, leaving a reeling nation wondering why.
lead_paragraph: Mass shootings came one after another, sometimes only hours apart, leaving a reeling nation wondering why.

headline: 6 Items to Sleep Well (or at Least Better) While Traveling
abstract: This is the gear that Wirecutter staffers use to get some rest while on the road.
lead_paragraph: Time-zone changes, jet lag, strange noises, beds that are simply different from what you’re used to — even people who usually have no trouble getting a good night’s sleep can become insomniacs when away from home. Here, the sleep team and the travel editors of Wirecutter share the gear they use to cope with restless nights on the road, vetted through hours of testing and years of personal experience.

headline: The Grandest of Watches Encroach on the Football Field
abstract: Fancy watches aren’t just for golf and tennis anymore. But, players are discovering, what’s on your wrist might not result in emotional fulfillment.
lead_paragraph: When Odell Beckham Jr. of the Cleveland Browns took the field wearing a $190,000 Richard Mille wristwatch during a blowout loss to the Tennessee Titans on Sept. 8, the question was: Was he violating league rules, or just the rules of common sense?

headline: Gabrielle Bernstein Loves a Routine
abstract: The self-help writer just wants you to live your best life.
lead_paragraph: On a typical morning, the self-help author Gabrielle Bernstein, 39, is up by 7 a.m. with her 9-month-old son, Oliver. Her husband Zach Rocklin, 42, an artist and the chief operating officer of his wife’s company, is in charge of feeding him. That’s when Ms. Bernstein heads upstairs to her “meditation loft” (also known as an office) in their two-bedroom, one-bathroom apartment in Alphabet City to do the first of two 20-minute meditations.

headline: Beep. Ding. Vroom. Electric Cars Need to Make Noise for Safety, but What Kind?
abstract: As electric cars become more popular, engineers, driven by government regulators, are crafting the sounds that will define the highways of the future.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Nissan hired the studio Man Made Music for what seemed like a straightforward task: Design a sound that its quiet electric vehicles could play to announce themselves on the road.

headline: Sydney Is for the Birds. The Bigger and Bolder, the Better.
abstract: Australia’s largest city has a rare superpower: It turns urbanites into bird people, and birds into urbanites. Interacting with the huge avian population is a daily adventure and (mostly) a delight.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — The bushy pair of laughing kookaburras that used to show up outside my daughter’s bedroom window disappeared a few months ago.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Lost Her Dream Job but Gained a Path to 2020
abstract: She had a plan to take on big banks. In the fight to get it done, she honed the approach to politics that defines her presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Warren did not want a goodbye party. She told her aides there would be no grand send-off, no celebration of a mission accomplished.

headline: Bill de Blasio Bows Out, Elizabeth Warren’s Big Speech: This Week in the 2020 Race
abstract: Here are six things that happened on the presidential campaign trail this week.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic field got a little bit smaller this week, shrinking to 19 candidates. Here’s our weekly catch-up on the 2020 election and some moments you may have missed.

headline: Meet the Photographer Who Brings Vivid Color to The Times Magazine’s Interview Column
abstract: For the Talk column, 22-year-old Mamadi Doumbouya has brought his distinctive, color-saturated style to photos of Megan Rapinoe, Dapper Dan, Robert A. Caro and many more.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: A Crackdown on Islam Is Spreading Across China
abstract: A secret Communist Party directive has led to restrictions on Islamic practices far from Xinjiang, the western region where Uighurs have been brutally repressed.
lead_paragraph: YINCHUAN, China — In China’s northwest, the government is stripping the most overt expressions of the Islamic faith from a picturesque valley where most residents are devout Muslims. The authorities have destroyed domes and minarets on mosques, including one in a small village near Linxia, a city known as “Little Mecca.”

headline: Melania Trump’s Say-Nothing State Dinner Dress
abstract: Her dress at the Australian state dinner wasn’t just understated, it was an absence of statement.
lead_paragraph: On Friday night, as the co-host of her second state dinner since becoming first lady and thus a figurehead of the nation, as well as a symbol of her husband’s administration (whether she likes it or not; that’s the job), Melania Trump clothed herself in her now-signature aplomb and ambivalence. As fashion statements at major public events when you know all eyes are on you go, hers was a polite nod; a no-teeth smile, lips clamped firmly together, in sartorial form. In fact, what was most notable about it was what it did not say.

headline: It Was in the Heavens and the Periodic Table
abstract: A priest and a scientist find proof of their love.

headline: Bernie Sanders Calls for Eliminating Americans’ Medical Debt
abstract: On top of his “Medicare for all” proposal, Mr. Sanders’s new plan would wipe out an estimated $81 billion in existing medical debt and ignore such debt in credit scores.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bernie Sanders has long wanted to remake the health care system so no one will have to pay directly for medical care again. Now, he also wants to go back and cancel all the medical debts of people who have been billed under the current system.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — It was sad enough when the bodies of Han Sung-ok and her 6-year-old son were found in their $74-a-month apartment in Seoul in July, two months after they had died.

headline: Running With My Mom: Nowhere to Go but Up

lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: How to Rent Out Your Driveway Parking Spot
abstract: Verbal agreements are often unenforceable, so get it in writing.
lead_paragraph: Q: My 85-year-old mother lives alone in a single-family home in Mill Basin, Brooklyn. Her neighbor offered her $20 a month to rent her driveway. After my mother said no, he offered $40, and she felt pressured to say yes. Given the lack of parking in this area, her driveway could be worth at least $100 a month, and my mom, who lives on Social Security, could use the extra income. I think the neighbor is taking advantage of her. What can I do? Nothing is in writing.

headline: Trump and Election Interference, Whistle-Blower Edition
abstract: Many elements are murky, but something clearly stinks.
lead_paragraph: There’s so much we don’t know about the whistle-blower complaint concerning President Trump. But here are four things we do know:

headline: The Graves of Afghanistan Speak
abstract: Even the flags on the graves of the Afghans killed in the long war announce competing allegiances.
lead_paragraph: In Deh Naw — my parents’ home village in Logar Province of Afghanistan — makeshift graves and markers for the dead lay scattered amid orchards, in between fields, or atop hills, a testament to the decades of war. Sometimes, the graves are marked by small slabs of stone with a name or a prayer carved onto it, but just as often, the names of the dead went unrecorded, their lives only traded in whispers. Open secrets permeate these graveyards. Buried atrocities from the Soviet occupation, the Afghan civil wars, and the seemingly unending American occupation.

headline: Shooting at South Carolina Bar Leaves 2 Dead and 8 Wounded, Officials Say
abstract: The shooting happened early Saturday morning near Lancaster, S.C. The gunman remained at large.
lead_paragraph: Two people were killed and eight others wounded in a shooting early Saturday morning at a sports bar near Lancaster, S.C., the authorities said.

headline: Area 51 Raid: How a Town of 40 Coped With an Invasion
abstract: Nobody actually rushed the top-secret military base. “We just wanted to see people like us,” one visitor said.
lead_paragraph: RACHEL, Nev. — The alien invasion was underway, and David Day wanted no part of it.

headline: 27 Amazing Slow Cooker Recipes
abstract: Chipotle-honey chicken tacos, white bean-Parmesan soup and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Don’t let that slow cooker languish in a cabinet. Make chicken tortellini tomato soup (above), BBQ pulled pork, white bean-Parmesan soup or any of the recipes in the collection below.

headline: Ukraine and Whistle-Blower Issues Emerge as Major Flashpoints in Presidential Race
abstract: The controversy centers on whether President Trump manipulated foreign policy to pressure Ukraine to take action to damage Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s election bid.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Allegations that President Trump courted foreign interference from Ukraine to hurt his leading Democratic rival, Joseph R. Biden Jr., dominated presidential politics on Saturday, as Mr. Biden demanded a House investigation of Mr. Trump’s phone call with Ukraine’s leader and as Mr. Trump lashed out, denying wrongdoing without releasing a transcript of the call.

headline: Despite Tough Talk, U.S.-China Trade Negotiations Continue
abstract: Both sides issued statements describing recent discussions as productive. The question now is whether high-level talks next month will yield progress.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The combination on Friday of tough words from President Trump and the cancellation of a planned trip by Chinese agriculture officials to two farm states seemed to cast a cloud over prospects for a trade deal and caused a sell-off in New York stock trading.

headline: Climate Protesters and World Leaders: Same Planet, Different Worlds
abstract: Friday’s global climate protests put the gap between activists and many of the world leaders preparing to meet in New York City next week into stark focus.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — This is the world we live in: Punishing heat waves, catastrophic floods, huge fires and climate conditions so uncertain that children took to the streets en masse in global protests to demand action.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon branch out with a cryptic.
lead_paragraph: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — I often say that I wish everyone would get into the variety puzzles for the surprise and delight they deliver. Anyone can get good at them, and if you look forward to the pun clues in regular crossword puzzles, then you owe it to yourself to try these when they come along every six weeks or so. The fact that not every letter is crossed raises the challenge level considerably, but that’s what Wordplay is here for.

headline: The General Motors Century
abstract: A century ago, the automaker rolled out its millionth car. America has never been the same.
lead_paragraph: A century ago this fall, a black two-door Oldsmobile coupe rolled off a General Motors assembly line. It was the company’s one millionth car. Today we take General Motors’s size for granted — we understand, immediately, that this week’s strike by the company’s workers will reverberate across the country. But it wasn’t always so, and the rapid rise of General Motors through the 1910s not only reshaped the Midwest but also reflected tremendous changes in the American economy and society.

headline: Trump Calls Reports That He Pressured Ukraine’s President a ‘Witch Hunt’
abstract: Mr. Trump, intensifying a line of attack his allies have stoked for months, accused the media of covering up the former vice president’s dealings with Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Saturday dismissed news reports that he urged the Ukrainian president to investigate former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s son as little more than a “witch hunt” and said his dealings were “perfectly fine” and routine.

headline: The Next Debate: Let’s Talk About …

headline: To Influence El Salvador, China Dangled Money. The U.S. Made Threats.

But for once, he kept his cards close to the vest, soliciting advice rather than doing all of the talking.

headline: The Corey Lewandowski Trap
abstract: Democrats keep underestimating the audacity of Trump and his tribe.
lead_paragraph: Did that look of unalloyed contempt come naturally to Corey Lewandowski, or did he rehearse it? I picture him in front of a mirror as his “testimony” before the House Judiciary Committee approached, fine-tuning his sneer, perfecting his glare, testing different tilts of his head to see which conveyed maximal disgust with his inquisitors. He was hellbent on acing this performance.

headline: The College Admissions Trilemma
abstract: Why it’s so hard for universities to balance class, race and their budgets.
lead_paragraph: For decades America’s universities have made extensive efforts to achieve racial diversity within their student bodies. The official justifications for these efforts have changed depending on political currents and Supreme Court whims: What began as explicit redress for African-Americans eventually morphed into a commitment to diversity as an educational good unto itself. But the implicit goal has always been a kind of elite legitimation, a demonstration that the meritocracy is actually fair and open and representative of the society that it aspires to rule.

headline: Trump Walks a Crooked Mile
abstract: Has he finally gone too far?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Everyone here is keyed up for the Big One.

Presidential Forum right off the floor in a great bear hug. Later, an audience member interrupted Senator Amy Klobuchar with what sounded like an appeal to “protect sex workers.”

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — At first, the man was just walking across the street. Then he was running for his life. He managed four steps before the blast from the car bomb caught him.

headline: Imagine Jair Bolsonaro Standing Trial for Ecocide at The Hague
abstract: A group of activists already has.
lead_paragraph: Since August, as vast stretches of the Amazon rainforest were being reduced to ashes and outrage and calls for action intensified, a group of lawyers and activists who have been advancing a radical idea have seen a silver lining in the unfolding tragedy: One day, a few years from now, they imagined Brazil’s president, Jair Bolsonaro, being hauled to The Hague to stand trial for ecocide, a term broadly understood to mean the willful and widespread destruction of the environment, and one that, they hope, will eventually be on par with other crimes against humanity.

headline: What Does It Mean to ‘Look Like Me’?
abstract: Minorities can find it gratifying to see people who resemble them onscreen. But resemblance is a tricky thing.
lead_paragraph: It’s a formula that we turn to again and again to affirm the value of inclusion, especially in the realm of popular culture: the importance of people who “look like me.”

headline: On the Up and Up
abstract: Tracy Gray is here to take us higher.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — You know you’re working on a good Sunday grid when you’re entertained and challenged at every turn and you haven’t even realized the theme yet. Today’s puzzle by Tracy Gray is a real peach. There are entries that make you feel like you know her, and there are entries that are like arrows of knowledge you can put in your quiver for later.

headline: An Improbable Relic of Auschwitz: a Shofar That Defied the Nazis

lead_paragraph: For years there have been fragmentary reports of almost unbelievable acts of faith at the Nazi death camps during World War II: the sounding of shofars, the ram’s horn trumpets traditionally blown by Jews to welcome the High Holy Days.

headline: Fact-Checking Trump’s Latest Claims About Space and Iran
