headline: What’s on TV Sunday: The Emmys and ‘Criminal’
abstract: Television’s biggest night airs on Fox, and a new police procedural focused on interrogations comes to Netflix.
lead_paragraph: THE EMMYS 8 p.m. on Fox. Awards season kicks into gear with the 71st annual Emmy Awards, television’s biggest night. With a whopping 32 nominations, “Game of Thrones” seems to be the front-runner for the drama awards. The show, which ended after eight seasons this spring, has already won 10 Creative Arts Emmy Awards, and could very well win best drama for the fourth time. But, as Margaret Lyons, a television critic for The New York Times, noted after this year’s nominations were announced, “The variety and flair of the comedy categories — performing, writing, even directing — are just way, way more interesting than the sort of blah drama contenders this year.” Among the newcomers are fan favorites like “Schitt’s Creek,” which is up for best comedy, and “Fleabag,” which was nominated for 11 awards, including best acting and best writing for its creator, Phoebe Waller-Bridge. The event itself will go hostless this year, but Jenny McCarthy, Shannon Sharpe and Kelly Osbourne will co-host Fox’s red carpet coverage starting at 6:30 p.m. Over on E!, Giuliana Rancic and Jason Kennedy will do the honors, beginning at 6 p.m.

headline: Refugee Cutbacks Could Isolate Rohingya Children in the U.S.
abstract: Thousands of Rohingya have quietly settled in America, but for children who fled violence in Myanmar, having their parents join them is becoming a distant hope.
lead_paragraph: ELK RAPIDS, Mich. — Not long after Hefzur Rahman enrolled at his new school in Michigan three years ago, his fifth-grade class studied the subhuman conditions that enslaved Africans endured in overcrowded ships bound for North America.

headline: Questions About Russian Doping Data Raise Fears About Manipulation
abstract: The World Anti-Doping Agency cites “inconsistencies” in a database provided by its Russian counterpart, and investigators may recommend a new suspension.
lead_paragraph: Inspectors at the World Anti-Doping Agency are considering recommending on Monday that the global regulator’s board once again ban Russia’s antidoping agency. The move would come days before the start of the world track and field championships in Qatar, and amid fears Russia manipulated athlete data provided to WADA earlier this year, according to two people familiar with the board’s plans.

headline: No Longer Taboo, Tattoos Are Reclaimed by Hondurans to Express Love Not Hate
abstract: In Honduras, tattoos have a malevolent history, long symbolic of violent gangs. But recently, they’ve been embraced by everyday citizens as a way to show love for parents and pets.
lead_paragraph: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — Ruth Pineda stood with her back to the mirror, the strap of her tank top tucked under her arm, revealing a new tattoo: a heart. Inside were three dolphins jumping over the sea at sunset.

headline: M.I.T. Media Lab, Already Rattled by the Epstein Scandal, Has a New Worry
abstract: Former researchers for a “food computer” initiative at the lab say the project’s leader misled outsiders about how it was going.
lead_paragraph: The M.I.T. Media Lab, an unconventional research center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has been under scrutiny since August, when its financial ties to the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein became public. Now researchers who worked at the lab say that one of its high-profile scientific projects was promoted with misleading claims.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 23, 2019
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Students

headline: The Week in Books
abstract: Ta-Nehisi Coates’s debut novel, a landmark biography of Susan Sontag, Ann Patchett and more.
lead_paragraph: We really look forward to putting certain issues out into the world, and here’s one we’ve been excited about for months. The Furies, this week’s theme package, looks at books about women fighting for their rights and fighting back, from a variety of angles and across genres.

headline: The Slow-Burning Success of Disney’s Bob Iger
abstract: Hollywood’s nicest C.E.O. on the great family dramas of Hollywood — and why he, too, is disturbed by Twitter.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif.— Bob Iger looks down at his phone and frowns.

headline: What to Expect at the U.N. General Assembly This Week
abstract: Nearly 200 leaders will converge on the world’s most prominent diplomatic stage for five days of speeches, hundreds of meetings — and clashes over climate change, Iran and trade.
lead_paragraph: The annual United Nations General Assembly will unfold this week against a backdrop of crises — from the warming planet to economic uncertainty to flaring conflicts that threaten to further entangle the United States in the volatile Middle East.

headline: Whistle-Blower, United Nations, Jonathan Van Ness: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Two 13-Year-Olds Are Arrested Over Hong Kong Protests
abstract: One of the minors, a girl, was arrested on charges of burning a Chinese national flag. She was held overnight in police detention.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong police arrested two 13-year-olds on the fringes of antigovernment demonstrations over the weekend, including a girl accused of burning a Chinese national flag, the authorities said on Sunday.

headline: The Week in Business: No More E-Cigarettes at Walmart, and an Attack on the World’s Oil Supply
abstract: Plus, a battle over California’s right to make its own car pollution rules.
lead_paragraph: Who knew the humble tailpipe could cause so much political rancor? Find out why, below, along with more business and tech news that you should know heading into the week. On that note, check out our in-depth analysis of life in the modern workplace, including a guide to office chitchat and snacks. See, Monday doesn’t need to be so bad.

headline: ‘Maybe This Was His Plan for Telling Me I Was Being Hired Full Time?’
abstract: A temp’s hopes rise, in a community garden on Sixth Street and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Smoky Fire at Bar Forces Evacuation of Hotel at Times Square, Officials Say
abstract: Guests were evacuated after the fire was reported about 7:40 a.m. A Fire Department official said there were three injuries.
lead_paragraph: A smoky fire at a bar adjacent to the Hyatt Centric Times Square on West 45th Street prompted the evacuation of hotel guests on Sunday morning.

headline: J. Lo Wins Milan. Fashion Comes Second.
abstract: Recycling of scenarios and silhouettes at Versace, Armani and Missoni; renovation at Marni.
lead_paragraph: The moment that ate Milan Fashion Week occurred at the end of the Versace show.

headline: Next Spring, Next Trends
abstract: We’re about halfway through the fashion show season and favorites are beginning to emerge.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — It often seems like anything goes in fashion today — hemlines are both up and down; jeans are both narrow and boyfriend — but as the five-day show and accessories cavalcade that is Milan Fashion Week came to an end, a consensus of sorts began to emerge. Here’s what to expect, wardrobe-wise, in 2020.

headline: How Does Post Malone Sound Like Everything and Nothing?
abstract: A conversation about his rapid rise and the questions — about genre and race — glossed over along the way.
lead_paragraph: Some days, it feels like there is no pop star besides Post Malone. His music is astronomically popular and ubiquitous, and sounds like it could belong everywhere: a hip-hop club, a honky-tonk, a rock concert, a poolside bar.

headline: How To Win School Lunch
abstract: Make something for dinner tonight with an eye toward leftovers.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. A lot of my time these days is spent getting ready for The New York Times Food Festival, which kicks off in New York City the first weekend in October. We’ve got a lot of exciting events planned, from onstage conversations with people like Alex Wagner and Sam Kass talking politics at the dinner table with Ginia Bellafante, to the chance to eat street food prepared by chefs who usually cook for starched tablecloths and shimmering crystal.

headline: Smoke Rises From Hyatt Times Square
abstract: Hotel guests were evacuated in response to a fire on Sunday that started in the duct work of an adjoining bar. A Fire Department spokesman said three people had minor injuries.
lead_paragraph: Hotel guests were evacuated in response to a fire on Sunday that started in the duct work of an adjoining bar. A Fire Department spokesman said three people had minor injuries.

headline: 3 Are Dead and 4 Hospitalized in Pittsburgh From Overdoses, Officials Say
abstract: All the victims were wearing orange wristbands and had been at the same event on Saturday night, but overdosed together at a private residence, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Three men died and four others were hospitalized in Pittsburgh early Sunday morning as a result of overdoses, the authorities said.

headline: The Week in Arts: Antonio Banderas Returns; ‘Transparent’ Goes Out Singing
abstract: The actor stars in Soderbergh’s “The Laundromat” and Almodóvar’s “Pain and Glory”; and Jill Soloway’s TV series wraps up as a musical.
lead_paragraph: Through Sept. 26; quadcinema.com.

headline: Antonio Brown Says He Is Done With the N.F.L.
abstract: Amid a sexual assault investigation and after being released by two teams in two weeks, the wide receiver tweeted that he was walking away from the league.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Brown, the free-agent wide receiver recently released by the New England Patriots, declared on Sunday that he would no longer play in the N.F.L.

headline: Ayman Odeh: We Are Ending Netanyahu’s Grip on Israel
abstract: The leader of the Joint List of predominantly Arab parties explains why it will use its power to help make Benny Gantz prime minister of Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Arab Palestinian citizens of Israel have chosen to reject Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, his politics of fear and hate, and the inequality and division he advanced for the past decade. Last summer, Mr. Netanyahu declared that Arab Palestinian citizens of Israel, who make up a fifth of the population, were to be second-class citizens, officially. “Israel is not a state of all its citizens,” Mr. Netanyahu wrote on Instagram after passing the Nation-State law. “According to the basic nationality law we passed, Israel is the nation-state of the Jewish people — and only it.”

headline: Israel’s Arab Parties Back Benny Gantz to End Netanyahu’s Grip
abstract: Ayman Odeh, leader of the Arab Joint List, said his group would support a government by Mr. Gantz to keep Benjamin Netanyahu from getting a new term.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After 27 years of sitting out decisions on who should lead Israel, Arab lawmakers on Sunday recommended that Benny Gantz, the centrist former army chief, get the first chance to form a government over Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, a watershed assertion of political power.

headline: Poor Schools Keep Getting Crushed in Football. Is It Time to Level the Playing Field?
abstract: A growing number of states are considering whether economic status should help determine which opponents schools play.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — An hour before kickoff at a game this month at Hoover High School, the opposing football team, Indianola High, pulled up and unloaded the large video monitor that would let its coaching staff analyze plays, moment by moment, throughout the game. The coaches at Hoover High, where most students qualify for free or reduced-price meals, would have to make do with watching the old-fashioned way. Another loss, a Hoover student told the principal, seemed imminent.

headline: Talking About Menopause (Finally)
abstract: Readers react with personal stories of pain and promise, and an ob-gyn shares data.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mystified and Appalled by Trump’s Faithful Base
abstract: A reader wonders about the president’s success with voters. Also: Environmental activism in France and the U.S.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ascensión Mendieta, 93, Dies; Symbol of Justice for Franco Victims
abstract: She fought for decades to recover the remains of her father, who had been executed by a firing squad in 1939. Finally, when she was 92, she found him.
lead_paragraph: Ascensión Mendieta was just 13 in 1939 when her father was lined up against a wall in Spain and shot by a firing squad of soldiers loyal to Gen. Francisco Franco. His body was then dumped into a mass grave.

headline: Review: The Lists We Live by in Daniel Fish’s ‘White Noise’
abstract: This distillation of Don DeLillo’s 1985 novel, by the director who deconstructed “Oklahoma!,” catalogs the clutter of the American mind.
lead_paragraph: It all begins with a man in a hole. Or rather, it begins with the hole itself, which occupies the center — dead center, I should say — of the screen that fills the stage at N.Y.U.’s Skirball Center.

headline: Does Your Real Estate Broker Owe You a Refund?
abstract: One renter paid $1,200 in dubious application fees. Thanks to a new state law, she got $800 back.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Pope.L’s Group Crawl: Protest, Pathos, Provocation
abstract: A communal performance through Greenwich Village kicks off explorations of the artist’s career at the Whitney and the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: “Crawlers, come to the line — please don your blindfolds,” said William Pope.L, the multidisciplinary artist, serving as master of ceremonies before a large crowd who assembled Saturday in a Greenwich Village playground.

headline: WeWork C.E.O.’s Ouster Is Weighed in Bid to Salvage I.P.O.
abstract: Some major money managers have reportedly said they wouldn’t invest unless an experienced operator was brought in to replace Adam Neumann.
lead_paragraph: Some board members and large investors in WeWork are privately discussing whether and how to replace the company’s co-founder, Adam Neumann, as chief executive to salvage the company’s fortunes, three people involved in the talks said.

headline: Egypt Protests Came as a Total Shock. The Man Behind Them Is Just as Surprising.
abstract: The videos of a potty-mouthed millionaire, who cheerfully insults the president, spurred protests across Egypt. His influence came out of the blue; no one knows how far it can go or long it can last.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Under the government of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt, so little dissent is allowed — and what little there is comes at such a high price — that when just a few hundred people across the country called for Mr. el-Sisi’s ouster in a burst of scattered protests on Friday night, it came as a shock.

headline: Trump Acknowledges Discussing Biden in Call With Ukrainian Leader
abstract: President Trump said his call with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was perfectly appropriate, as Democrats intensified demands for an inquiry into abuse of power.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump acknowledged on Sunday that he discussed former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. with Ukraine’s president as Democrats ramped up calls for an investigation into whether he improperly pressured a foreign leader to investigate a political opponent.

headline: Davo Karnicar Dies at 56; Made First Full Ski Descent of Everest
abstract: A Slovenian adventurer, Karnicar needed less than five hours to ski 12,000 feet from the summit of Mount Everest to its base camp.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 7, 2000, Davo Karnicar’s fervor for extreme skiing took him to the summit of Mount Everest. His goal: ski nonstop to base camp, 12,000 feet down — a feat no one had yet achieved.

headline: Fall TV Reviewed: Detectives, Sci-Fi and an Attempt at Romance
abstract: Cobie Smulders in “Stumptown”; Allison Tolman in “Emergence”; Michael Sheen in “Prodigal Son”; and Chuck Lorre’s “Bob Hearts Abishola.”
lead_paragraph: Broadcast television’s fall season begins on Monday. Here are reviews of some of the first week’s new shows.

headline: Review: In ‘Fern Hill,’ Scene-Stealing for the Common Good
abstract: John Glover lifts Michael Tucker’s otherwise convoluted and crowded dramedy of baby boomers contemplating life on a commune.
lead_paragraph: In soft, dusky light, the thievery gets underway. The brazen culprit is John Glover, and he embarks on his charisma-fueled caper right after intermission of Michael Tucker’s dramedy “Fern Hill.”

headline: Original or Copied? ‘Stairway to Heaven’ Is Back in Court
abstract: Who wrote the 1971 song’s opening passage, Jimmy Page and Robert Plant or Randy Wolfe? The music industry is hoping to get an answer on what makes a song original.
lead_paragraph: It seems only fitting that the most epic and dramatic of rock songs has resulted in one of the music industry’s most epic copyright fights.

headline: After Testifying Against the Bloods, Can Tekashi 69 Disappear?
abstract: He became a star witness for prosecutors, drawing death threats. Can a viral sensation now truly vanish? And would he want to?
lead_paragraph: For three short days in September, the rapper Tekashi 6ix9ine was back in his element: blowing up the internet. Abandoning his brand as a professional agitator, the Instagram celebrity became a star witness for the federal government, and testified at length about fellow rappers and his former crew, the Nine Trey Gangsta Bloods.

headline: China Scores Businesses, and Low Grades Could Be a Trade-War Weapon
abstract: Beijing hopes its social credit system will quickly punish companies accused of wrongdoing. U.S. firms could get hit, too.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China is funneling vast amounts of public and private data into huge databases aimed at tightening its control over its nearly 1.4 billion people.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Movie Tops the Box Office
abstract: Once a hit TV show, now a hit movie: “Downton Abbey” exceeded expectations with an estimated $31 million in ticket sales.
lead_paragraph: The take away from this weekend’s box-office results: Do not cross a dame.

headline: Who’s Speaking at the U.N. Climate Summit? Several Champions of Coal
abstract: Countries that continue to push coal will take the podium Monday at the United Nations Climate Action Summit.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In May of this year, on a trip to low-lying endangered Pacific islands, the United Nations secretary general, Antonio Guterres, made one of his boldest calls yet to the world’s presidents and prime ministers.

headline: Warren and Biden Join U.A.W. Picket Lines as Democrats Use Strike to Court Labor
abstract: Democratic candidates are publicly aligning themselves with union members in hopes of holding onto their support — and winning over those who flipped for President Trump in 2016.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Democratic presidential candidates have been chasing labor support all summer, appearing at small union halls and large conferences, and tweeting support for workers at companies like Amazon and Walmart. But now, as the United Automobile Workers, one of the nation’s largest unions, stages a strike that has even drawn words of support from President Trump, Democrats are seizing the moment to align themselves with workers in public and dramatic ways.

headline: Gucci M/W: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Gucci M/W: Spring 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Gucci M/W: Spring 2020 Collection.

headline: Even Before the Tears Stopped, She Took Action
abstract: As have other parents whose children were shot down at school, Lori Alhadeff is fighting for change.
lead_paragraph: The hours and days and weeks after her 14-year-old daughter, Alyssa, was killed in the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., are a blur. But some things Lori Alhadeff remembers. She remembers how she and her husband and sons tucked family pictures and a favorite pink teddy bear into the coffin before closing it, and how she kept her own fingers pressed against that coffin, even as it was being lowered into the ground. She does not remember screaming when it slipped, finally, from her reach. Friends later described the sound she made as unlike anything they had ever heard.

headline: As Trump Confirms He Discussed Biden With Ukraine, Pressure to Impeach Builds
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi warned of a “new chapter of lawlessness” and a turning point in the House investigation of President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump acknowledged on Sunday that he raised corruption accusations against former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. during a phone call with Ukraine’s leader, a stunning admission as pressure mounted on Democrats to impeach Mr. Trump over allegations he leaned on a foreign government to help damage a political rival.

headline: John L. Keenan, Who Led the ‘Son of Sam’ Manhunt, Dies at 99
abstract: At one point, Chief Keenan put 300 people on the case, and he was the one who took the confession from the killer, David Berkowitz, who had slain six young people.
lead_paragraph: John L. Keenan, the New York Police Department’s chief of detectives who oversaw the manhunt leading to the August 1977 arrest of David Berkowitz, the “Son of Sam” serial killer, died on Thursday in Mineola, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 99.

headline: 2019 Emmy Awards: ‘Game of Thrones’ and ‘Fleabag’ Win Big, One Last Time
abstract: Billy Porter made history by winning best lead actor in a drama. “Chernobyl” took home three prime-time awards, including best limited series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The dragon did it one last time.

headline: How 20 Photographers Captured New York Summer for The Times
abstract: For a Metro project, photographers fanned out across 65 block parties in all five boroughs to find camaraderie, community and cotton candy.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: India, U.N. General Assembly, China: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Modi's show of force in Texas.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Officer Under Investigation After Arresting 6-Year-Olds, Chief Says
abstract: One girl was arrested and handcuffed after having a tantrum at an Orlando, Fla., school, her grandmother said.
lead_paragraph: Update: Officer Dennis Turner was terminated on  Monday.

headline: ‘I Was Begging for Mercy’: How Undercover Officers in Hong Kong Launched a Bloody Crackdown
abstract: On Aug. 11, undercover officers in Hong Kong infiltrated crowds and severely beat protesters. We examined footage from that night and, for the first time, three men injured by the police told us their stories, painting a vivid picture of what happened.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 11, undercover officers in Hong Kong infiltrated crowds and severely beat protesters. We examined footage from that night and, for the first time, three men injured by the police told us their stories, painting a vivid picture of what happened.

headline: At Rally for India’s Modi, Trump Plays Second Fiddle but a Familiar Tune
abstract: Mr. Trump treated the giant Houston gathering as his own, seizing on the chance to brag about slashing regulations, lowering unemployment and implementing a tax cut.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — President Trump played second fiddle on Sunday to Narendra Modi, the prime minister of India, at a boisterous cultural rally in which the American president was technically just an invited guest.

headline: Police Dressed as Protesters: How Undercover Police in Hong Kong Severely Injured People
abstract: Officers dressed like demonstrators launched a bloody crackdown. Now, the men they targeted are telling their stories.
lead_paragraph: It was the end of another day of violent demonstrations in Hong Kong. The tear gas had dispersed and the crowds that had filled the streets were gone. The few demonstrators who remained were scattered around a popular shopping mall and getting ready to leave. Then, a group of men dressed in black rushed in, tackling people and beating them with batons.

headline: Yak, Yak, Yak
abstract: Andrea Carla Michaels returns to open our solving week.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Have you ever been in conversation with someone who just goes on and on and on, talking until they’re blue in the face without letting anyone get a word in edgewise?

headline: Photos and Highlights From the 2019 Emmys Red Carpet
abstract: Moments from the pre-show for television’s biggest night.
lead_paragraph: The director Ava DuVernay brought the Central Park Five as her dates. The real life stories of Antron McCray, Kevin Richardson, Yusef Salaam, Raymond Santana and Korey Wise — who were wrongfully convicted of assaulting and raping a woman in Central Park in 1989 — inspired her Netflix mini-series “When They See Us,” which is up for 16 awards. On the red carpet, Mr. Salaam said: “I think it was the most important thing for us to see each other’s stories because we hadn’t even talked about this.”

headline: 2020 Democrats Go All In on Iowa
abstract: The presidential candidates have embarked on a four-month sprint to a night of caucuses that remains the single biggest prize in American politics.
lead_paragraph: WEBSTER CITY, Iowa — Iowa’s presidential caucuses disenfranchise huge blocs of voters. The state is 91 percent white. It is not easy to get to, or get around in. But to a greater degree than in recent campaigns, this unrepresentative and idiosyncratic state is proving that it is the only electoral battleground that matters for Democrats from now until caucus night on Feb. 3.

headline: Emmys Red Carpet Photos 2019
abstract: All the pictures from the red carpet.
lead_paragraph: All the pictures from the red carpet.

headline: Trump Tower Theft: $353,000 in Jewelry Reported Stolen
abstract: Residents of two apartments in the president’s namesake residence on Fifth Avenue in New York told the police that diamonds, emeralds and sapphires were missing.
lead_paragraph: Two residents of Trump Tower in Manhattan reported the thefts of jewelry encrusted with diamonds, emeralds and sapphires from their apartments in the building where President Trump also lives when in New York, the police said.

headline: Woman Killed Her Lover and Then Set His House on Fire, Police Say
abstract: A tumultuous 20-year affair ended in murder last year when the man refused to give her money, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: When a fire engulfed a home on Long Island in November, it did not just take the life of a 75-year-old man.

headline: Emmy Awards Highlights and Analysis
abstract: Tune into the Emmy Awards along with Dave Itzkoff, our pop culture reporter, and James Poniewozik and Margaret Lyons, our television critics, for live analysis of the awards.
lead_paragraph: Tune into the Emmy Awards along with Dave Itzkoff, our pop culture reporter, and James Poniewozik and Margaret Lyons, our television critics, for live analysis of the awards.

headline: The Democrats Don’t Have the Suburbs Sewn Up Yet
abstract: To build a national majority, the party has to win the areas around smaller cities, which have resisted the blue wave.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party has been identified with urban America for nearly a century, and the city vote remains as blue as ever. In 2016, for instance, Hillary Clinton beat Donald Trump in New York City 80 percent to 20 percent. In Chicago, it was 83 percent to 13 percent. In Los Angeles, 72 percent to 23 percent.

headline: Donald Trump vs. the United States of America
abstract: Just the facts, in 40 sentences.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it’s worth stepping back to look at the full picture.

headline: We’re Ignoring the Biggest Cause of the Measles Crisis
abstract: It’s not anti-vaxxers. It’s parents who create their own vaccine schedules.
lead_paragraph: In September, New York City declared that its latest measles outbreak was over. More than 60 percent of the 650 people who contracted the illness were children under 5, those most susceptible to a severe measles illness.

headline: It’s a Fact: Mistakes Are Embarrassing the Publishing Industry
abstract: Errors and controversies involving several high-profile books are forcing writers and publishers to reconsider how they handle fact-checking.
lead_paragraph: In an era plagued by deep fakes and online disinformation campaigns, we still tend to trust what we read in books. But should we?

headline: C. C. Sabathia Says Goodbye at Yankee Stadium
abstract: The veteran pitcher was given a proper send-off on a day when Luis Severino threw five scoreless innings and the Yankees completed their final homestand.
lead_paragraph: C.C. Sabathia tried to remain stoic as the baseball world said its farewell. The scoreboard played one touching video after another on Sunday, from his past and present Yankees teammates, as well as rivals from other teams. Sabathia was alone at home plate, soaking up the love, until his mother, wife and children appeared on the gigantic screen reading letters of thanks to the man who proved he wasn’t afraid to cry.

headline: Don’t Mess With Modi in Texas
abstract: Trump joins Modi as the Indian prime minister defends the takeover of Kashmir and casts scorn on Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Who could resist an audience of more than 50,000 Indian-Americans packed into a Texas football stadium? Not Donald Trump, on the eve of an election year, so he joined the “Howdy, Modi!” party here to proclaim, with the Indian prime minister, a great future of shared values and mutual reinforcement for the world’s two largest democracies.

headline: Emmy Winners: The Full List of 2019 Awards
abstract: A look at the shows, actors and production teams who won at the 71st Primetime Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: “Game of Thrones” won best drama for the fourth time at the Emmy Awards on Sunday night, ending its eight-season run on a high note. “Fleabag” took home four awards, including best comedy.

headline: Trump, Biden and Ukraine: Sorting Out the Accusations
abstract: No evidence has surfaced that the former vice president intentionally tried to help his son by pressing for the ouster of a Ukrainian prosecutor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is trying to deflect attention from a firestorm of controversy around revelations that he pressed Ukraine’s leader to investigate a domestic political rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Carl Ruiz, Celebrity Chef and Restaurateur, Dies at 44
abstract: He made frequent appearances on the Food Network as a competitive chef and celebrity judge.
lead_paragraph: Carl A. Ruiz, a television celebrity chef and global restaurateur whose dishes celebrated his Latin upbringing, has died, his brother said on Monday. He was 44.

headline: Trump’s Hold on Military Aid Blindsided Top Ukrainian Officials
abstract: The withholding of aid is now at the center of questions about whether President Trump manipulated foreign policy to pressure the Ukrainian government to take action damaging to Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Senior Ukrainian officials said they were blindsided over the summer when they heard the United States would withhold security assistance to the country.

headline: Daniel Jones Runs the Giants to a Win in His First Start
abstract: After losing Saquon Barkley in the second quarter, Jones threw for two touchdowns and carried two in himself for a win over the Buccaneers.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The first prominent high note in the Daniel Jones era of Giants football was a daring 7-yard touchdown scamper in the second quarter of Sunday’s game against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. It was a play that symbolically breathed new life into the Giants, whose sideline was clearly buoyed not just by the score but by its execution.

headline: Emmys 2019: Homer Simpson and Friends Fill the Host Void
abstract: Homer Simpson, Anthony Anderson and Bryan Cranston helped viewers forget the 71st Emmy Awards was lacking a ringleader.
lead_paragraph: Is going host-less the mostest? Producers of Sunday night’s Emmy Awards sure hope so. Of course, it’s not like they had much to lose by shaking things up. Last year’s show drew a mere 10 million viewers, the lowest ever for the ceremony, despite television’s current status as the center of the entertainment universe.

headline: In the Decade Since Madoff, Ponzi Schemers Try New Tactics
abstract: The S.E.C. has prosecuted 50 percent more Ponzi cases in the last 10 years. Those scams cost their victims $31 billion.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than 10 years since Bernard L. Madoff was caught running the biggest Ponzi scheme in history, a case that became a cautionary tale for investors and a call to action for regulators. The Securities and Exchange Commission made changes in its enforcement division to better detect fraud, established specialized teams and even revamped its system for handling tips from the public.

headline: Trump, Unrestrained
abstract: America’s vulnerability is exploited by its president.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has discovered that the pillars of this temple we call the American democracy are weak. He’s growing ever more confident that he has the strength to topple them.

headline: A Motorcade on Mackinac Island? Pence’s Visit Breaks a Long Tradition
abstract: The popular Michigan vacation spot has preserved its quaint atmosphere in part by keeping automobiles out for more than a century — until the vice president came to visit.
lead_paragraph: It’s not hard to see why Mackinac Island, Mich., is called the jewel of the Great Lakes. Vacationers love it for the natural beauty and the quaint atmosphere, preserved from a simpler time.

headline: ‘Succession’ Season 2, Episode 7: London Calling
abstract: The Roys take a family trip abroad. Little surprise, it is no vacation.
lead_paragraph: Logan Roy has an odd vocabulary tic, which pops up whenever he is faced with his company’s latest scandal. “What’s the protein?” he’ll ask. He used those words last week, while skimming through New York magazine’s Brightstar Cruises exposé. He says it again this week, during a flight to London, while he, Kendall, Roman and Rhea Jarrell rip apart a memo Siobhan wrote to clarify her “dinosaur purge” Argestes comments. Again, Logan asks if anyone can find “the protein.” Is anything Shiv wrote worthy of his attention?

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 5, Episode 5 Recap: Boundaries
abstract: Sierra explores the power of breath, Helen the power of no. But where does self-empowerment end and selfishness begin?
lead_paragraph: It’s a big week for Sierra. Played by Emily Browning, this new-agey daughter of Hollywood royalty — and the mother of a son with Helen’s dead partner, Vik — joined the slim ranks of non-core characters who have gotten their own point-of-view segments. In that segment, she lands the title role in a hot director’s adaptation of “Madame Bovary.” (She lands the director, too.) She receives a visit from her movie star mom. And she nearly kills herself and her infant son in a coked-up car crash.

headline: Patricia Arquette Calls for Transgender Rights in Emmys Speech
abstract: Arquette’s sister Alexis, a transgender actress and cabaret performer, died in 2016. She was 47.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘The Voice’ and an S&M Rom-Com
abstract: A new season of “The Voice” premieres on N.B.C. And an unconventional love story is available on Hulu.
lead_paragraph: THE VOICE 8 p.m. on NBC. The singing competition returns for its 17th season with Taylor Swift set to reprise her role as “mega mentor” to the contestants who make it to the show’s Knockout Rounds. She appeared previously on “The Voice” in this capacity in 2014. Swift will dispense her wisdom to those singers who are chosen by Kelly Clarkson, John Legend, Blake Shelton and returning judge and coach Gwen Stefani. In the season premiere, the contestants will endure blind auditions, in which the four judges will begin each performance facing away from the stage, only seeing the person they’re listening to if they choose to serve as their coach. Through this process, each of the judges will accrue a team of contestants they’ll then shepherd through to the next stage of the competition.

headline: FIFA’s Best? It Depends on Whom You Ask. So We Asked.

headline: Thailand Shuttered a Notorious Tiger Zoo, but the Problem Has Only Gotten Worse
abstract: Activists say Thailand’s tiger zoos amount to little more than farms, which produce animal parts for a thriving black market.

headline: Why Can’t We Stop Pancreatic Cancer?
abstract: There is little a person can do to prevent it, and there is nothing comparable to mammography or colonoscopy to screen for it when it is most amenable to cure.
lead_paragraph: Pancreatic cancer, which will be diagnosed in about 56,770 people in the United States this year, is the only cancer with a rising mortality rate through 2014, although five-year survival has begun to inch up, from 8 percent to 9 percent by 2016. It remains the nation’s third leading cause of cancer deaths, after cancers of the lung and colon, and it is on track to overtake colon cancer within a decade. Three-fourths of people who develop pancreatic cancer die within a year of diagnosis, and only about one in 10 live five years or longer.

headline: Exploring a Possible Link Between C-Sections and Autism
abstract: Children born by cesarean section may have important differences that affect their neurodevelopment.
lead_paragraph: Cesarean delivery can save a baby — or a mother — at a moment of medical danger. However, cesarean births have been linked to an increased risk of various long-term health issues for both women and children, and a recent study shows an association between cesarean birth and the risk of developing autism or attention deficit disorder.

headline: ‘Value’ of Care Was a Big Goal. How Did It Work Out?

Naturally, I am insulted by this, but out of pride I don’t let my indignation show. My work is my reply, my travel is my defiance.

headline: At Home With a Creative Director Who Lets Objects Dictate the Space

headline: The Man Devoted to Radical Italian Design
abstract: At the creative director Dennis Freedman’s homes in East Hampton and Manhattan, his eye for objects is on full display.
lead_paragraph: DENNIS FREEDMAN WAS living in a rent-stabilized postwar apartment on Manhattan’s Beekman Place in 1998 when, while browsing an auction catalog, he saw the object that would change his life. Nearly four feet wide, the polyurethane foam Capitello sculpture-cum-lounge chair resembles the top of an Ionic column that has broken off and tumbled to earth. Although versions of the piece continue to be produced by a Barolo, Italy-based company called Gufram — which pioneered Guflac, a pliant yet sturdy varnish — this one was from an early production, designed in 1971 by Studio 65, one of several radical design collectives that formed in Italy during an era of tumultuous student protests. Such groups, including Superstudio and Archizoom Associati — influenced by American Pop Art, the films of the French New Wave and the avant-garde works of the Romanian-French playwright Eugène Ionesco — produced thousands of intricate renderings but were rarely able to translate them into actual objects. As the culture changed, their works, never mainstream, became obscure to all but a tiny subset of the cognoscenti.

headline: Why I Teach
abstract: Being a good teacher is hard. So is maintaining democracy. Our political leaders should take note.
lead_paragraph: My employer, the University of Southern California, requires me to teach a general education course every year. Although I sometimes resent the obligation, most of the time I am grateful for it. I have come to think of my general education classroom as  both a symptom of our flawed democracy and an attempt to exercise that democracy — an effort that requires work that we oftentimes do not want to put in.

headline: America’s Dirty Secret in East Asia
abstract: Japan and South Korea are at odds today because Washington has been playing favorites for decades.
lead_paragraph: For several months, Japan and South Korea, America’s main allies in East Asia, have been going at each other. Japan stripped South Korea of trading privileges; then South Korea removed Japan from a list of favored trade partners. In late August, Seoul announced that it would cancel an agreement with Tokyo over the sharing of sensitive military intelligence, including about North Korea’s nuclear and missile programs. The tiff, some observers argue, marks a low in relations since the two countries normalized ties in 1965 after decades of friction over conflicting interpretations of Japan’s record during its occupation of the Korean Peninsula from 1910 to 1945 — forced labor, territorial claims, sexual slavery. Those debates hardly have been settled, it turns out, and they still inflame nationalist impulses on both sides. History is more than just background music to the present.

headline: Do We Really Understand ‘Fake News’?
abstract: We think we are sharing facts, but we are really expressing emotions in the outrage factory.
lead_paragraph: Given how much it’s talked, tweeted about and worried over, you’d think we’d know a lot about fake news. And in some sense, we do. We know that false stories posing as legitimate journalism have been used to try to sway elections; we know they help spread conspiracy theories; they may even cause false memories. And yet we also know that the term “fake news” has become a trope, so widely used and abused that it no longer serves its original function.

headline: Harry Potter and the Poorly-Read Exorcists

Dan Reehil, a Catholic priest, ordered the removal of all Harry Potter books from the parish school’s library, the St. Edward community demanded an explanation. Father Reehil responded by email, noting that he had “consulted several exorcists, both in the United States and in Rome,” and had been assured that the “curses and spells used in the books are actual curses and spells; which when read by a human being risk conjuring evil spirits into the presence of the person reading the text.”

headline: We Need More Doctors Who Are Scientists
abstract: It’s in everyone’s benefit if physicians participate in research.
lead_paragraph: About a decade from now, public health statistics will begin to show a substantial decrease in cervical cancer in the United States and other developed countries. That’s because in 2006, young people began receiving vaccines against a sexually transmitted virus, HPV, that causes cervical cancer. By preventing HPV infections today, those vaccines have the potential to avert hundreds of thousands of cervical cancer cases.
