headline: Can We Please Talk About How Ukrainians Feel About This?
abstract: Donald Trump’s attempt to warp our judicial process for his own ends is a grievous offense against a country that is desperately fighting corruption.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukrainians have long been accustomed to the use and abuse of their government during our 28 years of independence.

headline: What Jonathan Van Ness’s Story Teaches Us About the H.I.V. Epidemic
abstract: The ‘Queer Eye’ star was fortunate to have a safety net. Too many people don’t.
lead_paragraph: In a recent profile, Jonathan Van Ness of “Queer Eye” courageously shared his story as an “out-and-proud ‘member of the beautiful H.I.V.-positive community’” who has remade his life after experiencing childhood sexual abuse, drug addiction and shame.

headline: Does Donald Trump Want to Be Impeached?
abstract: Four reasons the president might welcome articles of impeachment.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to determining when it makes sense to impeach a president, congressional Democrats are working with 200 words in the Constitution, three significant historical precedents, the fervor of impeachment advocates, the anxieties of swing-state members of Congress and all the polling data that a modern political party can buy.

headline: A Conversation With a Border Patrol Agent
abstract: We spoke with Art Del Cueto, who works in Arizona, about his views on President Trump’s immigration agenda and how his role had changed under the current administration.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: American Jews and American Muslims Have a Common Antagonist
abstract: Homegrown nativists strongly dislike both groups, which ought to help them work toward mutual understanding.
lead_paragraph: President Trump seeks to drive a wedge between American Jews and the Democratic Party. He claims that the Republican Party is more concerned with protecting Jewish people at home and abroad. He also wants to stoke tensions between American Jews and American Muslims. He loves to attack the Democratic Congresswomen Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib, among others, as anti-Semitic because of their positions on United States policy toward the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: DealBook Briefing: There’s No Right to Be Forgotten Globally
abstract: Europe’s highest court ruled that the privacy law can’t extend beyond the E.U. It’s a victory for Google and other global tech companies.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: Tropical Storm Karen’s Rains Begin to Soak Puerto Rico
abstract: Storm clouds were forecast to cover most of the island, which faces possible flash flooding and mudslides one day after an earthquake.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Karen began to drench Puerto Rico on Tuesday with heavy rain that is forecast to continue on Wednesday and could cause flash flooding and mudslides.

headline: ‘Anthropocene: The Human Epoch’ Review: Global Warnings
abstract: This documentary narrated by Alicia Vikander captures alarming ways in which Earth’s natural beauty has been disturbed.
lead_paragraph: “Anthropocene: The Human Epoch” puts a frightening twist on the standard nature documentary. Rather than exalting the awesome beauty of landscapes or animals, it captures alarming ways in which that beauty has been disturbed.

headline: Marine Serre: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Marine Serre: Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Marine Serre: Spring 2020 Collection

headline: E.U. Court Orders Fiat Chrysler to Pay Back $33 Million in Taxes
abstract: The decision to make the automaker repay taxes saved in a deal with Luxembourg offers clues about a similar case against Apple.
lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG — The second-highest court in the European Union ruled on Tuesday that the automaker Fiat Chrysler must pay back about $33 million in taxes that it saved by carving out a deal with Luxembourg, a decision that could have implications in cases involving other global corporations, including a multibillion-dollar suit against Apple.

headline: Bernie Sanders Proposes a Wealth Tax: ‘I Don’t Think That Billionaires Should Exist’
abstract: Mr. Sanders is embracing an idea at the center of Elizabeth Warren’s presidential campaign. His proposal goes further in who would be taxed and how much money would be raised.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Bernie Sanders on Tuesday unveiled a proposal to create a new tax on the wealth of the richest Americans, including a steep tax on billionaires that could greatly diminish their fortunes.

headline: VW Executives and Ex-C.E.O. Are Charged With Market Manipulation
abstract: Volkswagen’s top two leaders were charged by German prosecutors with failing to inform investors of the U.S. investigation into emissions cheating.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen was supposed to turn the corner this year from the shadow of a costly diesel emissions scandal, with a new emphasis on electric vehicles, a new logo and a new commitment to ethical behavior.

headline: A Slain Jewish Girl’s Diary of Life Under the Soviets and the Nazis
abstract: Described as a counterpart to Anne Frank’s diary, a journal written by Renia Spiegel, a Jewish girl who lived in Poland during World War II, is being published in English.
lead_paragraph: PRZEMYSL, Poland — She was a Jewish teenager in a small trade city in southeastern Poland when she began writing her diary, months before the advent of World War II. By the time she was shot in the head by Nazi soldiers, she had chronicled life under two totalitarian regimes: the Soviets who advanced from the east and the Nazis who came from the west.

headline: Forest in a Soccer Stadium Outrages Austria’s Far Right
abstract: An art installation meant to make people think about the environment has become a political target as elections approach.
lead_paragraph: The curator Klaus Littmann expected complaints when he installed 299 trees — some up to 50 feet tall — in a soccer stadium in Austria.

headline: Democrats Want to Tax the Rich. Here’s How Those Plans Would Work (or Not).
abstract: We break down the benefits and risks to the four main ideas that presidential candidates have embraced.
lead_paragraph: We break down the benefits and risks to the four main ideas that presidential candidates have embraced.

headline: Weekly News Quiz For Students: Climate Protests, Whistle-Blower, Emmy Awards
abstract: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
lead_paragraph: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?

headline: How Impeachment Shifted
abstract: Why this story is different.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
lead_paragraph: $1.01 MILLION

headline: On ‘The Good Place,’ Chidi Redefines the Black Nerd
abstract: William Jackson Harper has made Chidi Anagonye resonate with viewers. In doing so, he makes anxious black nerds like me more visible, and broadens TV’s notions about black masculinity.
lead_paragraph: William Jackson Harper is nervous. He and I have been on the phone for five minutes, and he’s walking around his living room as we speak, analyzing everything he’s saying and hoping he hasn’t said anything stupid. I can relate.

headline: Talking to Jerry Brown About Tackling Climate Change, With Help From China
abstract: Tuesday: An interview with the former governor about his new initiative at U.C. Berkeley. Also: Chanel Miller speaks out, and more Emmys coverage.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: U.K. Supreme Court Declared Boris Johnson’s Actions Unlawful. What Happens Next?
abstract: The ruling puts Parliament back in session almost three weeks earlier than expected, and has consequences for Brexit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British Supreme Court on Tuesday demolished Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s case for sending lawmakers home during the run-up to the Oct. 31 Brexit deadline, setting the stage for Parliament to return almost three weeks earlier than expected.

headline: Overtime Pay Eligibility Is Widened in New Federal Rule
abstract: The Labor Department set the income threshold at $35,500, the first increase since 2004 but a weaker standard than the Obama administration proposed.
lead_paragraph: The Labor Department announced Tuesday that it had finalized a rule expanding overtime pay eligibility to up to 1.3 million workers.

headline: Big3 Star Andre Emmett Is Shot and Killed in Dallas
abstract: Emmett, a 6-foot-5 guard, was Texas Tech’s career leading scorer under Coach Bob Knight.
lead_paragraph: Andre Emmett, a college basketball star at Texas Tech who rejuvenated his professional career in the Big3 league, was shot and killed in Dallas on Monday at 37.

headline: Lady Hale, U.K. Supreme Court Judge, Speaks Calmly and Brings Down the Hammer
abstract: The judge has carved out a long, trailblazing career as an academic, legal reformer and feminist — and she loves striking brooches.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the full weight of Britain’s Supreme Court came down on Tuesday against the suspension of Parliament, it was dropped like a hammer on Prime Minister Boris Johnson by the first woman to serve as the court’s president: Lady Hale.

headline: Coffee May Lower Risk of Gallstones
abstract: Every additional cup a day of coffee, up to six cups, resulted in a 3 percent lower risk for gallstones. B
lead_paragraph: Drinking coffee has been tied to a range of health benefits. Here’s another to add to the list: It may reduce the risk for gallstones.

headline: Trump Makes Clear He’s Ready for a Fight He Has Long Anticipated
abstract: Impeachment, he insists, will be “a positive for me.”
lead_paragraph: He knew it was coming. It almost felt inevitable. No other president in American history has been seriously threatened with impeachment even before his inauguration. So when the announcement came on Tuesday that the House would consider charging him with high crimes and misdemeanors, President Trump made clear he was ready for a fight.

headline: Trump Defends Call With Ukrainian President: It Was ‘Perfect’
abstract: Before his appearance at the United Nations, President Trump denied that his conversation with the President of Ukraine was improper. Leading Democrats in Congress are demanding that the Trump administration hand over documentation of the talks.
lead_paragraph: Before his appearance at the United Nations, President Trump denied that his conversation with the President of Ukraine was improper. Leading Democrats in Congress are demanding that the Trump administration hand over documentation of the talks.

headline: Nine Albums Later, Tegan and Sara Are Finally Ready to Discuss High School
abstract: In a new memoir and an album of songs they wrote as teenagers, the feminist pop stars look back at their traumas, triumphs and life as identical twins.
lead_paragraph: To be a twin can be a psychological house of mirrors. And so where better to meet up with Tegan and Sara Quin — feminist pop heroes, freshly minted authors, and, like us, identical twins — than at a kaleidoscopic infinity room in Chelsea? As we left the small mirrored room at the kitschy Museum of Illusions, where our likenesses warped and refracted, we encountered a third set of twins. Reality grew ever more psychedelic, and we snapped a photograph of the six of us to commemorate it.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Announces Formal Impeachment Inquiry of Trump
abstract: Faced with new allegations against President Trump and administration stonewalling, Democrats have ended months of caution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced on Tuesday that the House would initiate a formal impeachment inquiry against President Trump, charging him with betraying his oath of office and the nation’s security by seeking to enlist a foreign power to tarnish a rival for his own political gain.

headline: We Need a PBS for Social Media
abstract: Instead of breaking up Facebook, America should create a public alternative.
lead_paragraph: Social media is an opportunity wrapped in a problem. YouTube spreads propaganda and is toxic to children. Twitter spreads propaganda and is toxic to racial relations. Facebook spreads propaganda and is toxic to democracy itself.

headline: The Rohingya’s Right of No Return
abstract: Why the refugees still aren’t going back to Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Late last month, some 200,000 Rohingya living in refugee camps in southeastern Bangladesh gathered to mark the anniversary of the brutal crackdown by the Myanmar military that drove more than 700,000 people to flee western Myanmar in August 2017. Citing security concerns, the Bangladeshi government promptly banned phone companies from providing mobile services to the refugees living in the camps of Cox’s Bazar — one million or so. The authorities have become increasingly worried about an uptick in crime in and around the camps, an increase in drug smuggling from Myanmar and the potential influence of foreign jihadists among the Rohingya. Their patience is eroding.

headline: It Takes a Teenager to Help a Teenager in Crisis
abstract: Many troubled adolescents find it easier to share their angst and dread on a hotline with people their age, rather than their parents.
lead_paragraph: After losing his best friend to suicide, Taylor Harrison, then 18, was looking for ways to honor the memory of his friend, deal with his own grief, and help others going through a hard time. He decided to volunteer at Lines for Life, a nonprofit crisis-line organization in Portland, Oregon.

headline: Dior: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Dior: Spring 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Dior: Spring 2020 Collection.

headline: Sleep Apnea Tied to Mood Disorders
abstract: People with obstructive sleep apnea were more likely to be diagnosed with depression or anxiety than those without the condition.
lead_paragraph: Sleep apnea may increase the risk for mood disorders, researchers have found.

headline: If Liberalism Is in Crisis, Who’s to Blame?
abstract: New books by James Traub and Robert Kuttner advance theories about where liberalism went wrong and how to get it back on track.
lead_paragraph: WHAT WAS LIBERALISM?

headline: Earthquake Strikes Pakistan, Killing at Least 22
abstract: A 5.6 magnitude earthquake rocked several cities in Pakistan and some parts of the Kashmir region under its control.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — A 5.6 magnitude earthquake rocked several cities in northern Pakistan and parts of the Kashmir region under its control, leaving at least 22 people dead and more than 700 wounded, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Trump and Johnson, Together on World Stage, Eye Troubles Back Home
abstract: President Trump and Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, leaders who share an affinity and style of politics, are attending the United Nations General Assembly with domestic troubles at home.
lead_paragraph: If nothing else, they have each other.

headline: How the U.K. Supreme Court’s Rebuke to Boris Johnson Remakes British Law
abstract: In ruling a suspension of Parliament “unlawful,” some scholars argue that the court brought an American style of judicial review to Britain, with all that entails.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s all-consuming debate over Brexit has dragged another of its respected institutions into uncharted territory, as the Supreme Court struck down Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s suspension of Parliament, an extraordinary intervention by the judiciary into a political dispute.

headline: A Civilized Retreat, if You Know Where to Look
abstract: A new restaurant called Frevo offers refined, French-influenced cooking and a seclusion that starts with a speakeasy-style entrance.
lead_paragraph: A new restaurant called Frevo offers refined, French-influenced cooking and a seclusion that starts with a speakeasy-style entrance.

headline: Behind a Hidden Door, a Sleek Lair for Escaping New York
abstract: An unmarked gallery in Greenwich Village is the entryway to Frevo, and its suave tasting menus with a modern-French sensibility.
lead_paragraph: Last month I had dinner with a friend who lives a thousand miles away and doesn’t get to Manhattan as often as he once did. When I asked where he wanted to eat, he answered, a bit wistfully, “Somewhere that speaks of New York, a city I have lost touch with.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What I Learned in a Year of Weeknight Cooking
abstract: Keep it simple, keep it fast, and try to do something a little different.
lead_paragraph: In August, my husband and I rented a cottage in the woods near a beach for a week, a place where our toddler could barrel around and where we would cook most of our meals. The road up to the house was full of magic, as was the house itself, which dated to the 1700s. We roamed through it like the tourists we were, awed by the charm in its bones.

headline: Tulsi Gabbard Qualifies for Next Debate, Bringing Lineup to 12
abstract: Ms. Gabbard earned 2 percent support in a new poll in New Hampshire, enough to secure a spot on the stage in Ohio next month.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii became the 12th Democratic presidential candidate to qualify for the October debate after a poll released on Tuesday showed her with 2 percent support in New Hampshire.

headline: Trump Celebrates Nationalism in U.N. Speech and Plays Down Iran Crisis
abstract: Before an audience primed for him to focus on recent attacks on Saudi oil facilities, Mr. Trump said relatively little about the strikes that rattled global energy markets.
lead_paragraph: President Trump delivered a sharp nationalist message and assailed “globalists” in remarks to the world’s leading international body on Tuesday, while stopping short of urging any specific action against Iran for a major attack on Saudi oil facilities that his administration has said was Tehran’s responsibility.

headline: Dean & DeLuca Closes Its Midtown Store
abstract: As the company falters, only its flagship shop in SoHo remains open in New York.
lead_paragraph: After months of rumors, sinking morale and shrinking inventory, the Dean & DeLuca store in Midtown has closed.

headline: Alice Hoffman Brings Magical Realism to the Holocaust Novel
abstract: In “The World That We Knew,” two Jewish girls try to escape Nazi Germany, guided and guarded by a female golem.
lead_paragraph: THE WORLD THAT WE KNEW By Alice Hoffman

headline: As an Ohio City Struggles, Some See Salvation in a Prairie
abstract: A plan to develop a parcel near Dayton International Airport is pitting conservationists against city leaders.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — The 140-acre Paul E. Knoop Jr. Prairie in Dayton has become something of an inkblot test.

headline: For Joe Biden, Trump Impeachment Inquiry Brings a Long-Expected Test
abstract: As the House of Representatives begins an inquiry, Mr. Biden has been drawn into a wildly unpredictable situation that may affect his standing in the 2020 race.
lead_paragraph: In public, for the last five days, Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his campaign have been on a ferocious offensive, ripping into President Trump for allegedly abusing his powers in asking Ukraine’s leader to help hurt Mr. Biden politically, and castigating the news media for questioning his son Hunter Biden’s financial dealings there. On Tuesday, Mr. Biden made his biggest move yet, saying Congress should start an impeachment inquiry against Mr. Trump if he does not cooperate with their investigations.

headline: WeWork C.E.O. Adam Neumann Steps Down Under Pressure
abstract: The shake-up is the most significant step that the start-up, valued at nearly $50 billion at one point, has taken to win over Wall Street after a botched I.P.O.
lead_paragraph: Adam Neumann turned WeWork into one of the most valuable start-ups in the world largely through the force of his outsize personality. He persuaded investors to give him billions of dollars and employees to believe that the shared-office company was changing the world.

headline: ‘I’ve Been Dishonored’: French Chef Sues Michelin Guide Over Lost Star
abstract: Marc Veyrat is disputing the downgrade of La Maison des Bois, his restaurant in the French Alps, which lost the guide’s maximum three-star rating.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A celebrity chef has declared that he is suing France’s most revered culinary arbiter, the Michelin Guide, after its reviewers stripped his restaurant of its third star.

headline: At Gibney, a New Curatorial Director Makes a Revolution
abstract: Eva Yaa Asantewaa takes what she’s learned from a career in writing and puts it on the dance stage.
lead_paragraph: Eva Yaa Asantewaa may be a self-described introvert, but she’s far from unassuming. She’s persistent. And she knows when to say yes.

headline: More Flags, More Problems for the N.F.L.’s Offensive Linemen
abstract: Much to Tom Brady and other offensive players’ chagrin, game officials are calling offensive holding more often, thanks to a push from coaches.
lead_paragraph: Late last season, New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady was frustrated by the three offensive holding penalties his line took in a loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers. “Obviously there’s holding on every play in the N.F.L.,” he said, fuming. So far this season, it appears N.F.L. officials agree.

headline: When the Antiques Have to Go
abstract: With spare interiors and light colors all the rage right now, selling a home filled with period pieces can be a challenge.
lead_paragraph: The owners of the 2,000-square-foot loft in Chelsea loved antiques, and had furnished the apartment accordingly. There was a china cabinet topped with carved scrollwork and a grandfather clock standing sentry near the door. Persian rugs padded the floor.

headline: Korean Barbecue in an Elegant Space, at Hyun
abstract: A place for table-grilling Wagyu beef, a Tuscan-food choice in Midtown and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: On the edge of Koreatown, the entrepreneur Jae Kim is responding to his nostalgia for Korean food as he knew it in South Korea, with this elegant restaurant emphasizing barbecue. It’s small (seating only 40), sleek and minimalist, in neutral tones and black, with electric-grill tables for searing Wagyu on cast iron. To direct the restaurant and oversee the kitchen and its beverage lineup, Mr. Kim has enlisted Euikyu Bang, a native of Seoul who has worked in New York for the past eight years, notably at the barbecue restaurant New Wonjo. The many cuts of Wagyu on offer are sold by the ounce. There are starters like homemade soft tofu, chawanmushi and raw Wagyu with Asian pear; other dishes include pickled herbs, rice in a pot with sea urchin, and bibimbap. The luxury goes beyond the ingredients, with hand-forged brass tableware and traditional lacquer.

headline: Why It Matters That ‘Emily Doe’ in the Brock Turner Case Is Asian-American
abstract: In her memoir, Chanel Miller offers a new understanding of her treatment by the legal system.
lead_paragraph: When Emily Doe’s victim impact statement was published on BuzzFeed in June 2016, I read it in one breathless sitting. The previous day, she had read her statement at the sentencing hearing for Brock Turner, who was found guilty of three counts of felony sexual assault by a California jury. The maximum sentence for such a conviction was 14 years, but the judge, Aaron Persky, sentenced Mr. Turner to six months in county jail. He served three. Emily Doe’s statement went viral, read aloud on the floor of the House of Representatives and on CNN, and fueled public outrage over Mr. Turner’s lenient sentence. Later that year California imposed mandatory minimum sentences for sexual assault crimes and in 2018, voters recalled Judge Persky.

headline: Trump Says He Will Release Transcript of Call With Ukraine’s President
abstract: The president said the call was “totally appropriate” as he sought to tamp down a tidal wave of scrutiny over his dealings with Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Trump said on Tuesday that he would release the transcript of his July phone call with the Ukrainian president in an effort to quell the controversy over whether he pressed for Kiev to investigate a political rival.

headline: Journalism Under Siege
abstract: A reader stresses the importance of a free press, in response to an Op-Ed by A.G. Sulzberger, the publisher of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Greta Thunberg, After Pointed U.N. Speech, Faces Attacks From the Right
abstract: The young climate activist was widely celebrated after her speech at the United Nations. But critics have said she is being used, and a conservative commentator compared her likeness to Nazi imagery.
lead_paragraph: Greta Thunberg, the teenage climate activist from Sweden who delivered a much-watched speech at the United Nations on Monday, has been celebrated for her activism on climate change, including galvanizing the worldwide, youth-led protests of the last week. But she has also become a lightning rod, drawing attacks by television and social media commentators.

headline: Fiat Chrysler Manager Faces U.S. Fraud Charges on Diesel Emissions
abstract: An indictment followed the company’s costly settlement of lawsuits over rigging pollution test results.
lead_paragraph: A senior manager at Fiat Chrysler Automobiles has been charged with conspiring to rig diesel-emissions tests on the automaker’s vehicles, according to a grand jury indictment unsealed on Tuesday. The charges come months after the company agreed to a costly legal settlement of lawsuits over the deception.

headline: College Admissions Scandal: Parent Gets 4 Months in Brazen Scheme
abstract: Devin Sloane, who is accused of paying $250,000 to get his son into college, was the second parent sentenced in the sweeping case, after the actress Felicity Huffman.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The ruse was flagrant: The father ordered water polo gear online and had his son pose in it for a photograph in the family’s swimming pool. He then hired a graphic designer to enhance the photo, another piece in a scheme to pass his son off as a water polo player and secure admission to the University of Southern California — for the price of $250,000, some of it paid as a bribe to a U.S.C. official.

headline: Robert Hunter, Grateful Dead Lyricist, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Hunter wrote some of the band’s signature songs, including “Uncle John’s Band,” “Scarlet Begonias” and “Dark Star.”
lead_paragraph: Robert Hunter, the primary lyricist on many of the Grateful Dead’s most memorable songs, including “Uncle John’s Band,” “Scarlet Begonias,” “Dark Star” and “Truckin’,” died on Monday night at his home in San Rafael, Calif. He was 78.

headline: Weeknight Dinner Around the World
abstract: We asked 18 families to show us what they have for dinner on a typical weeknight.
lead_paragraph: Wasa Khuhaprema, center, prepares dinner for her family, including her parents, with help from her two young sons; the boys cook at least one night a week. This night, they ate an omelet with carrots, stir-fried minced pork and eggplant, and southern Thai sour curry with cauliflower. Family members are expected to clean up after themselves.

headline: Demanding Action on Climate Change
abstract: Readers discuss the U.N. summit and climate rallies and offer a response to Al Gore’s Sunday Review essay.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: A Splendid ‘Porgy and Bess’ Opens the Met Opera Season
abstract: As the title characters, Eric Owens and Angel Blue give one of the finest performances of their careers.
lead_paragraph: “Bess, you is my woman now,” the disabled beggar and unlikely hero of Gershwin’s “Porgy and Bess” sings when he realizes that, somehow, Bess — desirable, though troubled — may actually love him. She has been a lost soul, a glamorous, hard-drinking woman with a drug addiction who has allowed herself to be claimed by bullying men. Being with Porgy seems to offer a way out, a chance not just for decency, but also emotional stability.

headline: Trump’s Perfidy: A Laundry List
abstract: A reader calls the list succinct and “breathtaking.” Also: The U.N. meeting on universal health coverage; funding for the Hudson River tunnel.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How the Impeachment Process Works
abstract: The inquiry into President Trump has the potential to reshape his presidency. Here’s how impeachment works.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Looking for a Woman of Incredibly Poor Judgment’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I was in need of comfort as a child, my father would ask me, “¿Qué pasó, mi vida?” which means, “What happened, my life?” Like an incantation, these four words made me feel instantly less alone: What is happening to you is happening to me because you are my life. “¿Qué pasó, mi vida?” I now ask my partner when he wakes up with a headache. When he says he’s feeling flat. What is happening to him is happening to me because he, like my family, is my life. — Alexandra Clemente

headline: A Beating Heart, Even After Death
abstract: LVADs are changing human life. Are we ready?
lead_paragraph: Shows like HBO’s “Westworld” and the “Blade Runner” films depict a dystopian future where humankind and machine have merged, blurring the line between people and robots. As a cardiologist, I find myself face to face with both the promise and the peril of such a marriage — a reality for me and my patients rather than a distant hypothetical.

headline: Bolivia Is Burning. Who Will Stop Its Fires?
abstract: President Evo Morales must issue a national disaster declaration to control the fires and avoid further loss of life.
lead_paragraph: Fires have been ravaging the Bolivian lowlands for over a month. Nearly ten million acres have already burned, an area larger than Connecticut and New Jersey combined. Almost half the destruction lies in protected areas known for high biodiversity. It is a tragedy.

headline: A School Put an Autistic Boy’s Desk in a Bathroom, Setting Off a Debate on Stigmas
abstract: The 11-year-old student was given a desk over a toilet as a quiet place to do schoolwork. The school’s superintendent said the “idea was well-intentioned.”
lead_paragraph: Eleven-year-old Lucas Goodwin arrived at his middle school in Washington State last week only to find that his seat was in a new place: a bathroom.

headline: Whoopi Goldberg’s Secret to Setting the Table
abstract: The TV personality and author reflects on her childhood meals — and the object she relies on when hosting.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, Emily Spivack, the author of “Worn Stories,” interviews creative types about their most prized possessions. When Whoopi Goldberg entertains, she sets an elaborate table. Here, Goldberg, whose book “The Unqualified Hostess” is out this week, explains a unique part of her table setting.

headline: A Ring for a King in NBA 2K Simulation
abstract: In this week’s newsletter, Marc Stein tries to answer the season’s most pressing questions the only way possible now: with a video game.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: The Loophole That Turns Your Apps Into Spies
abstract: Just by downloading an app, you’re potentially exposing sensitive data to dozens of technology companies, ad networks, data brokers and aggregators.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a limited-run newsletter. You can sign up here.

headline: My American Surrogate
abstract: A Chinese businesswoman in California has become a matchmaker between Chinese parents and American wombs.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese businesswoman in California has become a matchmaker between Chinese parents and American wombs.

headline: My American Surrogate
abstract: A Chinese businesswoman in California has become a matchmaker between Chinese parents and American surrogates.
lead_paragraph: The first time I met Qiqi, in 2015, we bargained over the price of my eggs (their value shot up when I told her I had attended Stanford).

headline: New in Paperback: Rebecca Traister’s ‘Good and Mad’ and Tina Turner’s ‘My Love Story’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: GOOD AND MAD: The Revolutionary Power of Women’s Anger, by Rebecca Traister. (Simon & Schuster, $17.) Traister spotlights the role of anger in female political activism, contending that women’s organized, patriotic fury about being denied basic rights often gets underplayed in public discussions. Our reviewer, Elaine Blair, called the book “rousing,” praising its analysis of the women-led movements that have been transforming politics since the 2016 election.

headline: We Want to See Your Child’s Stuffed Animals
abstract: Extra-loved lovies, in all their glory.
lead_paragraph: Your children’s stuffed animals are disgusting. We stand by that message, delivered loud and clear by NYT Parenting’s lead editor Jessica Grose. And, they are extremely important. So in addition to publishing a no nonsense explainer on how to clean stuffed toys, we now want to put them in the spotlight.

headline: Italy to Lend Leonardo da Vinci Works to France in a Masterpiece Swap
abstract: The pieces will appear in an exhibition at the Louvre marking the 500th anniversary of the Renaissance master’s death, and Italy will borrow works by Raphael.
lead_paragraph: Leonardo da Vinci’s famous drawing of a spread-eagled male figure, known as the “Vitruvian Man,” will soon travel to Paris to star in a blockbuster Leonardo exhibition at the Louvre Museum. It will make the trip as part of an exchange agreement signed Tuesday by the culture ministers of France and Italy, after many months of sometimes bitter negotiations.

headline: The Story Behind the Times Correspondent Who Faced Arrest in Cairo
abstract: Times journalists have long relied on the U.S. government to intervene when danger arises abroad. That may no longer be the case.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Massachusetts Orders 4-Month Ban on Sale of All Vaping Products
abstract: The state’s action is the toughest to date, as vaping-related illnesses and teenage use of e-cigarettes climb. Facing declining sales and public backlash, Juul, the dominant e-cigarette maker, is considering layoffs.
lead_paragraph: Massachusetts on Tuesday went further than any other state in trying to keep e-cigarettes out of consumers’ hands, with its governor declaring a public health emergency and ordering a four-month prohibition on the sale of all vaping products.

headline: President Trump, Boris Johnson, WeWork: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Democrats move to impeach Trump.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced on Tuesday that the House will begin a formal impeachment inquiry of President Trump over startling allegations that he sought to enlist a foreign power for his own political gain.

headline: Big Spider Love: The Brooch That Ate Brexit
abstract: A British judge wore a large arachnid pin to rule against Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s suspension of Parliament. Social media went crazy.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, while announcing the British Supreme Court’s unanimous ruling that Prime Minister Boris Johnson had illegally suspended Parliament, Lady Brenda Hale — the court’s first female president — wore a brooding fantastical diamanté spider brooch.

headline: The Winners and Losers of the Latest Trump Scandal
abstract: A snapshot of the Ukrainian fallout.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Paul Krugman’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Beware of Impeaching Trump. It Could Hurt the Presidency.
abstract: We must avoid doing long-term harm to the president’s ability to conduct foreign policy and protect our nation.
lead_paragraph: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi authorized the opening of an impeachment inquiry over accusations that President Trump abused his foreign-relations powers to target political rivals. Realizing the gravity of the affair, the president had announced that the White House would release an unclassified and unredacted transcript of a phone call at the center of the whistle-blower complaint.

headline: Dr. Robert McClelland, Who Tried to Save President Kennedy, Dies at 89
abstract: He assisted in an emergency tracheotomy in Dallas and saw close up the gravity of the president’s head wound.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Robert McClelland, a surgeon who tried to help revive a mortally wounded President John F. Kennedy in 1963 after he was shot in Dallas, died on Sept. 10 in an assisted living facility in that city. He was 89.

headline: Cats Like People! (Some People, Anyway)
abstract: Despite apparent aloofness, cats are social creatures capable of relationships with people, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: In the perennial battle over dogs and cats, there’s a clear public relations winner.

headline: Junk Food at Monticello? Alice Waters Helps Lead a Revolution
abstract: Spurred by the pioneering chef, the cafe at Jefferson’s estate has reconnected with his agrarian ideals.
lead_paragraph: Alice Waters made her first pilgrimage to Monticello in 2011. Long an admirer of Thomas Jefferson, she marveled at the gardens full of heirloom varietals, like Tennis Ball lettuce and Marseilles fig, and paid homage to the man who praised small farmers as “the most valuable citizens,” Americans who are “tied to their country and wedded to its liberty and interests by the most lasting bands.”

headline: We Want to Hear Your Tiny Victories
abstract: Celebrate those small moments of triumph in the long days of parenting.
lead_paragraph: Each week in the NYT Parenting newsletter, we share a reader-submitted Tiny Victory. Tiny Victories are meant to celebrate those small moments of triumph in the long days of parenting. We want to hear about the ingenious way you headed off a toddler meltdown on a long car ride, or how you persuaded your youngster to take a bite of something foreign instead of just tossing it on the floor. (We don’t want to hear about your li’l Einstein reading Kant in kindergarten — save that for Grandma.)

headline: ‘No One Is Above the Law’: Pelosi Announces Trump Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the House would begin formal impeachment proceedings against President Trump, ending months of caution by Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the House would begin formal impeachment proceedings against President Trump, ending months of caution by Democrats.

headline: How to Find Yourself Someplace Else
abstract: It’s time to get out of your routine and have yourself a self-finding adventure. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to get out of your routine and have yourself a self-finding adventure. Here’s how.

headline: Pelosi Announces Impeachment Inquiry of Trump
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the House would begin a formal impeachment inquiry of President Trump, ending months of caution by Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the House would begin a formal impeachment inquiry of President Trump, ending months of caution by Democrats.

headline: Plácido Domingo Leaves Met Opera Amid Sexual Harassment Inquiry
abstract: The star singer, accused by multiple women of sexual misconduct, dropped out of Verdi’s “Macbeth” and indicated he would not return to the Met.
lead_paragraph: In an 11th-hour reversal, the superstar singer Plácido Domingo withdrew on Tuesday from the Metropolitan Opera’s production of Verdi’s “Macbeth” and indicated he would not return to the Met, amid rising tensions over the company’s response to allegations that he had sexually harassed multiple women.

headline: A Former Agent Investigates the F.B.I. and Finds It Lacking
abstract: Mark German was on the inside for 16 years. The title of his book — “Disrupt, Discredit, and Divide” — tells us what he thinks of the place now.
lead_paragraph: DISRUPT, DISCREDIT, AND DIVIDEHow the New FBI Damages DemocracyBy Mike German

headline: Families of Aurora Shooting Victims Express Concern About ‘Joker’
abstract: The hyper-realistic movie portrays the Batman villain as a mentally ill loner looking for societal revenge. Warner Bros. said the film was not an endorsement of real-world violence.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Warner Bros. became part of the gun safety debate again on Tuesday when relatives and friends of those killed during the 2012 movie theater shooting in Aurora, Colo., sent a letter to the studio expressing disquiet over its coming R-rated film “Joker.”

headline: FIFA Set to Take On Agents With Proposed Changes to Transfer Market
abstract: Limits on agents’ commissions and a cap on loans could reshape the international market for players.
lead_paragraph: A key committee at FIFA is expected to approve a series of proposals on Wednesday that would seek to reform the multibillion-dollar player transfer market by limiting the influence of the sport’s biggest agents and also prevent clubs like Chelsea, Juventus and Manchester City from stockpiling talent.

headline: This Upper West Side Psychic Parlor Specializes in Reincarnation (Its Own)
abstract: Three women operating out of the same fortunetelling shop were arrested and forced to repay their victims up to $60,000 apiece. But the parlor has proved resilient.

headline: New & Noteworthy Audiobooks, From Paul McCartney to ‘Puss in Boots’
abstract: A selection of recent audiobooks of note; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
lead_paragraph: EYES TO THE WIND: A Memoir of Love and Death, Hope and Resistance, by Ady Barkan, read by Bradley Whitford. (Simon & Schuster Audio.) Three years ago, at the age of 32, Barkan was diagnosed with A.L.S. and told he had just three to four years to live. The new father has dedicated the short time he has left to fighting for social justice.

headline: Sigmund Jähn, First German in Space and a Hero Back Home, Dies at 82
abstract: He spent almost eight days aboard a space station in 1978 and was hailed by East Germans as a symbol of socialist achievement.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Sigmund Jähn, whose distinction as the first German to travel into space made him a Cold War symbol of socialist unity at a time when East and West Germany competed for national achievements, died on Saturday in Strausberg, Germany, outside Berlin. He was 82.

headline: Saint Laurent: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Saint Laurent: Spring 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Saint Laurent: Spring 2020 Collection.

headline: When Should a President Be Impeached?
abstract: Only two presidents have ever been put on trial. Democrats may make Trump the third.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: Milwaukee Bucks Fined $50,000 for Tampering (With Their Own Player)
abstract: With tampering dominating the off-season discourse, the N.B.A. announced it was fining the Bucks for publicly discussing a future extension with Giannis Antetokounmpo.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. is cracking down on tampering. Just not the kind of tampering most fans would expect.

headline: Army Soldier Charged in Traffic Accident Death of West Point Cadet
abstract: The Army trainer at the wheel of a truck that overturned and killed a West Point cadet on the way to an exercise near the academy has been charged.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The soldier at the wheel of a truck that overturned in June,  killing a West Point cadet and injuring 21 others on the way to a training exercise, has been charged with involuntary manslaughter, negligent homicide, reckless driving and dereliction of duty, the Army said on Tuesday.

headline: Trump’s Misleading Defense for Withholding Assistance to Ukraine
abstract: The president, facing calls for impeachment over his pressuring Ukraine to investigate his political rival, inaccurately accused European countries of not providing aid to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Trump was responding to reports that he had directed his staff to freeze military aid to Ukraine before he pressed the country’s president to investigate unsubstantiated corruption allegations involving former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Impeachment, United Nations, Weeknight Cooking: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Three Suicides in One Navy Ship’s Crew Point to a Growing Problem
abstract: Across the military, and especially in the Navy, rates of suicide have been rising sharply in recent years, despite extensive prevention efforts.
lead_paragraph: A cluster of three suicides in less than a week among one ship’s crew has shocked the United States Navy, raising questions about why the suicide rate in the service has climbed sharply in recent years, despite sustained efforts at prevention.

headline: The Best of Paris Fashion Week, in Pictures
abstract: All the highlights from the spring 2020 shows.
lead_paragraph: The spring 2020 shows have come to a close in Paris. Here, our favorite images of the week and notes on the collections — and don’t forget to check out our recaps from New York, London and Milan.

headline: Nancy Pelosi’s Statement on Impeachment: ‘The President Must Be Held Accountable’
abstract: Ms. Pelosi addressed the nation to lay out the rationale for an impeachment inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Here is a transcript of Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s remarks on Tuesday announcing the impeachment inquiry against President Trump.

headline: Trump’s Calls With World Leaders Are Freewheeling, but Few Have Access
abstract: The protocols surrounding the president’s conversations with foreign leaders have changed since Mr. Trump took office, prompted largely by a fear of leaks, according to those familiar with the process.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sometimes President Trump is in the Oval Office when he talks on the phone with a president or prime minister. Occasionally he is flying aboard Air Force One. Often he is in the White House residence, picking up the phone from the Treaty Room, or from his private suite, to connect with a world leader.

headline: Alfred Haynes, Pilot Who Saved Scores in Crash Landing, Dies at 87
abstract: In 1989, he defied the odds in bringing his crippled United Flight 232 in for a crash landing; more than 180 people survived.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Haynes, a pilot who led a United Airlines crew through an extraordinary display of improvised emergency flying that guided a crippled jet to a crash landing in Sioux City, Iowa, in 1989, saving more than 180 of the 296 people on board, died on Aug. 25 in Tacoma, Wash. He was 87.

headline: Judge Throws Out Conviction of Michael Flynn’s Business Partner
abstract: A jury had convicted Bijan Kian, a former business partner of the former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn, of violating foreign lobbying laws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Tuesday threw out the conviction of a business associate of the former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn, saying prosecutors had failed to offer enough evidence to sustain their charges that he had secretly lobbied on behalf of Turkey.

headline: What Killed Thomas Cook, One of the Oldest Names in Travel?
abstract: The company that once served Britain’s elite has met an undignified end that would have “appalled” the man who started it, his biographer says.
lead_paragraph: The demise of Thomas Cook, Britain’s most venerated travel agency, is shaping up as one of the country’s greatest corporate fiascos.

headline: Follow Us to the Ends of the Earth
abstract: What is it about human beings that makes us want to see the unseen? We sent photographers across the world to find out.
lead_paragraph: What is it about human beings that makes us want to see the unseen? We sent photographers across the world to find out.

headline: The Sublime Desolation of Namibia's Skeleton Coast
abstract: Strewn with shipwrecks and bleached bones, the landscape is a reminder of how impermanent civilization is.
lead_paragraph: Strewn with shipwrecks and bleached bones, the landscape is a reminder of how impermanent civilization is.

headline: What Does the Future Look Like? Singapore
abstract: From its immersive airport art to its hyperengineered skyline, the urban state offers a sci-fi vision for the present day.
lead_paragraph: From its immersive airport art to its hyperengineered skyline, the urban state offers a sci-fi vision for the present day.

headline: Exploring the Ancient Mysteries of Borneo's Caverns
abstract: Far beneath the rainforest floor, in a pair of remote national parks, lie some of the world’s oldest signs of human activity.
lead_paragraph: Far beneath the rainforest floor, in a pair of remote national parks, lie some of the world’s oldest signs of human activity.

headline: A Guided Tour Through the Ruins of America's Democracy
abstract: A ragged industrial field 150 miles south of Washington has become a crumbling shrine to presidential history.
lead_paragraph: A ragged industrial field 150 miles south of Washington has become a crumbling shrine to presidential history.

headline: Seeking Flying Giants in Norway’s Fjords
abstract: Enormous and indefatigable, sea eagles turn their daily hunt into a thrilling display of aerial dominance.
lead_paragraph: Enormous and indefatigable, sea eagles turn their daily hunt into a thrilling display of aerial dominance.

headline: White House Seeks Deal for Whistle-Blower to Speak to Congress
abstract: As House Democrats moved to begin a formal impeachment inquiry, the administration also prepared to release a redacted version of the whistle-blower’s complaint.
lead_paragraph: White House and intelligence officials were working out a plan on Tuesday to release a redacted version of the whistle-blower complaint that helped ignite the impeachment drive against President Trump and to allow the whistle-blower to speak with congressional investigators, people briefed on the matter said.

headline: On His Deathbed, a Black Ex-Soldier Makes a Plea to Clear His Name
abstract: In 1955, a soldier was dishonorably discharged after a shooting in an Army club. Now he is seeking a military burial.
lead_paragraph: The young Army paratrooper had barely set foot in the club for noncommissioned officers at Fort Bragg, N.C., when he was confronted by a sergeant.

headline: New York Police Sergeant Who Led Weinstein Inquiry Is Investigated
abstract: Internal affairs officers are examining allegations of misconduct involving several police officials, including one who supervised a special victims investigation of the movie producer.
lead_paragraph: Internal affairs officers from the New York Police Department are examining allegations of serious misconduct involving several high-ranking officials in its Special Victims Division, including a sergeant who oversaw the troubled investigation of Harvey Weinstein, according to the police and four people with knowledge of the investigation.

headline: Why an Impeachment Inquiry Now? Democrats Cite the Clarity of the Case
abstract: After months of internal division over whether to begin a formal effort to oust President Trump, Democrats say his actions gave them no choice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, dozens of House Democrats anxiously avoided even the mention of impeaching President Trump — right up until the moment that they demanded it.

headline: It’s the Environment, Stupid
abstract: There is a winning campaign theme that progressives can use against Trump, and it isn’t “Medicare for all.”
lead_paragraph: I don’t know who sold progressive Democrats on the idea that the way to beat Donald Trump is to abolish the private health insurance of 160 million Americans and offer instead “Medicare for all” (and Mexico will pay for it), but it’s a political loser and an easy target for Trump to feast on. A much better campaign theme is hiding in plain sight. I call it “the Earth Race.”

headline: Mets Season a Failure? Not if You Ask Pete Alonso
abstract: The team’s young slugger is pursuing the rookie home run record and relishing every minute of this season with the Mets, who rallied late on Tuesday to stave off elimination from the playoff race.
lead_paragraph: The Mets staved off elimination from postseason contention with a stirring comeback victory on Tuesday. But even after they beat the Miami Marlins, 5-4, in 11 innings, their chances of making the playoffs remained a near impossibility because the Milwaukee Brewers and Washington Nationals each won on Tuesday.

headline: Boris Johnson’s Ultimate Deceit
abstract: Britain’s Supreme Court ruled that he misled the queen to illegally suspend Parliament.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the ironies of the rise of authoritarian movements in Western democracies that politicians who claim to be strengthening the foundations of democracy work so assiduously to undermine those foundations. So it was especially satisfying on Tuesday when Britain’s Supreme Court soundly and unanimously slapped down Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s brazen attempt at an end-run around Parliament to pull Britain out of the European Union.

headline: Group Behind California Privacy Law Aims to Strengthen It
abstract: The leaders of Californians for Consumer Privacy say they want to amend the law, which goes into effect next year, through a ballot initiative.
lead_paragraph: Privacy advocates got a big win last year, pushing through a landmark law in California. Now, before the law even goes into effect, they are moving to make the statute tougher.

headline: The Brewers’ M.V.P. Falls, but the Team Keeps Soaring
abstract: After Christian Yelich, the 2018 National League M.V.P., went down with a knee injury, the Brewers continued playing like contenders.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — When Christian Yelich crumpled to the dirt in Miami on Sept. 10, his kneecap shattered and his season over, Milwaukee Brewers Manager Craig Counsell used Trent Grisham to complete the at-bat. Grisham finished the strikeout, which went on Yelich’s record and froze his season average at .329.

headline: Congress Steps Up, Trump Blinks
abstract: It’s a start, maybe.
lead_paragraph: It turns out President Trump can push his fellow Republicans too far. Senate Republicans stuck up for themselves, and their institution, on Tuesday by joining unanimously with their Democratic colleagues to call on the president to stop stonewalling. They asked him to release to the relevant congressional committees the complaint from a whistle-blower that an inspector general had said raised an “urgent concern” about the president’s behavior.

headline: Vox Media Acquires New York Magazine, Chronicler of the Highbrow and Lowbrow
abstract: After more than 50 years and 44 National Magazine Awards, New York finds a home with a digital-media powerhouse.
lead_paragraph: After more than 50 years of chronicling the highbrow, lowbrow, brilliant and despicable characters of the city whose name it took, New York Magazine has a new owner.

headline: Democratic Moves Toward Impeaching Trump
abstract: Readers discuss how impeachment might play out, Boris Johnson’s comeuppance, Hunter Biden and more.
lead_paragraph: This was originally published on Tuesday night and has been updated with new letters.

headline: Why I Changed My Mind About Impeachment
abstract: Trump was always unfit, but that’s not enough.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Review: In ‘The Height of the Storm,’ Two Stars and an Enigma
abstract: Florian Zeller’s tiresome new play features Jonathan Pryce and Eileen Atkins as a long-married couple, one of whom may be dead.
lead_paragraph: So far, three of the French playwright Florian Zeller’s plays have made it to New York: “The Father,” “The Mother” and now “The Height of the Storm,” which for symmetry might have been called “The Father or the Mother.”

headline: Review: Paging Pablo Escobar in ‘Our Dear Dead Drug Lord’
abstract: Alexis Scheer’s vibrant play about four teenage girls, a Ouija board and a narco-terrorist summons the truly scary spirits that keep us awake at night.
lead_paragraph: Though we’ve just crossed the threshold into fall, you may already be thinking of Halloween, that time of year when we get to frighten ourselves with fantasies instead of being terrorized by the all-too-real world. It is also the moment when we can at least pretend to believe, for better or worse, that the dead do not stay dead.

headline: Subject of a 2016 U.K. Referendum
abstract: The J.A.S.A. crossword class in New York City has found some interesting wordplay in the news.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Administrivial alert! My apologies, but I forgot to change a thingy  in the backstage what’s-it and now the links in the apps and under the puzzle are broken. If I change it now, however, it will erase all of your lovely commentary, so I’m going to leave it as is.

headline: How Jussie Smollett Was Written Off the Last Season of ‘Empire’
abstract: Mr. Smollett still faces legal troubles over his claim that he was the victim of a racist and homophobic assault.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for Season 6, Episode 1 of “Empire.”

headline: The Truth About Olivier Rousteing
abstract: In a surprising new documentary, the Balmain designer leaves the Instagram filters behind and goes searching for his origins.
lead_paragraph: Lately it is starting to seem a truth universally acknowledged that any fashion brand in possession of a good story must be in want of a documentary.

headline: U.S. Intelligence Officer Who Tried to Share Secrets With China Is Sentenced to 10 Years
abstract: He was expected to receive a harsher sentence. But a federal judge said he had cooperated with investigators.
lead_paragraph: A former United States intelligence officer who tried to pass secret military information to the Chinese government was sentenced Tuesday to 10 years in prison — a term that was five years less than expected because he provided information that could help prevent foreign agents from targeting other Americans, the authorities said.

headline: Corrections: September 25, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, September 25, 2019.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day: Wednesday, September 25, 2019
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 25, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “No one is above the law.”

headline: Federal Prosecutors Ask Judge to Delay Subpoena of Trump Tax Returns
abstract: Prosecutors said they were considering whether to insert themselves in a lawsuit that argues the president cannot be criminally investigated.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan told a judge Tuesday night that they are considering inserting themselves into a lawsuit filed last week by President Trump that argued he cannot be criminally investigated while in office.

headline: South Korean Clinic Performed Abortion on Wrong Woman, Police Say
abstract: The police said they planned to ask prosecutors to indict the clinic’s doctor and a nurse on charges of inflicting accidental injury.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — An expectant mother who visited a medical clinic in Seoul, South Korea, last month to receive a nutritional shot woke up hours later to learn she had mistakenly been given an abortion, the police said on Wednesday.

headline: Hazzaa al-Mansoori, First U.A.E. Astronaut, Launches to Space Station
abstract: The Persian Gulf country has an ambitious, budding space program.
lead_paragraph: The United Arab Emirates has sent its first astronaut to space. That is a step in a budding, ambitious space program for an oil-rich country the size of Maine along the southern side of the Persian Gulf. Next year, it plans to send a robotic spacecraft to Mars, and its leaders talk of colonizing the red planet a century from now.

headline: Politics Has No Place at the Supreme Court, Chief Justice Roberts Says
abstract: In a frequently lighthearted conversation, the chief justice also discussed classic rock and whether he could best Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in the gym.
lead_paragraph: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. on Tuesday forcefully rejected criticism that the Supreme Court’s work had been warped by partisanship.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Stumptown’ and ‘Abstract’
abstract: A new crime drama debuts on ABC. And “Abstract: The Art of Design” returns for a second season on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: STUMPTOWN 10 p.m. on ABC. A pair of hairy kidnappers discuss the origins of the beans in a cup of coffee (“It’s tart, but it has an earthy finish — I’m going with Ethiopian”) in the first episode of this new crime drama, which is set in Portland, Ore. Based on a comic book series by Greg Rucka and Matthew Southworth, the series stars Cobie Smulders (“How I Met Your Mother,” the “Avengers” movies) as Dex Parios, a private investigator with a military background and an uneasy mind. “Assuming Dex has weekly cases, they’ll need to tighten up; the pilot’s kidnapped-girl plot is expository filler,” Mike Hale wrote in a review for The New York Times. “There’s a potentially appealing mix of wisecracking humor and underplayed, credible action, though, that could blossom if it’s given precedence over the melodramatic back story.”

headline: Who Gets Arrested for Having an Abortion?
abstract: Laws that criminalize “immoral” behavior in Morocco and elsewhere aren’t about ethics. They’re tools for state control.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 31, six plainclothes policemen arrested a woman named Hajar Raissouni outside the office of her obstetrician-gynecologist in Morocco’s capital, Rabat. She was detained along with her fiancé, her doctor, his anesthesiologist and his secretary. Her doctor was compelled to hand over her medical records while Ms. Raissouni was forced to undergo a medical examination and to answer questions about her sex life.

headline: Word + Quiz: churl
abstract: This word has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: A Blood-Red Sky: Fires Leave a Million Indonesians Gasping
abstract: Wildfires burning across Indonesia have created respiratory problems for nearly a million people.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Nearly 2,000 wildfires are burning across Indonesia, turning the sky blood red over central Sumatra and creating dense clouds of smoke that have caused respiratory problems for nearly a million people.

headline: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s Next Big Effort: Tackling Poverty
abstract: After the Green New Deal and Medicare for all, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is turning her attention — and that of her supporters — to poverty and housing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a House freshman and political neophyte, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York has proved to be remarkably adept at shaping the debate on her Democratic Party’s left flank, boosting the visibility of single-payer health care through her support of “Medicare for all” and elevating climate change with her Green New Deal.

headline: Lordstown Plant Is Idle, but It Hovers Over G.M. Strike Talks
abstract: The automaker has reportedly offered to create a battery factory in the same Ohio area. But the work would pay far less than the shuttered plant.
lead_paragraph: In its negotiations with the striking United Auto Workers union, General Motors has put a seemingly tantalizing offer on the table: It has proposed building a new plant in Ohio to produce batteries for some of the one million electric cars it hopes to sell globally by 2026.

headline: He Didn’t Abuse His Daughter. The State Took Her Anyway.
abstract: What does it mean to be a parent? One man hopes his case will change how a decades-old New York law treats unwed fathers.

headline: Did Cuomo Rig a Commission to Sabotage His Political Foes?
abstract: The governor says he created the panel to deal with money in politics, and suggestions otherwise are delusional.

headline: Who Is Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukraine President in the Trump Impeachment Crisis?
abstract: Mr. Zelensky acted in a comedy before becoming Ukraine’s president, and has been thrust into the center of the American debate.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As a television actor in Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky played an idealistic schoolteacher whose tirade against corruption is filmed by his students, winds up online and suddenly goes viral, propelling him to the presidency.

headline: Stephen Colbert Sees Trump Impeachment Inquiry as a Thing to Celebrate
abstract: “Hello, Ukraine? You up for interfering with our election?” Colbert joked of the allegation that the president sought to enlist a foreign leader to dig up dirt on a rival.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Boris Johnson Says U.K. Supreme Court ‘Was Wrong’
abstract: A day after the Supreme Court reversed Boris Johnson’s suspension of Parliament, his critics clashed angrily with the government over Brexit and other issues.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson defended his attempt to suspend Parliament in the critical weeks ahead of Britain’s deadline to leave the European Union, accusing lawmakers of “sabotaging” Brexit talks and saying the Supreme Court was wrong to rule his actions unlawful.

headline: Window in the Drapes
abstract: The most hidden corners of our bodies are exposed and manipulated by surgeons, then put back together again, all in the course of a morning or afternoon.
lead_paragraph: “Our patient has surgery today, would you like to observe?” my doctoring mentor asked.

headline: The Motorcycle Whisperer
abstract: Hugh Mackie represents a dying breed in the five boroughs: bikers.
lead_paragraph: To love motorcycles is to love some measure of suffering. Hugh Mackie knows this. He has had the smashed collarbone, cracked ribs, cracked shoulder blade and broken thumb to prove it.

headline: Travel
abstract: What story could this picture tell?
lead_paragraph: What story does this image inspire for you?

headline: Trump Attracts Central American Support for Hard-Line Migration Policies
abstract: The Salvadoran president, Nayib Bukele, has courted the White House. And on Wednesday, Honduras signed an agreement to help thwart asylum seekers from entering the United States.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — When President Trump sat down with President Nayib Bukele of El Salvador in New York City on Wednesday, the American leader may have seen some of himself reflected in his Central American counterpart.

headline: South Carolina Deputy in Video of Violent Arrest Is Fired
abstract: Surveillance footage at an auto repair shop showed Greenville County sheriff’s deputies hitting a 56-year-old man who was later charged with traffic violations and resisting arrest.
lead_paragraph: Mechanics at an auto repair shop in Greenville, S.C., were toiling on a busy summer afternoon last month when they heard a commotion outside. According to Nick Simmons, the shop manager, someone was shouting, “Stop resisting!” while another voice asked, “What did I do?”

headline: Time to Trot Out the Fishnets and Put on a Show
abstract: A museum exhibition offers an empathetic look at the intimate lives of sex workers in the L.G.B.T. community.
lead_paragraph: A pair of tartan-patterned pole dance pumps, a tiny pleated schoolgirl skirt and a leather merry widow — they emerged one by one from a nondescript cardboard carton, the raffish trappings of the sex trade.

headline: Plastic Surgery and the Secret World of Instagram Dolls
abstract: An Instagram community of “doll pages” lets women find valuable information about body-sculpting journeys.
lead_paragraph: They call themselves dolls. These are cosmetic surgery patients who document their desires and results on Instagram, but only, most say, for other patients or prospective clients. They use names and hashtags that connect the work to their provider. So, for example, KathySmithDoll would be a woman who underwent surgery with a Dr. Kathy Smith.

headline: How an Ice Bath May Undermine Your Weight Workout
abstract: Cold water immersion is popular with some athletes, but it may slow the growth of new muscle.
lead_paragraph: Bathtubs filled with frigid water and occasionally dotted with ice cubes are a common sight in professional athletes’ training rooms and at some gyms. Many recreational athletes also slip into cold baths at home after intense workouts.

headline: Have You Ever Read a Book You Weren’t Supposed to Read?
abstract: What have adults tried to stop you from reading? Did you listen to them? Or did you read the book anyway?
lead_paragraph: It’s Banned Books Week in the United States, which, according to the American Library Association, is an annual event that celebrates “the freedom to read” and “spotlights current and historical attempts to censor books in libraries and schools.”

headline: China Wants the World to Stay Silent on Muslim Camps. It’s Succeeding.
abstract: Beijing is using economic and diplomatic pressure to quash any outcry, while governments are reluctant to risk financial ties and trade deals.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When Turkey’s leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, visited Beijing this summer, he hailed a new Silk Road bridging Asia and Europe. He welcomed big Chinese investments for his beleaguered economy. He gushed about China’s sovereignty.

headline: Highway 61 Revisited, With Jessica Lange
abstract: With a new book of her photographs and a gallery show to follow, the two-time Oscar winner talks about her passion for being behind the camera.
lead_paragraph: DULUTH, Minn. — When Jessica Lange finally admitted that her driving was a bit unpredictable it came as a relief. I was afraid to bring it up from the passenger seat.

headline: How to Make the Most of Apple’s New Privacy Tools in iOS 13
abstract: We tested the new suite of privacy tools in Apple’s latest mobile software, from minimizing location sharing to silencing robocalls.
lead_paragraph: To get the latest security protections against viruses, exploits and whatever other nasty stuff is out there, it’s wise to keep the software for our devices updated.

headline: Major Cruise Line to Abandon Plastic Water Bottles
abstract: Norwegian Cruise Line, the world’s third-biggest cruise company, aims to switch its fleet to paper-based water cartons by 2020.
lead_paragraph: When the Norwegian Encore, the newest ship from Norwegian Cruise Line, launches in November, it will carry no plastic water bottles to offer guests.

headline: What We Know and Don’t About the Trump-Ukraine Affair
abstract: The major question is whether President Trump used American foreign policy to try to damage a political rival.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced a formal impeachment inquiry on Tuesday amid mounting furor over President Trump’s efforts to pressure Ukraine’s government to investigate former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., apparently the subject of a classified whistle-blower complaint the administration refused for weeks to show to Congress before dropping objections.

headline: I Voted to Impeach Nixon. I’d Do the Same for Trump.
abstract: The Ukraine scandal has a lot of similarities to Watergate.
lead_paragraph: For those of us who were there during Watergate, the Ukraine scandal is beginning to sound like an echo chamber.

headline: In the Swiss Alps, Walking a Cliff’s Edge to History
abstract: Hiking along bisses, ancient irrigation channels in the mountains above the Rhone River Valley, is a journey back in time.
lead_paragraph: Just outside the train station in the Swiss town of Sion, a yellow signpost points hikers in two main directions with no fewer than 16 routes to choose from. As you cross the medieval downtown, keeping the Valère Basilica and the Tourbillon Castle on the right, aim for the Valaisanne Brewery. If you can resist the brewery’s new tap room and its outdoor tables, be sure to duck as you scramble up a staircase and through the tunnel of holly and its busy bees and onto the Bisse de Clavau and 500 years of history.

headline: Behind WeWork Leader’s Rise and Fall: A Wall St. Bank Playing Many Angles
abstract: JPMorgan Chase, an ardent backer of the start-up and Adam Neumann, was as well placed as any investor to see his conflicts of interest.
lead_paragraph: The ouster of WeWork’s co-founder and its botched initial public offering are a remarkable collapse of what was considered, up until weeks ago, one of the most valuable start-ups in the world.

headline: U.S. Will Remain in Postal Treaty After Emergency Talks
abstract: The United States can start setting its own rates in July, a move that will help companies compete with China’s lower fees.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United States agreed on Wednesday to stay in a United Nations body that has regulated international mail service for more than a century after delegates agreed during emergency talks to change the way postal fees are structured.

headline: ‘I Vow to Tread Lightly’
abstract: Tourism “pledges” to promote respect for local customs and natural resources have proliferated in recent years. But whether these largely voluntary vows have changed behaviors is hard to track.
lead_paragraph: When Lynn Englum of New York City visited the Republic of Palau in February as part of a travel project exploring places imperiled by climate change, she received an elaborate stamp in her passport. The full-page stamp featured a 59-word promise, addressed to the “Children of Palau,” to “tread lightly, act kindly and explore mindfully.” She was required to sign the stamp, known as the Palau Pledge and adopted in December 2017, as a condition of entry designed to promote respect for the country’s natural resources.

headline: The Honest Beauty of Wild Grasses
abstract: They once covered great swaths of the United States. Now, humble grasses are returning as focal points in free-spirited bouquets.
lead_paragraph: SAY THE WORD “grass” and you picture not a lone blade but a mass undulation. It is for all practical purposes uncountable, a tease of the infinite. More than 10,000 species compose Poaceae, the family of grass, and together they cover around 40 percent of the earth’s lands (outside of Greenland and Antarctica). Traders and settlers venturing into the American interior in the 18th century took the French word for meadow — prairie, from the Latin pratum — to name the vast expanse that met them, bare of trees, holding up nothing but sky. Even a modern suburban lawn, mowed into submission and confined to an angular patch, is a grasp at space, an attempt to reconjure the great wide open.

headline: Living In ... Guilford, Conn.
abstract: The small town on the Long Island Sound has historic homes and rolling farmland, forgoing the sprawl and density of some of its neighbors.
lead_paragraph: The small town on the Long Island Sound has historic homes and rolling farmland, forgoing the sprawl and density of some of its neighbors.

headline: The World’s Oceans Are in Danger, Major Climate Change Report Warns
abstract: Climate change is severely straining the world’s oceans, creating profound risks for coastal cities and food supplies, a U.N. report finds.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Climate change is heating the oceans and altering their chemistry so dramatically that it is threatening seafood supplies, fueling cyclones and floods and posing profound risks to the hundreds of millions of people living along the coasts, according to a sweeping United Nations report issued Wednesday.

headline: Guilford, Conn.: Proud of Its Place in New England
abstract: The town on the Long Island Sound has historic homes and rolling farmland, forgoing the sprawl and density of some of its neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Both woodsy and watery, Guilford, Conn., can seem to squeeze a lot of New England into 47 square miles.

lead_paragraph: The environmental impact of our clothing choices extends far beyond our closets and buying fewer items that are more durable can lower the impact on the planet. Here’s what to look for when shopping for clothes.

abstract: Wednesday: Residences in Manhattan within 1,000 feet of two or more shelters would sell for an estimated 17 percent less, a study found.

headline: In a First for Australia, the Capital Legalizes Recreational Marijuana
abstract: The move echoed efforts in the United States, where some states have legalized recreational use of marijuana even as it has remained illegal under federal law.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s capital on Wednesday became the first jurisdiction in the country to legalize the recreational possession and cultivation of marijuana, a move that runs counter to federal laws that can carry prison terms for personal use of the drug.

headline: Breaking Through to Brandon
abstract: To reach a discouraged student, a learning disabilities specialist enters his world and learns a lesson of her own.
lead_paragraph: “I’m sick of writing! They assign one dumb essay after another. Can’t we do a puzzle for a change?”

headline: An Impeachment Inquiry Begins
abstract: The opening of formal proceedings sets up a history-making showdown between the Democratic-led House and President Trump — and carries heavy risks for both.
