headline: ‘The Daily’ Transcript: Interview With Representative Mikie Sherrill
abstract: After months of caution, dozens of House Democrats have announced their support for an impeachment inquiry of President Trump. Representative Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey, a moderate first-term Democrat, is one of them. Moments before Speaker Nancy Pelosi declared the formal initiation of the inquiry into Mr. Trump’s actions, Ms. Sherrill spoke with Michael Barbaro, the host of the podcast “The Daily,” about why she’d changed her mind on impeachment.
lead_paragraph: After months of caution, dozens of House Democrats have announced their support for an impeachment inquiry of President Trump. Representative Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey, a moderate first-term Democrat, is one of them. Moments before Speaker Nancy Pelosi declared the formal initiation of the inquiry into Mr. Trump’s actions, Ms. Sherrill spoke with Michael Barbaro, the host of the podcast “The Daily,” about why she’d changed her mind on impeachment.

headline: Red and Blue Voters Live in Different Economies
abstract: And they are headed in different directions — with serious consequences for the president and his political opponents.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the 2016 presidential election, scholars, journalists and ordinary citizens battled over whether economic anxiety or racial and cultural animus were crucial to the outcome.

headline: Every Part of the Supply Chain Can Be Attacked
abstract: When it comes to 5G technology, we have to build a trustworthy system out of untrustworthy parts.
lead_paragraph: The United States government’s continuing disagreement with the Chinese company Huawei underscores a much larger problem with computer technologies in general: We have no choice but to trust them completely, and it’s impossible to verify that they’re trustworthy. Solving this problem — which is increasingly a national security issue — will require us to both make major policy changes and invent new technologies.

lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Lanvin: Spring 2020 Collection

headline: MacArthur ‘Genius’ Grant Winners for 2019: The Full List
abstract: The MacArthur fellowships are awarded annually for exceptional “originality, insight and potential.” Below are this year’s fellows.
lead_paragraph: The MacArthur fellowships, awarded annually by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation for “extraordinary originality and dedication,” come with a no-strings-attached award of $625,000, distributed over five years. Here is a complete list of the 2019 fellows.

headline: MacArthur Foundation Announces 26 ‘Genius’ Grant Winners
abstract: This year’s fellows include artists, writers, scientists, urban designers, community activists and others who have demonstrated “extraordinary originality.”
lead_paragraph: This has been an emotionally intense year for the poet and fiction writer Ocean Vuong.

headline: Highlights: Whistle-Blower Complaint Goes to House as Ukraine Phone Call Gets Released
abstract: A whistle-blower’s private expressions of concern about President Trump’s actions kicked off an extraordinary series of revelations that have prompted Democrats in Congress to officially begin an impeachment inquiry.
lead_paragraph: The acting director of national intelligence, under pressure from Congress to release the full complaint of a whistle-blower who touched off the Ukraine impeachment furor, handed over the document to the House Intelligence Committee.

headline: Juul Replaces Its C.E.O. With a Tobacco Executive
abstract: The surprise announcement was the latest sign of crisis at a company under scrutiny over its vaping products that have been highly popular among teenagers.
lead_paragraph: The vaping powerhouse Juul Labs replaced its chief executive  with a veteran of Big Tobacco on Wednesday, deepening the company’s turmoil and raising doubts about the very future of the e-cigarette industry.

headline: Marina Abramovic Comes Home, and Comes Clean
abstract: The artist received a lavish welcome when she returned to Belgrade, Serbia, the city of her birth, for her first exhibition there in nearly 50 years.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE, Serbia — It was looking doubtful whether Marina Abramovic would manage to eat lunch. She had barely taken her seat in the restaurant before being interrupted by an emotional admirer who dashed over for a selfie. Moments after presenting the main dish, the waiter came back seeking an autograph. Then a message arrived that a fan had delivered 44 bottles of brandy to her assistant’s apartment — one for each year since Ms. Abramovic last staged an exhibition in Belgrade, the city of her birth.

headline: Indonesia’s Leader Faces Student Protests and Crises Heading Into New Term
abstract: President Joko Widodo’s decision to limit the power of Indonesia’s anticorruption commission has helped set off protests before his second term begins.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s president, Joko Widodo, preparing for his second term, faces a sudden loss of public support amid mounting crises, including student protests, burning forests and deadly violence in distant Papua province.

headline: They’re Excited for California’s Primary. Except They Won’t Be Able to Vote.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a rainy morning here, the day after Greta Thunberg issued her end-of-days clarion call at the United Nations, another young woman made an environmental statement of her own that was impossible to ignore.

headline: What You Get for $3 Million
abstract: A modernist showplace in Taghkanic, N.Y.; a 1937 French chateau-style house in Denver; and a duplex condominium in an 1888 Victorian in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: A modernist showplace in Taghkanic, N.Y.; a 1937 French chateau-style house in Denver; and a duplex condominium in an 1888 Victorian in San Francisco.

headline: $3 Million Homes in New York, Colorado and California
abstract: A modernist showplace in Taghkanic, a 1937 French chateau-style house in Denver and a duplex condominium in an 1880 Victorian in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: The architect Toshiko Mori designed this 2005 house for a site in the Hudson Valley, where glaciers carved out hillsides and tossed around giant boulders. The wood-sided building sits between two rocky promontories and comprises a one-story pavilion with a wraparound terrace cantilevering over the side of a cliff and a parallel two-story wing.

headline: Sustainable Serenity in the Mountains of Chile

lead_paragraph: This modern three-bedroom house in western Chile is on the market for $1.04 million.

headline: House Hunting in … Chile

lead_paragraph: This modern three-bedroom house sits on a secluded 17-acre plot near the entrance of La Campana-Peñuelas Biosphere Reserve, a Unesco-recognized site near the Pacific coast of Chile.

headline: Countdown Begins in Israel on Efforts to Forge a Power-Sharing Deal

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Update: On Wednesday, President Rivlin nominated Prime Minister Netanyahu to try to form Israel’s next government.

headline: Former Head of Danske Bank in Estonia Is Found Dead in Suicide
abstract: The death of Aivar Rehe, whose bank served as a hub for dirty money, is another twist in a scandal that expanded on Wednesday to include Deutsche Bank.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Aivar Rehe was once one of Estonia’s most prominent bankers, the chief executive of Danske Bank’s unit in Tallinn and an integral part of the former Soviet state’s transition to a free-market economy.

headline: French #MeToo Movement’s Founder Loses Defamation Case
abstract: Sandra Muller started #BalanceTonPorc, or #ExposeYourPig, when she accused a former TV executive of making crude comments to her. He admitted the comments but denied harassment.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A court in Paris found on Wednesday that the journalist who had started France’s equivalent of the #MeToo campaign against sexual harassment defamed a former television executive she had accused of making salacious and humiliating advances to her.

headline: Ukraine’s President Says Call With Trump Was ‘Normal’
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, unwillingly entangled in an impeachment inquiry in the United States, said, “I don’t want to be involved in the democratic elections of U.S.A.”
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s president, in his first public comments on the phone call that led to an impeachment inquiry into President Trump, said Wednesday that the call was “normal,” that “nobody pushed me,” and that he did not want to become entangled in American elections.

headline: Florence Knoll Bassett’s Collection to Be Auctioned
abstract: Phillips is offering a peek into how the designer decorated her homes in New York, and then Florida: 50 artworks are being offered at sales this fall.
lead_paragraph: Before there was “Mad Men” and Don Draper, there was Florence Knoll, as she was known, arguably the designer most responsible for the square-jawed corporate look that conquered American offices after World War II.

headline: Mary-Louise Parker and Adam Rapp Conjure a Haunting
abstract: The star and the playwright of “The Sound Inside” talk about confidence and fame, monsters and witches, and their dogs.

headline: ‘Do Us a Favor’: Call Shows Trump’s Interest in Using U.S. Power for His Gain
abstract: The president pressed Ukraine’s leader on potential investigations that could benefit him politically.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It did not take long for President Trump to see an opening during his July 25 call with Volodymyr Zelensky, the young new president of Ukraine.

headline: Full Document: Trump’s Call With the Ukrainian President
abstract: Trump is accused of pressing Ukraine to investigate his political rivals.
lead_paragraph: Trump is accused of pressing Ukraine to investigate his political rivals.

headline: You Need To Make This Right Now
abstract: Whether it’s crab Rangoon burgers or a Sri Lankan dal, you’ve come to the right place for dinner.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I was in Omaha over the weekend, talking food and culture with the good folks of Lauritzen Gardens and driving around town with Sarah Baker Hansen, the food critic for the Omaha World-Herald. We drank tall lattes from Archetype and ate ridiculously good focaccia at Farine and Four, then woofed down fried chicken for elevenses at Time Out Foods in advance of lunch at Block 16, downtown. Later there were slabs of Flintstone’s-style beef from Omaha Steaks.

headline: White House Bars Iranian Officials From U.S. as Its Diplomatic Efforts Falter
abstract: The move was extraordinary given that dozens of Iranian diplomats were in New York for the U.N. General Assembly, though it was not expected to force them to leave.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The Trump administration barred senior Iranian government officials from entering the United States on Wednesday, just hours after a failed attempt to renew diplomacy with President Hassan Rouhani as he attended an annual gathering of world leaders in New York.

headline: As ‘SVU’ Makes History, Mariska Hargitay Makes Olivia Benson’s Mission Her Own
abstract: This week “Law & Order: SVU” becomes the longest-running drama in prime-time history. But in some ways, the culture is just catching up to the series and its crusading star.
lead_paragraph: When Mariska Hargitay isn’t grilling perps in gloomy interrogation rooms, she spends most of her time in a real-life Pinterest board.

headline: Vogue Dancers Subvert a Baroque Spectacle at the Paris Opera
abstract: Rameau’s “Les Indes Galantes” was designed to show the triumph of Enlightenment order over the exotic “other.” Can hip-hop dance make it feel less toxic?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The choreographer Bintou Dembélé was at the Paris Opera one recent afternoon, rehearsing a new production of Rameau’s rarely performed Baroque spectacle “Les Indes Galantes.”

headline: Gum Disease May Raise Hypertension Risk
abstract: People with gum disease tended to have higher blood pressure, increasing their risk of heart disease and stroke.
lead_paragraph: People with gum disease may be at increased risk for high blood pressure.

headline: Britain Now Has a Politicized Supreme Court, Too
abstract: Tuesday’s decision, which rebuked Prime Minister Boris Johnson, was reminiscent of Bush v. Gore.
lead_paragraph: British citizens were jolted Tuesday morning by a landmark decision of their Supreme Court. The court’s 11 justices ruled unanimously that the government, led by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, had illegally suspended — or “prorogued” — Parliament earlier this month at the height of the debate over Brexit.

headline: Our Family Members Are Being Held Hostage in Iran. Help Us.
abstract: Tehran has ramped up hostage-taking as a key element of its foreign policy and is wrongly imprisoning our kin who are American and British citizens.
lead_paragraph: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran is in New York to attend the United Nations General Assembly. Before his departure from Iran, he complained about the “unjust and oppressive actions” that have been carried out against Iran and described his visit to the General Assembly as “an opportunity to state and explain the views of nations, especially the great nation of Iran.”

headline: How Mandatory Minimums Enable Police Misconduct
abstract: They drastically limit accountability for those with the power to take away a person’s liberty.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Jacob, a young man I represented, made an exceedingly rare choice. He rejected a favorable plea offer because he wanted to hold the police accountable in a hearing to challenge his illegal stop, search and arrest.

headline: Pelosi Tells Trump: ‘You Have Come Into My Wheelhouse’
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi was once the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee. She is drawing on that experience as she opens an impeachment inquiry into President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi and President Trump were discussing gun violence over the telephone Tuesday morning when the president abruptly changed the topic to an intelligence community whistle-blower complaint that had Democrats talking about impeachment.

headline: Giant Glacier on Mont Blanc Is in Danger of Collapse, Experts Warn
abstract: The Italian authorities have closed two roads and evacuated mountain huts after researchers found a gaping crack in an ice mass on the Mont Blanc massif.
lead_paragraph: A giant section of a glacier on the Mont Blanc massif in the Alps is in danger of collapsing, experts warned on Wednesday, prompting the precautionary closing of two roads and the evacuation of mountain huts in northwestern Italy.

headline: The Trump-Zelensky Phone Call: Key Takeaways From Two New Documents
abstract: A reconstructed transcript showed President Trump pressing Ukraine to investigate the Bidens, and a Justice Department memo added new details about a whistle-blower’s concerns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Wednesday released a reconstructed transcript of President Trump’s 30-minute conversation with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on July 25 that was at least in part the focus of a disputed whistle-blower complaint.

headline: 2020 Democrats Say Trump’s Ukraine Call Is a ‘Smoking Gun’ for Impeachment
abstract: Across the Democratic field, candidates are approaching the impeachment battle as a necessary process, but perhaps not one that ought to redefine their own campaigns.
lead_paragraph: KEENE, N.H. — Senator Elizabeth Warren’s message on impeachment was blunt and brief. On a college campus here, Ms. Warren reminded a crowd of hundreds that she had called for President Trump’s impeachment last spring, after the release of Robert S. Mueller III’s report on Russian interference in the 2016 election. Taking action against Mr. Trump, she said then, was “a matter of constitutional responsibility.”

headline: The Impeachment Process Is Complicated. Ask Our Reporters Your Questions.
abstract: The Times’s Washington reporters are available to answer readers’ questions about the impeachment inquiry.
lead_paragraph: When Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced Tuesday that the House would launch a formal impeachment inquiry against President Trump and whether he enlisted a foreign power to help his political aims, she initiated a constitutional showdown without a certain outcome that will likely consume Washington for months to come.

headline: Biden’s Strategy for Managing the Ukraine Story
abstract: Wary of the way Republicans and President Trump attacked Hillary Clinton in 2016, the Biden camp is looking for ways to control the story line.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a reporter asked former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Saturday if he had spoken to his son Hunter about his work in Ukraine, Mr. Biden jabbed his finger repeatedly at the reporter and shot back: “Ask the right questions.”

headline: Given the State of the World, Is It Irresponsible to Have Kids?
abstract: “Walking through life with curiosity and a sense of investment and joy in no way requires having a child,” writes one of our new advice columnists.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the second edition of Culture Therapist, T’s new advice column in which either Ligaya Mishan or Megan O’Grady solves your problems using art. Have a question? Need some comfort? Email us at advice@nytimes.com.

headline: What a Trump Impeachment Battle Means for Financial Markets
abstract: Political drama seldom alters economic fundamentals. But it can influence presidential behavior, which in turn can affect economic policy.
lead_paragraph: From the date burglars broke into the Democratic National Committee headquarters in the Watergate complex in 1972 until the resignation of President Richard Nixon two years later, the S&P 500 fell 25 percent.

headline: ‘Seems You’d Remember Something Like That’: When Harris Questioned Barr About Investigations

lead_paragraph: In May, Senator Kamala Harris asked Attorney General William P. Barr whether President Trump or any member of his administration had ever suggested that he “open an investigation of anyone.”

headline: Trump Announces a Trade Pact With Japan

lead_paragraph: The United States and Japan signed a limited trade deal on Wednesday that will open Japanese markets to American farm goods and secure a win for an administration that has struggled to complete trade pacts with China, Canada, Mexico and other countries.

headline: Why a Trump Impeachment Should Terrify You
abstract: What’s just and what’s wise aren’t always the same.
lead_paragraph: This article is adapted from Frank Bruni’s free weekly newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every Wednesday.

headline: Employer Health Insurance Is Increasingly Unaffordable, Study Finds
abstract: A relentless rise in premiums and deductibles is putting insurance out of reach for many workers, especially those with low incomes.
lead_paragraph: Jessie McCormick had to quit her job to afford health care.

headline: Prehistoric Parents Used Baby Bottles Made of Pottery
abstract: With the advent of agriculture, parents began feeding animal milk to children, a change in how babies were weaned.
lead_paragraph: As long as 7,000 years ago, Stone Age farmers in Central Europe were making and using small pottery bottles or cups with spouts. Ancient baby bottles?

headline: Ian McEwan’s Political Satire ‘The Cockroach’ Offers a Reversal of Kafka
abstract: McEwan’s slim new novel is about a cockroach that wakes up in the body of a man who happens to be the prime minister of the United Kingdom.
lead_paragraph: “If you intend to have a long career in show business,” Elvis Costello wrote in “Unfaithful Music & Disappearing Ink,” his terrific memoir, “it is necessary to drive people away from time to time, so they can remember why they miss you.”

headline: ‘Judy’ Review: The Singer (Disaster, Legend) at Rainbow’s End
abstract: Renée Zellweger plays Judy Garland near the end of her life, when she grasped onto one more comeback and one last chance.
lead_paragraph: One day in 1968, the year before she died, Judy Garland watched a television interview she had done with Dick Cavett. Noticing Cavett’s fidgeting, she wondered why she made everyone so uncomfortable. Because, a friend replied, no one knew if she was going to sing “Over the Rainbow” or open her veins. “Sometimes I do both,” Garland said, “at the same time.”

headline: ‘The Laundromat’ Review: Meryl Streep in a Cycle of Spin
abstract: In a film about the Panama Papers scandal, Steven Soderbergh convenes a seminar in international finance, with Antonio Banderas, Gary Oldman and Sharon Stone.
lead_paragraph: “The Laundromat” is like an enthusiastic high-school teacher — maybe you know the type — who tries to liven up dry material with skits, games and funny costumes. The film’s subject matter could hardly be more urgent: the deep and pervasive corruption of the global financial system, as documented in the 2016 data leak known as the Panama Papers. But the movie, directed by Steven Soderbergh from a screenplay by Scott Z. Burns, conducts its business with brisk, breezy irreverence. It’s a didactic comedy, an earnest lesson in political economy dressed up as a farce.

headline: In a Twist, Netanyahu Wins a Chance to Keep His Job
abstract: The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, must now assemble a parliamentary majority, a task that eluded him in the previous election.

headline: John Coltrane Took a Detour in 1964. Now It’s a New Album.
abstract: “Blue World,” culled from the sessions the saxophonist led for a film soundtrack, is a moment of looking back before he pushed even further ahead.
lead_paragraph: John Coltrane’s creative flame was burning at its brightest in 1964. The saxophonist had recently let go of his fixation on complex, layered harmonies, and he would soon pioneer a dry, squalling approach to group improvisation — nearly abandoning Western harmony altogether, and changing the course of jazz history.

headline: Review: The Tapper Ayodele Casel, Honoring Ancestors, Radiating Joy

lead_paragraph: Ayodele Casel has brought joy back into the Joyce Theater. Making a triumphant debut as a leader there on Tuesday, this tap dancer radiated joy and personified it. Joy, unsurprisingly, is the meaning of her name.

lead_paragraph: Last week at MoMA PS1, an epic sprawl of artists’ books were on display at New York Art Book Fair, which was started by the nonprofit organization Printed Matter. You can still visit Printed Matter’s Chelsea location, however, and see more than 75 books by the conceptual artist and sculptor Sol LeWitt, one of the organization’s founders, in the show “Book as System: The Artists’ Books of Sol LeWitt.”

abstract: Lisette Oropesa’s performance in Massenet’s opera at the Met is alone worth the price of admission.

lead_paragraph: Since it was released in 1998, Massive Attack’s third album, “Mezzanine,” has endured as a bleak milestone.

abstract: Jell-O as art, repurposed Roman coins and more.

headline: Trump Has Just One Plan for Victory
abstract: To get re-elected, he will stop at nothing. That’s why impeachment is crucial.

abstract: One story from WeWork’s inevitable blow-up: Our offices offer few spaces for deep work.
lead_paragraph: What was We thinking? That’s the only question worth asking now about the clowncar start-up known as The We Company, the money-burning, co-working behemoth whose best-known brand is WeWork.

headline: 87-Year-Old Killed Her Disabled Grandson With Overdose, Police Say
abstract: The woman, Lillian Parks, “purposely overdosed” her grandson over worries about who would care for him after she died, according to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: A Florida woman who cared for her disabled adult grandson on weekends faces second-degree murder charges after she told the police she gave him a fatal overdose over concerns about who would care for him when she died, the authorities said.

headline: The Zelensky Memo Is All the Proof Needed to Impeach Trump
abstract: It is far worse than we could have imagined.
lead_paragraph: Facing growing momentum behind a full House impeachment inquiry, President Trump evidently concluded that releasing a memorandum of his phone call on July 25 with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine would quiet the investigative fervor. He could not have been more wrong.

headline: Trump and Johnson on the Brink
abstract: The American and British leaders meet their nemesis. It’s called the law.

headline: Hong Kong, I Am Listening
abstract: Conversation can triumph over conflict, calm can be restored, and trust can be rebuilt within the community.

headline: An Artist Who Appropriates With a Wink
abstract: Piotr Uklanski has a brush with fantasy portraits in “Ottomania,” his new gallery show that melds East and West.

headline: Trump Pressed Ukraine’s President to Investigate Democrats as ‘a Favor’

headline: Match.com Used Fake Ads to Swindle Users, F.T.C. Says

headline: $250 Million to Keep Votes Safe? Experts Say Billions Are Needed
abstract: After months of pressure, Mitch McConnell agreed to spend $250 million for election security. Pennsylvania alone plans to spend $125 million just to update voting machines for 2020.
