headline: The Best Words: Trump, Zelensky and a Very Explosive Phone Call
abstract: How the president deploys his “buddy-buddy” diplomatic vernacular.
lead_paragraph: Talk to Rudy Giuliani, President Trump instructed — “highly respected man,” “very capable guy,” the best.

headline: Impeachment, Indonesia, Britain: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: More details of Trump impeachment inquiry.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: CBS Podcast Episode 3 BG
abstract: CBS Podcast Episode 3 BG
lead_paragraph: CBS Podcast Episode 3 BG

headline: Review: In ‘Invention of Tragedy,’ Wordplay Over Plotlines
abstract: Mac Wellman’s ode to theater does away with character and basic grammar. Here, language baffles and delights.
lead_paragraph: Tragedy was born, old-school anthropologists will tell you, when a dithyramb singer stepped out of the chorus and decided to act out the story instead. Western theater owes everything to that scene-stealer.

headline: White House Sends Impeachment Talking Points to Democrats, Then Tries to Recall Them
abstract: “They’re complete Orwellian lies and toxic trash,” Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., a Democrat who received the message, said of the talking points. (He did not use them.)
lead_paragraph: A White House official on Wednesday accidentally sent talking points for allies defending the president to Democratic officials, then tried to “recall” the memo.

headline: What Polling Can Tell Us About Impeachment (and What It Can’t)
abstract: Until now, it was clearly unpopular with the public. Now it’s hard to predict.
lead_paragraph: A majority of Americans have long opposed impeaching President Trump. Whether that will change, and what happens if it doesn’t, are some of many factors that will shape the political consequences for both parties.

headline: The Jewelry Designer Who Collects Other People’s Stories
abstract: Kim Dunham, who launched her custom signet ring collection three years ago, uses gold and sometimes gemstones to create wearable biographies.
lead_paragraph: On an overcast morning last month, Kim Dunham stood in her airy home office in Lower Manhattan flipping through manila folders arranged on an accordion-style rack. “So, this is a client who’s Native American, part of the Choctaw Nation,” she says, pulling out a dossier. “He feels a real connection to the matriarchs in his life, specifically his grandmother. She was a Native American activist in the ’60s and ’70s and involved in the occupation of Alcatraz.” He had shown Dunham an image of the first Choctaw school, still standing in Kentucky. “We went deep into that,” she notes, and selects another folder from the rack. “This client was telling me about her fiancé — he’s a sound engineer for a bunch of famous bands,” Dunham says. “I asked her later to send me some photos, and all of a sudden, I found myself thinking, ‘I feel like I know you guys.’”

headline: Tony Danza, Eileen Atkins and Jonathan Pryce on the Town
abstract: Patsy’s restaurant turns 75. And “The Height of the Storm” opened on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Patsy’s restaurant turns 75. And “The Height of the Storm” opened on Broadway.

headline: Pakistan Leader Will Urge U.N. Intervention in Kashmir
abstract: Prime Minister Imran Khan denounced India’s military clampdown in Muslim-majority Kashmir, attributing it to a “racist, fascist, Hindu supremacist mind-set.”
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s leader, lamenting what he said was the world’s indifference to civilian suffering in Kashmir, on Wednesday condemned India’s military clampdown there and said he would appeal to the United Nations for help.

headline: Patsy’s, a Rat Pack Redoubt, Turns 75
abstract: And “The Height of the Storm” opens on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: “I met Sinatra in 1947,” said Joe Scognamillo, 87, at Patsy’s Italian Restaurant on Monday night. Standing by the bar in a tuxedo, he greeted guests at the 75th anniversary of the landmark red sauce joint on West 56th Street founded by his father, Pasquale, during World War II.

headline: How CrowdStrike Became Part of Trump’s Ukraine Call
abstract: President Trump mentioned an American cybersecurity firm that is at the center of a conspiracy theory in a call with Ukraine’s president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump in July asked the president of Ukraine to “do us a favor” by looking into an American cybersecurity firm, CrowdStrike, and the location of a Democratic National Committee server that Mr. Trump said was believed to be in Ukraine’s possession.

headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things to Beef Up Your Digital Security
abstract: Here are a few simple things to at least prevent the worst problems and keep most of your private information as safe as possible from hacks or security negligence.
lead_paragraph: Everything you do online is tracked, logged and studied by someone, either through advertising or more malicious means. Being watched is an unpleasant feeling; it’s gotten to the point where even my “I have nothing to hide” friends are growing uncomfortable with the whole thing. As the privacy and security editor for Wirecutter, a New York Times company that reviews and recommends products, I’ve tested a variety of fixes over the years, and the following items are what I recommend to anyone who wants to beef up his or her digital security.

headline: Governor Cuomo and Sandra Lee Have Split Up
abstract: Rumors swirled after the couple’s house in Westchester County was put on the market.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — After more than a decade together, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and his longtime girlfriend, Sandra Lee, announced on Wednesday that they are ending their relationship.

headline: Amazon Wants Alexa to Move (With You) Far Beyond the Living Room
abstract: New devices were introduced on Wednesday to get the digital assistant in your earbuds, in your eyeglasses and in your bathroom.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Alexa has already made herself at home in kitchens and living rooms. Now Amazon is trying to get her in your ears. And on your face. And in your bathroom.

headline: Donald Trump, Israel, John Coltrane: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The 2020 Democratic Candidates Calling for Impeachment
abstract: The party’s presidential contenders say that President Trump’s attempt to encourage a foreign leader to investigate a political rival constituted an impeachable offense.
lead_paragraph: The party’s presidential contenders say that President Trump’s attempt to encourage a foreign leader to investigate a political rival constituted an impeachable offense.

headline: Volodymyr Zelensky: The Ukrainian President Linked to Trump Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: President Trump is facing calls for impeachment related to a phone call with Ukraine’s president. Who’s the man on the other end of the phone?
lead_paragraph: President Trump is facing calls for impeachment related to a phone call with Ukraine’s president. Who’s the man on the other end of the phone?

headline: Sol Stein, Publisher, Author and Champion of James Baldwin, Dies at 92
abstract: A founder of the publishing house Stein and Day, he also worked with Dylan Thomas, Budd Schulberg and David Frost and wrote more than a dozen books.
lead_paragraph: Sol Stein, a prolific novelist and playwright, savvy publisher and visionary editor who helped fashion a collection of trenchant essays by James Baldwin, a former high school classmate, into a literary classic, “Notes of a Native Son,” died on Thursday at his home in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 92.

headline: Fall TV Reviewed: Choir Wars, Zany Immigrants and Demons of the Week
abstract: “Evil,” from the “Good Wife” team; Patricia Heaton in “Carol’s Second Act”; Bradley Whitford in “Perfect Harmony”; and Kal Penn in “Sunnyside.”
lead_paragraph: The broadcast television fall season continues with many new shows making their debuts on Thursday night. Here are reviews of four of them.

headline: Pelosi’s Bad Impeachment Call
abstract: The speaker’s haste may end up helping the president.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, prominent Democrats called for the impeachment of a powerful conservative officeholder, only to be embarrassed into silence when it turned out that the basis for their calls was arguable and incomplete, handing their Republican opponents a P.R. coup.

headline: 48 Hours with Margherita Maccapani Missoni
abstract: The designer presented her debut collection for M Missoni using pieces from the house’s archives — and debuted it all on a tram ride around Milan.
lead_paragraph: The designer presented her debut collection for M Missoni using pieces from the house’s archives — and debuted it all on a tram ride around Milan.

headline: Margherita Maccapani Missoni Takes on a New Challenge, by Looking Back
abstract: The 36-year-old designer, and scion of the family business, tackles the design for M Missoni, its offshoot brand, with fresh eyes.
lead_paragraph: The day before her inaugural presentation in Milan, Margherita Maccapani Missoni, scion of the knitwear dynasty and the new creative director of her family’s M Missoni brand, arrives at her sun-filled showroom just south of the city’s Duomo. Preternaturally calm after a car-ride meditation, she exudes an easygoing, surfer vibe with long blond-tipped hair, a braided choker and the remnants of a summer tan.

headline: Ruth Abrams, Judge Who Broke a Glass Ceiling Installed in 1692, Dies at 88
abstract: In Massachusetts she wrote landmark decisions on family law and gender equality that were widely cited across the country. And she quietly recruited many women to the bench.
lead_paragraph: Ruth I. Abrams, the first woman to sit on the highest court in Massachusetts since its founding in 1692, and the author of landmark decisions on family law and gender equality that reverberated nationwide, died on Sept. 12 at a senior residence in Boston. She was 88.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Kal Penn Reads ‘First I Met My Children, Then My Girlfriend. They’re Related.’
abstract: The creator and star of “Sunnyside” reads an essay about a sperm donor who finds both offspring and love.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Boris Johnson Is Defiant as U.K. Parliament Reconvenes
abstract: After a stinging Supreme Court defeat, the prime minister came out fighting on Brexit. He also infuriated some lawmakers by invoking the memory of Jo Cox, a Brexit opponent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A day after suffering a crushing rebuke from his country’s highest court, a notably unchastened Prime Minister Boris Johnson appeared before a hastily reconvened Parliament and doubled down on his hard-line Brexit approach.

headline: $250 Million Feud Lingers, but Senecas and N.Y. Reach Small Truce
abstract: A stretch of highway fell into disrepair as New York and its largest Native American tribe bickered for years. Now, it will finally be repaired.
lead_paragraph: For years, motorists flying down Interstate 90 southwest of Buffalo were putting the well-being of their vehicles — not to mention their occupants — at risk, as they entered a three-mile stretch crossing the Seneca Nation’s tribal lands.

headline: They Survived Hurricane Dorian. Their Community Will Not.
abstract: The government of the Bahamas has prohibited rebuilding in the Haitian shantytowns destroyed by the Category 5 storm in early September.
lead_paragraph: The government of the Bahamas has prohibited rebuilding in the Haitian shantytowns destroyed by the Category 5 storm in early September.

headline: It’s No ‘Glengarry’: A Times Theater Critic Reviews ‘Eyes Only’
abstract: As a work of high drama, Jesse Green writes, the Trump-Zelensky script lacks stagecraft and subtlety.
lead_paragraph: You’d expect a better script from two showbiz professionals.

headline: Tekashi 69: How His Trial Testimony Left Him Labeled a ‘Snitch’
abstract: He testified for the prosecution about the Bloods, Jim Jones and Cardi B. Now he faces an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Hernandez, better known as Tekashi 69 or 6ix9ine, rocketed to viral Instagram fame as a rapper with an over-the-top persona. But in just under a year, his career has taken a remarkable turn: He is the prosecution’s star witness in a racketeering and firearms case against members of his former crew, the Nine Trey Gangsta Bloods.

headline: Jann Wenner Steps Down From the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame
abstract: The longtime Rolling Stone editor helped found the Rock Hall in 1983 and became its public face.
lead_paragraph: For years, Jann Wenner, the co-founder and longtime editor of Rolling Stone, held court over the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame’s annual induction ceremony, formally ushering the night’s assembled superstars into the pantheon.

headline: White Girls, 10 and 11, Accused in Hate Crime After Assault on Black Classmate
abstract: The mother of the alleged victim told the police that the girls who attacked her daughter on a school bus used racial slurs.
lead_paragraph: Two girls, 10 and 11, face criminal charges of harassment and assault of a 10-year-old girl on a school bus in a small upstate New York town, in an episode that the local police are treating as a racial hate crime.

headline: Trump Officials Turn Over Whistle-Blower Complaint as Impeachment Inquiry Begins
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the House should work “expeditiously” to build its case. It is not yet clear what that means.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats rushed on Wednesday to plot the course of their formal impeachment inquiry into President Trump, getting their first glimpses of the secret intelligence whistle-blower complaint that touched off the investigation that could lead to his removal.

headline: Justice Dept.’s Dismissal of Ukraine Call Raises New Questions About Barr
abstract: The Justice Department took four weeks to dismiss the significance of a phone call that has, in days, created a furor that could consume the Trump presidency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the end of August, when two top intelligence officials asked a Justice Department lawyer whether a whistle-blower’s complaint should be forwarded to Congress, they were told no, Attorney General William P. Barr and his department could handle the criminal referral against the president of the United States.

headline: Trump Doesn’t Need to Commit a Crime to Be Kicked Out of Office
abstract: The Constitution is clear that the standard for an impeachable offense is political, not criminal.
lead_paragraph: An important line of defense for President Trump against the House decision to formalize impeachment proceedings is that he did not commit a crime. In this view, asking a foreign government to investigate your chief political rival is not a “thing of value” for purposes of campaign finance statutes, meaning that there was technically no violation of federal criminal law.

headline: In California, Former Congressman Darrell Issa Will Challenge Indicted Congressman Duncan Hunter
abstract: Darrell Issa, the former nine-term congressman, is the latest Republican to launch a bid against Representative Duncan Hunter, who was indicted last August.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Darrell Issa, the former nine-term congressman from California, will try to return to Congress by challenging Representative Duncan Hunter, who was indicted last year, setting up a clash among two Trump allies for one of Republicans’ most endangered seats.

headline: Robert Boyd, Journalist Whose Reporting Shifted an Election, Dies at 91
abstract: He shared a Pulitzer for detailing how George McGovern’s initial running mate in 1972 had undergone electroshock therapy for depression.
lead_paragraph: Robert S. Boyd, a journalist who shared a Pulitzer Prize for uncovering evidence that Senator Thomas F. Eagleton had undergone electroshock therapy for depression, a revelation that compelled Senator George S. McGovern to jettison Mr. Eagleton as his Democratic running mate for vice president in 1972, died on Friday in Philadelphia. He was 91.

headline: ‘When They Speak, Everybody Listens.’ How Freshmen Are Shaping the Impeachment Push.
abstract: The drive to open an impeachment inquiry into President Trump began with pressure from the left, and ended with a tide of statements from moderates concerned about national security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the first day of the 116th Congress, the strident cry of a first-term lawmaker encapsulated the fervor of the progressive left for impeaching President Trump.

headline: The Mets Are Eliminated. Now Will Mickey Callaway Survive?
abstract: The manager has led the team to its third winning record since 2009, but he faces doubts over the weak first half of the season and his decision making in the tactically challenging National League.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the Mets were mathematically eliminated from playoff contention on Wednesday night, despite a 10-3 win over the Miami Marlins, Manager Mickey Callaway gathered the players in the clubhouse and expressed his gratitude for how hard they had played through most of the season.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Is Sending a Message
abstract: Lots of them, in fact.
lead_paragraph: Only three previous American presidents have faced removal from office via impeachment, so Tuesday’s announcement by Speaker Nancy Pelosi that the House is opening a formal impeachment investigation of President Trump was historic.

headline: Trump to Ukraine: Such a Shame if Anything Happened to Your Nice Country
abstract: No, Trump didn’t make an explicit threat. He didn’t have to.
lead_paragraph: On Fox News, Tucker Carlson agreed with a guest who said of allegations against President Trump, “This is all acceptable political behavior by presidents.”

headline: Elated, Furious, Wary: Impeachment Divides Voters, Like Everything Trump
abstract: For many Democratic voters around the country, the prospect of an explosive impeachment battle in Washington left them nervous. Republicans were mostly unmoved.
lead_paragraph: DAVENPORT, Iowa — Kristy Schneeberger, a Democrat in Eastern Iowa, said it was about time that Democrats in Congress moved to impeach President Trump. “No one is above the law,” she said.

headline: Person of Interest Is Named in Killing of Transgender Woman in Florida
abstract: The man is also a person of interest in what the authorities believe was an unrelated killing three months earlier.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after the body of Bee Love Slater, a black transgender woman, was found burned in an abandoned car near Clewiston, Fla., the authorities on Wednesday named a Belle Glade man as a “person of interest” in her killing.

headline: Citing Falsehoods, Nicolle Wallace of MSNBC Cut Away From Trump’s Remarks
abstract: Live coverage of President Trump’s news conference presented networks and cable news channels with a challenge: How, and when, should the fact-checking begin?
lead_paragraph: Seven minutes after President Trump began his first news conference since House Democrats opened a formal impeachment inquiry, MSNBC made a decision that stood alone among the major networks on Wednesday: It cut away.

headline: Trump’s Not-So-Excellent Day
abstract: On Wednesday the president’s mood went from angry to aggrieved to self-pitying as he fended off questions about a phone call with the Ukrainian president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s mood went from feisty to self-pitying to deflated on Wednesday as he fended off questions about a July phone call in which he urged the president of Ukraine to work with Attorney General William P. Barr on potential corruption investigations connected to former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Democratic rival.

headline: Whistle-Blower Is Said to Allege Concerns About White House Handling of Ukraine Call
abstract: New details have emerged about the intelligence officer who raised alarms about the president’s pressure on Ukraine to open inquiries that could benefit him politically.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The intelligence officer who filed a whistle-blower complaint about President Trump’s interactions with the leader of Ukraine raised alarms not only about what the two men said in a phone call, but also about how the White House handled records of the conversation, according to two people briefed on the complaint.

headline: Rudy Giuliani — World’s Worst Best Friend
abstract: He’s loud, he’s confused and he’s got a great plan for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Rudy Giuliani is the Trump administration’s point man on Ukraine. Just remember that, and everything else will make a lot more sense.

headline: Phone Call Showed Only a Slice of Trump’s Obsession With Ukraine
abstract: Since the 2016 campaign, the president has had an intense fixation on the country, which he believes is tied up in the origins of the special counsel’s investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was not a country that would naturally have seemed high on the priority list of a president who came to office relishing a trade clash with China, promising to reorder the Middle East and haranguing European allies to spend more on NATO.

headline: Corrections: September 26, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, September 26, 2019.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: New York City F.C. Routs Atlanta and Inches Closer to Top Seed
abstract: Thumping the second-place Atlanta United, N.Y.C.F.C. moved a step closer to ensuring that its playoff run would go through Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: It must seem a little bit funny at New York City F.C. today, after four years of big-name signings (David Villa, Andrea Pirlo), big-name coaches (Patrick Vieira) and at least one big-time mistake (Frank Lampard), that it was a tiny Romanian who put them on the verge of the first-place finish the team has been after all along.

headline: Quotation of the Day: For Some, a 3-Hour Game Is a Great Time to Knit a Sweater
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 26, 2019
lead_paragraph: “I could miss a home run, but if I hear the crowd, I could always look up. It’s not over by the time I look up.”

headline: It Has Begun
abstract: An impeachment inquiry is nothing to celebrate. Still, it is evidence of what’s right being put ahead of what’s expedient.
lead_paragraph: It is truly wondrous and arresting to see the Constitution in action, to see its ultimate tool — impeachment — employed, to see this mechanism that the drafters of the document must have considered an 11th-hour alternative be called up out of necessity.

headline: ‘Mothers’ Review: Mommy and Me and the Apocalypse
abstract: A barbed comedy takes a grim turn when friends find themselves tested over how far they’ll go to defend their choices and protect their children.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps “mother knows best” isn’t so accurate. And maybe “motherly love” is more complicated than it seems. Anna Moench’s “Mothers,” at the Duke on 42nd Street, cracks open a vision of motherhood to reveal a ghastly core.

headline: Presented in a Small Box
abstract: Brendan McGrady, Doug Peterson and Will Shortz pull a fast one.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle by Doug Peterson made me smile from ear to ear, as his puzzles are wont to do, but this one was special.

headline: One Homeless Man Tried to Set Another on Fire Near Los Angeles, Police Say
abstract: The episode was the latest in a series of attacks against homeless people in and around Los Angeles, and came amid heated debate about the homelessness crisis in California.
lead_paragraph: The man was sleeping under a jumble of cardboard boxes in downtown Glendale, Calif., the police said, when another homeless man approached, lit the cardboard on fire — and then started taking pictures.

headline: Strong Earthquake Strikes Indonesia, Killing at Least 20
abstract: The epicenter of the 6.5-magnitude earthquake was about 23 miles from Ambon, the capital of Maluku Province.
lead_paragraph: A 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck the remote Maluku Islands in eastern Indonesia on Thursday morning, killing at least 20 people.

headline: Labradoodle Creator Says the Breed Is His Life’s Regret
abstract: “I opened a Pandora box and released a Frankenstein monster,” said Wally Conron, who developed the mopheaded dog.
lead_paragraph: The inventor of the labradoodle, the ubiquitous, mopheaded designer dog, said that creating the mixed breed was one of his life’s regrets.

headline: At Least 70 Countries Have Had Disinformation Campaigns, Study Finds
abstract: Governments are using “cyber troops” to discredit political opponents, bury opposing views and interfere in foreign affairs, according to Oxford researchers.
lead_paragraph: In Vietnam, citizens were enlisted to post pro-government messages on their personal Facebook pages. The Guatemalan government used hacked and stolen social media accounts to silence dissenting opinions. Ethiopia’s ruling party hired people to influence social media conversations in its favor.

headline: Immigrant Population Growth in the U.S. Slows to a Trickle
abstract: The U.S. population gained immigrants last year at the slowest pace since 2008. President Trump’s approach to immigration is seen as the likely cause.
lead_paragraph: The United States population gained immigrants at the slowest pace in a decade last year, according to an analysis of new census data, a notable slowdown that experts said was quite likely linked to a more restrictive approach by the Trump administration.

headline: Trump, Brexit, Israel: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Indonesia Has a Papua Problem
abstract: A racial slur. Riots. And the real character of a popular president revealed.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — In an ideal Indonesia, a Papuan man would live in Jakarta and become a civil servant. He would marry a Padang woman from western Indonesia. They would open a small restaurant and hire a young Sundanese woman. Their customers would be a mix of Javanese, Betawi and other ethnic groups.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Evil’ and ‘Sunnyside’
abstract: A supernatural drama series debuts on CBS. And Kal Penn stars in a new NBC series.
lead_paragraph: EVIL 10 p.m. on CBS. “Is my client possessed by a demon?” The question is posed to Dr. Kristen Bouchard, the fictional forensic psychologist at the center of this new series, during a court proceeding early in the story. The query does a tidy job of summing up what this show does: mix procedural and supernatural thrills. “Evil” is the latest series from Robert and Michelle King, the married duo behind the long-running legal drama “The Good Wife.” The new series is led by the actress Katja Herbers, who plays Dr. Bouchard, and the actors Mike Colter (“Luke Cage”) and Aasif Mandvi (“The Daily Show”), as an investigator and his colleague who look into potentially paranormal phenomena. In Dr. Bouchard, that pair finds a person whose expertise can help distinguish demonic possession from run-of-the-mill insanity. The first episode debuts Thursday, alongside two notable new CBS sitcoms: THE UNICORN, airing at 8:30 p.m., which casts Walton Goggins as an obliviously handsome widower wading into the dating pool, and CAROL’S SECOND ACT, at 9:30 p.m., with Patricia Heaton as a retired teacher attempting to make a midlife career pivot into medicine.

headline: Word + Quiz: svelte
abstract: This word has appeared in 23 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: The Berlin Police Are Confident the Killer Is in Jail. They Just Don’t Know His Name.
abstract: The German authorities suspect the well-planned killing of a former Chechen separatist in Berlin was carried out by a Russian hit man released from prison for that purpose.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — At the outset, the German officers investigating the brazen daylight assassination of a former Chechen separatist commander were lucky.

headline: Top of Mind for the W.N.B.A.? A New Mental Health Plan for Players
abstract: After the W.N.B.A. finals, the league will enter off-season discussions that will dictate the future of the W.N.B.A. One top agenda item? Mental health care.
lead_paragraph: The W.N.B.A. finals begin Sunday as the Washington Mystics face the Connecticut Sun, each team looking for its first championship trophy. Shortly after the last bit of confetti falls and the Champagne showers end, both teams will join the rest of the league in an off-season that could reshape the future of the W.N.B.A.

headline: At Tech’s Leading Edge, Worry About a Concentration of Power
abstract: A.I. research is becoming increasingly expensive, leaving few people with easy access to the computing firepower necessary to develop the technology.
lead_paragraph: Each big step of progress in computing — from mainframe to personal computer to internet to smartphone — has opened opportunities for more people to invent on the digital frontier.

headline: He Sued Over a Priest’s Abuse. Then the Diocese Filed for Bankruptcy.
abstract: The Rochester diocese’s move has left many who were promised justice under New York’s Child Victims Act feeling betrayed.
lead_paragraph: Peter Saracino was in elementary school when, he said, a priest lured him away from a swimming pool and sexually abused him inside a seminary.

headline: 70 Countries and Counting: On the Tennis Governance Campaign Trail
abstract: Dave Miley used a windfall to visit 70 countries, by his count, to try to sell himself as an outsider candidate in a fractious period in tennis governance.
lead_paragraph: With help from $100,000 of a Wimbledon windfall, Dave Miley has been running for president of the International Tennis Federation, meeting and greeting people around the world and watching the bank balance count down.

headline: Packers Try to Stay Unbeaten as They Host the Eagles
abstract: Green Bay’s 3-0 start has been fueled by the team’s defense. Is this the week that Aaron Rodgers and the offense take over?
lead_paragraph: The rest of Week 4’s picks will be published on Friday.

headline: Baseball’s Pace of Play Is Perfect for at Least One Group: Knitters
abstract: Games have steadily gotten longer, but a subset of fans has embraced the plodding pace by stitching together sweaters, mittens and scarves in the stands.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Victoria Pojrazov pulled her gaze away from the action on the field only once, and that was to show her progress on the tunic sweater she was knitting for a friend. As she sat in her usual spot behind the Toronto Blue Jays bullpen in left field — Section 137 at the Rogers Centre — during a recent game, Pojrazov’s fingers twirled through green yarn as if independent from the rest of her body.

headline: O.K. Hand Sign Is a Hate Symbol, Anti-Defamation League Says
abstract: The many symbols, slogans and memes used by white supremacists — like the bowl haircut of one gunman — are seen as imperfect signposts in the effort to combat violence.
lead_paragraph: The bowl-shaped haircut worn by the white supremacist who killed nine black worshipers in Charleston, S.C., stands among the most disturbing and distinctive images that extremists have shared online. Others include letters drawn from the ancient runic alphabet — a particular favorite among neo-Nazis — or slogans like “Diversity=White genocide.”

headline: Caltech Gets a Windfall for Climate Research: $750 Million
abstract: The gift from Stewart and Lynda Resnick, the billionaire owners of bottled water and agriculture companies, comes amid growing urgency over climate change.
lead_paragraph: It will take huge efforts, according to experts, to avert disasters related to climate change. Commitments from reluctant leaders to reform the global economy. Shifts in the daily routines of citizens. And research from the world’s greatest minds — lots of it.

headline: A Desperate Battle, and a Victory for Now, at a Remote Afghan Outpost
abstract: Struggling Afghan forces took three northern districts from the Taliban. But the cost was high, and troops depend on American airstrikes to hold on.
lead_paragraph: CHAKARAN, Afghanistan — In one of the most remote places in Afghanistan, government forces this month managed to achieve something vanishingly rare these days: They clawed back not one but three districts from the Taliban’s grip.

headline: Late Night Gives Account of Trump’s Ukrainian Call 5 Stars
abstract: “And these notes that they released of this phone call make Trump look — and I don’t want to get too technical — bad,” Stephen Colbert said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Women in Parliament Call Out Boris Johnson for His Incendiary Language on Brexit
abstract: The prime minister this week came up with new slurs for those who disagree with him about Britain’s departure from the European Union, saying they were humiliating their country.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One after another, women rose in Britain’s House of Commons and pleaded with Prime Minister Boris Johnson to stop calling his opponents traitors, lest a madman take his words to heart.

headline: Barred From Owning Land, Rural Chinese Miss Spoils of Country’s Success
abstract: A region that is the cradle of China’s economic overhauls shows how decisions made four decades ago are hobbling China’s farmers and hampering economic growth.
lead_paragraph: XIAOXIHE, China — Every year, the message is the same: the government will fix China’s left-behind countryside through a raft of reforms. This year was no different, with measures meant to help farmers move to cities, educate their children, and invest in improving their land.

headline: I Run War Games. Too Often, I Am the Only Woman in the Room.
abstract: There is something empowering about being able to command a room of my male colleagues. But the thing is, I’m tired of being a rarity.
lead_paragraph: I looked over the green plastic soldiers I held in the palm of my hand as my colleagues debated whether one figure should represent a battalion or a brigade. As I placed a single figure on the board, I was conscious of the fact that it wasn’t just a piece of plastic and that the discussion over what it represented wasn’t mere talk. Instead, what we were debating was whether we would put 400 or 4,000 men and women along the border of the Demilitarized Zone on the Korean Peninsula to potentially face combat. The outcome of that debate would in turn determine how people playing the game — whether they were uniformed military or high-school-age girls — would think about how a potential future conflict between North Korea and the Republic of Korea and the United States could play out.

headline: When Music Is the Best Medicine
abstract: Music therapists can meet the spiritual, psychological and aesthetic needs of the afflicted by producing sounds testifying to the fact that beauty continues to exist in the world.
lead_paragraph: When Emily Caudill learned she had an ovarian germ cell tumor at the age of 25, she did not want to undergo chemotherapy. An accomplished bluegrass fiddler, she knew that hearing loss is a common side effect of some chemicals — so common that drugs harmful to the ear have acquired an adjective: they are ototoxic.

headline: A Bodega With Kale and Activism on the Menu
abstract: A Los Angeles take on the New York neighborhood staple harks back to social justice programs of the ’60s.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From the outside, LaRayia’s Bodega looks like a harbinger of the sort of gentrification it is designed to fight.

headline: Jeanette Winterson Owns the Entire Oxford English Dictionary
abstract: “To me, a proper dictionary is a book of spells,” says the novelist, whose most recent book is “Frankissstein.”
lead_paragraph: “To me, a proper dictionary is a book of spells,” says the novelist, whose most recent book is “Frankissstein.”

headline: When Depression Is Like a Cancer
abstract: Like cancer, depression is a chronic disease that may be cured. But for some patients, both diseases may ultimately prove fatal, even with state-of-the-art care and resources.
lead_paragraph: Depression is not cancer. It’s a completely different disease. Yet when I look back on my husband’s depression and death by suicide three years ago, it sure looks a lot like cancer to me.

headline: Favorite Season
abstract: What’s yours? Why?
lead_paragraph: What’s your favorite season? Why?

headline: Already Light, Legislative Menu Chopped Down by Impeachment Fight
abstract: Rancor surrounding impeach inquiry certain to spill over and constrict an already limited legislative agenda
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress wasn’t doing much legislatively in this polarized environment. President Trump wasn’t exactly tearing through his policy to-do list, either. Now, with an explosive impeachment inquiry suddenly thrown into the mix, they are likely to do even less than the little they were already doing.

headline: They Needed a Kid-Friendly Apartment in Williamsburg. Which Did They Choose?
abstract: A couple attempts to find enough space to live with — and separately from — their 5-year-old daughter. Here’s where they wound up.
lead_paragraph: A couple attempts to find enough space to live with — and separately from — their 5-year-old daughter. Here’s where they wound up.

headline: ‘They’
abstract: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or our world today?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or our world today? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘What Is the United Nations? Its History, Its Goals and Its Relevance’
abstract: In this lesson, students will examine the legacy, purpose and power of the United Nations. Does it make the world a better and safer place?
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “What Is the United Nations? Its History, Its Goals and Its Relevance”

headline: Sharp Increase in Visitor Park Fees Proposed for the Galápagos
abstract: With concerns growing over the impact of an exploding tourist population, officials hope the increased income will help sustainability and conservation of the archipelago.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the Galápagos Islands will likely pay an increased park fee starting next year, a decision that reflects growing concerns that skyrocketing tourism on the Ecuadorean archipelago is harming its fragile and unique ecosystem.

headline: Looking For a New Way to Live
abstract: James Ehrlich, the founder of ReGen Villages, wants to create neighborhoods that will generate their own power and grow their own food.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a new series on Visionaries. The New York Times selected people from all over the world who are pushing the boundaries of their fields, from science and technology to culture and sports.

headline: Get Ready for Impeachment
abstract: And the Republicans running against Trump.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

headline: How Do You Practice Self-Care?
abstract: What do you do to preserve or improve your mental, physical or emotional health, and why?
lead_paragraph: Have you heard the term self-care? If not, Oxford Dictionaries defines it as the practice of taking action to “preserve or improve one’s own health.”

headline: In California, a ‘Surprise’ Billing Law Is Protecting Patients and Angering Doctors
abstract: The state’s closely watched law is similar to an approach Congress is considering nationally.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, California passed one of the strongest laws in the country to outlaw surprise medical billing. That legislation made sure that when patients went to a hospital covered by their insurance, doctors couldn’t later ambush them with unexpected bills.

headline: Why We Upgraded Our Reviews Approach for Apple’s iPhone 11
abstract: While tech reviewers last week encouraged people to upgrade to Apple’s newest phones, The New York Times recommended something different: to cherish the phone you have, and upgrade if you must. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: How Being a 13-Year-Old Busboy Prepared Darren Walker to Lead the Ford Foundation
abstract: Mr. Walker rode the United States’ “mobility escalator” from rural Texas to Wall Street. Now he feels “both gratitude and rage” for a country that he says has reached an inflection point.
lead_paragraph: Darren Walker is the first to acknowledge his own privilege. As president of the Ford Foundation, he oversees a $13 billion philanthropic giant. As a board member at PepsiCo, he has the ear of the business world’s elite. With a magnetic personality, he enjoys friendships with everyone from Elton John to Mark Zuckerberg.

headline: Why Impeachment Might Be Trouble for Some Democratic Presidential Candidates
abstract: Top contenders like Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren can continue to command attention. Second- and third-tier candidates, however, are at greater risk of falling off the radar screen.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Oddly, it has been business as usual on the campaign trail this week. Senator Elizabeth Warren explained her policy plans to voters in New Hampshire on Wednesday, Senator Bernie Sanders walked a picket line with striking auto workers in Detroit and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. courted donors in Bel Air, Calif., and went on Jimmy Kimmel’s late-night TV show.

headline: A Modernist Sanctuary That Overlooks the Trancoso Jungle
abstract: The fashion executive turned hotelier Wilbert Das built a modern vacation house steeped in Brazil’s design history.
lead_paragraph: THE DUTCH DESIGNER Wilbert Das first visited the Brazilian beach town of Trancoso in 2004 on a whim after hearing about it from a friend in the Italian province of Vicenza, where he’d moved in 1988 at the age of 24 and eventually became the creative director of what was then a fledgling denim line called Diesel. Das’s friend had raved about Trancoso’s unassuming glamour, its 17th-century bone-white chapel that fronted the electric blue Atlantic and the fishermen’s houses in Easter-egg hues that line its grassy main square, the Quadrado. Das, now 55, went in June — “the lowest of the low season” — and left completely enchanted: “I’d never been any place like it.” A town of 11,000 people, Trancoso had neither electricity nor running water until the early 1980s, shortly after the first hippies, fleeing Brazil’s military regime, started migrating from São Paulo, 870 miles to the south. Even today, Trancoso seems not so much frozen in time as indifferent to it.

headline: 14 Answers to the Impeachment Inquiry, and What May Come Next
abstract: Our journalists in Washington responded to readers’ questions about the Ukraine dispute and the impeachment process.
lead_paragraph: After House Democrats took the extraordinary step this week of initiating a formal impeachment inquiry, numerous questions have arisen about the complicated process, and how it could play out for President Trump.

headline: 36 Hours in Dublin
abstract: A vibrant culture of Irish food, crafts, booze, literature and music offers a weekend of diversions, but it’s Dublin’s complex history and its welcoming spirit that will linger longest.
lead_paragraph: A lively, cosmopolitan and walkable city, Dublin is a perennial favorite but there are more reasons to come here now than ever before. Immigrant influence — from Chinese dumpling restaurants to Polish grocery stores — has added color and variety to an already vibrant culture of Irish food, crafts and booze. Dip into James Joyce’s “Ulysses” notebooks at the new Museum of Literature Ireland and then relax with a glass of natural wine; shop for modern Irish linen and locally roasted espresso; and follow an into-the-wee hours traditional music session with a next-morning shakshuka (a tomato and egg dish from the Middle East) breakfast. Irish art has always leaned heavily on tragedy, and Dublin’s historic cemeteries and jails are worth visiting for enlightenment into what has fueled the country’s often-melancholy nature. But it’s the local sense of humor — occasionally dark as it can be — that’s what most visitors take away from a visit to the capital.

headline: Eddie Murphy Is Bringing Eddie Murphy Back
abstract: In a wide-ranging interview, the star explains why he’s returning to stand-up and the big screen, why he regrets leaving and why it’s hard to watch himself in “Raw” these days.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In the middle of shooting a scene from the new biopic “Dolemite Is My Name,” Eddie Murphy went off script. Playing the comic Rudy Ray Moore onstage, he needled a member of the audience, then asked where he came from. The man, an extra, improvised: “Your mama’s house!”

headline: Kathryn Murdoch Steps Out of the Family Shadow to Fight Climate Change
abstract: You know her last name, and her father-in-law, Rupert, the conservative media mogul. Now, she hopes to remove partisan obstacles to climate progress that her family’s empire helped build.
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Murdoch is sitting with a reporter in her offices in the West Village, talking about climate change and democracy.

headline: When Filming in New York, the City Is Always the Star
abstract: Is there an Oscar for Best Supporting Zip Code?
lead_paragraph: One of the durable clichés of film criticism is the observation that “the city is like another character in the movie.” While I don’t have the data to prove it, my strong suspicion is that this has been said more about New York than any other city.

headline: N.Y. Weather: Why Doesn’t It Feel Like Fall Yet?
abstract: Thursday: On the first day of fall, temperatures reached the high 80s. Since then, it has gotten cooler — and yet it still does not feel like autumn.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Political Plays for Political Times
abstract: From a member of Parliament in “Hansard” to the users of a threatened community center in “Faith, Hope and Charity,” London theaters are exploring how power works.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If you’re going to crib from one of the greats, it helps to have great actors at your command. “Hansard,” at the National Theater through Nov. 25, is the debut play from the actor Simon Woods, perhaps best known for the TV series “Cranford.” But even as the writing makes plain a slavish debt to Edward Albee, this two-hander is kept aloft by a pair of performers, Lindsay Duncan and Alex Jennings, able to make its overfamiliar contours seem fresh.

headline: Houston Museum Buys Delacroix Discovery
abstract: This early version of the striking “Women of Algiers” was lost for more than a century and a half, until a French gallerist encountered it.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, has acquired a long-lost early version of Eugène Delacroix’s famed 1834 masterpiece, “Women of Algiers in Their Apartment,” that hangs at the Louvre in Paris.

headline: Joseph Maguire, Jacques Chirac, Renée Zellweger: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: For Bride (and Groom) Gifting: Think Inside The Box
abstract: Couples can plan and prepare for their big day with monthly subscription and curated gift boxes filled with useful wedding day essentials.
lead_paragraph: In the same way trendy monthly subscriptions and curated boxes allow you to discover new beauty products, food prep and fashion, a new crop of expertly crafted boxed gifts, specifically catered to engaged couples, have made their way to the wedding industry.

headline: These High-Tech Sensors May Be the Key to Autonomous Cars
abstract: What were once believed to be exotic technologies are now being considered to fill in perceived safety gaps.
lead_paragraph: In a year when the autonomous vehicle business has hit a big reset button, consensus is growing among designers that self-driving cars just aren’t perceptive enough to make them sufficiently safe. So now engineers are considering using more sophisticated sensors and technology — tech that can see through rain and even look underground.

headline: There Was More to the Price Hike on Stamps Than the Cost
abstract: There has to be a reason for official decisions beyond “because we say so.”
lead_paragraph: I’m taking a momentary break from my gloomy columns of recent months — not because I’m no longer worried about the Supreme Court becoming the Trump administration’s lap dog or about the eagerness of some justices to put the Second Amendment on steroids.

headline: Trump Has Overplayed His Hand
abstract: And may have awakened a long-dormant Congress.
lead_paragraph: Empires collapse when they overreach. The imperial presidency is no different. It has long been disdainful of Congress, but now, under the Trump administration, it is reaching a peak of contempt for it. Even so, President Trump’s recent aggrandizement of the executive branch may have the ironic and salutary effect of shrinking the power of the presidency by awakening the countervailing power of a long-dormant Congress.

headline: ‘I Would Like You to Do Us a Favor’
abstract: According to a White House record of the phone call, those were President Trump’s words to Ukraine’s leader. But what do they mean for the impeachment inquiry?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Jacques Chirac, Who Led France Envisioning European Unity, Is Dead at 86
abstract: As president he opposed the Iraq war, sought a ‘United Europe of States’ and cultivated comity between the left and the right. But an embezzlement conviction damaged him.
lead_paragraph: Jacques Chirac, who molded the legacy of Charles de Gaulle into a personal power base that made him one of the dominant leaders of France across three decades  and a vocal advocate of European unity, died on Thursday at his home in Paris. He was 86.

headline: On Khashoggi Killing and Yemen, Saudis Cannot Avoid Fresh Scrutiny
abstract: Saudi Arabia failed to stop an inquiry on atrocities in Yemen, and a documentary quotes Prince Mohammed bin Salman saying he has “all the responsibility” for the death of Jamal Khashoggi.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — An attempt by Saudi Arabia to halt an investigation into human rights abuses in Yemen went down to defeat on Thursday, as news broke that the kingdom’s crown prince said in an upcoming documentary that he bears “all the responsibility” for the killing of the writer Jamal Khashoggi, but denied prior knowledge of the plot.

headline: Chloé: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Chloé: Spring 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Chloé: Spring 2020 Collection.

headline: DealBook Briefing: How the Impeachment Fight Could Affect the Markets
abstract: The political drama in Washington won’t necessarily cause jitters on Wall Street. But it could lead to decisions that do.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: ‘Abominable’ Review: Are We There, Yeti?
abstract: Visual dazzle helps animate a familiar creature-rescue story.
lead_paragraph: “Abominable” is an exceptionally watchable and amiable animated tale written and directed by Jill Culton. Its opening scene is like that of a first-person video game. From the point of view of something in captivity, we, the audience, break free, bouncing out of a cell and into a lab, where a red-haired female scientist informs us, in a plummy British accent, that we really ought not to be out and about.

headline: ‘The Death of Dick Long’ Review: About Last Night …
abstract: Three young Alabama men have a less-than-enchanted evening in this dark comedy.
lead_paragraph: One might not expect a film with this title to properly sustain a feature-length running time, and one would be correct. But “The Death of Dick Long,” until it meanders into a semisincere dramatic dimension, manages to pack in a good number of laughs for a significant amount of time.

headline: ‘Sister Aimee’ Review: Bible Belter
abstract: In this weird, erratic film, a famous evangelist and singer fakes her own death and heads for Mexico.
lead_paragraph: With “Sister Aimee,” the writers and directors Samantha Buck and Marie Schlingmann turn a bizarre, real-life event from the 1920s — the sudden disappearance of the celebrity evangelist Aimee Semple McPherson — into a mischievous feminist fable.

headline: ‘The Day Shall Come’ Review: The Revolution Will Be Compromised
abstract: This cartoonish counterterrorism satire is a slapstick circus that can’t decide who is slapping whom.
lead_paragraph: A circular firing-squad of full-on crazy, Chris Morris’s “The Day Shall Come” barges into American counterterrorism tactics with sledgehammer satire and a numbingly repetitive plot.

headline: Woman Trying to End Sexual Assault at V.A. Centers Says She Is Attacked in One
abstract: “He pressed his entire body against mine,” said Andrea Goldstein, a staff member for the House veterans committee, and he said, “You look like you could use a good time.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A senior policy adviser on female veterans issues for the House said she was assaulted last week at the V.A. Medical Center in Washington by a man who slammed his body against hers and then pressed himself against her in the center’s cafe.

headline: ‘Jim Allison: Breakthrough’ Review: Taking On Cancer
abstract: He won a Nobel Prize for his discoveries in immunotherapy. This documentary shows how he got there.
lead_paragraph: Documentaries about innovative figures don’t always offer correspondingly innovative filmmaking. But even coloring within the lines of conventional biographical storytelling, “Jim Allison: Breakthrough” provides an accessible introduction to James P. Allison, who, along with Tasuku Honjo of Japan, won a Nobel Prize in 2018 for discoveries in cancer immunotherapy.

headline: ‘First Love’ Review: Eluding Assassins With the Help of a Boxer
abstract: The prolific director Takashi Miike delivers an unusually satisfying Japanese genre romp.
lead_paragraph: The ultra-prolific director Takashi Miike already had about 30 films under his belt at the end of the 1990s, when the one-two punch of the art-horror date picture “Audition” and the ultraviolent art-horror gangster movie “Dead or Alive” wowed Western audiences. Now he’s beyond his 100th movie. Not all of his efforts make it to the States but his latest, “First Love,” demonstrates that his energy and inventiveness are still intact.

headline: ‘The Golden Glove’ Review: Honka, Portrait of a Serial Killer
abstract: The movie, directed by Fatih Akin, ups the ante for grossness.
lead_paragraph: Filmmakers can have a tough time distinguishing themselves in the crowded serial-killer genre. For Fatih Akin, the director of “The Golden Glove,”  the solution seems to have been making his movie as vomitous as possible.

headline: ‘10 Minutes Gone’ Review: A Forgettable Shoot-’em-Up
abstract: Bruce Willis and Michael Chiklis star in this crime potboiler about a robbery gone wrong in Cincinnati.
lead_paragraph: The title of this movie proves unusually apt: You will figure out its climactic plot twist within the first 10 minutes. Directed by Brian A. Miller from a script by Kevin Mao and Jeff Jingle, “10 Minutes Gone,” a crime potboiler whose central virtue is its briskness, stars Michael Chiklis as Frank, a crook managing a heist that of course goes wrong.

headline: ‘Sink or Swim’ Review: Pool Boys
abstract: In over their heads, these unlikely underwater artistes find their happy place.
lead_paragraph: A gentle, genial dip into a pool of midlife despair, Gilles Lellouche’s body-positive comedy, “Sink or Swim,” follows a small group of variously troubled men who find purpose in forming an all-male synchronized swimming team.

headline: Carrie Lam Comes Face to Face With Angry Hong Kong Residents at Town Hall
abstract: Mrs. Lam met with 150 people on Thursday inside a heavily guarded stadium. She said she wanted to heal divisions and hear “constructive suggestions.”
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After months of public unrest and criticism that she was ignoring the demands of protesters, Hong Kong’s embattled leader, Carrie Lam, came face to face on Thursday with the fury and frustration coursing through the city during a question-and-answer session billed as a community dialogue.

headline: Trump Impeachment Inquiry Updates: The Complaint, the Testimony, the Reaction
abstract: A whistle-blower’s complaint accused President Trump of using his office to try to get Ukraine to help him in 2020. The acting intelligence chief told Congress that the controversy is “unprecedented.”
lead_paragraph: “In the course of my duties, I have received information from multiple U.S. government officials that the President of the United States is using the power of his office to solicit interference from a foreign country in the 2020 U.S. election.” Thus began an explosive criminal complaint drafted by an American intelligence officer and released by the House Intelligence Committee on Thursday.

headline: Joseph Maguire, Acting D.N.I., Holds His Ground
abstract: Mr. Maguire became the acting director of national intelligence last month. Almost immediately, a whistle-blower complaint plunged him into crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For days, the nation’s top intelligence official found himself wedged between lawmakers eager to see a potentially explosive whistle-blower complaint and other Trump administration officials who deemed it off-limits.

headline: The Collaboration to End All Collaborations
abstract: Dries Van Noten and Christian Lacroix team up.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — If only Blaine Trump had been here to see it. The pouf skirt, relic of the go-go 1980s, favorite party dress of the Wives of Wall Street, is back. Only, now it is in the shape of a sleeve (singular). Also a waistband. That’s a tell.

headline: Dries Van Noten and Christian Lacroix: A Collaboration 2-Step
abstract: “Dries, you don’t need me.” “But I did need you very much.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The morning after unveiling their secret spring 2020 collaboration, the designers Dries Van Noten and Christian Lacroix explained how it happened and why. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Five Years Ago, 43 Students Vanished. The Mystery, and the Pain, Remain
abstract: The case has become a symbol of Mexico’s broken rule of law.
lead_paragraph: That weekend began like so many others in the southern Mexico town: The main square hosted a political rally and there was a soccer match nearby. Students from a rural teacher-training college were trying to secure buses for a trip to Mexico City.

headline: Australia’s Most Populous State Decriminalizes Abortion
abstract: The measure, which was approved in New South Wales, home to Sydney, after days of debate, overturned a 119-year-old law.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia’s most populous state decriminalized abortion on Thursday, becoming the last jurisdiction in the country to revise blanket penalties enacted decades ago.

headline: Trumpism, in Five Pages
abstract: The phone call,  the man, the favor.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Full Video: Intelligence Chief’s Testimony Before Congress
abstract: Joseph Maguire, the acting director of national intelligence, appeared before the House Intelligence Committee on Thursday to discuss a whistle-blower complaint against President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Maguire, the acting director of national intelligence, appeared before the House Intelligence Committee on Thursday to discuss a whistle-blower complaint against President Trump.

headline: White House Tried to ‘Lock Down’ Ukraine Call Records, Whistle-Blower Says
abstract: The whistle-blower’s complaint accused President Trump of trying to compel Ukraine’s leader to help investigate a 2020 rival, and the White House of trying to “lock down” records of the call.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior White House officials tried to “lock down” a record of President Trump’s call with the leader of Ukraine in an attempted cover-up of Mr. Trump’s efforts to compel an investigation of a Democratic rival, a whistle-blower alleged in an explosive complaint released Thursday.

headline: Document: Read the Whistle-Blower Complaint
abstract: The complaint filed by an intelligence officer about President Trump’s interactions with the leader of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The complaint filed by an intelligence officer about President Trump’s interactions with the leader of Ukraine.

headline: Will Backing Impeachment Inquiry Hurt Freshman Democrats?
abstract: Thursday: The short answer? Probably not. Also: An update to the Camp Fire death toll, and remembering Robert Hunter.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Jason Moran’s Jazz Journey at the Whitney Upends Space and Time
abstract: The pianist and conceptual artist engages with the physical history of jazz in collaborations with Kara Walker, Joan Jonas and other art world figures.
lead_paragraph: At the Whitney Museum of American Art last week, Jason Moran and his Bandwagon trio had been playing for about 10 minutes inside a replica of the stage at the Three Deuces, a bebop club from 1940s New York, when he suddenly got up from the piano and snaked through the crowd assembled inside the museum’s eighth-floor gallery.

headline: A Canadian Creative Director’s Take on a French Crepe Cake
abstract: For Christine Charlebois of Want Les Essentiels, the only thing better than a thin pancake is a stack of them dusted with matcha powder.
lead_paragraph: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Northport, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Westport, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom in Northport, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Westport, Conn.

abstract: This week’s properties are in Park Slope, Turtle Bay and Lincoln Square.
