headline: Where Can Teachers Afford the Rent?
abstract: If they are the sole breadwinner in their home, hardly anywhere in America’s largest metro areas.
lead_paragraph: Teachers are notoriously underpaid in the United States, with many working second jobs to make ends meet. A new study by Zillow shows just how difficult paying rent is for teachers, especially new teachers, across the country. Many spend over 30 percent of their pay on housing, making them technically “cost burdened,” as the term is defined by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

headline: Paco Rabanne: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Paco Rabanne: Spring 2020 Collection.
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Paco Rabanne: Spring 2020 Collection.

headline: Utkarsh Ambudkar Finally Gets His Broadway Shot in ‘Freestyle Love Supreme’
abstract: The rapper and actor missed having a “Hamilton” moment with his longtime collaborators. But after getting sober and forging his own path, he’s ready to spit the truth.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In 2004, Utkarsh Ambudkar completed the acting program at N.Y.U.’s Tisch School of the Arts feeling disillusioned. He’d spent his days in class but his nights at clubs in the East Village, freestyling and battle rapping — in his mind, he was much more of a rapper than an actor. A life chasing down parts in an industry where talent mattered less than “the amount of roles for people that look like you” seemed grim, he said recently, over a gargantuan bowl of chili at a restaurant near his Los Angeles home.

headline: A Tap Dancer’s Place: After the Horn Player, Before the Drummer
abstract: For Michela Marino Lerman and others in her generation, the answer to “where does the tap dancer fit?” is with the band.
lead_paragraph: At the White Plains Jazz Festival earlier this month, the band Mwenso & the Shakes was setting up, plugging in instruments and checking microphones. Michela Marino Lerman was among them. She set down a wooden board and hooked it up to the sound system. Then she changed out of her sandals into tap shoes. Ms. Lerman is a tap dancer, and she is also a member of the band.

headline: Boeing Underestimated Cockpit Chaos on 737 Max, N.T.S.B. Says
abstract: The federal agency, after a monthslong review, said the company had failed to account for how a misfire of an automated system could lead to other problems for pilots.
lead_paragraph: A monthslong federal investigation into Boeing’s 737 Max plane has called into question some of the most fundamental assumptions used by manufacturers and regulators when certifying aircraft, and challenged Boeing’s repeated assertions that pilots should have been able to easily handle a malfunction on its jet.

headline: ‘They Want a Public Spectacle,’ Nunes Says, Criticizing Democrats
abstract: Representative Devin Nunes, the top Republican on the Intelligence Committee, defended President Trump against the allegations made by a whistle-blower. Mr. Nunes has been one of the president’s most steadfast allies on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: Representative Devin Nunes, the top Republican on the Intelligence Committee, defended President Trump against the allegations made by a whistle-blower. Mr. Nunes has been one of the president’s most steadfast allies on Capitol Hill.

headline: Karl Lagerfeld Remembered With White Shirts
abstract: As the Chanel designer loved the garment, friends and admirers create a charity project to honor him.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Chanel might be famous for the little black dress. But Karl Lagerfeld, the longtime creative director of the famed French fashion house, who died in February, had another wardrobe staple that he longed to call his own.

headline: Visit Quebec City for a Distinctly Old World Holiday
abstract: Discover how the city becomes a 17th-century winter wonderland.
lead_paragraph: Discover how the city becomes a 17th-century winter wonderland.

headline: E.P.A. Accuses California of ‘Significant’ Air and Water Problems
abstract: In the Trump administration's latest jab at California, the Environmental Protection Agency is saying the state is not protecting its water quality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Thursday, pressing the president’s complaints about homelessness in California, demanded the state improve the way it deals with human waste, arsenic and lead in water as it escalated the administration’s war with the country’s most populous state.

headline: Solving the Mystery of a Mother’s Brief Disappearance, 90 Years Later
abstract: In “Five Days Gone,” the art critic Laura Cumming writes about trying to discover what happened when her mother, at 3 years old, was kidnapped from a quiet beach.
lead_paragraph: Laura Cumming, the art critic for The Observer newspaper in London, published “The Vanishing Velázquez,” about a lost painting by the Spanish master, in 2016. Her new book, “Five Days Gone,” is about a disappearance of a much different — and much more personal — sort. In 1929, when Cumming’s mother was 3 years old, she was kidnapped from a quiet beach on the coast of England. A few days later, she turned up unharmed. She grew up with no memory of the event, and wasn’t even told it had happened until more than 50 years later. In the book, Cumming attempts to figure out what occurred, and in the process unlocks a great deal of convoluted family history. Below, she discusses discovering a bag of photos that changed the course of the book, looking at her subjects with an open mind and more.

headline: My Grown-Up, Live-In Boyfriend Is Really Close With His Mother. Ugh.
abstract: A reader dreads Mom’s first visit.
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend is 50 years old. He calls his mother every day; they discuss any problems he has. I think it’s sweet. He was married for 15 years to a woman he says ignored him, though he admits to cheating on her with his last girlfriend, with whom he says he was incompatible. We’ve been dating for eight months now and just moved in together. His mother wants to visit and stay with us. But I want this man to view me as a partner, so I’ve asked if she can postpone her visit until we’ve had more time together. He says he can’t refuse her. Would it be rude to help him cut these apron strings?

headline: The Police Can’t Solve the Problem. They Are the Problem.
abstract: Twenty-five years after the infamous 1994 crime bill, too many criminal justice groups are simply reimagining mass incarceration.
lead_paragraph: A quarter-century on, criminal justice advocates agree that the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act, signed by Bill Clinton in September 1994, was a disaster for poor people and people of color, and a driver of mass incarceration. Elected officials, policy experts and academics have recently sought to undo this damage by reimagining public safety. But too many of them are keeping law enforcement central to their vision for reform. This is a fundamental mistake.They are not reimagining public safety. They are reimagining mass incarceration.

headline: In a League of Its Own
abstract: Iraqi House may be the only restaurant in New York City expressly devoted to Iraqi cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Iraqi House may be the only restaurant in New York City expressly devoted to Iraqi cuisine.

headline: Why I Resigned From the Gates Foundation
abstract: By honoring India’s divisive and authoritarian prime minister Narendra Modi, the foundation is going against its professed belief of considering every life valuable.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On Tuesday, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation presented Narendra Modi, the Hindu nationalist prime minister of India, with one of its Global Goal Awards in New York. The Gates Foundation has chosen to honor Mr. Modi for his Swachh Bharat Abhiyaan, or Clean India Mission, which claims to have built 100 million new toilets in India over the past five years.

headline: A Menu Ruled by Chance at Iraqi House in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn
abstract: ‘Every dish is different,’ said Mohammed Almandalawi, who is the owner, chef, waiter and, so far, the sole employee at this restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Order dolma at Iraqi House, and you submit, happily, to chance. What arrives might be whole onions or green bell peppers, or eggplant, or tomatoes, their insides emptied to make way for a meld of ground lamb and basmati rice, tinged by tomato, with vivid threads of parsley and dill running through.

headline: ‘The Whistle-Blower Did the Right Thing,’ Maguire Says
abstract: The acting director of national intelligence, Joseph Maguire, defended the whistle-blower’s handling of the complaint during a House Intelligence Committee hearing.
lead_paragraph: The acting director of national intelligence, Joseph Maguire, defended the whistle-blower’s handling of the complaint during a House Intelligence Committee hearing.

headline: How Blink-182’s Tom DeLonge Became a U.F.O. Researcher
abstract: Two years after Mr. DeLonge left the band, he found a new life trying to make sense of outer space.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the discussion of whether or not U.F.O.s exist has been debated in American pop culture and within science communities.

headline: What Whales and Dolphins Left Behind for Life in the Ocean
abstract: The ancestors of dolphins and whales survived in the seas by shedding genes involved in sleep, DNA repair and other seemingly critical activities.
lead_paragraph: When the land-dwelling ancestors of today’s whales and dolphins slipped into the seas long ago, they gained many things, including flippers, the ability to hold their breath for long periods of time and thick, tough skin. Along the way they also discarded many traits that were no longer relevant or useful.

headline: Where The Times’s Restaurant Critic Likes to Eat
abstract: For The New York Times Food Festival, Pete Wells lists the 10 places where he’d open his own wallet to dine.
lead_paragraph: When The New York Times asked me to help choose restaurants where a series of dinners will be held in late September and early October, I started by thinking of all the places where I’d spend my own money. The list was ultimately narrowed to 10. Here they are, in alphabetical order, along with some reasons they’re among my favorites.

headline: Where Should You Eat in New York? Go to These Favorite Spots
abstract: Whether it’s for a celebration, or for some familiar food, cooking experts and Times journalists share their top places.
lead_paragraph: A good restaurant provides comfort, a place to meet a friend, or a way to celebrate a milestone. Here, some familiar names share their go-to restaurants.

headline: Finding the Deliciousness in New York City
abstract: Sam Sifton, The Times’s Food editor, introduces our first festival that showcases the city’s culinary diversity in Bryant Park.
lead_paragraph: New York City is one of the great food cities, has been for decades, centuries, even as a rising tide of interest in the delicious has made it possible to eat brilliantly in places around the world.

headline: How to Develop an Appetite for Insects
abstract: Scientists who study bugs are thinking harder about how to turn them into good food.
lead_paragraph: Repeat after me: entomophagy.

headline: Twitch Users Watch Billions of Hours of Video, but the Site Wants to Go Beyond Fortnite
abstract: The live-streaming platform, owned by Amazon, has more viewers than many cable channels. But a new ad campaign aims to show it’s good for more than video games.
lead_paragraph: Without video games, Twitch would not be what it is now: a live-streaming platform with millions of devoted viewers and broadcasters, some of them with tattoos of the company’s logo. But the company, which Amazon bought five years ago for more than $1 billion, has ambitions beyond serving fans of Fortnite and World of Warcraft.

headline: ‘Did You Ever Speak to the President About This Complaint?,’ Himes Asks
abstract: Joseph Maguire, the acting director of national intelligence, said he could not reveal the contents of his conversations with President Trump, in response to a question from Representative Jim Himes.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Maguire, the acting director of national intelligence, said he could not reveal the contents of his conversations with President Trump, in response to a question from Representative Jim Himes.

headline: 8 Takeaways From the Whistle-Blower Complaint
abstract: The whistle-blower’s complaint and the inspector general’s report have been released. Here’s what they say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Intelligence Committee on Thursday released a declassified version of a whistle-blower complaint about President Trump’s effort to press the leader of Ukraine to launch an investigation into former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., a leading contender for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: BoomBoom
abstract: We’re in love with MTV’s “Are You the One?”
lead_paragraph: We’re in love with MTV’s dating-reality TV show “Are You the One?” In its eighth season, the show features 16 “sexually fluid” cast members looking to find their “perfect match” and win a million dollars. The show highlights queer relationships in ways we rarely see on TV.

headline: Y/Project: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Y/Project: Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Y/Project: Spring 2020 Collection

headline: Why I Was Wrong to Oppose Impeachment
abstract: I wanted to let voters decide President Trump’s fate in 2020. He has made that impossible.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year on these pages I argued against moving forward with impeachment proceedings against President Trump. From my experience as press secretary to President Bill Clinton, I believed impeaching Mr. Trump could backfire politically for Democrats. More important, I believed impeachment proceedings at that time could have jeopardized a bigger political and policy prize — the collapse of Mr. Trump’s Republican Party and the prospect of progressives controlling the White House and Congress for many years to come.

headline: Canada’s Green Party Doctors a Photo. Opponents Cry Hypocrisy
abstract: A photoshopped image of Canada’s Green Party leader that shows her holding a reusable cup has raised charges of hypocrisy.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s Green Party, which prides itself on its environmentalism, has admitted to photoshopping an image of its leader, Elizabeth May, to show her holding a reusable plastic cup — attracting accusations of hypocrisy from its political opponents.

headline: Plato Cacheris, Washington ‘Super Lawyer’ in Headline Cases, Dies at 90
abstract: If there was a national scandal — Watergate, Iran-contra, “Monica-gate,” the Snowden affair — he got the call. His deal making was legend.

headline: Nick Kyrgios Gets Six Months’ Probation From ATP Tour
abstract: Found to have committed a “major offense” to the tour’s code of conduct, he will not serve an immediate suspension. Instead, he is expected to begin a probationary period on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Nick Kyrgios, the temperamental and talented Australian tennis player, was set to be put on probation for six months by the ATP Tour.

headline: Review: Netflix’s ‘Politician’ Is a Chaos Candidate
abstract: Ryan Murphy’s first series for the streaming platform has the acid humor of “Glee,” but also the flighty attention span.
lead_paragraph: When Netflix signed a mammoth production deal with Ryan Murphy, one natural question was: Which one of him would they get? The big-hearted storyteller of “Pose”? The gore-splashing fabulist of “American Horror Story” and “9-1-1”? The drawn-from-life dramatist of “Feud” and “American Crime Story”?

headline: These Ants Use Germ-Killers, and They’re Better Than Ours
abstract: Parasitic fungi do not seem to develop resistance to the chemicals, suggesting new ways to prevent antibiotic resistance.
lead_paragraph: As a microbiologist, Massimiliano Marvasi has spent years studying how microbes have defeated us. Many pathogens have evolved resistance to penicillin and other antimicrobial drugs, and now public health experts are warning of a global crisis in treating infectious diseases.

headline: England Overwhelms U.S. at Rugby World Cup
abstract: England rolled to a 45-7 victory as the top nations continued to dominate the tournament’s lesser lights.
lead_paragraph: KOBE, Japan — The 20 teams at the Rugby World Cup fall equally into two groups, defined by World Rugby as Tier 1 and Tier 2.

headline: Trump Attacks Whistle-Blower’s Sources and Alludes to Punishment for Spies
abstract: “You know what we used to do in the old days when we were smart with spies and treason, right?” the president asked a room full of American diplomats.
lead_paragraph: President Trump told staff members at the United States Mission to the United Nations on Thursday that he wants to know who provided information to a whistle-blower about his phone call with the president of Ukraine, saying that whoever did so was “close to a spy” and that “in the old days” spies were dealt with differently.

headline: ‘In the Shadow of the Moon’ Review: A Twisty Romp Through Time and Genre
abstract: Jim Mickle’s unconventional serial-killer movie for Netflix is clever, if bloody messy.
lead_paragraph: Netflix’s “In the Shadow of the Moon” gets started with a particularly grisly piece of business. One by one, an assortment of Philadelphians — a bus driver, a classical pianist, the guy grilling up a cheese steak at a greasy spoon — begin bleeding from their orifices before collapsing dead. At least the pianist is thoughtful enough to provide the paradoxically high-tone soundtrack for the carnage.

headline: How a ‘Walking Dead’ Guru Brought ‘Creepshow’ Back to Life
abstract: The 1982 film, directed by George Romero and written by Stephen King, changed Greg Nicotero’s life. Now he has brought the franchise full circle, and invited his old friends.
lead_paragraph: Before he made his name figuring out creative ways for zombies to stalk people, or for serial killers to dismember people, or for cannibal piranhas to eat people, Greg Nicotero had plans to eventually take over his father’s medical practice. Then George Romero called.

headline: Now Rising to the Top of the Beer World: Foam
abstract: That billowy head of bubbles, long dismissed as empty fluff, is finally getting some attention from American brewers.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing fast about the Slow Pour Pils from Bierstadt Lagerhaus. The Denver brewery spends 30 hours brewing the straw-colored pilsner, ferments it for weeks and, finally, makes its taproom customers wait at least five minutes for a taste.

headline: Antonio Brown Says He Wants to Come Back to N.F.L. After All
abstract: The receiver rescinded a pledge to walk away from the league in a Twitter post, saying, ‘why stop now?’
lead_paragraph: About that retirement? Forget it.

headline: Around the Movie World in 17 Days at the New York Film Festival
abstract: This year’s edition includes the latest from Martin Scorsese, Pedro Almodóvar, Kelly Reichardt and Bong Joon-ho.
lead_paragraph: Every fall, the New York Film Festival arrives to remind you of the pleasures of sitting in the dark with a community of movie nuts as new worlds and visions open your mind and blow it. This year’s edition — 153 movies, two dozen talks, assorted free events — offers plenty of chances for mind-and-spirit expansion with new and old movies, short and long. If you’ve never seen Bela Tarr’s seven-hour masterwork, “Satantango,” now’s your chance. The opening-night title — Martin Scorsese’s “The Irishman” — is comparatively fleet at three hours, 29 minutes.

headline: Congress Gives Final Approval to Spending Measure That Would Stave Off Shutdown
abstract: The legislation would give lawmakers an additional two months to iron out differences in the 12 spending bills needed to keep the government funded.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress on Thursday gave final approval to a short-term spending bill that would punt the threat of a government shutdown to just before Thanksgiving, giving lawmakers an additional two months to resolve their differences over paying for President Trump’s policies.

headline: Maaza Mengiste Sings a Modern Song of War
abstract: Namwali Serpell reviews “The Shadow King,” a historical novel set during the Second Italo-Ethiopian War.
lead_paragraph: THE SHADOW KING By Maaza Mengiste

headline: Vaping-Related Illnesses Climb to 805, C.D.C. Says
abstract: The latest weekly tally includes 275 more reports of patients sickened, in 46 states. There are now 12 deaths linked to vaping-related lung injuries.
lead_paragraph: The number of people with lung illnesses linked to vaping has risen to 805, from last week’s figure of 530 cases, and 12 people have died, compared to a total of seven last week, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Thursday.

headline: McDonald’s to Test Plant-Based Burgers in Canada
abstract: The chain’s new “P.L.T.” sandwich — plant, lettuce and tomato — will be sold at 28 restaurants.
lead_paragraph: McDonald’s will offer a plant-based burger made by Beyond Meat at some of its locations in Canada, the fast-food giant said on Thursday, marking the company’s first foray into the growing market for meat alternatives in North America.

headline: Security Tightens Over Protests in Egypt
abstract: Several small anti-government protests broke out in Egypt, despite a pre-emptive crackdown in which nearly 2,000 Egyptians were arrested.
lead_paragraph: [Read more about Friday’s protests in Egypt.]

headline: BBC Rebukes Anchor Who Criticized Trump ‘Go Back’ Tweet. Now, It’s Under Fire.
abstract: The reprimand of a morning anchor, Naga Munchetty, for her remarks about the American president and racism, outraged many.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The BBC was taken to task on Thursday after it ruled that one of its veteran television anchors had broken the company’s editorial guidelines by criticizing President Trump for   saying that four female American lawmakers should return to the “broken and crime-infested places from which they came.”

headline: Ann Demeulemeester: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Ann Demeulemeester: Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Ann Demeulemeester: Spring 2020 Collection

headline: White House Knew of Whistle-Blower’s Allegations Soon After Trump’s Call With Ukraine Leader
abstract: The whistle-blower, a C.I.A. officer detailed to the White House at one point, first expressed his concerns anonymously to the agency’s top lawyer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House learned that a C.I.A. officer had lodged allegations against President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine even as the officer’s whistle-blower complaint was moving through a process meant to protect him against reprisals, people familiar with the matter said on Thursday.

headline: G.M. Restores Workers’ Health Coverage as Strike Continues
abstract: With the United Auto Workers walkout in its 11th day, the company reversed a decision to cut off employees’ medical insurance at the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said Thursday that it would continue health care coverage for striking workers, reversing an earlier decision, as the company and the United Auto Workers union negotiated a new labor contract.

headline: How $2,000 in Yankees Tickets Show Weinstein’s New Trial Strategy
abstract: Defense lawyers will seek to raise police misconduct allegations, including that a sergeant on the case accepted tickets from a lawyer for one of Harvey Weinstein’s accusers.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: It’s a funny thing, working on the Books desk of The Times. When momentous news is loosed on the world — when hurricanes strike, or protesters mass, or governments tremble and fall — we follow it as avidly as any well-informed person with an interest in the course of human events. We refresh our screens; we gather in conference rooms to watch the speeches or the flames. We wonder what it will all amount to. But when we get back to work, our job is to forget all that. Let others work the phones or cultivate sources in search of the next White House scoop. We have books to read.

headline: 18 New Books to Watch For in October
abstract: Ronan Farrow’s exposé about power, stories by Zadie Smith, a former C.I.A. agent’s tell-all and more.
lead_paragraph: It’s another big month for books.

headline: For One L.P.G.A. Golfer, a Million-Dollar Prize Is Worth the Pain
abstract: Lee-Anne Pace is clinging to the lead in the race for one of the biggest paydays in women’s golf. Will her body hold up?
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The South African golfer Lee-Anne Pace was ready to retire this spring. She had been on the road for more than a decade, her body ached almost constantly, and her peaks, which included topping the Ladies European Tour’s money list in 2010, seemed like specks in a rearview mirror.

headline: Review: Plácido Domingo Is Gone, but He Still Haunted ‘Macbeth’
abstract: You have to admire the Met’s intrepid cast, chorus and orchestra for rallying. But they seemed affected by an 11th-hour upheaval.
lead_paragraph: For regulars at the Metropolitan Opera, alarms immediately go off when an usher hands you a program with a white slip of paper inserted. “Uh oh, someone’s not singing,” you think. “What happened?”

headline: Cecilia Chiang, a Pioneering Restaurateur, Marks a Century of Flavors
abstract: Turning 99, the San Francisco chef who changed the way Americans regarded Chinese cuisine, is still a joyful force in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On her 99th birthday, Cecilia Chiang wore a leopard-print silk shirt and black trousers, slipped on two thick, glittering cocktail rings, and met her granddaughter for an early lunch at Yank Sing, in Rincon Center.

headline: Israeli Arab Faction Explains Why It Didn’t Back Netanyahu’s Rival
abstract: The leader of Balad, part of the Joint Arab List bloc in Israel’s Knesset, said the differences between Benjamin Netanyahu and Benny Gantz were minor.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli Arab party that broke with its allies and refused to back Benny Gantz, the former army chief, as Israel’s next leader said Thursday that his policies were “virtually indistinguishable” from those of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is widely reviled by the country’s Arab minority.

headline: Eugene Scalia Confirmed by Senate as Labor Secretary
abstract: The nominee has long been a lawyer for corporate clients, and critics asked whether he could be a sufficient advocate for American workers.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Thursday confirmed Eugene Scalia, a longtime lawyer representing corporations, to be labor secretary.

headline: Rick Owens: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Rick Owens: Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Rick Owens: Spring 2020 Collection

headline: Judy Garland Is Back! (For Some of Us, She Never Went Away)
abstract: The new film “Judy” offers another chance to bask in her glory, 50 years after the demise of her fairy tale gone wrong.
lead_paragraph: What is it about the magical career and tragic ending of Judy Garland that rivets us half a century after her death? Why is she a saint-like icon for gay men and other devotees? And who isn’t a fan? Well, certainly nobody’s trolley I’d want to clang.

headline: Trump’s E.P.A. Chooses Rodents Over People
abstract: The agency will curtail its reliance on animal testing, putting public health at risk.
lead_paragraph: Snowball, the pig in George Orwell’s “Animal Farm,” uses this catchy adage to summarize his view that people are enemies and animals are friends: “Four legs good, two legs bad.” Bizarrely, the Trump administration appears to have been persuaded, announcing a policy that will harm human health to protect animals used in laboratory experiments. The move will compromise an important source of evidence of the impacts of contaminants.

headline: Film Club: ‘Dancing in the Air With 9-Foot Stilts’
abstract: Why is creative expression essential to life?
lead_paragraph: Why is creative expression essential to life?

headline: What Students Are Saying About: The Bystander Effect, Fraying Friendships, and Endless Wars
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: In our writing prompts on The Learning Network, we love to ask teenagers about jovial topics like their favorite scents and their most memorable neighborhood celebrations. But we don’t shy away from the more challenging ones either.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Oct. 2, 2019
abstract: Here are two graphs that measure education success differently.
lead_paragraph: These graphs originally appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com. By Friday morning, October 4, we will provide the “Reveal” — the graphs’ free online link, additional background and questions, shout outs highlighting student comments and headlines, and Stat Nuggets.

headline: The Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry: What We Know So Far
abstract: A whistle-blower complaint about President Trump’s call with the leader of Ukraine, in which he asked for help investigating political rivals, has stirred a storm. Here’s how to catch up.
lead_paragraph: Washington has been roiled by revelations about President Trump’s contacts with the Ukrainian president. A whistle-blower complaint alleges that Mr. Trump tried to press Ukraine to interfere in the 2020 election by investigating a rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. The report prompted House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to announce a formal impeachment inquiry against the president.

headline: Brace Yourself for the Internet Impeachment
abstract: Disinformation experts are preparing for fast-twitch media manipulation, droves of false and misleading claims and hyper-polarized audiences fiercely clinging to their side’s version of reality.
lead_paragraph: Even before the impeachment inquiry against President Trump was announced on Tuesday, the president’s re-election campaign blasted an email to supporters, urging them to defend Mr. Trump against the “baseless and disgusting attacks.” Facebook quickly filled with ads for impeachment-themed merchandise, including $3 “Impeach Now!” bumper stickers and $35 “Impeach This!” T-shirts. In a private chat room, pro-Trump internet trolls discussed which memes, videos and news stories to push on social media in order to reclaim the narrative.

headline: Finding Wine and Meaning in Ancient Vineyards
abstract: Old vines are cultural treasures that deepen our understanding and the ties between present and past, as these wines from Chile’s Itata Valley do.
lead_paragraph: All over the world, treasures for wine lovers have been hiding in plain sight, unnoticed or unimagined.

headline: Argentine Malbecs, With an Eye Toward Terroir
abstract: This category of wine has become the generic red of bars and restaurants. But what can it be when made with careful, conscientious intent?
lead_paragraph: Itata Valley cinsault may be a niche wine. But you can’t say that about our next subject, malbec from the Mendoza region of Argentina.

headline: The Memo About Trump’s Ukraine Call
abstract: Readers cite both “The Godfather” and “The Simpsons” as they discuss the president’s request for a Biden investigation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic has recommendations, including the new season debut of “Bob’s Burgers.”
lead_paragraph: ‘Bob’s Burgers’When to watch: Sunday at 9 p.m., on Fox.

headline: Off-White : Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Off-White: Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Off-White: Spring 2020 Collection

headline: ‘Everything You’re Seeing Is Deception’: How Right-Wing Media Talks About Impeachment
abstract: The pro-Trump media has wasted no time constructing its own version of events about Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Mark Levin, the talk radio host who has been one of President Trump’s most ardent defenders, tried to offer his listeners some reassurance this week as they processed the dizzying developments in Washington. “There’s a lot of disinformation and misinformation,” he warned. “I’m here to help us walk through this and defend this nation against a tyranny in our midst.”

headline: Impeachment, Boeing, Climate Change: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Allegations of a "cover-up" and election interference
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: SoftBank Bet Big on Disruptive Companies. Many Have Not Paid Off.
abstract: The Japanese technology company’s investments in WeWork, Uber, Sprint and other businesses have produced disappointing results, raising questions about how it picks companies.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has taken an Uber, sent a Slack message or enjoyed a free beer at a WeWork owes a little something to Masayoshi Son.

headline: Cooking, Tasting, Talking
abstract: We interviewed the chefs and owners of more than two dozen of the city’s best restaurants who are participating in The New York Times Food Festival.
lead_paragraph: We interviewed the chefs and owners of more than two dozen of the city’s best restaurants who are participating in The New York Times Food Festival.

headline: Jennifer Lopez and Shakira to Perform at Super Bowl LIV
abstract: A year after artists shunned the N.F.L., the league formed a partnership with Jay-Z to attract top musical talent.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lopez and Shakira will perform at the Super Bowl in Miami in February as the N.F.L. tries to restore the cachet of its halftime show.

headline: New U.S. Aid to Saudi Arabia Will Include 200 Troops
abstract: The small deployment of defensive military hardware is tepid in comparison to some of the remarks leveled by American officials after the Sept. 14 strikes on Saudi oil fields.
lead_paragraph: The United States military is sending roughly 200 troops, a surface-to-air missile battery and several advanced radars to Saudi Arabia, the Pentagon said in a statement Thursday, after well-orchestrated attacks this month on a Saudi oil refinery that United States and Saudi officials blamed on Iran.

headline: Deep Looking, With Vija Celmins
abstract: A ravishing retrospective of art, both intimate and cosmic, is at the Met Breuer. Bring your nose close. Let it slow you down.
lead_paragraph: In the 1960s art world, illusion was a dirty word. The old tradition of a painting as a window onto imaginary realities seemed beyond exhausted — just more proof of painting’s death. Abstract painting was tolerated, especially if big and flatly painted so that it was undeniably an object. Magic and poetry were banished. “What you see is what you see,” said the young Frank Stella, the moment’s dominant painter.

headline: Review: A Spellbinding ‘Antigone,’ Both Timeless and Urgent
abstract: An easily legible production of the ancient Greek tragedy borrows from the tradition of Noh theater at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: They make the gentlest rippling sound, these candlelit figures gliding ever so slowly through the water, perambulating around a spare scattering of boulders. In a vast, shallow pool, beneath the high-arched ceiling of the Park Avenue Armory’s Wade Thompson Drill Hall, the hems of their filmy white kimonos trail along the surface.

headline: Former M.M.A. Fighter Returns to U.S. to Face Charges in 2011 Killing
abstract: Ariel Gandulla returned voluntarily from Canada this week to face charges of murder, conspiracy and kidnapping in Miami-Dade County, Fla. Four other men have been charged in the case.
lead_paragraph: On June 1, 2011, officers with the Miami-Dade Police Department went to investigate a brush fire in a desolate area near the Everglades. Instead, they found a murder.

headline: Something Classified Was Scheduled at Guantánamo. A Judge Stopped It.
abstract: What it was remains a mystery, and a federal court provided no information in halting it. Welcome to the military commission system.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: Who Paid for the N.R.A.’s ‘Special Projects’ Trip to Russia?
abstract: Internal emails and a tangle of reimbursements raise new questions about a visit to Russia by N.R.A. board members and supporters.
lead_paragraph: In January, as congressional investigators were examining a trip to Russia by a delegation of its board members and supporters, the National Rifle Association issued a statement of disavowal.

headline: ‘How Did We Miss Him?’: Student Death Prompts Inquiries in New Zealand
abstract: The body of a male student was discovered Monday evening at a campus residence in Christchurch, reportedly weeks after his death.
lead_paragraph: The body of a male New Zealand college student went undiscovered in his room at a campus residence complex, possibly for weeks, according to local news reports.

headline: 12 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 6 Classical Music Concerts to See in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 25 Art Exhibitions to View in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.
lead_paragraph: ‘ARTISTIC LICENSE: SIX TAKES ON THE GUGGENHEIM COLLECTION’ at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum (through Jan. 12). Displays that artists select from a museum’s collection are almost inevitably interesting, revealing and valuable. After all, artists can be especially discerning regarding work not their own. Here, six artists — Cai Guo-Qiang, Paul Chan, Richard Prince, Julie Mehretu, Carrie Mae Weems and Jenny Holzer — guided by specific themes, have chosen, which multiplies the impact accordingly. With one per ramp, each selection turns the museum inside out. The combination sustains multiple visits; the concept should be applied regularly. (Roberta Smith) 212-423-3840, guggenheim.org

lead_paragraph: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: Theodore Olson, Conservative Stalwart, to Represent ‘Dreamers’ in Supreme Court
abstract: Mr. Olson argued for the winning sides in Bush v. Gore and Citizens United and was a leader in the fight for a right to same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The young immigrants known as “Dreamers” have gained an unlikely ally in the Supreme Court.

abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

abstract: Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

abstract: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: Why The Times Published Details of the Whistle-Blower’s Identity
abstract: Our executive editor, Dean Baquet, addresses readers’ concerns about the decision to publish information on a person who is central to the Trump impeachment inquiry.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, The Times published exclusive details about the identity of the whistle-blower whose claims led Democrats to begin an impeachment inquiry against President Trump this week. (The article reported that the whistle-blower is a C.I.A. officer who was previously detailed to work at the White House and had expertise on Ukraine.)

headline: U.S. Concludes Syria Used Chemical Weapons in May Attack
abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stopped short of threatening a military response against President Bashar al-Assad’s government for the chlorine-loaded rocket attack.
lead_paragraph: The United States has concluded that Syria used chlorine gas in an attack against rebels last May, saying Thursday that it was the latest use of chemical weapons by President Bashar al-Assad’s government in the eight-year civil war but stopping short of threatening a military response.

headline: Occupy Detroit: A Look at 90 Years of Auto Strikes
abstract: Walkouts and sit-ins by the United Automobile Workers over the decades helped secure contracts that lifted members into the middle class.
lead_paragraph: After 11 days and no deal, United Automobile Workers members are still on strike at General Motors factories across the United States. The strike is the longest walkout at G.M. since 1970, when workers halted assembly lines for 67 days.

headline: How Did Ukraine Land in the Middle of an American Political Drama?
abstract: For the second time in three years, Ukraine has been caught in the glare of American news cameras.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in three years, Ukraine, the former Soviet republic between Russia and the West, has been caught in the glare of American news cameras because of an American political drama. In 2016, the spotlight was trained on the campaign chairman for Donald J. Trump, then the Republican candidate for president, and the aide’s  undisclosed business with a pro-Russia political party.

headline: Trump Slashes Refugee Cap to 18,000, Curtailing U.S. Role as Haven
abstract: The president approved an 18,000-person limit on the number of refugees who can be admitted into the United States in fiscal 2020, about half the current limit of 30,000.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has decided to slash the American refugee program by almost half, greatly dimming the United States’ role in accepting persecuted refugees from most parts of the world, the State Department announced Thursday.

headline: Tekashi69 Courted Gang Life. Then Reality Became Too Real.
abstract: The rapper’s testimony about the Nine Trey Gangsta Bloods showed how social media has upended the traditional relationship between hip-hop and gangs.
lead_paragraph: Setting out to film the video for “Gummo” in the summer of 2017, the rapper 6ix9ine, then largely unknown, had a vision in mind. He spoke with a member of the Nine Trey Gangsta Bloods who he’d just met, and asked for some set decoration.

headline: Whistle-Blower, Boeing, Labradoodles: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Spies and Treason’: Read a Transcript of Trump’s Remarks Related to the Whistle-Blower
abstract: President Trump made remarks to the United States Mission to the United Nations on Thursday, the same day a House committee released a declassified version of a complaint.
lead_paragraph: President Trump addressed a crowd from the United States Mission to the United Nations on Thursday. Mr. Trump discussed a range of topics, including a whistle-blower complaint against him that says he tried to compel the president of Ukraine to help him in the 2020 presidential election.

headline: Anthony Mancinelli, World’s Oldest Working Barber, Dies at 108
abstract: A barber who spent nearly a century of cutting hair in upstate New York “didn’t know the meaning of the word retired.”
lead_paragraph: When Anthony Mancinelli became a barber nearly a century ago, Warren Harding was in the White House, a haircut cost 25 cents and leeches were still used to treat high blood pressure.

headline: George Lardner Jr., 85, Dies; Reported on His Daughter’s Murder
abstract: She was shot to death by a former boyfriend. He wrote about it for The Washington Post. His article won a Pulitzer Prize.
lead_paragraph: George Lardner Jr., a Washington Post reporter who won a Pulitzer Prize for his monthslong investigation into the murder of his 21-year-old daughter by a former boyfriend, died on Saturday in a hospice facility in Aldie, Va. He was 85.

headline: Do We Need a Wealth Tax?
abstract: Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren have proposed taxing the fortunes of America’s richest.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: The Artist Creating a New Mythology for the North Pole
abstract: Inspired by her own journey to the Arctic Circle, Himali Singh Soin upends traditional stories of exploration in her new commission for Frieze.
lead_paragraph: In her sunlit live-work space overlooking Brick Lane in East London, the artist Himali Singh Soin is spinning a narrative about the farthest reaches of our planet. Singh Soin, a poet and artist from north-central India, has spent the past couple of years contemplating, among other things, the earth’s polar caps. “It’s a blank screen to project so much on it, it’s almost asking for hyperbole and fantasy,” she says. “These two spaces seem like the closest to outer space.”

headline: Netanyahu’s Amazing Reversal: Election Loser to Presumptive Premier
abstract: A week after an election appeared to jeopardize his career, Prime Minister Netanyahu is tapped to assemble a government. Israelis are wondering how it happened.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Even in a country whose politics are routinely fractious and confusing, many Israelis were scratching their heads on Thursday.

headline: Why Doesn’t This Impeachment Moment Have a Name?
abstract: Is it impeachment … gate? How will we remember this moment, without a “gate”?
lead_paragraph: For the last few decades, we’ve appended the suffix “gate” to basically any scandal, mostly political, but not exclusively — Donutgate, Nipplegate, Gamergate. (Wikipedia has a list; it’s huge.) The names seemed to write themselves.

headline: Trump’s Efforts to Push Ukraine Toward a Biden Inquiry: A Timeline
abstract: A guide to the key figures and dates as President Trump and his allies pressured Ukraine to investigate his political opponents.
lead_paragraph: A guide to the key figures and dates as President Trump and his allies pressured Ukraine to investigate his political opponents.

headline: Facebook Tests Hiding ‘Likes’ on Social Media Posts
abstract: The social network, which has been under fire for extreme content on its site, said it was testing making Likes to posts private in Australia.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, people who use Facebook, Instagram and Twitter have chased Likes as a status symbol. More Likes on a social media post meant it was popular, engaging and worthwhile.

headline: Impeachment Inquiry Intensifies With Testimony, Accusations and Attacks
abstract: The acting director of national intelligence testified. Speaker Nancy Pelosi accused the White House of a cover-up and President Trump suggested punishing the sources used in a whistle-blower’s complaint against him.
lead_paragraph: The acting director of national intelligence testified. Speaker Nancy Pelosi accused the White House of a cover-up and President Trump suggested punishing the sources used in a whistle-blower’s complaint against him.

headline: Discrimination Against L.G.B.T.Q. Employees
abstract: A risk to L.G.B.T. Americans’ health. Also: A Jewish relic from a death camp; women who have been abused.

headline: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Impeachment
abstract: Whether you were afraid to ask or not, we have answers.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox.

headline: Wall Street Deflates America’s Favorite Start-Ups
abstract: Companies like WeWork and Uber were expected to become a new generation of corporate giants. But investors have backed away.
lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be the year when America’s biggest start-ups would finally make their triumphant debut on the stock market.

headline: 11,168 Children Tested Positive for Lead. The City Didn’t Inspect the Homes.
abstract: A new report highlighted systemic failures slowing New York City from eradicating lead paint from its aging housing.
lead_paragraph: As a lead-paint crisis engulfed New York City’s public housing system last year, Mayor Bill de Blasio defended his administration by repeatedly pointing to data showing that the number of children citywide with high levels of lead in their blood was actually at historic lows.

headline: Trump Calls Whistle-Blower’s Source ‘Close to a Spy’
abstract: President Trump made remarks to the United States Mission to the United Nations on Thursday, the same day a House committee released a declassified version of a complaint.
lead_paragraph: President Trump made remarks to the United States Mission to the United Nations on Thursday, the same day a House committee released a declassified version of a complaint.

headline: Yes, Trump Is Guilty, but Impeachment Is a Mistake
abstract: This political brawl will leave Trump victorious.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump committed an impeachable offense on that call with the Ukrainian president. But that doesn’t mean Democrats are right to start an impeachment process.

headline: Impeaching Trump Is Good for the Economy
abstract: It will slow down the administration’s war on competence.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing the tweeter in chief believes, it is that what’s good for Donald Trump is good for America. A little over a month ago (although it seems like much longer) he told a rally that “you have no choice but to vote for me,” because his electoral defeat would lead to a market crash.

headline: Trump Organization Receives Approval to Expand Golf Resort in Scotland
abstract: The president’s company plans to build 500 homes, 50 hotel cottages, and sports and retail complexes near Aberdeen, despite intense opposition from residents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite opposition from many local residents, the Trump Organization on Thursday received approval in Scotland for what will be the largest new company-financed real estate development project since President Trump was elected: a major expansion of its golf resort near the northeast port city of Aberdeen.

headline: Phil Scott Is First G.O.P. Governor to Back Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: Mr. Scott, a moderate from Vermont who has broken with President Trump in the past, said he hoped the House would go “wherever the facts lead.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Phil Scott of Vermont on Thursday endorsed the impeachment inquiry against President Trump, becoming the first Republican governor to do so.

headline: Looming Presence in Drug Conspiracy Case: Honduras’s President
abstract: President Juan Orlando Hernández, who won’t be at his brother’s U.S. trial, has been accused of using trafficking to “help assert power and control in Honduras.”
lead_paragraph: When a former Honduran congressman goes on trial next week in Manhattan, charged with conspiring to import cocaine into the United States, his older brother will be absent from the courtroom but will loom large over the case.

headline: N.B.A. Will Get to the Bottom of How Tall Its Players Are
abstract: A rule will require teams to verify a player’s height and age, ending a quirky tradition of size being a matter of opinion.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: Why Can’t We Get Rid of Bad Sheriffs?
abstract: They have little accountability and a lot of power.
lead_paragraph: A North Carolina prosecutor last week filed felony charges against Brindell Wilkins, the sheriff of Granville County, N.C. According to the indictment, a former deputy had recorded Sheriff Wilkins making racist comments and threatened to make them public. To protect his reputation, Sheriff Wilkins allegedly tried to hire a hit man to kill the deputy. This plan was concealed for years until recorded phone calls emerged between Sheriff Wilkins and the would-be killer.

headline: Trump-Rouhani Meeting Was a Near Miss, but Iran Leaves the Door Open
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani did not dismiss the idea that a meeting with the American leader was entirely possible — under conditions set by the Iranians.
lead_paragraph: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran never met President Trump in New York this week. It was a near miss, according to European officials, who were desperately trying to avert a conflict by putting the two adversaries together in a room and hoping for the best.

headline: How the Climate Kids Are Short-Circuiting Right-Wing Media
abstract: Young people like Greta Thunberg are participating in the culture wars while also managing to float above the fray.
lead_paragraph: The kids aren’t just all right — they’re scrambling the brains of their political enemies.

headline: Whistle-Blower Shines Light on Super-Secret N.S.C. Computer System
abstract: The complaint alleges that the National Security Council took an extra and previously unknown step to shield President Trump’s call with the Ukrainian leader from all but a very small number of officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the White House first released the reconstructed transcript of President Trump’s July 25 phone conversation with the president of Ukraine, some former government officials noticed something peculiar about it.

headline: As Republicans Face Impeachment Dilemma, Romney Is a Lonely Voice of Concern
abstract: With most Republicans rushing to defend President Trump against an impeachment push, a “deeply troubled” Mitt Romney stands apart.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As House Democrats push forward with an impeachment inquiry into President Trump, Republicans have largely rushed to Mr. Trump’s defense, or at least tempered their criticism to avoid his furious reprisals.

headline: Louisiana’s Coast Is Vanishing. Can a Mining Company’s $100 Million Offer Help Save It?
abstract: Freeport-McMoRan’s deal to resolve claims that its aggressive drilling damaged the coast could lead to more. But oil giants like BP, ExxonMobil and Shell have bristled at the idea.
lead_paragraph: Coastal Louisiana parishes announced on Thursday that they had reached a deal with a mining company over claims that its aggressive drilling for oil damaged the state’s vanishing coast, a settlement that could lead to other agreements with energy giants as the state scrambles to stop its disastrous land loss.

headline: Anxious Biden Allies May Unleash Super PAC
abstract: Wary of the former vice president’s slipping poll numbers and the onslaught of attacks from President Trump, some Biden supporters want him to embrace a super PAC.
lead_paragraph: Allies of Joseph R. Biden Jr., concerned about his slipping poll numbers in the Democratic presidential primary and an onslaught of attacks from President Trump, are weighing whether to mobilize a super PAC supporting Mr. Biden and have held conversations with wealthy donors to gauge their interest in contributing money.

headline: Trump Said Ukraine Envoy Would ‘Go Through Some Things.’ She Has Already.
abstract: Marie Yovanovitch was forced out as ambassador after Trump allies called her disloyal. Others say she fell victim to the president’s efforts to hurt Joe Biden.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Follow our live coverage of Marie Yovanovitch’s public hearing in the impeachment inquiry.

headline: Just How Corrupt Is Bill Barr?
abstract: Trump’s attorney general is implicated in the Ukraine scandal, but refuses to recuse.
lead_paragraph: Trump’s attorney general is implicated in the Ukraine scandal, but refuses to recuse.

headline: Ryan Murphy, Super Producer, Reboots Himself for Netflix and ‘The Politician’
abstract: To create his first Netflix series, which starts streaming on Friday, Mr. Murphy ripped up his playbook and tried some new narrative tricks to encourage binge-watching.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ryan Murphy, the prolific television producer behind “American Horror Story,” “American Crime Story” and “Pose,” had a plan for the moment his first Netflix series would become available.

headline: Complaint in Hand, Democrats Aim for a Fast, and Focused, Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: Lawmakers said they could potentially draft articles of impeachment over Ukraine by the end of October.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A crucial cache of evidence in hand, House Democrats moved quickly on Thursday with an impeachment inquiry they said would be focused tightly on President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine, using an incendiary whistle-blower complaint as a road map for their investigation.

headline: Man Who Berated Woman Over Puerto Rico Shirt Is Convicted of Hate Crimes
abstract: The man faces up to five years in prison after the encounter in a Chicago park last year.
lead_paragraph: A Chicago man who was seen last year in a widely viewed video berating a woman in a city park for wearing a T-shirt with the Puerto Rican flag was convicted this week of two felony hate crime charges.

headline: It Gets a Party Started
abstract: Jack Mowat makes a tasty, twisty debut.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This is a very cool, self-assured debut by a young guy with a very cool name, if you’re at all a fan of wilderness literature and thought of a mash-up of Jack London and Farley Mowat. I solved this grid and went to xwordinfo to check out Jack Mowat’s earlier constructions, since I didn’t recognize the name; finding nothing there, I went to Google to learn more about his puzzles. It turns out that this very puzzle and its constructor made the local news when it was first accepted, which is pretty neat.

headline: Review: Peter Brook Asks the Ultimate Question in ‘Why?’
abstract: A new work from one of the indisputably great directors is partly a tribute to theater and partly a warning about theatricality.
lead_paragraph: Though he has been a director for 70 years, Peter Brook doesn’t like to call himself that. He prefers “distiller”: someone who boils away everything extraneous to render the essence of the story he’s telling.

headline: In Trump’s Ukraine Phone Call, Alarmed Aides Saw Trouble
abstract: The alarm among officials who heard the exchange between President Trump and his Ukrainian counterpart led to an extraordinary effort to keep many more people from learning about it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No one bothered to put special limits on the number of people allowed to sit in the “listening room” in the White House to monitor the phone call because it was expected to be routine. By the time the call was over 30 minutes later, it quickly became clear that it was anything but.

headline: The Concussion Crisis in Australian Rules Football
abstract: It’s a brutal game, and retired players are suffering the consequences of hits to the head. But the league there is following a familiar playbook, one used by the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Australian rules football is one of the world’s most violent sports. Thirty-six players careen across a massive field, where they are exposed to blindside hits and errant elbows, bruising shoulders and airborne knees. Their protection is a mouthpiece and sometimes a padded cap. Collisions can be cringe-inducing. Concussions are common.

headline: What It’s Really Like to Eat Your Way Around the Globe
abstract: Our Australia critic went on a whirlwind dining tour for two magazines. Here’s what happened.
lead_paragraph: On Mother’s Day, I lay sprawled across a bed on the top floor of a riad in the middle of a medina in Morocco, trying desperately to remember where I’d woken up that morning.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Ally on Right Will Help ‘Dreamers’ in Legal Fight
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 27, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “This government acts in a manner that is almost the definition of arbitrary and capricious. It’s ready, shoot, aim.”

headline: Corrections: September 27, 2019
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, September 27, 2019.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, September 27, 2019.

headline: Impeachment, Chirac, Boris Johnson: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Gift of the Missing Men
abstract: A long line of absentee fathers taught me a lesson in love that was hard to undo. It also gave me a powerful tribe of matriarchs.
lead_paragraph: I am the daughter of a “holiday man,” a term my grandmother used to describe three generations of our family’s absentee fathers who, like clockwork, would return around Christmas before disappearing again to whereabouts unknown.

headline: Locast, a Free Streaming Service, Sues ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox
abstract: The nonprofit behind the app, which relays broadcast feeds online, claims the networks have colluded in an effort to shut it down.
lead_paragraph: Locast, a little-known nonprofit behind a free streaming service, sued ABC, NBC, CBS and Fox on Friday, alleging that the television networks colluded in an effort to chill its business.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘The Politician’ and ‘Creepshow’
abstract: Ben Platt and Gwyneth Paltrow star in a new Netflix series. And a new horror anthology series is streaming on Shudder.
lead_paragraph: THE POLITICIAN Stream on Netflix. Ryan Murphy, the TV creator whose disparate curriculum vitae includes “Glee,” “American Crime Story” and “Pose” (to name a few), makes his Netflix debut with this lustrous new series, which stars the Broadway darling Ben Platt. Platt plays Payton Hobart, a Santa Barbara, Calif., teenager of staggering privilege who is running for student body president at his high school — a race Payton sees as an early step in his plan to eventually make it to the White House. The lavish setting comes with a lavish cast: In addition to Platt, the series stars Gwyneth Paltrow (Payton’s wealthy mother), Zoey Deutch (his running mate), Jessica Lange (her grandmother) and, later in the season, Bette Midler and Judith Light. “Often there seems to be nothing but ideas, raised and dispensed with, elbowing aside character, emotional momentum and story coherence,” James Poniewozik wrote in his review for The New York Times. “The series has enough wit and visual style, though, that it’s a pleasure to watch in the moment — just as long as you don’t think beyond the moment.”

headline: Hong Kong and the Independence Movement That Doesn’t Know Itself
abstract: The protesters are more radical than they realize. Just like during the 2014 Umbrella Revolution.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Exactly five years ago, the Umbrella Movement broke out to demand respect for Hong Kong’s democratic freedoms. After it ended, having obtained no concessions from the local government or the Chinese authorities, political time accelerated in the city.

headline: Are the Kids Alright in the Era of Climate Change?
abstract: The dissonance between slow action by politicians and increasing urgency from scientists has made young people more angry than anxious.
lead_paragraph: The Australia Letter is a weekly newsletter from our Australia bureau. Sign up to get it by email. This week’s issue is written by Isabella Kwai, a reporter with the Australia bureau.

headline: Word + Quiz: reveille
abstract: This word has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

headline: British-Flagged Tanker Leaves Iran, Two Months After It Was Seized
abstract: The Stena Impero, which Iranian authorities impounded in July, was heading to Dubai, where crew members will undergo medical checks.
lead_paragraph: The British-flagged oil tanker that was seized by Iran two months ago left port with its crew, sailed into international waters in the Strait of Hormuz and headed for Dubai on Friday, bringing an end to at least one source of contention between Iran and the West.

headline: Smash ’Em, Bake ’Em or Sit on ’Em: The Inexact Science of Breaking In Gloves
abstract: Even major league fielders struggle to find that perfect shape for their most important defensive tool. And despite plenty of technology in the game, old-school techniques still reign.
lead_paragraph: To break in a new first baseman’s glove, Pete Alonso, the Mets’ rookie slugger, sat down at his Citi Field locker, slipped his left hand inside and punched the pocket with his right fist six times. He then paused to assess  the mitt’s malleability.

headline: ‘Show Us You Are Not Racist’: Students Demand Answers After Dean’s Resignation
abstract: A black dean at the University of Alabama resigned after old tweets were recirculated, a move that prompted a sit-in at the president’s office, a letter of admonishment and a reckoning.
lead_paragraph: [For more coverage of race, sign up here to have our Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.]

headline: Why Construction Noise Is Keeping You Up at 3 A.M.
abstract: A building boom in New York City means that more cacophonous construction is being done overnight. A proposal would lower the volume.
lead_paragraph: It barely mattered, night or day, weekend or not, when the clangor of old metal cabinets being heaved into dumpsters would invade Michael Riley’s Manhattan apartment, disrupting all manner of peace.

headline: It’s Manhattan’s Last Affordable Neighborhood. But for How Long?
abstract: Inwood has the lowest average rents in the borough. Now developers and their high-rise buildings are coming.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Inwood has been one of New York City’s untouched gems. Nestled among rivers and rolling forest at the northernmost tip of Manhattan, the 500-acre neighborhood has again and again batted away the forces of gentrification — until now.

headline: This Week’s News Quiz: Impeachment, United Nations, Emmy Awards
abstract: Did you stay up to date this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you stay up to date this week?

headline: Trump and Ukraine: What Could ‘Play Ball’ Mean?
abstract: “O.K., Ukraine. You gotta play ball, O.K.? And I mean let me get to second base, O.K.?” Stephen Colbert joked.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Young People Are Going to Save Us All From Office Life’
abstract: In this lesson, students explore how Gen Z-ers and millennials are changing the workplace. Are these changes good for all workers?
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Young People Are Going to Save Us All From Office Life”

headline: Afghanistan Presidential Vote Presses On Despite Concerns About Legitimacy
abstract: Accusations of systemic fraud and fears of Taliban threats have compromised an election that is likely to have the fewest voters since the first presidential vote in 2004.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Elections in Afghanistan have become increasingly chaotic spectacles since the country’s first presidential vote in 2004. Each has proved more corrupt and compromised than the last, calling into question whether ambitions for a Western-style democracy can survive in a country consumed by war.

headline: How Do You Rewrite the ABCs? The Secrets of Songwriting on ‘Sesame Street’
abstract: “Sesame Street” has been teaching the ABCs for 50 years with music. Elmo, Usher and the writing team tell us how they create some of the best-known songs in educational media.
lead_paragraph: “Sesame Street” has been teaching the ABCs for 50 years with music. Elmo, Usher and the writing team tell us how they create some of the best-known songs in educational media.

headline: Social Mania
abstract: His bipolar episodes were unpredictable in every way, except for how predictably they manifested on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: My brother Roland’s Facebook post set off a flurry of concern throughout his social network.

headline: Who’s Irish Now?
abstract: The Rose of Tralee International Festival takes stock of Irish manners and Irish meanings.
lead_paragraph: TRALEE, Ireland — Ask about the Rose of Tralee International Festival, held each year in this west coast town in County Kerry, and participants will immediately tell you what it’s not.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Muscles, Coffee and Sleep
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Where Do We Stand on the Exclamation Point?
abstract: Some people who have been told to avoid them are wondering. (The rest of us don’t care!)
lead_paragraph: Meredith Golden says that finding your soulmate on Tinder is easy, as long as you swear off one vice. It isn’t cigarettes or cheese fries. It’s slimmer, sneakier. That cardinal sin: the exclamation point.

headline: The Inscrutable Mike Pence
abstract: Tom LoBianco’s “Piety and Power” tells us what there is to know about the vice president, which is far from everything.
lead_paragraph: PIETY AND POWERMike Pence and the Taking of the White HouseBy Tom LoBianco

headline: Do You Believe Aliens Exist?
abstract: People are flocking to Area 51, a secretive military facility in the desert of Nevada, in search of aliens. Do you think there is intelligent life on other planets?
lead_paragraph: Did you hear about the meme-inspired Facebook event encouraging people to “storm Area 51,” a secret military site that has long been rumored — in television shows, movies and online forums — to be the home of extraterrestrial life?

headline: In Defense of Jane Austen. Also Zebras.
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Who Owns Gay Street?
abstract: A singular Manhattan block grows to include many orientations — but does it erase black history?
lead_paragraph: Winding south from Waverly Place, north to Christopher Street, Gay Street is one of the shortest stretches of road in New York. But its mythology runs long. Let’s begin with the question “Why is it called Gay Street?’” There is no conclusive answer but plenty of postured certainty.

headline: Those Irresistible Price Alerts: ‘HOT!! Chicago to Barcelona, Spain for Only $272’
abstract: It’s a golden age for price alerts, which have expanded from emails touting sales to fare predictions and deal disseminators.
lead_paragraph: Penny Yim-Barbieri, 47, a freelance translator based in Las Vegas, didn’t have the Cook Islands on her travel radar when she got an email alert from Scott’s Cheap Flights about round-trip tickets to Rarotonga from Los Angeles at $495. She and her husband jumped on the deal and soon found themselves scuba diving in the South Pacific with humpback whales.

headline: This Politician Lives in His Mom’s Basement and He’s Campaigning on It
abstract: Josh Lafazan is one of the youngest legislators in New York. His interns — some of them only 12 years old — are part of his youth movement.
lead_paragraph: Twelve-year-old Nicholas Fernandes didn’t spend his vacation at camp or playing Xbox all day. Instead, he devoted his summer to work on a political campaign.

headline: In Art and Words, a Book Lover Honors the Characters He Can’t Forget
abstract: Alberto Manguel sketches 10 classic figures from fiction, including Dracula, Captain Nemo and Long John Silver.
lead_paragraph: DRACULA

headline: Five Places to Visit in Provincetown, Mass., with John Derian
abstract: The summer crowds have faded in this bohemian Cape Cod haven. But the designer and home goods retailer is a fan of P-town in autumn and shares his go-to spots.
lead_paragraph: Provincetown, Mass., the artsy beach town on the frothy final wisp of Cape Cod, swells with sandy-toed visitors in the peak summer months. With autumn upon us, the crowds have all but disappeared. But John Derian, the New York City-based designer and home goods retailer, says he loves this time of year in P-town. Since 2007, he has decamped to his getaway home, an antique of a house built for a local sea captain in 1789. An outpost of his flagship New York store, John Derian Company, is in his property’s carriage house. After the tourists are gone, Provincetown is “beautiful and quiet,” Mr. Derian said. “It’s a small town that’s also like a city. I can walk out of my house and get a coffee.”

headline: The White-Collar Job Apocalypse That Didn’t Happen
abstract: Economists once warned that office jobs in the United States would soon follow factory jobs in moving overseas. New research suggests that jobs may be moving to other parts of the country instead.
lead_paragraph: Ron Kincaid remembers what it was like to worry that his job would be sent overseas.

headline: In Hong Kong, Unity Between Peaceful and Radical Protesters. For Now.
abstract: Five years ago, protesters were critical of even breaking windows. Now, some are throwing firebombs.
lead_paragraph: One slogan in the Hong Kong protests has taken on new significance: “Don’t distance yourself; don’t snitch.”

headline: 18 Transgender Killings This Year Raise Fears of an ‘Epidemic’
abstract: The killings, many of them against transgender women of color, have deeply disturbed groups already familiar with threats to their safety.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In the most recent killing of a transgender woman, her body was found inside an abandoned car, burned beyond recognition. In another case, the woman was pulled from a lake at a Dallas park. And in a third, she was found dead near a golf course, just weeks after she survived a brutal beating that was captured on video.

headline: Prison Book Bans Called ‘Arbitrary and Irrational’
abstract: A report from PEN America says some restrictions targeted books by authors including Barack Obama, John Updike and Joyce Carol Oates.
lead_paragraph: A prison in Ohio blocked an inmate from receiving a biology textbook over concerns that it contained nudity. In Colorado, prison officials rejected Barack Obama’s memoirs because they were “potentially detrimental to national security.” And a prison in New York tried to ban a book of maps of the moon, saying it could “present risks of escape.”

headline: M.L.B. Awards 2019: Who Deserves the Honors?
abstract: The hardware won’t be handed out until after the postseason, but as the regular season wraps up this weekend, here are the players and managers who deserve baseball’s top honors.
lead_paragraph: The Baseball Writers’ Association of America has presented awards for decades, and despite an ever-changing media landscape, those honors have retained their prominence within the sport. Some news organizations, including The New York Times, do not allow their writers to vote — but we still have opinions, and here’s how the awards picture looks as the regular season scrambles to the finish on Sunday afternoon.

headline: South of Sydney, the Australian Coast Becomes Its Own Destination
abstract: New South Wales offers sandy beaches, excellent seafood and a growing arts and craft scene.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s Eurobodalla, Shoalhaven and Sapphire coasts run about 250 miles from the dairy town of Berry — two hours south of Sydney via the Grand Pacific Drive, which is bordered by rolling farmland on one side and gleaming ocean on the other — down to a historic whaling center near the Victorian state border. In the mountains above are sites sacred to the Yuin and Ngarigo peoples, who have lived in the southeastern part of what is now known as New South Wales for as long as 60,000 years, as well as a half-dozen bird-rich national parks, including one in Eurobodalla that is an important roost for the highly endangered Swift parrot.

headline: How a SoHo Salon Host Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Susan MacTavish Best, who organizes elaborate dinner parties in her SoHo loft, gets the day started by running 14 miles. And ice cream.
lead_paragraph: “There’s a huge hunger among people to connect in real time and to look in people’s eyes,” said Susan MacTavish Best, the founder of Posthoc, a salon series with notable speakers, home-cooked meals and music presented in the SoHo loft where she also lives. “The city can be lonely,” she said. “There’s such a sense of community and warmth here. I want people to feel that.”

headline: One of These Bed-Stuy Homes Is Not Like the Others
abstract: An ornate 1889 townhouse in Brooklyn gets a 21st-century makeover as a passive house.
lead_paragraph: An ornate 1889 townhouse in Brooklyn gets a 21st-century makeover as a passive house.

headline: Why the Trump Impeachment Inquiry Is the Only Option
abstract: As traumatic and divisive as the process can be, the time has arrived.
lead_paragraph: As traumatic and divisive as the process can be, the time has arrived.

headline: A 19th-Century Home in Brooklyn Gets a 21st-Century Makeover
abstract: For passive-house proponents, an ornate 1889 house in Bed-Stuy presented the ultimate challenge: How do you embrace the future without destroying the past?
lead_paragraph: When Bobby Johnston and Ruth Mandl found the townhouse they wanted to buy in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, it had just one glaringly obvious problem: It was too nice.

headline: Why The Times Editorial Board Supports an Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: And what is an editorial board anyway?
lead_paragraph: As the Times editorial board argues in support of the impeachment inquiry into President Trump, it seems like a moment to address two obvious questions.

headline: Building Is Booming 24/7. So Is the Noise.
abstract: Friday: In 2018, the city's Buildings Department received about 3,700 noise complaints about late-night construction.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Whistle-Blower, Refugees, Egypt: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here's what you need to know
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Our Love Is Built to Last’
abstract: Anthony Hemingway and Steven Norfleet traveled in similar Hollywood circles, but didn’t meet until after a church service.
lead_paragraph: On Easter Sunday in 2014, Anthony Hemingway, a director and producer, was mingling with fellow congregants after a service at the Potter’s House at One LA in Los Angeles. Through the crowd gathered outside on La Brea Avenue, he noticed a friend chatting up a handsome stranger in a black suit, bow tie and round-frame glasses, bearing a striking resemblance to a young Malcolm X.

headline: The Whistle-Blower’s Complaint
abstract: The document was made public just before lawmakers questioned the acting intelligence chief on why it had taken so long.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: If Donald Trump Does It, It’s Not a Crime
abstract: Trump sees the Ukraine call as a “nothing” because he has spent his entire adult life skirting, mocking, ignoring or breaking the law.
