lead_paragraph: The two biggest victories came in quick succession.

headline: Dutch Railroad Reckons With Holocaust Shame, 70 Years Later
abstract: Even as the national railroad company in the Netherlands begins paying compensation to the relatives of those it transported to death camps, new details of its collaboration are emerging.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — The indispensable role that German railroads played as part of the Nazi machinery of genocide during World War II has long been known. But it may be only now that the Dutch are beginning to fully reckon with the role that their own national railroad played in the Holocaust.

headline: Altuzarra: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Altuzarra: Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Altuzarra: Spring 2020 Collection

headline: Tens of Thousands Rally in Hong Kong Before China’s National Holiday
abstract: The police used water cannons and tear gas as protesters commemorated the fifth anniversary of the pro-democracy Umbrella Movement, days before a major anniversary in China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Antigovernment protesters in Hong Kong rallied in a downtown park, occupied a major road and blanketed several neighborhoods with pro-democracy artwork on Saturday, days before a sensitive national holiday that will commemorate 70 years of Communist rule in China.

headline: Police Watchdog Is Asked to Review Boris Johnson’s Ties to U.S. Businesswoman
abstract: Britain’s prime minister is being accused of having given undue aid to an American entrepreneur while serving as mayor of London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A monitor at London’s City Hall has referred Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain to a police watchdog for a possible investigation of claims that he unduly favored an American entrepreneur while mayor of the city, intensifying a politically risky scandal as he faces a hostile Parliament and a looming Brexit deadline.

headline: Can My Landlord Force Me to Get Renters Insurance?
abstract: In some cases, yes. But the better question may be: Why don’t you already have it?
lead_paragraph: Q: I’m a renter living in a Midtown co-op, subletting my apartment from a shareholder. The co-op board recently changed its rules, and now requires all shareholders and subletters to purchase renters insurance. But my landlord is the shareholder, not the co-op, so am I really required to follow the co-op’s policy? Since my sublease does not include any requirement about renters insurance, how could my landlord enforce such a rule?

headline: How a Tuxedoed Sommelier Wound Up Homeless in California
abstract: As life unraveled, a skilled wine steward joined the swelling ranks of homeless people in tents across the San Francisco Bay Area.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Opus One, Château Lynch-Bages or Petrus. The crimson ribbons of fine wine trickled delicately into his customers’ bulbous crystal glasses.

headline: 25 Apple Dessert Recipes Our Readers Love
abstract: Make something sweet and seasonal this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Cinnamon apple quick bread with apple cider glaze (above) is one of many delicious apple desserts you can tackle this weekend. Try a crumble or a crisp, bake them in a pie or on their own, or get the kids in the kitchen to help with the candied version.

headline: Listen to the Storm Songs of the Caribbean
abstract: When hurricanes are a part of life, people cope and quell their anxiety through their music.
lead_paragraph: Every island in the Caribbean has one, if not many: Popular songs inspired by the awful storms that have always been at once facts of life and shapers of history. In this region, from whose indigenous people we got our word — “huracan” — for the fierce tempests that swirl off the Atlantic in late summer and early fall, hurricanes have long been key to culture.

headline: Democrats’ 2020 Campaign Message: Not Impeachment, They Insist
abstract: The party is bracing for a pitched battle with President Trump that will likely overshadow its policy agenda. But Democrats say they do not want impeachment to dominate the election.
lead_paragraph: After the 2016 election, Democratic leaders reached an all but unanimous conclusion: To defeat President Trump in 2020, they would have to do more than condemn his offensive behavior and far-right ideology, as Hillary Clinton had done. They would need, above all, to promote a clear and exciting agenda of their own.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon remind us that there’s more than one way to solve an acrostic.  As in, you can look things up.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s excerpt is by a very funny writer and television personality, Stephen Fry, from his memoirs, “The Fry Chronicles.”  Mr. Fry has a wide range of credits, including a  brainy game show called “Qi” and a lot of work done with wildlife and nature conservation.

headline: Justin Trudeau, the Instagram Prime Minister, Struggles to Resonate With Young Voters
abstract: Mr. Trudeau came to power by galvanizing young supporters. Keeping them in his corner is critical as he seeks re-election.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Four years ago Emmanuel Amoussa, a chemistry student, voted for Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada, drawn by what he saw as a young progressive leader whose policies on climate change and immigration resonated with him and other members of his generation.

headline: T’s Beauty Guide to Paris
abstract: Where to get a facial, a manicure and even a lymphatic drainage massage in the French capital.
lead_paragraph: Parisians have long been viewed as paragons of natural beauty, so much so that the English term “effortless” has been co-opted into their cultural lexicon. Today, though, most locals know that the “I just rolled out of bed” look is often a ruse — one that takes plenty of time and money to perfect. Mussed-up hair is best achieved with the help of France’s top hairstylists, and barefaced, natural beauty is enhanced by stimulating facial massage and a long steam session in one of the city’s many hammams. Here, we’ve compiled a list of the city’s most sought-after beauty experts, brands and salons. Just make sure you book well in advance.

headline: Impeachment Battle to Turn for First Time on a President’s Ties to a Foreign Country
abstract: To the founding fathers, foreign influence on an American president was an abiding fear and a basis for impeachment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Alexander Hamilton, as usual, got right to the heart of the matter. When the framers were designing the Constitution and its power of impeachment, one of the high crimes they had in mind was giving into what Hamilton called “the desire in foreign powers to gain an improper ascendant in our councils.”

headline: Elon Musk Sets Out SpaceX Starship’s Ambitious Launch Timeline
abstract: The founder of the private launch company presented new details about its next major rocket.
lead_paragraph: BOCA CHICA VILLAGE, Texas — As Elon Musk, the founder and chief executive of SpaceX, says repeatedly, he created a rocket company because he wanted to colonize Mars. His fervent argument is that humanity must spread to a second planet as insurance for long-term survival.

headline: Comme des Garçons: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Comme des Garçons: Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Comme des Garçons: Spring 2020 Collection

headline: Clarence Thomas Is Not a ‘Sellout’
abstract: Whether or not you agree with his jurisprudence, it is rooted in a commitment to black people.
lead_paragraph: Say the name “Clarence Thomas” in any liberal setting and the response is likely to be short and swift: “self-hating,” “stupid,” “sellout.”

headline: Are We Living in a Post-Happiness World?
abstract: With happiness harder to come by these days, people are grasping at any moment of joy they can get.
lead_paragraph: Joy, it seems, is everywhere these days.

headline: The Long, Strange Tale of California’s Surf Nazis
abstract: When I set out to become a surfer, I didn’t realize what I was getting myself into.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco — The first time I saw a swastika in the wild, I happened to be carrying a surfboard. The year was 1989. I’d just come home from college hungry to claim the California identity that felt like my birthright. I could not have told you what that identity was except that its highest form appeared to be something like a blue-eyed, blond surfer with a golden tan, preternaturally skilled at riding the waves of his native beach.

headline: The Church of Techno-Optimism
abstract: Neither liberal nor conservative, the true ideology of Silicon Valley is an unwavering belief in the power of technology.
lead_paragraph: What are Silicon Valley’s politics?

headline: The Sterile, Efficient Life of a Millennial
abstract: I’d love a dining car on the train. Or any chance to slow down.
lead_paragraph: I was covered in a layer of sweat, and my iPhone charger was dangling out of a bag that contained the after-hours work I still needed to do along with a Lara bar, crushed under the weight of my laptop. It should have been obvious: I’d been stressed, and moving way too fast. But, as usual, I didn’t realize it until I was on the train. I poked my head out of my inbox long enough to play peek-a-boo with a toddler clutching her snack, and chat with an older couple en route to vacation. I felt joy, and a familiar pang of shame that comes from realizing you’ve moved too fast to cherish what’s in front of you.

headline: The Making of a Chinese Patriot
abstract: What happens when you mix rage, shame and pride with years of nationalist education?
lead_paragraph: Over the past few months, reports on Chinese mainlanders hurling curses at Hong Kong protesters have disturbed people around the world. These self-appointed guardians of Beijing’s authority have appeared in Australia, where they shouted profane insults in Mandarin about the mothers of a group of Hong Kong supporters. In Canada, mainland students driving their Ferraris and Aston Martins to “demonstrate force” derided Hong Kongers as poor and added an expletive for good measure.

headline: ‘Ours Will No Longer Be a Nation Subject to Insult and Humiliation’
abstract: From climate change to Taiwan, China’s foreign policy is about impressing the masses at home, not fighting enemies abroad.
lead_paragraph: The past few months have been challenging for China: A trade war with the United States has taken a toll on the economy, while months of protests in Hong Kong have raised questions about the sustainability of Chinese political control at the edges of its rule.

headline: I Pray for Murder (Sometimes)
abstract: I’ve learned how to dodge a bullet. But how do you dodge a stroke?
lead_paragraph: The first time I had a gun pulled on me was a joke. Not to the guy with the shotgun; he was serious enough to park his Cutlass, snatch the shotty out of his trunk and point it at a crew of 11- and 12-year-olds in the street who hadn’t jumped onto the sidewalk fast enough when he beeped at us to move.

headline: Message From a Proud Island: ‘We Need Your Help’
abstract: Dorian devastated this place, but hope keeps washing ashore.
lead_paragraph: OCRACOKE, N.C. — I write this from a barrier island 26 miles off the mainland coast, accessible only by boat or plane. It has been about three weeks since Hurricane Dorian blew through, tore up and submerged the place that my 1,000 or so neighbors and I call home. While it might seem from a distance that the storm has passed, we are all as shellshocked as we were on Day 1.

headline: Soldier Assigned to Mar-a-Lago Sentenced for Lying in Child Pornography Case
abstract: Staff Sgt. Richard Ciccarella was sentenced on Friday to three years of probation for making a false statement to a federal officer, court documents said.
lead_paragraph: A noncommissioned Army officer who was once in charge of White House communications equipment at Mar-a-Lago, President Trump’s private club in Palm Beach, Fla., was sentenced to three years of probation on Friday for lying to a federal officer during a child pornography investigation, court documents show.

headline: The Tenacity of Chinese Communism
abstract: How the party revived an ancient philosophy to extol order and compel obedience.
lead_paragraph: When Chairman Mao Zedong stepped forward in Tiananmen Square on Oct. 1, 1949, and proclaimed — in standard Chinese but in a thick Hunanese accent — the founding of the People’s Republic of China, many patriots rejoiced. A large number of Chinese who were not Communists were still happy that after years of humiliation by foreign powers, a vicious Japanese invasion and a bloody civil war, China was now finally united. For the first time in roughly a century the Chinese had regained their dignity. Mao was widely credited for this.

headline: At the Border, Lawmakers See a Broken System and Little Common Ground
abstract: Dozens of lawmakers have flocked to the southwestern border to see with their own eyes how migrants are being treated. They have come away with little consensus about what needs to be done.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — The delegation of Democratic lawmakers jostled for space in the cramped room in the border processing center, straining to hear over the sounds of crinkling mylar blankets and a crying baby, as a Venezuelan migrant told her grim story.

headline: 5 Stabbed at Hunt Valley Mall Near Baltimore, Police Say
abstract: The attacker, who was fatally shot by officers, had a three-inch hunting-type knife, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Five people were stabbed at a Baltimore-area shopping center on Saturday, and the attacker was fatally shot by police officers, the authorities said.

headline: When Trump’s Envoy for Ukraine Resigned, a College Journalist Had the Scoop
abstract: An editor at Arizona State University’s student newspaper beat everyone else to the news that Kurt Volker had stepped down.
lead_paragraph: Kurt D. Volker has traveled halfway around the world as a United States diplomat. He has met with world leaders, negotiated foreign policy and served under multiple American presidents.

headline: Tanks, Missiles and No Pigeons: China to Celebrate 70th Birthday of the People’s Republic
abstract: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, will use a military parade commemorating the 70th anniversary of Communist rule to highlight his power in the face of rising challenges.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Enormous flower arrangements in Beijing extol the signature promise of China’s leader to realize the Chinese Dream. Red banners urge people to “rally closer” to the Communist Party with “Comrade Xi Jinping at its core.” The authorities have restricted live entertainment venues, ordered people to vacate apartments and banned flying kites, sky lanterns and even homing pigeons, a charming feature of many neighborhoods.

headline: How a Shadow Foreign Policy in Ukraine Prompted an Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: Details of the push by President Trump and Rudolph Giuliani for Ukraine to investigate Democrats show a sustained effort that encompassed elections in both countries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Petro O. Poroshenko was still the president of Ukraine earlier this year when his team sought a lifeline. With the polls showing him in clear danger of losing his re-election campaign, some of his associates, eager to hold on to their own jobs and influence, took steps that could have yielded a signal of public support from a vital ally: President Trump.

headline: Hermès: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Hermès: Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Hermès: Spring 2020 Collection

headline: Syria Demands Immediate Withdrawal of U.S. and Turkish Forces, Again
abstract: Syria’s foreign minister demanded both countries evacuate their forces from the war-ravaged country or face “countermeasures.” Syria has made such threats before without taking steps to enforce them.
lead_paragraph: Syria’s foreign minister demanded on Saturday that American and Turkish forces evacuate the war-ravaged country immediately or face “any and all countermeasures authorized under international law.”

headline: Now Weight Just a Second
abstract: Tom McCoy’s Sunday puzzle tips the scales.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Tom McCoy is a steady Sunday grid contributor who specializes in creative pun interpretation, as well as this type of puzzle, where he finds a quirk in the English language and spins it out to entertaining effect. Fittingly, Mr. McCoy is in a Ph.D. program in cognitive science at Johns Hopkins, specializing in computational linguistics.

headline: Haiti Gripped by Violent Protests Amid Calls for President’s Ouster
abstract: Streets, schools and banks were closed throughout the country, bringing the economy to a standstill. “President Jovenel Moise is not doing anything for us, just killing us,” said a protester.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Burned-out cars, makeshift barricades and shuttered businesses signaled a week of unrest in Haiti, where protesters are demanding the resignation of President Jovenel Moïse and more violent protests are feared.

headline: Christian Coleman Wins Track Gold Amid Doping Test Controversy
abstract: Coleman, a 23-year-old American, placed first in the men’s 100-meter world championship race after missing three doping tests in 12 months.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Christian Coleman has earned the right to be called the fastest man in the world, but some question whether he even should have been in the running.

headline: ‘You’re a Bad Police Officer’: Official Confronts Deputy at Awards Ceremony
abstract: A city commissioner in Florida accused the deputy of making a false arrest in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The first time that officials in a southern Florida city publicly commended county deputies for their exemplary work turned out to be memorable — but not for the reasons leaders had intended.

headline: Mets’ Pete Alonso Breaks Rookie Home-Run Record
abstract: Alonso, 24, hit his 53rd home run of the season on Saturday to surpass the record set by Yankees outfielder Aaron Judge in 2017.
lead_paragraph: After Pete Alonso hit his 52nd home run of the season to tie with Yankees outfielder Aaron Judge’s major league record for most homers by a rookie on Friday, Alonso stood at his locker and considered his place in baseball history.

headline: Republican Mark Amodei Tiptoes Around Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: The lawmaker on Saturday parsed his words about supporting congressional oversight of a whistle-blower’s complaint against President Trump.
lead_paragraph: A Republican member of the House of Representatives spent Saturday clarifying his support for congressional oversight of a whistle-blower’s complaint against President Trump, which the lawmaker’s office contended was not the same as endorsing the impeachment inquiry being led by Democrats.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Beijing Parade Glorifies Party, and Xi’s Power
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 29, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “In the past 70 years, the development and growth of the Chinese military is there for all to see. We have neither the intention nor the need to flex muscle through military parades.”

headline: Corrections: September 29, 2019
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, September 29, 2019.
lead_paragraph: ARTS & LEISUREThis weekend’s cover article about Eddie Murphy’s new projects misstates the number of children he has. He has 10 children, not eight.•A picture caption with an article last Sunday about the new “Downton Abbey” movie misidentified the man who is dancing with the actress Michelle Dockery. He is the actor Matthew Goode — not Henry Talbot, who is Goode’s character.•A museum entry in the listings pages of the New Season issue on Sept. 15 about “Betye Saar: Call and Response” at LACMA referred incorrectly to the exhibition. It is a show, not a retrospective.

headline: The Internet Is Overrun With Images of Child Sexual Abuse. What Went Wrong?
abstract: Online predators create and share the illegal material, which is increasingly cloaked by technology. Tech companies, the government and the authorities are no match.
lead_paragraph: Online predators create and share the illegal material, which is increasingly cloaked by technology. Tech companies, the government and the authorities are no match.

headline: Sarah Jane Van den Bergh, Christian Sahner
abstract: The couple were introduced almost three years ago by a sister of the bride in London. They were married at the Oxford Oratory in Oxford, England.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Jane Lucy Mary Van den Bergh and Christian Casey Sahner were married Sept. 28. The Rev. Edward Van den Bergh, a Roman Catholic priest and a brother of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Oxford Oratory in Oxford, England.

headline: Kaytlin Roholt, William Lane III
abstract: The couple met when both took leave from their law firms to work for the Senate Judiciary Committee during the Neil M. Gorsuch hearings.
lead_paragraph: Kaytlin Lara Roholt and William Kerwin Lane III were married Sept. 28 at the Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart at Georgetown University in Washington. The Rev. Donald J. Planty Jr., a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Rachel Wellhausen, Alexander Torok
abstract: The couple met in 2002 at Irkutsk State Technical University in Siberia, where they studied Russian language.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Louise Wellhausen and Alexander Jakim Torok were married Sept. 28 at St. Martin’s Evangelical Lutheran Church in Austin, Tex. The Rev. John Van Haneghan, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Ann Honor and Dr. Patrick Michael Kozak were married Sept. 28. John R. Charlet, a civil celebrant in Richmond, Va., solemnized the marriage in the winery at Seven Oaks Farm, a vineyard and events space in Greenwood, Va.

headline: Johanna Byer, James Adcock
abstract: They bonded over their love of family, giving back to the community, and cowboy boots.
lead_paragraph: Johanna Frances Byer and James Samuel Adcock were married Sept. 28 at the Oaks, the bride’s family home in Indian Hill, Ohio. Robert D. Bauer, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Alyssa Gerharter, Daniel Cohn
abstract: She swept him off his feet when she mentioned she was into high fantasy novels.
lead_paragraph: Alyssa Marie Gerharter and Daniel James Cohn were married Sept. 28 at Sound River Studios, an events space in Long Island City, Queens. Christopher A. Bruffee, a friend of the couple who is a Universal Life minister, officiated in a ceremony incorporating Jewish elements.

headline: Meredith Kennedy, Brett Forrest
abstract: The bride and groom met at the wedding of the groom’s brother in 2012, but didn’t start dating until three years later.
lead_paragraph: Meredith Matson Kennedy and Brett Jacob Forrest were married Sept. 28 at an events space in Germantown, N.Y., called A Private Estate. Anthony K. Maciulis, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Courtney Rottenberger, Jason McKean
abstract: The bride, a dancer and former Radio City Rockette, and the groom, a group creative director at McCann, met in 2016 through the dating app Bumble.
lead_paragraph: Courtney Louise Rottenberger and Jason Robert McKean were married Sept. 28 at Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. The Rev. David Nolan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Aaron Kurosu, Gregory Henselman
abstract: The couple met in October 2016 in a photo booth during a graduate student function at Princeton.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Kurosu and Gregory Frank Henselman were married Sept. 28 in a self-uniting outdoor ceremony at Gunnison Point Overlook, which is at the Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park in Colorado.

headline: Seton Hartnett, Luke O’Brien
abstract: The bride and groom, both lawyers in New York, met through the dating app Bumble.
lead_paragraph: Seton Elizabeth Hartnett and Luke James O’Brien were married Sept. 28 at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York. The Rev. Eugene Squeo, a Roman Catholic priest and friend of the bride’s family, performed the ceremony.

headline: A ‘Grand Séducteur,’ With Politicians and the Press
abstract: Jacques Chirac had a habit of turning on the charm. It worked with the French public, with women and even, at times, with the media.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Dana Hagar, Stuyve Pierrepont
abstract: The couple met in an elevator in the Washington office building where both worked.
lead_paragraph: Dana Elizabeth Hagar was married Sept. 28 to Rutherfurd Stuyvesant Pierrepont IV. William T. Nolan, a friend of the groom’s family who was ordained through Open Ministry, performed the ceremony at the Adirondack League Club in Old Forge, N.Y.

headline: Frances Cheever, Andrew Ong
abstract: The couple met in 2011 as associates in the intellectual property litigation group at Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe.
lead_paragraph: Frances Sargent Cheever and Andrew Shichen Ong were married Sept. 28 at the Pittsburgh Golf Club in Pittsburgh. Nora Barry Fischer, a senior district judge of the United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania, officiated.

headline: Miranda Campbell, Athul Acharya
abstract: The couple met in March 2015 on the dating app Tinder. The groom was the bride’s first and last Tinder date.
lead_paragraph: Miranda Tai Campbell and Athul Karinja Acharya were married Sept. 28 at the Barn PNW, an events space in Dayton, Ore. Judge Michael H. Simon, of the United States District Court for the District of Oregon, officiated.

headline: Preying on Children: The Emerging Psychology of Pedophiles
abstract: Images of child sex abuse have reached a crisis point on the internet. Now, science is beginning to shed light on why people abuse children in the first place.
lead_paragraph: Images of child sex abuse have reached a crisis point on the internet, spreading at unprecedented rates in part because tech platforms and law enforcement agencies have failed to keep pace with the problem. But less is understood about the issue underlying it all: What drives people to sexually abuse children?

headline: Michael Foote, Bradley Sherburne
abstract: The couple met in New York through OkCupid, the dating app, in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Michael Charles Foote and Bradley Stephen Sherburne were married Sept. 28. William J. Weiner, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated at Founders Landing, a park in Southold, N.Y.

headline: George Santiago Jr., David Dovnarsky
abstract: The couple met over the Memorial Day weekend in 1999 at a gay bar in Philadelphia, where both then lived.
lead_paragraph: George Santiago Jr. and Dr. David Karl Dovnarsky were married Sept. 27 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Joey Tai, a member of the New York city clerk’s staff, officiated.

headline: Theresa Incampo, Dillard Taylor
abstract: The couple met while undergraduates at Trinity College in Hartford.
lead_paragraph: Theresa Ann Incampo and John Dillard Taylor are to be married Sept. 29 at Bar Lurcat, a restaurant in Minneapolis. Richard J. Bresnahan, a friend of the groom’s family who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

headline: Jennifer Cuminale, Jay Russell
abstract: On their first date they discovered they were both reading the novel “A Gentleman in Moscow.”
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Anne Cuminale and Jamieson Ford Russell were married Sept. 28 at the First Congregational Church of Greenwich in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Patrick Collins, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: An Explosion in Online Child Sex Abuse: What You Need to Know
abstract: Emerging tech platforms and overwhelmed law enforcement agencies have contributed to a boom in digital abuse imagery, a Times investigation found. Here are some key takeaways.
lead_paragraph: Tech companies are reporting a boom in online photos and videos of children being sexually abused — a record 45 million illegal images were flagged last year alone — exposing a system at a breaking point and unable to keep up with the perpetrators, an investigation by The New York Times found.

headline: Lauren Marsh, Christopher Thomas
abstract: The couple met in North Carolina six years ago at a wedding for which she was a bridesmaid and he a groomsman.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Keslye Marsh and Christopher William Thomas were married Sept. 28 in an outdoor ceremony in Aspen, Colo. The Rev. Gregg Aerson, chaplain emeritus at the Aspen Chapel, performed the ceremony atop Aspen Mountain.

headline: Kelly Park, Walter Kim
abstract: The bride and groom are both medical doctors. She specializes in dermatology, and he is an orthopedic surgeon.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Kelly KyungWha Park and Dr. Walter Jinwoo Kim were married Sept. 28 at the Langham, a hotel in Chicago. Dr. Mark Romanelli, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Andrea Park, James Downey
abstract: The couple met through the dating app Tinder in March 2016.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Da-Hae Park and James Wright Downey were married Sept. 28 in Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. Kathryn Beilke, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Basilica Hudson, an events space.

headline: Jessica Mercer, Derek Bazemore Jr.
abstract: The couple, both doctors, met at Howard University, from which each graduated. They were married at the Château Élan Winery and Resort in Braselton, Ga.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jessica Jakita Mercer and Dr. Derek Glenn Bazemore Jr. were married Sept. 28 at the Château Élan Winery and Resort in Braselton, Ga. The Rev. Dr. Edward Best, a United Methodist minister, officiated with Dr. Dan A. Sims, a friend of the couple, taking part.

headline: Heather Hicks, Michael Schade
abstract: The couple were married at Spillian, an events space in Fleischmanns, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Heather Marie Hicks and Michael Francis Schade were married Sept. 28 at Spillian, an events space in Fleischmanns, N.Y. Kathryn E. Petho, a friend of the couple who was ordained by Open Ministry, officiated.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Bob’s Burgers’ and ‘Shark Tank’
abstract: “Bob’s Burgers” returns for a 10th season on Fox. And “Shark Tank” is back on ABC.
lead_paragraph: BOB’S BURGERS 9 p.m. on Fox. The boisterous Belcher family is back for a 10th season. Bob plans to surprise Linda for their anniversary, but things get complicated when Tina, Louise and Gene get involved. The episode features guest voices from Megan Mullally, Jillian Bell and Brooke Dillman.

headline: Soweto, Once Unified Against Apartheid, Is Now Divided by Wealth
abstract: The township was once a symbol of united resistance to a racist regime in South Africa. Now it embodies the class divisions in the country’s black majority.
lead_paragraph: SOWETO, South Africa — Nomsa Victorino had a Lexus in her garage, a pool in her yard, eight bedrooms in her villa and a message for the world about her famous hometown. “Whatever people have in their mind about Soweto — that Soweto is a place for poor people — it’s not like that,” said Ms. Victorino, 50, sitting in one of her three sitting rooms. “It has changed drastically.”

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Premiere Meets Impeachment Head-On, but Not Shane Gillis
abstract: Woody Harrelson hosted and Alec Baldwin returned as President Trump. But the Gillis controversy was only hinted at. Maybe.
lead_paragraph: A certain amount of tension always precedes a “Saturday Night Live” season premiere, but this weekend’s curtain raiser, kicking off its 45th year, seemed tenser than usual.

headline: Major Clashes Erupt in Hong Kong Ahead of China’s National Day
abstract: The demonstrations openly defy Beijing’s rule just two days before the central government celebrates 70 years of Communist rule.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Three of Hong Kong’s main commercial districts were engulfed in thick clouds of tear gas on Sunday as pro-democracy demonstrators battled the police in an open challenge to Beijing just two days before China celebrates 70 years of Communist rule.

headline: U.S. Businesswoman Admitted Affair With Boris Johnson, U.K. Report Says
abstract: The woman, Jennifer Arcuri, reportedly told friends that she was having an affair with Mr. Johnson when he was mayor, deepening the scandal as he tries to navigate an impasse over Brexit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An American businesswoman who received thousands of pounds from a government agency that Boris Johnson controlled when he was mayor of London told friends that she and Mr. Johnson were having a sexual affair, according to a British news report this weekend.

headline: Revisiting Hitler, in a New Authoritarian Age
abstract: With nationalism and anti-Semitism on the rise around the world, two big new biographies look at the Nazi leader’s march to power.
lead_paragraph: When not at work on a book about the roots of anti-Semitism in his country, the German historian and Holocaust expert Peter Longerich has been thinking about 1923.

abstract: “The alleged conduct in this case is truly outrageous,” the district attorney said.

abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

abstract: Ben Cohen, the co-founder of Ben & Jerry’s Ice Cream, calls spending huge amounts on the effort “a tragic waste.” Another urges creation of a cabinet-level agency to deal with threats.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: The Week in Business: The Economics of Impeachment
abstract: Plus, WeWork’s chief executive steps down.
lead_paragraph: It’s tough to say who had a worse week — President Trump, WeWork or the vaping industry. (O.K., it’s pretty obvious — here’s a handy guide to the impeachment process, should you be curious.) Vegans, on the other hand, should be delighted. To find out why, read on.

headline: Police Officer Killed in Bronx Project Scarred by Gangs
abstract: The officer was restraining a man who had fled questioning, and could be heard on body camera footage yelling, “He’s reaching for it!”
lead_paragraph: [Latest: The police commissioner said on Monday that Officer Brian Mulkeen was killed by “friendly fire” from fellow officers’ guns.]

headline: Ahead of 2020, Facebook Falls Short on Plan to Share Data on Disinformation
abstract: The social network says it has struggled to get the information to researchers because it also wants to protect its users’ privacy.
lead_paragraph: In April 2018, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, told Congress about an ambitious plan to share huge amounts of posts, links and other user data with researchers around the world so that they could study and flag disinformation on the site.

headline: SpaceX Unveils Silvery Vision to Mars: ‘It’s Basically an I.C.B.M. That Lands’
abstract: Elon Musk delivered an update on his company’s Starship prototype, which faces business challenges and neighbors not happy to live so close to its test site.
lead_paragraph: BOCA CHICA VILLAGE, Tex. — As you drive east along Texas State Highway 4, it looks like a giant, shiny and pointy grain silo is rising out of the scrubby flatland at the tip of southern Texas.

abstract: See the looks from the Balenciaga: Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Balenciaga: Spring 2020 Collection

headline: Unveiling Monument to Migrants, Pope Francis Urges Compassion for Refugees
abstract: The pope unveiled the sculpture in St. Peter’s Square during a special Mass and portrayed migration as an opportunity to “promote the integral human development of all people.”
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis has always urged compassion and charity toward the refugees of the world. But on Sunday, during a special Mass on the 105th World Day of Migrants and Refugees, he unveiled a monument to migration in St. Peter’s Square as a homage to the displaced.

headline: In the Age of the Yellow Vests, Designer Jeans. Really?
abstract: Celine’s Hedi Slimane says this is what we want now. Haider Ackermann and Rei Kawakubo have other ideas.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Yellow Vests are back in France — albeit not quite in the same numbers as the social and economic inequality protesters once rallied. The world’s oldest travel company just closed in Britain, putting about 21,000 people out of work. There’s so much nervousness about a looming recession, the ’70s seem to be all any designer can think about (followed by that other recessionary decade, the ’90s).

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Roast chicken with plums, short ribs with prunes and almonds, a Parmesan broth with greens and beans: Set yourself up for days of good eating.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Rosh Hashana celebrations will take place for some after services this evening, for others after services on Monday night and for a few on both nights, happy new year. If you’re in the first camp or just want something good to eat tonight, I’m thinking Melissa Clark’s recipe for roast chicken with plums (above). If you’re in the second or just want something good to eat on Monday night that benefits from an overnight sit in the refrigerator, try these awesome short ribs braised with prunes and almonds, from Joan Nathan, whom I think of fondly as America’s Jewish mom.

headline: Thom Browne: Spring 2020
abstract: See the looks from the Thom Browne: Spring 2020 Collection
lead_paragraph: See the looks from the Thom Browne: Spring 2020 Collection

headline: A New Flood of English-Spanish Pop Is Here. Is It Opportunism or Progress?
abstract: Collaborations have flourished in the wake of “Despacito,” some sounding natural, some sounding forced.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the remix of Luis Fonsi’s “Despacito” featuring Justin Bieber became one of the defining pop songs of the decade, spending 16 weeks atop the Billboard Hot 100 and radically shifting how Spanish-language pop moved in the American mainstream. Reggaeton and its many offshoots were outrageously popular in Spanish-speaking markets, and the success of “Despacito” suggested that English-speaking audiences were finally open to it as well.

headline: How an Israeli Unity Government Could Shrink the Conflict
abstract: Shaking the rigid ideologies that have defined Israel’s politics.
lead_paragraph: The inconclusive results of Israel’s Sept. 17 election have thrust Israeli politics into a gripping deadlock. The center-left has no way to form a coalition, but for the first time in many years, neither does the right. This political paralysis reflects a profound change sweeping Israeli society in the last decade in the debate about the conflict.

headline: Federal Election Commissioner Posts Foreign Interference Memo on Twitter
abstract: The election commission’s Democratic chairwoman said a Republican commissioner had blocked official publication of the memo.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Election Commission chairwoman, Ellen L. Weintraub, on Friday took the dramatic step of using Twitter to release the entire draft of a memo addressing foreign election interference after its disputed publication in the agency’s weekly digest.

headline: Note to the Impeachment Investigators: Trump Rarely Acts Alone
abstract: Here’s who the House needs to hear from during its inquiry.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s assaults on democracy are rarely solo endeavors. His schemes often entangle, by chance or by choice, an array of accomplices, enablers, observers and victims — many of whom will need to be heard from as House members begin investigating the Ukraine scandal as part of the impeachment inquiry announced last week.

headline: Calling All Parent Pet-Owners
abstract: Send us your photos of pets and babies.
lead_paragraph: Send us your photos of pets and babies.

abstract: Readers, some of them speaking from experience, discuss how family members are often blamed or feel they could have prevented it.

headline: Baseball Saw a Million More Empty Seats. Does It Matter?
abstract: A 12-year slide in M.L.B. attendance has clubs turning to deals like standing room subscription passes. These days, filling the seats is less crucial to baseball’s bottom line.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Gaare, a 25-year-old “big time” Mets fan, spent this season watching games from a perch behind center field. He is an Amazin’ Mets ballpark pass subscriber, so he can go to as many home games as he wants for $40 a month. There’s just one catch: His ticket is for standing room only with no assigned seat.

headline: How the Tiny Village of Aa Became Estonia’s New ‘National Capital.’ Sort of.
abstract: A puzzle magazine called Nuti asked readers to vote on their favorite crosswordese.
lead_paragraph: This summer, readers of the Estonian puzzle magazine “Nuti” were asked to vote on a new capital — but not to worry, this did not constitute a cruciverbal coup. The vote was based on 10 towns and villages with short names that come up frequently in the country’s crosswords, and was the idea of Kaarel Silmato, a “Nuti” editor.

headline: We’re Looking for the Cutest Photos of Pets and Babies
abstract: Because the only thing cuter than a pet or a baby is a pet and a baby.
lead_paragraph: Calling all parents with pets! The only thing cuter than a pet or a baby is a pet and a baby. However, taking care of both isn’t always easy, which is NYT Parenting has a guide on how to introduce your newborn baby to your furry or feathered one. And, we want to see them together. Send us photos of your pets alongside your bundles of joy (or chaos, depending on the day), and we’ll feature some of the best images here and on our Instagram account (@NYTParenting).

headline: Chiefs Get Wild Win Over Lions, and Bills Lose to Patriots
abstract: Detroit and Buffalo lost their first games this season, but neither team made things easy for Kansas City or New England.
lead_paragraph: Seven teams entered the day undefeated but Buffalo and Detroit, in games that were far closer than most people expected, narrowly lost. We were following along with the early action in Week 4.

headline: 50,000 Lose Electricity in Northern California, Power Company Says
abstract: Power was fully restored after more than three hours.
lead_paragraph: A widespread power failure left 50,000 people in Northern California without power for more than three hours on Sunday morning.

lead_paragraph: A fleet of supercars said to have been seized by the Swiss authorities in a money-laundering investigation involving the son of the leader of Equatorial Guinea was auctioned on Sunday in Switzerland.

headline: Joe Maddon Will Not Return to Cubs Next Season
abstract: Theo Epstein, the Chicago Cubs’ president of baseball operations, said the team would not renew its contract with Maddon, who guided the Cubs to their first championship in 108 years in 2016.
lead_paragraph: It took the Chicago Cubs 108 years to win their most recent championship. It took them less than three years to dismiss the manager who led them there.

abstract: Starring a cute, fluffy yeti, a new animated family movie led sales at domestic theaters this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Yeti sightings were anything but rare this weekend — if a fluffy, digital version of that creature counts.

headline: Review: A New Godfather, in Harlem This Time
abstract: Forest Whitaker takes the antihero role as the 1960s heroin kingpin Bumpy Johnson in “Godfather of Harlem,” a new series on Epix.
lead_paragraph: A Harlem shoeshine man, sitting at the feet of Ellsworth (Bumpy) Johnson and watching Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and Malcolm X argue nearby, exclaims, “I just love seeing those silver-tongued Negroes go at it.” He’s a character in the new series “Godfather of Harlem,” beginning Sunday on Epix, and he’s just delivered a succinct review of it.

headline: Who Succeeds Mark Carney? Brexit Brings Uncertainty to the Bank of England
abstract: The central bank is independent, but its future leadership rests on the most political of questions: Who is in government?
lead_paragraph: The British government is hiring.

headline: Trump Was Repeatedly Warned That Ukraine Conspiracy Theory Was ‘Completely Debunked’
abstract: Thomas P. Bossert, President Trump’s first homeland security adviser, said he was “deeply disturbed” that Mr. Trump had urged Ukraine to investigate Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was repeatedly warned by his own staff that the Ukraine conspiracy theory that he and his lawyer were pursuing was “completely debunked” long before the president pressed Ukraine this summer to investigate his Democratic rivals, a former top adviser said on Sunday.

headline: As Deadly Floods Engulf Nepal Border, Anger Turns to India
abstract: Nepal said embankments built by India along a shared border made flooding worse in their country during the summer monsoon season, killing dozens.
lead_paragraph: GAUR, Nepal — The monsoon rains would not stop. They lashed Nepal’s border with India, pooling into a swift current that crumbled homes, cut electricity and swept away people and animals.

headline: Inside the F.B.I. File of Trump’s Mentor, Roy Cohn
abstract: The president isn’t mentioned in just-released documents. Still, the thick file is a timely reminder of the unusual realm his feared mentor inhabited.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Kurz Wins Austria Election. Will He Turn to Far Right or Greens to Govern?
abstract: Sebastian Kurz, who came in first in a snap election in Austria, has a choice: Partner again with the far-right party that collapsed his government or shift left?
lead_paragraph: Austria’s former chancellor Sebastian Kurz won a snap election he called four months ago after his government collapsed because of a scandal engulfing his far-right coalition partner. But the result of Sunday’s vote raised the question of whether he would need to team up again with the far right to form a government, or would shift to the left.

headline: State Dept. Investigating Email Practices of Hillary Clinton’s Former Staff
abstract: The inquiry is examining whether the employees used secure channels and the proper classification designations for what appeared to be routine emails at the time.
lead_paragraph: The State Department is continuing an investigation of email use among employees who worked for Hillary Clinton, the former secretary of state, asking scores of current and former officials to submit to questioning by the bureau overseeing diplomatic security, former officials said on Sunday.

headline: What Ukrainian-Americans Are Saying About the Ukraine Scandal
abstract: Ukraine might be at the center of a political furor, but that’s seen as an opportunity for a community that feels its homeland has long been overlooked and misunderstood.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Bohdan Czmola kicked off the Ukrainian Film Festival on Saturday night with a topical opener: “Has anybody been watching the news this week?”

headline: How Mark Milley, a General Who Mixes Bluntness and Banter, Became Trump’s Top Military Adviser
abstract: As the new chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Mark A. Milley must manage the most consequential professional relationship of his life, with President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mark A. Milley never planned to spend his life in the military.

headline: ‘LAPD Is Hiring!’: Recruitment Ad on Breitbart Sparks an Inquiry
abstract: The Los Angeles Police Department said that the ad’s appearance on the right-wing website created “a negative juxtaposition to our core values.”
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Police Department said it would open an inquiry into how a recruitment ad for its department had appeared on the website for Breitbart, saying that it created “a negative juxtaposition to our core values.”

headline: Biden Campaign Urges TV Networks to Stop Booking Giuliani
abstract: Advisers to the former vice president wrote to executives at ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN and Fox News to “demand” that Mr. Giuliani not be invited on the air to discuss Ukraine and President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign contacted top television anchors and networks on Sunday to “demand” that Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, be kept off the air because of what they called his misleading comments about the Biden family and Ukraine.

headline: Review: ‘jazz singer’ Looks to Complicate a Film’s Fraught History
abstract: A director and a composer play versions of themselves in a fascinating but frustrating reconsideration of a movie infamous for its use of blackface.
lead_paragraph: Few films are as culturally significant as “The Jazz Singer.” Starring Al Jolson and released in 1927, it was the first feature-length “talkie.”

abstract: Pageantry in China, protests in HK.

headline: 40 Inches of Snow in Montana: ‘It’s a February Storm in September’
abstract: A powerful winter storm socked much of the state with a wave of heavy snowfall on Sunday, breaking century-long daily records.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — A powerful winter storm socked much of Montana with a wave of heavy snowfall on Sunday, with weekend totals climbing to 40 inches in some places, and breaking century-long daily records.

headline: Desperate Migrants on the Border: ‘I Should Just Swim Across’
abstract: A growing number of migrants, blocked at the border by new immigration policies, are using riskier tactics to get in.
lead_paragraph: MATAMOROS, Mexico — Peering out over the Rio Grande, separated from Brownsville, Tex., by only about 100 feet of coursing water, Ana Galeano Valdez talked herself down from a perilous decision — something she has done several times in the weeks she has been living in a tent in one of Mexico’s most dangerous cities.

headline: Top Bodyguard to 2 Saudi Kings Is Shot Dead
abstract: Gen. Abdulaziz al-Faghem, who oversaw protection for two Saudi kings, was shot and killed in what the Saudi news media called a personal dispute.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A longtime personal bodyguard to two Saudi kings was shot and killed by a friend during a personal dispute, the Saudi state news media said on Sunday.

headline: Bash Some Tobacco Holders
abstract: We need to cheer Lynn Lempel up.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Lynn Lempel, the constructor of this puzzle, seems down. None of the things in her theme are making her happy.

headline: California’s Latest Wildfire Problem: Insuring the Tree Trimmers
abstract: Contractors crucial to clearing vegetation around power lines face higher coverage costs because of potential liability in later disasters.
lead_paragraph: PARADISE, Calif. — D.J. Gomes and his logging crew were working in California’s wine country last fall, helping clear vegetation away from power lines and reduce the ever-growing wildfire risk. While they were gone, fire came for their hometown.

headline: Discovering Cuba, an Island of Music
abstract: On a road trip across the island, music is everywhere and each region moves to its own defining rhythm.
lead_paragraph: On a road trip across the island, music is everywhere and each region moves to its own defining rhythm.

headline: Three Billion Canaries in the Coal Mine
abstract: What does it mean for us that birds are dying? And what can we do about it?
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — During the nearly quarter-century that my family has lived in this house, the changes in our neighborhood have become increasingly apparent: fewer trees and wildflowers, fewer bees and butterflies and grasshoppers, fewer tree frogs and songbirds. The vast majority of Tennessee is still rural, and for years I told myself that such changes were merely circumstantial, specific to a city undergoing rapid gentrification and explosive growth. I wasn’t trying to save the world by putting up nest boxes for the birds or letting the wildflowers in my yard bloom out before mowing. I was hoping only to provide a small way station for migrating wildlife, trusting they would be fine once they cleared the affluence zone that is the New Nashville.

headline: Back Home, House Democrats Tread Carefully on Impeachment and 2020
abstract: A tricky balancing act is underway for Democrats in battleground districts: protecting political gains from 2018 while selling voters on an inquiry into the president.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Orange County was the epicenter of the 2018 House Democratic takeover, where Republicans lost four seats in what was once the heart of Ronald Reagan conservatism in California. On Saturday night, as three of the victorious Democrats were honored at an annual political dinner, a new battle was on everyone’s minds: How to protect those gains in 2020 by selling voters on the impeachment inquiry of President Trump.

headline: Republicans, the Time Has Come
abstract: America is better than Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: To the Republican members of the United States Senate:

headline: Boris Johnson Still Basks in Favor of Hard-Line Tories, Who Forgive All for Brexit
abstract: In London, the British prime minister seems to be facing one crisis after another. But in Manchester, where his Conservative party is meeting, it’s another story altogether.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — He has been accused of inciting violence, misleading Queen Elizabeth II, running roughshod over the British Constitution and having a conflict of interest in his dealings with an American businesswoman.

headline: Impeach the Malignant Fraudster
abstract: This is how Republicans can redeem themselves.
lead_paragraph: It is the clarity of Donald Trump’s transgression that is most remarkable.

headline: The Mets Had Pete Alonso and Jacob deGrom. So Why Did They Fall Short?
abstract: Pete Alonso and Jacob deGrom provided reasons for Mets fans to hope, but the team’s first season under General Manager Brodie Van Wagenen ended without a playoff berth.
lead_paragraph: Early in spring training, as the Mets were practicing rundowns in Port St. Lucie, Fla., the team’s new general manager, Brodie Van Wagenen, observing from the left-field line, took his phone out of his pocket.

headline: Daniel Jones (2-0) Steadies the Giants in a Win Over Shaky Washington
abstract: Jones’s first home win came as another rookie quarterback, Dwayne Haskins, took over for Case Keenum.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Daniel Jones made his regular-season debut at MetLife Stadium on Sunday afternoon and, other than a pair of interceptions, did not disappoint an excited fan base. Jones showed the same poise and mobility that he displayed last week in his first N.F.L. game, and the Giants pounded Washington, 24-3.

headline: The New York Fed Chief Is Facing His Biggest Test. Here’s His Response.
abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York president, a top economist, has been criticized for his bank’s response to turmoil in the repo market.
lead_paragraph: John C. Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has spent the past two weeks grappling with the regional bank’s most tumultuous period in years.

headline: Yankees Turn Their Focus to the Playoffs, and Stifling the Twins
abstract: The Yankees have four days to prepare for what promises to be a power-heavy series against Minnesota, and several roster questions remain.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — On Saturday, the day before the final game of the regular season, the Yankees’ brass, including General Manager Brian Cashman’s front office and Manager Aaron Boone’s coaching staff, held the first of many meetings to determine the team’s roster for its American League division series, which begins Friday in New York. The Yankees’ opponent for the series had been decided the day before: the Minnesota Twins.

headline: Man Is Charged With Terrorism After Driving S.U.V. Through Illinois Mall
abstract: The driver was denied bail on Sunday in connection with the episode, which happened on Sept. 20.
lead_paragraph: A 22-year-old man who drove his black sport utility vehicle into a mall in a Chicago suburb on Sept. 20 was charged with terrorism, the police said on Sunday.

headline: M.L.B.’s Juggernauts Set to Clash After a Season of Extraordinary Numbers
abstract: Four teams recorded at least 100 victories for the first time in M.L.B. history, and four more had at least 100 losses for just the second time.
lead_paragraph: It was a regular season of extremes for Major League Baseball, in the standings and on the stat sheets. For the first time, four teams reached 100 victories. But for only the second time, four teams had 100 losses.

headline: Hong Kong’s Status as Neutral Ground at Risk as China Asserts Power
abstract: The territory’s traditional role as a gateway is under assault from President Trump’s trade war and a crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: In a part of the world familiar with conflict, dislocation and ruthless ideological extremism, Hong Kong has long beckoned as an oasis of stability.

headline: U.S. Sees Rising Threat in the West From Qaeda Branch in Syria
abstract: American counterterrorism officials are voicing alarm about a Qaeda affiliate in Syria that they say is plotting attacks from the country’s northwest.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American counterterrorism officials are voicing increased alarm about a Qaeda affiliate in Syria that they say is plotting attacks against the West by exploiting the chaotic security situation in the country’s northwest and the protection inadvertently afforded by Russian air defenses shielding Syrian government forces allied with Moscow.

headline: Elena Delle Donne Gets Help as Mystics Take Game 1 Over the Sun
abstract: The league’s M.V.P. dominated but got an assist from Ariel Atkins.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If the big stage was supposed to spook either the Washington Mystics or the Connecticut Sun, neither team gave any indication of bad nerves in the early moments of Sunday’s Game 1 of the best-of-five W.N.B.A. finals.

headline: Pelosi Pushes for Simple Message on Impeachment as Inquiry Barrels Ahead
abstract: “Our tone must be prayerful, respectful, solemn, worthy of the Constitution,” the House speaker privately told her colleagues as Democrats planned more subpoenas, including to Rudy Giuliani.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi made a private appeal on Sunday to Democrats not to squander their chance to build public support for a full-scale impeachment inquiry into President Trump, pressing lawmakers to maintain a simple and somber message as she declared “we are ready” to push forward with a politically divisive process.

headline: 4 Inmates Recaptured After Ohio Jail Escape
abstract: The men were apprehended in North Carolina after overpowering guards at a county jail in Ohio early Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Four inmates who overpowered guards and escaped from a county jail in Ohio early Sunday were apprehended in North Carolina on Monday, the authorities said.

headline: Forever 21 Bankruptcy Signals a Shift in Consumer Tastes
abstract: The retailer fell victim to the eroding power of shopping malls and said it would cease operations in 40 countries and close up to 178 stores in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Forever 21, the California retailer that helped popularize fast fashion in the United States with its bustling stores and $5 tops, said on Sunday night that it would file for bankruptcy, a sign of the eroding power of shopping malls and the shifting tastes of young consumers.

headline: On Opening Weekend, Another Horse Dies at Santa Anita
abstract: The beginning of the fall race meeting brought hopes that a series of changes would stop the carnage. On the second day, another death.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — The most critical racing meeting in the 85-year history of Santa Anita racetrack opened on Friday amid a swirl of new safety measures, personnel changes and nerves.

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 5, Episode 6: Generational Trauma
abstract: Joanie fears she is becoming her mother, but a big discovery calls her assumptions into question.
lead_paragraph: An affair shaped Joanie Lockhart’s childhood. Now an affair of her own has upended her marriage. If the man involved is to be believed, that’s more than just human nature — it’s science.

headline: ‘Succession’ Season 2, Episode 8: Bad Rap
abstract: The Roys travel back to the Scottish town where Logan grew up. But he’s in no mood to stroll down memory lane.
lead_paragraph: What’s the most horrifying part of Kendall’s “L to the O.G.” rap in this week’s “Succession?” Is it the way he strips off his suit jacket to reveal an oversized baseball jersey? How about completing the spelling of his dad’s name in the chorus with, “A.N. he playing?” Maybe it’s that hideous plaid baseball cap Ken places on his stone-faced father’s head. For a few minutes of TV time, “Succession” fans everywhere surely identified with Tabitha, who watches Kendall bust rhymes and says, “It is burning my eyes but I cannot look away.”

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Le Samouraï’ and ‘The Silence of Others’
abstract: A classic crime film is new to the Criterion Channel. And a documentary about Franco’s legacy in Spain debuts on PBS.
lead_paragraph: LE SAMOURAÏ (1967) Stream on the Criterion Channel. Rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. In Jean-Pierre Melville’s seminal crime film, Alain Delon plays Jef Costello, a highly disciplined hit man whose life is disrupted when he is seen leaving the scene after killing a nightclub owner. He’s saved from immediate prosecution when the club’s piano player, Valérie (Cathy Rosier), refuses to cooperate with the police. The film reveals little of Costello’s inner life or Valérie’s motivations. These mysteries deepen as the investigation continues and Costello’s ruthless employer circles. Even the film’s violent ending, which seems to promise some resolution, only reinforces its central enigmas.

headline: What Really Happened at Sonia Rykiel
abstract: How an adored French brand ended up in liquidation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — This should have been Sonia Rykiel’s moment.

headline: Impeaching Trump: Why One N.Y.C. House Democrat Is a Holdout

lead_paragraph: To understand the anomaly of Representative Max Rose, one of the few House Democrats who has not endorsed an impeachment inquiry into President Trump, one must first understand a few other anomalies.

headline: Gems, Warlords and Mercenaries: Russia’s Playbook in Central African Republic
abstract: After meddling in the 2016 American election, Russia is using similar tactics in the Central African Republic. But as it sows political chaos, this time it is also seeking diamonds.
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic — The dealer pulled back a shiny pink curtain and sprinkled the contents of two white envelopes across his desk: sparkling diamonds, more than 100 of them.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Kehinde Wiley’s Times Square Monument: That’s No Robert E. Lee’
abstract: In this lesson, students consider the significance of a new sculpture and its current and future placement. They also weigh whether this or any work of art has the power to bring about cultural change.

headline: Kara Walker Takes a Monumental Jab at Britannia
abstract: Using the Tate Modern as her stage, Ms. Walker examines the empire, the debate over memorials and the tragedy of Emmett Till. Is London ready?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Queen Victoria Memorial, centerpiece of the plaza that fronts Buckingham Palace, is possibly the most bombastic of this city’s monuments to British grandeur.

headline: Bill Maher on the Perils of Political Correctness
abstract: “Religions always talk about the one true religion. Now on the left we have the one true opinion.”
lead_paragraph: “Religions always talk about the one true religion. Now on the left we have the one true opinion.”

headline: Keeping an Older Dog Vibrant
abstract: As with people, probably the most important measure for keeping dogs healthy and promoting a long, active and happy life is to keep them trim.
lead_paragraph: As Max the First neared his 17th birthday, we knew his days were numbered. He approached the wrong side of the door to go out and often started to pee in the vestibule, a common sign of cognitive impairment. Long walks — and sometimes any walks — were now out of the question.

headline: In Death Penalty Cases, Sotomayor Is Alone in ‘Bearing Witness’
abstract: Over the last month, Justice Sonia Sotomayor has issued three opinions describing flaws in the capital justice system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The terse Supreme Court rulings arrived in the evening, in time to allow an execution later that night. There were three rulings in the last month or so, at 5:52 p.m., at 7:01 p.m. and at 10:13 p.m. They were bland and formulaic, saying only that the court had denied an “application for stay of execution of sentence of death.” The inmates who had filed the applications were put to death within hours.

headline: Intensive Care: What Makes a ‘Good’ Parent?
abstract: Parents can feel inadequate if they fall short of the idealized view of intensive parenting, in which they act directly and decisively in the child’s life.
lead_paragraph: [The topics parents are talking about. Evidence-based guidance. Personal stories that matter. Sign up now to get NYT Parenting in your inbox every week.]

headline: What Do You Eat for Dinner on a Typical Weeknight?
abstract: The New York Times asked 18 families from around the world this question. How would you answer? And what would you show in photographs of a typical dinner at your house?
lead_paragraph: What’s for dinner tonight? Will the people who live with you sit down and eat together? Who prepares the meal, sets the table and cleans up?

headline: The Most Watched Editor at Fashion Week
abstract: Sara Moonves, the new editor in chief of W, has been around the limelight all her life. Now the attention is on her.
lead_paragraph: “It’s literally the most insane fashion week ever,” said Sara Moonves, standing outside her Chinatown apartment one evening during New York Fashion Week waiting for an Uber.

headline: China Plays ‘Fight the Landlord’ to Tame Hong Kong
abstract: State media puts pressure on Li Ka-shing, a powerful property tycoon, showing the Communist Party’s view of business as a means of control.
lead_paragraph: “Fight the Landlord” is one of the most popular card games in China. The name comes from the 1950s, when the Chinese Communist Party confiscated property from landowners, often violently, in the name of the masses. As many as two million people were killed.

headline: What’s the Matter With Republicans?
abstract: Trump has given them another chance to break away. Why won’t they take it?
lead_paragraph: In a sane world, the reaction of Republicans to the “memorandum of telephone conversation” between President Trump and the president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, combined with the whistle-blower complaint filed by an intelligence officer describing a White House cover-up, would be similar to the response of Republicans after the release, on Aug. 5, 1974, of the “smoking gun” tape that finally broke the Nixon presidency. Republicans would begin to abandon Mr. Trump, with senior figures urging him in private and in public to resign.

headline: What Democrats Could Lose With Their Left Turn
abstract: A survey experiment shows that some independents are already being turned off.
lead_paragraph: One defining feature of the Democratic primary so far has been the party’s leftward turn. In recent debates, candidates have supported policies like offering health insurance to undocumented immigrants, and commenters have warned about the potential electoral penalty of repelling persuadable voters.

headline: Xi Extols China’s ‘Red’ Heritage in a Land Haunted by Famine Under Mao
abstract: Seventy years after Mao founded the People’s Republic, Xi Jinping visited Xinyang to rekindle revolutionary traditions. Its survivors of mass starvation went unmentioned.
lead_paragraph: XINYANG, China — Harrowing memories of China’s revolutionary past hang over the rolling wheat fields and scattered villages where the Communist Party’s leader, Xi Jinping, recently visited to commemorate 70 years since Mao Zedong founded the People’s Republic.

headline: What a Jazz Critic Hears on Coltrane’s ‘New’ Album
abstract: With a bit of time travel, a writer can understand where a record came from and where it eventually led.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Wrongly Convicted, They Had to Choose: Freedom or Restitution
abstract: Prosecutors are adopting strategies to keep from having to pay for mistakes.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Outside of Jimmy Dennis’s house, on a quiet block, it was one of those perfect summer days. But Mr. Dennis preferred to stay inside, behind drawn shades, where there was little risk anyone would misinterpret what he was up to.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Quarterback Youth Movement Has Its Growing Pains
abstract: With more quarterbacks under the age of 26 thrust into starting roles, their teams find renewal, frustration and everything in between.
lead_paragraph: The start of the N.F.L. season was a rough one for some of the league’s most bankable quarterbacks. Andrew Luck retired before the start of the season. Drew Brees hurt his thumb and will be out another month or so. Ben Roethlisberger is done for the season because of an elbow injury. Eli Manning, the cornerstone of the Giants since 2004, was replaced by a rookie, Daniel Jones.

headline: Living Where You Can Walk to Work
abstract: A dance teacher at the 92nd Street Y finds her way to the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Megan Doyle has been teaching dance at the 92nd Street Y — the renowned cultural and community center on the Upper East Side — for nearly 10 years, and in that time she has lived in five different homes across three boroughs.

headline: Joe Biden’s Digital Ads Are Disappearing. Not a Good Sign, Strategists Say.
abstract: In a race where many voters are following politics online, Mr. Biden’s pullback is a striking and potentially worrisome sign about his appeal among the digitally active.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign has sharply scaled back his online advertising, cutting spending so severely since August that he is now investing only a fraction of what his top rivals are on Facebook and Google, the two dominant internet platforms.

abstract: As the Communist Party celebrates 70 years in power, protests in Hong Kong threaten to overshadow the festivities.

headline: What Happened in Week 4 of the N.F.L.
abstract: The Bills and the Lions were valiant in defeat, the Browns were incredible and the Rams gave up an ugly 55 points.
lead_paragraph: If you thought Week 4 was going to separate the pretenders and contenders, you were sorely mistaken. The Bills and the Lions were terrific in defeat, the Browns reminded everyone why they were hyped so much during the off-season and the Rams showed off quite a few flaws in a devastating loss at home.

headline: Blood, Money, Oil. And Clothes.
abstract: What else is there to talk about? Balenciaga, Givenchy and Valentino get in on the conversation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In a large circular chamber covered in periwinkle blue velvet and hung with curtains all around, seats curling outward in snail shell tiers, Demna Gvasalia of Balenciaga convened his parliament. Then he scented it with Blood and Money and Petrol (after starting with a bit of Anti-Sceptic, literally: he had perfumes made for the show) — the engines that drive the world’s rotting power structures — and a low thrum began.

headline: What Kind of Problem Is Climate Change?
abstract: Knowing the answer might force us toward a real solution.
lead_paragraph: If the summer heat, followed by Hurricane Dorian, hasn’t convinced you that climate change is real, probably nothing will. Those of us convinced will want to mitigate it if we can. Doing that requires understanding the different kinds of problems climate change presents. They are economic, political and philosophical. The three kinds of problems are inextricably intertwined. That’s one lesson taught by the relatively new discipline of politics, philosophy and economics (PPE).

abstract: World leaders gathered in Paris for a final tribute to the fondly remembered former French president, who died last week at age 86.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — World leaders and dignitaries gathered in Paris on Monday as France marked a national day of mourning for Jacques Chirac, the former French president who died last week.
